[34:176] The flame could not approach nor hurt the innocent and righteous Children praising God, and He delivered them out of the fire Some one saith, Lo, truly righteous were those who were heard, as it is written, "The righteous cried, and the Lord heard them, and delivered them out of all their troubles:" but I have cried, and He delivereth me not; either I am not righteous, or I do not the things which He commandeth me, or haply He seeth me not.

[34:177] Fear not: only do what He commandeth; and if He deliver thee not bodily, He will deliver thee spiritually.

[34:178] For He who took out of the fire the Three Children, did He take out of the fire the Maccabees? Did not the first sing hymns in the flames, these last in the flames expire? The God of the Three Children, was not He the God also of the Maccabees? The one He delivered, the other He delivered not.

[34:179] Nay, He delivered both: but the Three Children He so delivered, that even the carnal were confounded; but the Maccabees therefore He delivered not so, that those who persecuted them should go into greater torments, while they thought that they had overcome God's Martyrs.

[34:180] He delivered Peter, when the Angel came unto him being in prison, and said, "Arise, and go forth," and suddenly his chains were loosed, and he followed the Angel, and He delivered him.

[34:181] Had Peter lost righteousness when He delivered him not from the cross? Did He not deliver him then? Even then He delivered him.

[34:182] Did his long life make him unrighteous? Haply He heard him more at last than at first, when truly He delivered him out of all his troubles.

[34:183] For when He first delivered him, how many things did he suffer afterwards! For thither He sent him at last, where he could have suffered no evil.

[34:184] "The Lord is nigh unto them that have broken their heart; and saveth such as be lowly in spirit".

[34:185] God is High: let a Christian be lowly.

[34:186] If he would that the Most High God draw nigh unto him, let him be lowly.

[34:187] A great mystery, Brethren.

[34:188] God is above all: thou raisest thyself, and touchest not Him: thou humblest thyself, and He descendeth unto thee.

[34:189] "Many are the troubles of the righteous" : doth He say, "Therefore let Christians be righteous, therefore let them hear My Word, that they may suffer no tribulation? He promiseth not this; but saith, "Many are the troubles of the righteous".

[34:190] Rather, if they be unrighteous they have fewer troubles, if righteous they have many.

[34:191] But after few tribulations, or none, these shall come to tribulation everlasting, whence they shall never be delivered: but the righteous after many tribulations shall come to peace everlasting, where they shall never suffer any evil.

[34:192] "Many are the tribulations of the righteous: but the Lord delivereth him out of all".

[34:193] "The Lord keepeth all their bones: not one of them shall be broken" : this also, Brethren, let us not receive carnally.

[34:194] Bones are the firm supports of the faithful.

[34:195] For as in flesh our bones give firmness, so in the heart of a Christian it is faith that gives firmness The patience then which is in faith, is as the bones of the inner man: this is that which cannot be broken.

[34:196] "The Lord keepeth all their bones: not one of them shall be broken".

[34:197] If of our Lord God Jesus Christ he had said this, "The Lord keepeth all the bones of His Son; not one of them shall be broken;" as is prefigured of Him also in another place, when the lamb was spoken of that should be slain, and it was said of it, "Neither shall ye break a bone thereof:"  then was it fulfilled in the Lord, because when He hung upon the Cross, He expired before they came to the Cross, and found His Body lifeless already, and would not break His legs, that it might be fulfilled which was written But He gave this promise to other Christians also, "The Lord keepeth all their bones; not one of them shall be broken".

[34:198] Therefore, Brethren, if we see any Saint suffer tribulation, and haply either by a Physician so cut, or by some persecutor so mangled, that his bones be broken; let us not say, This man was not righteous, for this hath the Lord promised to His righteous, of whom He said, "The Lord keepeth all their bones; not one of them shall be broken".

[34:199] Wouldest thou see that He spoke of other bones, those which we called the firm supports of faith, that is, patience and endurance in all tribulations? For these are the bones which are not broken.

[34:200] Hear, and see ye in the very Passion of our Lord, what I say.

[34:201] The Lord was in the middle Crucified; near Him were two thieves: the one mocked, the other believed: the one was condemned, the other justified: the one had his punishment both in this world, and that which shall be, but unto the other said the Lord, "Verily I say unto thee, To-day shalt thou be with Me in Paradise;" and yet those who came brake not the bones of the Lord, but of the thieves they brake: as much were broken the bones of the thief who blasphemed, as of the thief who believed.

[34:202] Where then is that which is spoken, "The Lord keepeth all their bones; not one of them shall be broken"? Lo, unto whom He said, "To-day shalt thou be with Me in Paradise," could He keep all his bones? The Lord answereth thee: Yea, I kept them: for the firm support of his faith could not be broken by those blows whereby his legs were broken.

[34:203] "The death of sinners is the worst".

[34:204] Attend, Brethren, for the sake of those things which I said.

[34:205] Truly Great is the Lord, and His Mercy, truly Great is He who gave to us to eat His Body, wherein He suffered such great things, and His Blood to drink.

[34:206] How regardeth He them that think evil and say, "Such an one died ill, by beasts was he devoured: he was not a righteous man, therefore he perished ill; for else would he not have perished".

[34:207] Is he then righteous who dieth in his own house and in his own bed? This then (sayest thou) it is whereat I wonder; because I know the sins and the crimes of this same man, and yet he died well; in his own house, within his own doors, with no injury of travel, with none even in mature age.

[34:208] Hearken, "The death of sinners is worst".

[34:209] What seemeth to thee a good death, is worst if thou couldest see within.

[34:210] Thou seest him outwardly lying on his bed, dost thou see him inwardly carried to hell? Hearken, Brethren, and learn from the Gospel what is the "worst death" of sinners.

[34:211] Were there not two in that age, a rich man who was clothed in purple and fine linen, and fared sumptuously every day; another a poor man who lay at his door full of sores, and the dogs came and licked his sores, and he desired to be fed with the crumbs which fell from the rich man's table? Now it came to pass that the poor man died (righteous was that poor man), and was carried by Angels into Abraham's bosom.

[34:212] He who saw his body lying at the rich man's door, and no man to bury it, what haply said he? So die he who is my enemy; and whoever persecutes me, so may I see him.

[34:213] His body is accursed with spitting, his wounds stink; and yet in Abraham's bosom he resteth If we are Christians, let us believe: if we believe not, Brethren, let none feign himself a Christian.

[34:214] Faith bringeth us to the end.

[34:215] As the Lord spake these things, so are they.

[34:216] Doth indeed an astrologer speak unto thee, and it is true, and doth Christ speak, and it is false? But by what sort of death died the rich man? What sort of death must it not be in purple and fine linen, how sumptuous, how pompous! What funeral ceremonies were there! In what spices was that body buried! And yet when he was in hell, being in torments, from the finger of that despised poor man he desired one drop of water to be poured upon his burning tongue, and obtained it not.

[34:217] Learn then what meaneth, "The death of sinners is worst;" and ask not beds covered with costly garments, and to have the flesh wrapped in many rich things, friends exhibiting a show of lamentation, a household beating their breasts, a crowd of attendants going before and following when the body is carried out, marble and gilded memorials.

[34:218] For if ye ask those things, they answer you what is false, that of many not light sinners, but altogether wicked, the death is best, who have deserved to be so lamented, so embalmed, so covered, so carried out, so entombed.

[34:219] But ask the Gospel, and it will show to your faith the soul of the rich man burning in torments, which was nothing profited by all those honours and obsequies, which to his dead body the vanity of the living did afford.

[34:220] But because there are many kinds of sinners, and not to be a sinner is difficult, or perhaps in this life impossible, he added immediately, of what kind of sinners the death is worst.

[34:221] "And they that hate the righteous one" (saith he) "shall perish".

[34:222] What righteous one, but "Him that justifieth the ungodly"? Whom, but our Lord Jesus Christ, who is also "the propitiation for our sins"? Who then hate Him, have the worst death; because they die in their sins, who are not through Him reconciled to our God.

[34:223] "For the Lord redeemeth the souls of His servants".

[34:224] But according to the soul is death to be understood either the worst or best, not according to bodily either dishonour, or honours which men see.

[34:225] "And none of them which trust in Him shall perish" ; this is the manner of human righteousness, that mortal life, however advanced, because without sin it cannot be, in this perisheth not, while it trusteth in Him, in whom is remission of sins, Amen.

[35:1] Psalm XXXV.

[35:2] The title of it causeth us no delay, for it is both brief, and to be understood not difficult, espe cially to those nursed in the Church of God.

[35:3] For so it is, "To David himself".

[35:4] The Psa lm then is to David himself: now David is interpreted, Strong in hand, or Desirable.

[35:5] The Psalm then is to the Strong in hand, and Desirable, to Him who for us hath overcome death, who unto us hath promised life: for in this is He Strong in hand, that He hath overcome death for us; in this is He Desirable, that He hath promised unto us life eternal.

[35:6] For what stronger than that Hand which touched the bier, and he that was dead rose up? What stronger than that Hand which overcame the world, not armed with steel, but pierced with wood? Or what more desirable than He, whom not having seen, the  Martyrs wished even to die, that they might be worthy to come unto Him? Therefore is the Psalm unto Him: to Him let our heart, to Him our tongue sing worthily: if yet Himself shall deign to give somewhat to sing.

[35:7] "Judge Thou, O Lord" (saith he), "them that hurt me, and fight Thou against them that fight against me".

[35:8] "If God be for us, who can be against us?" And whereby doth God this for us? "Take hold" (saith he) "of arms and shield, and rise up to my help".

[35:9] A great spectacle is it, to see God armed for thee.

[35:10] And what is His Shield, what are His Arms? "Lord," in another place saith the man who here also speaketh, "as with the shield of Thy good-will hast Thou compassed us".

[35:11] But His Arms, wherewith He may not only us defend, but also strike His enemies, if we have well profited, shall we ourselves be.

[35:12] For as we from Him have this, that we be armed, so is He armed from us.

[35:13] But He is armed from those whom He hath made, we are armed with those things which we have received from Him who made us.

[35:14] These our arms the Apostle in a certain place calleth, "The shield of Faith, the helmet of Salvation, and the sword of the Spirit, which is the Word of God".

[35:15] He hath armed us with such arms as ye have heard, arms admirable, and unconquered, insuperable and shining; spiritual truly and invisible, because we have to fight also against invisible enemies.

[35:16] If thou seest thine enemy, let thine arms be seen.

[35:17] We are armed with faith in those things which we see not, and we overthrow enemies whom we see not.

[35:18] "Pour forth the weapon, and stop the way against them that persecute me".

[35:19] Who are they that persecute thee? Haply thy neighbour, or he whom thou hast offended, or to whom thou hast done wrong, or who would take away what is thine, or against whom thou preachest the truth, or whose sin thou rebukest, or whom living ill by thy well living thou offendest.

[35:20] There are indeed even these enemies to us, and they persecute us: but other enemies we are taught to know, those against whom we fight invisibly, of whom the Apostle warneth us, saying, "We wrestle not against flesh and blood," that is, against men; not against those whom ye see, but against those whom ye see not; "against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the world, of this darkness".

[35:21] "The whole world lieth in wickedness;" therefore the Apostle explained of what world they were rulers, he said, "of this darkness".

[35:22] The rulers of this world, I say, are the rulers of this darkness.

[35:23] And what follows? "Let them be confounded and put to shame, that seek after my soul" : for to this end they  seek after it, to destroy it.

[35:24] For I would that they would seek it for good! for in another Psalm he blameth this in men, that there was none who would seek after his soul: "Refuge failed me: there was none that would seek after my soul".

[35:25] Who is this that saith, "There was none that would seek after my soul"? Is it haply He, of whom so long before it was predicted, "They pierced My Hands and My Feet, they numbered all My Bones, they stared and looked upon Me, they have parted My Garments among them, and cast lots for My Vesture"? Now all these things were done before their eyes, and there was none who would seek after His Soul.

[35:26] Many have been confounded to their health: many, put to shame, have passed over from the persecution of Christ to the society of His members with devoted piety; and this would not have been, had they not been confounded and put to shame.

[35:27] Therefore he wished well to them.

[35:28] Let them not go before, but follow; let them not give counsel, but take it.

[35:29] For Peter would go before the Lord, when the Lord spake of His future Passion: he would to Him as it were give counsel for His health.

[35:30] The sick man to the Saviour give counsel for His health! And what said he to the Lord, affirming that His future Passion? "Be it far from Thee, Lord.

[35:31] Be gracious to Thyself.

[35:32] This shall not be to Thee".

[35:33] He would go before that the Lord might follow; and what said He? "Get thee behind Me, Satan".

[35:34] By going before thou art Satan, by following thou wilt be a disciple.

[35:35] The same then is said to these also, "Let them be turned back and brought to confusion that think evil against me".

[35:36] For when they have begun to follow after, now they will not think evil against me, but desire my good.

[35:37] What of others? For all are not so conquered as to be converted and believe: many continue in obstinacy, many preserve in heart the spirit of going before, and if they exert it not, yet they labour with it, and finding opportunity bring it forth.

[35:38] Of such, what followeth? "Let them be as dust before the wind".

[35:39] "Not so are the ungodly, not so; but as the dust which the wind driveth away from the face of the earth".

[35:40] The wind is temptation; the dust are the ungodly.

[35:41] When temptation cometh, the dust is raised, it neither standeth nor resisteth.

[35:42] "Let them be as dust before the wind, and let the Angel of the Lord trouble them".

[35:43] "Let their way be darkness and slipping".

[35:44] A horrible way! Darkness alone who feareth not? A slippery way alone who avoids not? In a dark and slippery way how shalt thou go? where set foot? These two ills are the great punishments of men: darkness, ignorance; a slippery way, luxury.

[35:45] "And let the Angel of the Lord persecute them;" that they be not able to stand.

[35:46] For any one in a dark and slippery way, when he seeth that if he move his foot he will fall, and there is no light before his feet, haply resolveth to wait until light come; but here is the Angel of the Lord persecuting them.

[35:47] These things he predicted would come upon them, not as though he wished them to happen.

[35:48] Although the Prophet in the Spirit of God so speaketh these things, even as God doth the same, with sure judgment, with a judgment good, righteous, holy, tranquil; not moved with wrath, not with bitter jealousy, not with desire of wreaking enmities, but of punishing wickedness with righteousness; nevertheless, it is a prophecy.

[35:49] But wherefore these so great evils? By what desert? Hear by what desert.

[35:50] "For without cause have they hid for me the corruption of their trap".

[35:51] For Him that is our Head, observe, the Jews did this: they hid the corruption of their trap.

[35:52] For whom hid they their trap? For Him who saw the hearts of those that hid.

[35:53] But yet was He among them like one ignorant, as though He were deceived, whereas they were in that deceived, that they thought Him to be deceived.

[35:54] For therefore was He as though deceived, living among them, because we among such as they were so to live, as to be without doubt deceived.

[35:55] He saw His betrayer, and chose him the more to a necessary work.

[35:56] By his evil He wrought a great good: and yet among the twelve was he chosen, lest even the small number of twelve should be without one evil.

[35:57] This was an example of patience to us, because it was necessary that we should live among the evil: it was necessary that we should endure the evil, either knowing them or knowing them not: an example of patience He gave thee lest thou shouldest fail, when thou hast begun to live among the evil.

[35:58] And because that School of Christ in the twelve failed not, how much more ought we to be firm, when in the great Church is fulfilled what was predicted of the mixture of the evil.

[35:59] But yet what is to be done? "Without a cause have they hid for me the corruption of their trap".

[35:60] What meaneth, "Without a cause"? I have done them no evil, I have hurt them not at all.

[35:61] "Vainly have they reviled my soul".

[35:62] What is, "Vainly"? Speaking falsely, proving nothing.

[35:63] "Let a trap come upon them which they know not of".

[35:64] A magnificent retribution, nothing more just! They have hidden a trap that I might know not: let a trap come upon them which they know not of.

[35:65] For I know of their trap.

[35:66] But what trap is coming upon them? That which they know not of.

[35:67] Let us hear, lest haply he speak of that.

[35:68] "Let a trap come upon them, which they know not of".

[35:69] Perhaps that is one which they hid for him, that another which shall come upon themselves.

[35:70] Not so: but what? "The wicked shall be holden with the cords of his own sins".

[35:71] Thereby are they deceived, whereby they would deceive.

[35:72] Thence shall come mischief to them, whence they endeavoured mischief.

[35:73] For it follows, "And let the net which they have hidden catch themselves, and let them fall into their own trap".

[35:74] As if any one should prepare a cup of poison for another, and forgetting should drink it up himself: or as if one should dig a pit, that his enemy might fall thereinto in the darkness and himself forgetting what he had dug, should first walk that way, and fall into it.

[35:75] This then for the wicked that would hurt me: what for me? "But my soul shall rejoice in the Lord" ; as in Him from whom it hath heard, "I am thy salvation;" as not seeking other riches from without; as not seeking to abound in pleasures and good things of earth; but loving freely the true Spouse, not from Him wishing to receive aught that may delight, but Him alone proposing to itself, by whom it may be delighted.

[35:76] For what better than God will be given unto me? God loveth me: God loveth thee.

[35:77] See He hath proposed to thee, Ask what thou wilt If the emperor should say to thee, Ask what thou wilt, what commands, what dignities, wouldest thou burst forth with! What great things wouldest thou propose to thyself, both to receive and to bestow! When God saith unto thee, Ask what thou wilt, what wilt thou ask? empty thy mind, exert thy avarice, stretch forward as far as possible, and enlarge thy desire: it is not any one, but Almighty God that said, Ask what thou wilt.

[35:78] If of possessions thou art a lover, thou wilt desire the whole earth, that all who are born may be thy husbandmen, or thy slaves.

[35:79] And what when thou hast possessed the whole earth? Thou wilt ask the sea, in which yet thou canst not live.

[35:80] In this greediness the fishes will have the better of thee.

[35:81] But perhaps thou wilt possess the islands.

[35:82] Pass over these also; ask the air although thou canst not fly; stretch thy desire even unto the heavens, call thine own the sun, the moon, and the stars, because He who made all said, Ask what thou wilt: yet nothing wilt thou find more precious, nothing wilt thou find better, than Himself who made all things.

[35:83] Him seek, who made all things, and in Him and from Him shalt thou have all things which He made.

[35:84] All things are precious, because all are beautiful; but what more beautiful than He? Strong are they; but what stronger than He? And nothing would He give thee rather than Himself.

[35:85] If aught better thou hast found, ask it.

[35:86] If thou ask aught else, thou wilt do wrong to Him, and harm to thyself, by preferring to Him that which He made, when He would give to thee Himself who made.

[35:87] "But my soul shall be joyful in the Lord; it shall rejoice in His salvation".

[35:88] The salvation of God is Christ: "For mine eyes have seen Thy salvation".

[35:89] "All my bones shall say, Lord, who is like unto Thee".

[35:90] Who can speak anything worthily of these words? I think them only to be pronounced, not to be expounded.

[35:91] Why seekest thou this or that? What is like unto thy Lord? Him hast thou before thee.

[35:92] "The unrighteous have declared unto me delights, but not after Thy law, O Lord!" Persecutors have been who have said, Worship Saturn, worship Mercury.

[35:93] I worship not idols (saith he): "Lord, who is like unto Thee? They have eyes, and see not; ears have they, but they hear not".

[35:94] "Lord, who is like unto Thee," who hast made the eye to see, the ear to hear? But I (saith he) worship not idols, for them a workman made.

[35:95] Worship a tree or mountain; did a workman make them also? Here too, Lord, who is like unto Thee? Earthly things are shown unto me; Thou art Creator of the earth.

[35:96] And from these haply they turn to the higher creation, and say to me, Worship the Moon, worship this Sun, who with his light, as a great lamp in the Heavens, maketh the day.

[35:97] Here also I plainly say, "Lord, who is like unto Thee?" The Moon and the Stars Thou hast made, the Sun to rule the day hast Thou kindled, the Heavens hast Thou framed together.

[35:98] There are many invisible things better.

[35:99] But haply here also it is said to me, Worship Angels, adore Angels.

[35:100] And here also will I say, "Lord, who is like unto Thee?" Even the Angels Thou hast created.

[35:101] The Angels are nothing, but by seeing Thee.

[35:102] It is better with them to possess Thee, than by worshipping them to fall from Thee.

[35:103] O Body of Christ, Holy Church, let all thy bones say, "Lord, who is like unto thee?" And if the flesh under persecution hath fallen away, let the bones say, "Lord, who is like unto Thee?" For of the righteous it is said, "The Lord keepeth all their bones; not one of them shall be broken".

[35:104] Of how many righteous have the bones under persecution been broken? Finally, "The just shall live by faith," and "Christ justifieth the ungodly".

[35:105] But how justifieth He any except believing and confessing? "For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness, and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation".

[35:106] Therefore also that thief, although from His theft led to the judge, and from the judge to the cross, yet on the very cross was justified: with his heart he believed, with his mouth he confessed.

[35:107] For neither to a man unrighteous and not already justified, would the Lord have said, "To-day shalt thou be with Me in Paradise," and yet his bones were broken.

[35:108] For when they came to take down the bodies, by reason of the approaching Sabbath, the Lord was found already dead, and His Bones were not broken But of those that yet lived, that they might be taken down, the legs were broken, that so from this pain having died, they might be buried.

[35:109] Were then of the one thief, who persisted in his ungodliness on the cross, the bones broken, and not also of the other who with his heart believed, and with his mouth made confession unto salvation? Where then is that which was said, "The Lord keepeth all his bones; not one of them shall be broken;" except that in the Body of the Lord the name of bones is given to all the righteous, the firm in heart, the strong, yielding to no persecutions, no temptations, so as to consent unto evil?.

[35:110] "Which deliverest the poor from him that is too strong for him; yea, the poor and needy from him that spoileth him".

[35:111] Who that deliverest, but He who is Strong in hand? Even that David shall deliver the poor from him that is too strong for him.

[35:112] For the devil was too strong for thee, and held thee, because he conquered thee, when thou consentedst unto him.

[35:113] But what hath the Strong in hand done? "No man entereth into a strong man's house, to spoil his goods, except he first bind the strong man".

[35:114] By His own Power, most Holy, most Magnificent, hath He bound the devil by pouring forth the weapon to stop the way against him, that He may deliver the poor and needy, to whom there was no helper For who is thy helper but the Lord to whom thou sayest, "O Lord, My Strength, and My Redeemer".

[35:115] If thou wilt presume of thy own strength, thereby wilt thou fall, whereof thou hast presumed: if of another's, he would lord it over thee, not succour thee.

[35:116] He then alone is to be sought Who hath redeemed them, and made them free, and hath given His Blood to purchase them, and of His servants hath made them His Brethren.

[35:117] Let then our Head say, "False witnesses did rise up, they laid to My charge things that I knew not".

[35:118] But let us say to our Head, Lord, what knewest Thou not? Didst Thou indeed know not anything? Didst Thou not know the hearts of them that charged Thee? Didst Thou not foresee their deceits? Didst Thou not give Thyself into their hands knowingly? Hadst Thou not come that Thou mightest suffer by them? What then knewest Thou not? He knew not sin, and thereby He knew not sin, not by not judging, but by not committing.

[35:119] There are phrases of this kind also in daily use, as when thou sayest of any one, He knoweth not to stand, that is, he doth not stand; and, He knoweth not to do good, because he doth not good; and, He knoweth not to do ill, because he doth not ill.

[35:120] What knew not Christ so much, as to blaspheme? Thereof was He called in question by His persecutors, and because He spake truth, He was judged to have spoken blasphemy But by whom? By them of whom it followeth, "They rewarded Me evil for good, and barrenness to My Soul".

[35:121] I gave unto them fruitfulness, they rewarded Me barrenness; I gave life, they death; I honour, they dishonour; I medicine, they wounds; and in all these which they rewarded Me, was truly barrenness.

[35:122] This barrenness in the tree He cursed, when seeking fruit He found none Leaves there were, and fruit there was not: words there were, and deeds there were not.

[35:123] See of words abundance, and of deeds barrenness.

[35:124] "Thou that preachest a man should not steal, stealest: thou that sayest a man should not commit adultery, committest adultery".

[35:125] Such were they who charged Christ with things that He knew not.

[35:126] "But I, when they troubled me, clothed myself with sackcloth, and humbled my soul with fasting, and my prayer shall return into mine own bosom" Brethren, if for some little space with pious curiosity we lift the veil, and search with the intent eye of the heart the inner part of this Scripture, we find that even this the Lord did.

[35:127] Sackcloth, haply He calleth His mortal flesh.

[35:128] Wherefore Sackcloth? For the likeness of sinful flesh.

[35:129] For the Apostle saith, "God sent His Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, that through sin He might condemn sin in the flesh:" that is, He clothed His Own Son with sackcloth, that through sackcloth He might condemn the goats.

[35:130] Not that there was sin, I say not in the Word of God, but not even in that Holy Soul and Mind of a Man, which the Word and Wisdom of God had so joined to Himself as to be One Person.

[35:131] Nay, nor even in His very Body was any sin, but the likeness of sinful flesh there was in the Lord; because death is not but by sin, and surely that Body was mortal.

[35:132] For had It not been mortal, It had not died; had It not died, It had not risen again; had It not risen again, It had not showed us an example of eternal life.

[35:133] So then death, which is caused by sin, is called sin; as we say the Greek tongue, the Latin tongue, meaning not the very member of flesh, but that which is done by the member of flesh.

[35:134] For the tongue in our members is one among others, as the eyes, nose, ears, and the rest: but the Greek tongue is Greek words, not that the tongue is words, but that words are by the tongue.

[35:135] So then the sin of the Lord is that which was caused by sin; because He assumed flesh, of the same lump which had deserved death by sin.

[35:136] For to speak more briefly, Mary who was of Adam died for sin, Adam died for sin, and the Flesh of the Lord which was of Mary died to put away sin.

[35:137] With this sackcloth the Lord clothed Himself, and therefore was He not known, because He lay hid under sackcloth.

[35:138] "When they," saith He, "troubled Me, I clothed Myself with sackcloth:" that is, they raged, I lay hid.

[35:139] For had He not willed to lie hid neither could He have died, since in one moment of time one drop only of His Power, if indeed it is to be called a drop, He put forth, when they wished to seize Him, and at His one question, "Whom seek ye?" they all went back and fell to the ground Such power could He not have humbled in passion, if He had not lain hid under sackcloth.

[35:140] Again, if we have understood the sackcloth, how understand we the fasting? Wished Christ to eat, when He sought fruit on the tree, and if He had found, would He have eaten? Wished Christ to drink, when He said to the woman of Samaria, "Give Me to drink"? when He said on the Cross, "I thirst"? For what hungered, for what thirsted Christ, but our good works? Because in them that crucified and persecuted Him He had found no good works, He fasted; for they rewarded barrenness to His soul.

[35:141] For what a fast was His, who found barely one thief, whom on the Cross He might taste! For the Apostles had fled, and had hidden themselves in the multitude.

[35:142] And even Peter, who even to the death of his Lord had promised to persevere, had now thrice denied Him, had now wept, and still lay hid in the multitude, still feared lest He should be known.

[35:143] Lastly, having seen Him dead, all of them despaired of their own safety and despairing He found them, after His resurrection, and when He spake with them, found them grieving and mourning, no longer hoping anything.

[35:144] In great fasting had the Lord remained, had He not refreshed them that He might feed on them.

[35:145] For He refreshed them, He comforted them, He confirmed them, and into His Own Body converted them.

[35:146] In this manner then was our Lord also in fasting.

[35:147] "And My prayer shall return into Mine Own Bosom".

[35:148] In the bosom of this verse is plainly a great depth, and may the Lord grant that it be fathomable by us.

[35:149] For in the "bosom" a secret is understood.

[35:150] And we ourselves, Brethren, are here well admonished to pray within our own bosom, where God seeth, where God heareth, where no human eye penetrateth, where none seeth but He who succoureth; where Susanna prayed, and her voice, though it was not heard by men, yet by God was heardWe read also that in the mount Jesus prayed alone, we read that He passed the night in prayer, even at the time of His Passion What then? "And My prayer shall return into Mine Own Bosom".

[35:151] I know not what better to understand concerning the Lord: take meanwhile what now occurs; perhaps something better will occur hereafter, either to me or to some better: "My prayer shall return into Mine Own Bosom:" this I understand to be said, because in His Own Bosom He had the Father.

[35:152] "For God was in Christ reconciling the world unto Himself".

[35:153] In Himself He had Him to whom He prayed.

[35:154] He was not far from Him, for Himself had said, "I am in the Father, and the Father in Me".

[35:155] But because prayer rather belongeth to very Man (for according as Christ is the Word, He prayeth not, but heareth prayer; and seeketh not to be succoured for Himself, but with the Father succoureth all): what is, "My prayer shall return into Mine Own Bosom," but in Me My Manhood invoketh in Me My Godhead.

[35:156] "As a Neighbour, as our Brother, so I pleased Him: as one mourning and sorrowful, so I humbled myself".

[35:157] Now looketh He back to His Own Body: let us now look to this.

[35:158] When we rejoice in prayer, when our mind is calmed, not by the world's prosperity, but by the light of Truth: (who perceiveth this light, knoweth what I say, and he seeth and acknowledgeth what is said, "As a Neighbour, as our Brother, so I pleased Him"): even then our soul pleaseth God, not placed afar off, for, "In Him," saith one, "we live and move and have our being,"  but as a Brother, as a Neighbour, as a Friend.

[35:159] But if it be not such that it can so rejoice, so shine, so approach, so cleave unto Him, and seeth itself far off thence, then let it do what followeth, "As one mourning and sorrowful, so I humbled Myself.

[35:160] As our Brother, so I pleased Him," said He, drawing near; "As one mourning and sorrowful, so I humbled Myself," said He, removed and set afar off.

[35:161] Did not Peter draw near, when he said, "Thou art the Christ, the Son of the Living God"? And yet the same man became afar off by saying, "Be it far from Thee, Lord; this shall not be unto Thee".

[35:162] Lastly, what said He, his Neighbour, as it were, to him drawing near? "Blessed art thou, Simon, Barjona".

[35:163] To him afar off, as it were, and unlike, what said He? "Get thee behind Me, Satan".

[35:164] To him drawing near, "Flesh and blood," saith He, "hath not revealed it unto thee, but My Father, which is in Heaven".

[35:165] His Light is shed over thee, in His Light thou shinest.

[35:166] But when having become afar off, he spake against the Lord's Passion, which should be for our Salvation, "Thou savourest not," said He, "the things that be of God, but those that be of men".

[35:167] One rightly placing together both of these saith in a certain Psalm, "I said in my ecstasy, I am cast off from before Thine Eyes".

[35:168] In my ecstasy, would he not have said, had he not drawn near; for ecstasy is the transporting of the mind.

[35:169] He poured over himself his own soul, and drew near unto God; and through some cloud and weight of the flesh being again cast down to earth, and recollecting where he had been, and seeing where he was, he said, "I am cast off from before Thine Eyes".

[35:170] This then, "As a Neighbour, as our Brother, so I pleased Him," may He grant to be done in us; but when that is not, let even this be done, "As one mourning and sorrowful, so I humbled myself".

[35:171] "And against Me they rejoiced, and gathered themselves together" , against Me only: they rejoicing, I sorrowful.

[35:172] But we heard just now in the Gospel, "Blessed are they that mourn".

[35:173] If they are blessed that mourn, miserable are they that laugh.

[35:174] "Against Me they rejoiced, and gathered themselves together: scourges were gathered together against Me, and they knew not".

[35:175] Because they laid to My charge things that I knew not, they also knew not Whom they charged.

[35:176] "They tempted Me, and mocked Me with mocking".

[35:177] That is, they derided Me, they insulted Me; this of the Head, this of the Body.

[35:178] Consider, Brethren, the glory of the Church which now is; remember its past dishonours, remember how once were Christians everywhere put to flight, and wherever found, mocked, beaten, slain, exposed to beasts, burned, men rejoicing against them.

[35:179] As it was to the Head, so it is also to the Body.

[35:180] For as it was to the Lord on the Cross, so has it been to His Body in all that persecution which was made but now: nor even now cease the persecutions of the same.

[35:181] Wherever men find a Christian, they are wont to insult, to persecute, to deride him, to call him dull, senseless, of no spirit, of no knowledge.

[35:182] Do they what they will, Christ is in Heaven: do they what they will, He hath honoured His punishment, already hath He fixed His Cross in the foreheads of all; the ungodly is permitted to insult, to rage he is not permitted; but yet from that which the tongue uttereth, is understood what he beareth in his heart: "They gnashed upon Me with their teeth".

[35:183] "Lord, when wilt Thou look on? Rescue My Soul from their deceits, My Darling from the lions".

[35:184] For to us the time is slow; and in our person is this said, "When wilt Thou look on?" that is, when shall we see vengeance upon those who insult us? When shall the Judge, overcome by weariness, hear the widow? But our Judge, not from weariness, but from love, delayeth our salvation; from reason, not from need; not that He could not even now succour us, but that the number of us all may be filled up even to the end.

[35:185] And yet out of our desire, what do we say? "Lord, when wilt Thou look on? Rescue My Soul from their deceits, My Darling from the lions:" that is, My Church from raging powers.

[35:186] Lastly, wouldest thou know what is that Darling? Read the words following: "I will confess unto Thee, O Lord, in the great Congregation; in a weighty people will I praise Thee".

[35:187] Truly saith He, "I will confess unto Thee:" for confession is made in all the multitude, but not in all is God praised: the whole multitude heareth our confession, but not in all the multitude is the praise of God.

[35:188] For in all the whole multitude, that is, in the Church which is spread abroad in the whole world, is chaff, and wheat: the chaff flieth, the wheat remaineth; therefore, "in a weighty people will I praise Thee".

[35:189] In a weighty people, which the wind of temptation carries not away, in such is God praised.

[35:190] For in the chaff He is ever blasphemed.

[35:191] "Let not them that are Mine enemies wrongfully rejoice over Me:" for they rejoice over Me because of My chaff.

[35:192] "Who hate Me without a cause;" that is, whom I never hurt; "winking with their eyes" : that is, pretending hypocrites, "For they spake indeed peace to Me".

[35:193] What is, "winking with their eyes"? Declaring by their looks, what they carry not in their heart.

[35:194] And who are these "winking with their eyes"? "For they spake indeed peace to Me; and with wrath devised craftily".

[35:195] "Yea they opened their mouth wide against Me".

[35:196] First winking with their eyes, those lions sought to ravish and devour; first fawning they spake peace, and then with wrath devised craftily.

[35:197] What peace spake they? "Master, we know that Thou acceptest not man's person, and teachest the way of God in truth.

[35:198] Is it lawful to give tribute unto Caesar, or not?" They spake indeed peace unto Me.

[35:199] What then? Didst not Thou know them, and deceived they Thee, winking with their eyes? Truly He knew them; therefore said He, "Why tempt ye Me, ye hypocrites?" Afterward, "they opened their mouth wide against Me," crying, "Crucify Him, Crucify Him! and said, Aha, Aha, our eyes have seen it".

[35:200] This, when they insulted Him, "Aha, Aha, Prophesy unto us, Thou Christ".

[35:201] As their peace was pretended when they tempted Him concerning the money, so now insulting was their praise.

[35:202] "They said, Aha, Aha, our eyes have seen it" : that is, Thy deeds, Thy miracles.

[35:203] This Man is the Christ.

[35:204] "If He be the Christ, let Him come down from the Cross, and we will believe Him.

[35:205] He saved others, Himself He cannot save".

[35:206] "Our eyes have seen it".

[35:207] This is all whereof He boasted Himself, when "He called Himself the Son of God".

[35:208] But the Lord was hanging patient upon the Cross: His power had He not lost, but He showed His patience.

[35:209] For what great thing was it for Him to come down from the Cross, who could afterward rise again from the sepulchre? But He seems to have yielded to His insulters; and this, beloved, that having risen again He should show Himself to His own, and not to them, and this is a great mystery; for His resurrection signified the New Life, but the New Life is known to His friends, not to His enemies.

[35:210] "This Thou hast seen, O Lord; keep not silence".

[35:211] What is, "keep not silence"? Judge Thou.

[35:212] For of judgment is it said in a certain place, "I have kept silence; shall I keep silence for ever?" And of the delaying of judgment it is said to the sinner, "These things hast thou done, and I kept silence;" "Thou thoughtest that I was altogether such an one as thyself".

[35:213] How keepeth He silence, who speaketh by the Prophets, who speaketh with His own mouth in the Gospel, who speaketh by the Evangelists, who speaketh by us, when we speak the truth? What then? He keepeth silence from judgment, not from precept, not from doctrine.

[35:214] But this His judgment the Prophet in a manner invoketh, and predicteth: "Thou hast seen, O Lord: keep not silence;" that is, Thou wilt not keep silence, needs must that Thou wilt judge.

[35:215] "O Lord, be not far from Me".

[35:216] Until Thy judgment come, be not far from Me, as Thou hast promised, "Lo, I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world".

[35:217] "Arise, Lord, and attend to My judgment".

[35:218] To what judgment? That Thou art in tribulation; that Thou art tormented with labours and pains? Do not even many wicked men suffer the same? To what judgment? Therefore art Thou righteous, because Thou sufferest these things? No: but what? "To My judgment".

[35:219] What followeth? "Attend to My judgment; even to My cause, My God, and My Lord".

[35:220] Not to My punishment, but to My cause: not to that which the robber hath in common with Me, but to that whereof is said, "Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness' sake".

[35:221] For this cause is distinguished.

[35:222] For punishment is equal to good and bad.

[35:223] Therefore Martyrs, not the punishment, but the cause maketh, for if punishment made Martyrs, all the mines would be full of Martyrs, every chain would drag Martyrs, all that are executed with the sword would be crowned.

[35:224] Therefore let the cause be distinguished; let none say, because I suffer, I am righteous.

[35:225] Because He who first suffered, suffered for righteousness' sake, therefore He added a great exception, "Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness' sake".

[35:226] For many having a good cause do persecution, and many having a bad cause suffer persecution.

[35:227] For if persecution could not be done rightly, it had not been said in a certain Psalm, "Whoso privily slandereth his neighbour, him did I persecute".

[35:228] Let none then say, I suffer persecution: let him not sift the punishment, but prove the cause: lest if he prove not the cause, he be numbered with the ungodly.

[35:229] Therefore how watchfully, how excellently hath This Man recommended Himself, "O Lord, attend to My judgment," not to My punishments; "even to My cause, My God, and My Lord".

[35:230] "Judge me, O Lord, according to My righteousness" ; that is, attend to My cause.

[35:231] Not according to My punishment, but "according to My righteousness, O Lord, My God," that is, according to this judge Thou Me.

[35:232] "And let them not rejoice over Me;" that is, Mine enemies.

[35:233] "Let them not say in their heart, Aha, aha, so would we have it" ; that is, We have done what we could, we have slain him, we have taken him away.

[35:234] "Let them not say:" show them that they have done nothing.

[35:235] "Let them not say, We have swallowed him up".

[35:236] Whence say those Martyrs, "If the Lord had not been on our side, then they had swallowed us up quick".

[35:237] What is, "had swallowed us up"? Had passed into their own body.

[35:238] For that thou swallowest up, which thou passest into thy own body.

[35:239] The world would swallow thee up; swallow thou the world, pass it into thy own body: kill and eat.

[35:240] As it was said to Peter, "Kill and eat;" do thou kill in them what they are, make them what thou art.

[35:241] But if they on the other hand persuade thee to ungodliness, thou art swallowed up by them.

[35:242] Not when they persecute thee art thou swallowed up by them, but when they persuade thee to be what they are.

[35:243] "Let them not say, We have swallowed him up".

[35:244] Do thou swallow up the body of Pagans.

[35:245] Why the body of Pagans? It would swallow thee up.

[35:246] Do thou to it, what it would to thee.

[35:247] Therefore perhaps that calf, being ground to powder, was cast into the water and given to the children of Israel to drink, that so the body of ungodliness might be swallowed up by Israel.

[35:248] "Let them be ashamed and brought to confusion together that rejoice at mine hurt: let them be clothed with shame and dishonour" ; so that we may swallow up them ashamed and brought to confusion.

[35:249] "Who speak evil against me:" let them be ashamed, let them be brought to confusion.

[35:250] What sayest thou now, the Head with the Members? "Let them shout for joy and be glad that favour My righteous cause:" who cleave to My Body.

[35:251] Yea, let them say "continually, Let the Lord be magnified, which hath pleasure in the prosperity of His servant".

[35:252] "And my tongue shall speak of Thy righteousness, and of Thy praise all the day long".

[35:253] And whose tongue endureth to speak the praise of God all the day long? See now I have made a discourse something longer; ye are wearied.

[35:254] Who endureth to praise God all the day long? I will suggest a remedy, whereby thou mayest praise God all the day long if thou wilt.

[35:255] Whatever thou dost, do well, and thou hast praised God.

[35:256] When thou singest an hymn, thou praisest God, but what doth thy tongue, unless thy heart also praise Him? Hast thou ceased from singing hymns, and departed, that thou mayest refresh thyself? Be not drunken, and thou hast praised God.

[35:257] Dost thou go away to sleep? Rise not to do evil, and thou hast praised God.

[35:258] Dost thou transact business? Do no wrong, and thou hast praised God.

[35:259] Dost thou till thy field? Raise not strife, and thou hast praised God.

[35:260] In the innocency of thy works prepare thyself to praise God all the day long.

[36:1] Psalm XXXVI.

[36:2] "The ungodly hath said in himself that he will sin: there is no fear of God before his eyes".

[36:3] Not of one man, but of a race of ungodly men he speaketh, who fight against their own selves, by not understanding, that so they may live well; not because they cannot, but because they will not.

[36:4] For it is one thing, when one endeavours to understand some thing, and through infirmity of flesh cannot; as saith the Scripture in a certain place, "For the corruptible body presseth down the soul, and the earthly tabernacle weigheth down the mind that museth upon many things;" but another when the human heart acts mischievously against itself, so that what it could understand, if it had but good will thereto, it understandeth not, not because it is difficult, but because the will is contrary.

[36:5] But so it is when men love their own sins, and hate God's Commandments.

[36:6] For the Word of God is thy adversary, if thou be a friend to thy ungodliness; but if thou art an adversary to thy ungodliness, the Word of God is thy friend, as well as the adversary of thy ungodliness.

[36:7] "For he hath wrought deceitfully in His sight".

[36:8] In whose sight? In His, whose fear was not before the eyes of him that did work deceitfully.

[36:9] "To find out his iniquity, and hate it".

[36:10] He wrought so as not to find it.

[36:11] For there are men who as it were endeavour to seek out their iniquity, and fear to find it; because if they should find it, it is said to them, Depart from it: this thou didst before thou knewest; thou didst iniquity being in ignorance; God giveth pardon: now thou hast discovered it, forsake it, that to thy ignorance pardon may easily be given; and that with a clear face thou mayest say to God, "Remember not the sins of my youth, and of my ignorance".

[36:12] Thus he seeketh it, thus he feareth lest he find it; for he seeketh it deceitfully.

[36:13] When saith a man, I knew not that it was sin? When he hath seen that it is sin, and ceaseth to do the sin, which he did only because he was ignorant: such an one in truth would know his sin, to find it out, and hate it.

[36:14] But now many "work deceitfully to find out their iniquity:" they work not from their heart to find it out and hate it.

[36:15] But because in the very search after iniquity, there is deceit, in the finding it there will be defence of it.

[36:16] For when one hath found his iniquity, lo now it is manifest to him that it is iniquity.

[36:17] Do it not, thou sayest.

[36:18] And he who wrought deceitfully to find it out, now he hath found, hateth it not; for what saith he? How many do this! Who is there that doth it not? And will God destroy them all? Or at least he saith this: if God would not these things to be done, would men live who commit the same? Seest thou that thou didst work deceitfully to find out thy iniquity? For if not deceitfully but sincerely thou hadst wrought, thou wouldest now have found it out, and hated it; now thou hast found it out, and thou defendest it; therefore thou didst work deceitfully, when thou soughtest it.

[36:19] "The words of his mouth are iniquity and deceit: he would not understand, that he might do good".

[36:20] Ye see that he attributeth that to the will: for there are men who would understand and cannot, and there are men who would not understand, and therefore understand not.

[36:21] "He would not understand, that he might do good".

[36:22] "He hath meditated iniquity on his bed".

[36:23] What said He, "On his bed?".

[36:24] "The ungodly hath said in himself, that he will sin:" what above he said, in himself, that here he said, "On his bed".

[36:25] Our bed is our heart: there we suffer the tossing of an evil conscience; and there we rest when our conscience is good.

[36:26] Whoso loveth the bed of his heart, let him do some good therein.

[36:27] There is our bed, where the Lord Jesus Christ commands us to pray.

[36:28] "Enter into thy chamber, and shut thy door".

[36:29] What is, "Shut thy door?" Expect not from God such things as are without, but such as are within; "and thy Father which seeth in secret, shall reward thee openly".

[36:30] Who is he that shutteth not the door? He who asketh much from God such things, and in such wise directeth all his prayers, that he may receive the goods that are of this world.

[36:31] Thy door is open, the multitude seeth when thou prayest.

[36:32] What is it to shut thy door? To ask that of God, which God alone knoweth how He giveth.

[36:33] What is that for which thou prayest, when thou hast shut the door? What "eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, or hath entered into the heart of man".

[36:34] And haply it hath not entered into thy very bed, that is, into thy heart.

[36:35] But God knoweth what He will give: but when shall it be? When the Lord shall be revealed, when the Judge shall appear.

[36:36] "He hath set himself in every way that is not good".

[36:37] What is, "he hath set himself"? He hath sinned perseveringly.

[36:38] Whence also of a certain pious and good man it is said, "He hath not stood in the way of sinners".

[36:39] As this "hath not stood," so that "hath set himself".

[36:40] "But wickedness hath he not hated".

[36:41] There is the end, there the fruit: if a man cannot but have wickedness, let him at least hate it.

[36:42] For when thou hatest it, it scarcely occurs to thee to do any wickedness.

[36:43] For sin is in our mortal body, but what saith the Apostle? "Let not sin reign in your mortal body, that ye should obey it in the lusts thereof".

[36:44] When beginneth it not to be therein? When that shall be fulfilled in us which he saith, "When this corruptible shall have put on incorruption, and this mortal shall have put on immortality".

[36:45] Before this come to pass, there is a delighting in sin in the body, but greater is the delighting and the pleasure in the Word of Wisdom, in the Commandment of God.

[36:46] Overcome sin and the lust thereof.

[36:47] Sin and iniquity do thou hate, that thou mayest join thyself to God, who hateth it as well as thou.

[36:48] Now being joined in mind unto the Law of God, in mind thou servest the Law of God.

[36:49] And if in the flesh thou therefore servest the law of sin, because there are in thee certain carnal delightings, then will there be none when thou shalt no longer fight.

[36:50] It is one thing not to fight, and to be in true and lasting peace; another to fight and overcome; another to fight and to be overcome; another not to fight at all, but to be carried away.

[36:51] "Thy mercy, O Lord, is in the heavens, and Thy truth reacheth even unto the clouds".

[36:52] I know not what Mercy of Him he meaneth, which is in the heavens.

[36:53] For the Mercy of the Lord is also in the earth.

[36:54] Thou hast it written, "The earth is full of the Mercy of the Lord".

[36:55] Of what Mercy then speaketh He, when He saith, "Thy Mercy, O Lord, is in the heavens"? The gifts of God are partly temporal and earthly, partly eternal and heavenly.

[36:56] Whoso for this worshippeth God, that he may receive those temporal and earthly goods, which are open to all, is still as it were like the brutes: he enjoyeth indeed the Mercy of God, but not that which is excepted, which shall not be given, save only to the righteous, to the holy, to the good.

[36:57] What are the gifts which abound to all? "He maketh His sun to rise on the evil and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust".

[36:58] Who hath not this Mercy of God, first that he hath being, that he is distinguished from the brutes, that he is a rational animal, so as to understand God; secondly, that he enjoys this light, this air, rain, fruits, diversity of seasons, and all the earthly comforts, health of body, the affection of friends, the safety of his family? All these are good, and they are God's gifts.

[36:59] But this man rightly understood what mercy he should pray for from God.

[36:60] "Thy Mercy, O Lord, is in the Heavens; and Thy Truth reacheth even to the clouds".

[36:61] That is, the Mercy which Thou givest to Thy Saints, is Heavenly, not earthly; is Eternal, not temporal.

[36:62] And how couldest Thou declare it unto men? Because "Thy Truth reacheth even unto the clouds".

[36:63] For who could know the Heavenly Mercy of God, unless God should declare it unto men? How did He declare it? By sending His truth even unto the clouds.

[36:64] What are the clouds? The Preachers of the Word of God.

[36:65] Truth reached even to the clouds: therefore unto us could be declared the Mercy of God, which is in Heaven and not in earth.

[36:66] And truly, Brethren, the clouds are the Preachers of the Word of Truth.

[36:67] When God threateneth through His Preachers, He thunders through the clouds.

[36:68] When God worketh miracles through His Preachers, He lightneth through the clouds, He terrifieth through the clouds, and watereth by the rain.

[36:69] Those Preachers, then, by whom is preached the Gospel of God, are the clouds of God.

[36:70] Let us then hope for Mercy, but for that which is in the Heavens.

[36:71] "Thy Righteousness is like the mountains of God: Thy Judgments are a great deep".

[36:72] Who are the mountains of God? Those who are called clouds, the same are also the mountains of God.

[36:73] The great Preachers are the mountains of God.

[36:74] And as when the sun riseth, he first clothes the mountains with light, and thence the light descends to the lowest parts of the earth: so our Lord Jesus Christ, when He came, first irradiated the height of the Apostles, first enlightened the mountains, and so His Light descended to the valley of the world.

[36:75] And therefore saith He in a certain Psalm, "I lifted up mine eyes unto the mountains, from whence cometh my help".

[36:76] But think not that the mountains themselves will give thee help: for they receive what they may give, give not of their own.

[36:77] And if thou remain in the mountains, thy hope will not be strong: but in Him who enlighteneth the mountains, ought to be thy hope and presumption.

[36:78] Thy help indeed will come to thee through the mountains, because the Scriptures are administered to thee through the mountains, through the great Preachers of the Truth: but fix not thy hope in them.

[36:79] Hear what He saith next following: "I lifted up mine eyes unto the mountains, from whence cometh my help".

[36:80] What then? Do the mountains give thee help? No; hear what follows, "My help cometh from the Lord, which made Heaven and earth".

[36:81] Through the mountains cometh help, but not from the mountains.

[36:82] From whom then? "From the Lord, which made Heaven and earth".

[36:83] "Thy Judgments are like the great abyss".

[36:84] The abyss he calleth the depth of sin, whither every one cometh by despising God; as in a certain place it is said, "God gave them over to their own hearts' lusts, to do the things which are not convenient".

[36:85] Because then they were proud and ungrateful, they were held worthy to be delivered up to the lusts of their own hearts, and became a great abyss, so that they not only sinned, but also worked craftily, lest they should understand their iniquity, and hate it.

[36:86] That is the depth of wickedness, to be unwilling to find it out and to hate it.

[36:87] But how one cometh to that depth, see; "Thy Judgments are the great abyss".

[36:88] As the mountains are by the Righteousness of God,  who through His Grace become great: so also through His Judgments come they unto the depth, who sink lowest.

[36:89] By this then let the mountains delight thee, by this turn away from the abyss, and turn thyself unto that, of which it is said, "My help cometh from the Lord".

[36:90] But whereby? "I have lifted up mine eyes unto the mountains".

[36:91] What meaneth this? I will speak plainly In the Church of God thou findest an abyss, thou findest also mountains; thou findest there but few good, because the mountains are few, the abyss broad; that is, thou findest many living ill after the wrath of God, because they have so worked that they are delivered up to the lusts of their own heart; so now they defend their sins and confess them not; but say, Why? What have I done? Such an one did this, and such an one did that.

[36:92] Now will they even defend what the Divine Word reproves.

[36:93] This is the abyss.

[36:94] Therefore in a certain place saith the Scripture (hear this abyss), "The sinner when he cometh unto the depth of sin despiseth".

[36:95] See, "Thy Judgments are like the great abyss".

[36:96] But yet not art thou a mountain; not yet art thou in the abyss; fly from the abyss, tend towards the mountains; but yet remain not on the mountains.

[36:97] "For thy help cometh from the Lord, which made Heaven and earth".

[36:98] Because he said, Thy Mercy is in the Heavens, that it may be known to be also on earth, he said, "O Lord, Thou savest man and beast, as Thy Mercy is multiplied, O God".

[36:99] Great is Thy Mercy, and manifold is Thy Mercy, O God; and that showest Thou both to man and beast.

[36:100] For from whom is the saving of men? From God.

[36:101] Is not the saving of beasts also from God? For He who made man, made also beasts; He who made both, saveth both; but the saving of beasts is temporal.

[36:102] But there are who as a great thing ask this of God, which He hath given to beasts.

[36:103] "Thy Mercy, O God, is multiplied," so that not only unto men, but unto beasts also is given the same saving which is given to men, a carnal and temporal saving.

[36:104] Have not men then somewhat reserved with God, which beasts deserve not, and whereunto beasts arrive not? They have evidently.

[36:105] And where is that which they have.

[36:106] "The children of men put their trust under the shadow of Thy wings".

[36:107] Attend, my Beloved, to this most pleasant sentence; "Thou savest man and beast".

[36:108] First, he spake of "man and beast," then of "the children of men;" as though "men" were one, "the children of men" other.

[36:109] Sometimes in Scripture children of men is said generally of all men, sometimes in some proper manner, with some proper signification, so that not all men are understood; chiefly when there is a distinction.

[36:110] For not without reason is it here put; "O Lord, Thou savest man and beast: but the children of men;" as though setting aside the first, he keepeth separate the children of men.

[36:111] Separate from whom? Not only from beasts, but also from men, who seek from God the saving of beasts, and desire this as a great thing.

[36:112] Who then are the children of men? Those who put their trust under the shadow of His wings.

[36:113] For those men together with beasts rejoice in possession, but the children of men rejoice in hope: those follow after present goods with beasts, these hope for future goods with Angels.

[36:114] "They shall be satiated with the fulness of Thy House".

[36:115] He promiseth us some great thing.

[36:116] He would speak it, and He speaketh it not.

[36:117] Can He not, or do not we receive it? I dare, my Brethren, to say, even of holy tongues and hearts, by which Truth is declared to us, that it can neither be spoken, which they declared, nor even thought of.

[36:118] For it is a great thing, and ineffable; and even they saw through a glass darkly, as saith the Apostle, "For now we see through a glass darkly; but then face to face".

[36:119] Lo, they who saw through a glass darkly, thus burst forth.

[36:120] What then shall we be, when we shall see face to face? That with which they travailed in heart, and could not with their tongue bring forth, that men might receive it.

[36:121] For what necessity was there that he should say, "They shall be satiated with the fulness of Thy House"? He sought a word whereby to express from human things what he would say; and because he saw that men drowning themselves in drunkenness receive indeed wine without measure, but lose their senses, he saw what to say; for when shall have been received that ineffable joy, then shall be lost in a manner the human soul, it shall bec ome Divine, and be satiated with the fulness of God's House.

[36:122] Wherefore also in another Psalm it is said, "Thy cup inebriating, how excellent is it!" With this cup were the Martyrs satiated when going to their passion, they knew not their own.

[36:123] What so inebriated as not to know a wife weeping, not children, not parents? They knew them not, they thought not that they were before their eyes.

[36:124] Wonder not: they were inebriated.

[36:125] Wherewith were they so? Lo, they had received a cup wherewith they were satiated.

[36:126] Wherefore he also gives thanks to God, saying, "What shall I render unto the Lord for all His benefits towards me? I will take the cup of Salvation, and call upon the Name of the Lord".

[36:127] Therefore, Brethren of men, let us be children and let us trust under the shadow of His wings and be satiated with the fulness of His House.

[36:128] As I could, I have spoken; and as far as I can I see; and how far I see, I cannot speak "And of the torrent of Thy Pleasure shalt Thou give them to drink".

[36:129] A torrent we call water coming with a flood.

[36:130] There will be a flood of God's Mercy to overflow and inebriate those who now put their trust under the shadow of His wings.

[36:131] What is that Pleasure? As it were a torrent inebriating the thirsty.

[36:132] Let him then who thirsts now, lay up hope: whoso thirsts now, let him have hope; when inebriated, he shall have possession: before he have possession, let him thirst in hope.

[36:133] "Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness, for they shall be filled".

[36:134] With what fountain then wilt thou be overflowed, and whence runneth such a torrent of His Pleasure? "For with Thee," saith he, "is the fountain of Life".

[36:135] What is the fountain of Life, but Christ? He came to thee in the flesh, that He might bedew thy thirsty lips: He will satisfy thee trusting, who bedewed thee thirsting.

[36:136] "For with Thee is the fountain of Life; in Thy Light shall we see light".

[36:137] Here a fountain is one thing, light another: there not so.

[36:138] For that which is the Fountain, the same is also Light: and whatever thou wilt thou callest It, for It is not what thou callest It: for thou canst not find a fit name: for It remaineth not in one name.

[36:139] If thou shouldest say, that It is Light only, it would be said to thee, Then without cause am I told to hunger and thirst, for who is there that eateth light? It is said to me plainly, directly, "Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God".

[36:140] If It is Light, my eyes must I prepare.

[36:141] Prepare also lips; for That which is Light is also a Fountain: a Fountain, because It satisfieth the thirsty: Light, because It enlighteneth the blind.

[36:142] Here sometimes, light is in one place, a fountain in another.

[36:143] For sometimes fountains run even in darkness; and sometimes in the desert thou sufferest the sun, findest no fountain: here then can these two be separated: there thou shalt not be wearied, for there is a Fountain; there thou shalt not be darkened, for there is Light.

[36:144] "Show forth Thy Mercy unto them that know Thee; Thy Righteousness to them that are of a right heart".

[36:145] As I have said, Those are of a right heart who follow in this life the Will of God.

[36:146] The will of God is sometimes that thou shouldest be whole, sometimes that thou shouldest be sick.

[36:147] If when thou art whole God's Will be sweet, and when thou art sick God's Will be bitter; thou art not of a right heart.

[36:148] Wherefore? Because thou wilt not make right thy will according to God's Will, but wilt bend God's Will to thine.

[36:149] That is right, but thou art crooked: thy will must be made right to That, not That made crooked to thee; and thou wilt have a right heart.

[36:150] It is well with thee in this world; be God blessed, who comforteth thee: it goeth hardly with thee in this world; be God blessed, because He chasteneth and proveth thee; and so wilt thou be of a right heart, saying, "I will bless the Lord at all times: His Praise shall be ever in my mouth".

[36:151] "Let not the foot of pride come against me".

[36:152] But now he said, The children of men shall put their trust under the shadow of Thy wings: they shall be satiated with the fulness of Thy House.

[36:153] When one hath begun to be plentifully overflowed with that Fountain, let him take heed lest he grow proud.

[36:154] For the same was not wanting to Adam, the first man: but the foot of pride came against him, and the hand of the sinner removed him, that is, the proud hand of the devil.

[36:155] As he who seduced him, said of himself, "I will sit in the sides of the north;" so he persuaded him, by saying, "Taste, and ye shall be as gods".

[36:156] By pride then have we so fallen as to arrive at this mortality.

[36:157] And because pride had wounded us, humility maketh us whole.

[36:158] God came humbly, that from such great wound of pride He might heal man.

[36:159] He came, for "The Word was made Flesh, and dwelt among us".

[36:160] He was taken by the Jews; He was reviled of them.

[36:161] Ye heard when the Gospel was read, what they said, and to Whom they said, "Thou hast a devil:" and He said not, Ye have a devil, for ye are still in your sins, and the devil possesseth your hearts.

[36:162] He said not this, which if He had said, He had said truly: but it was not meet that He should say it, lest He should seem not to preach Truth, but to retort evil speaking.

[36:163] He let go what He heard as though He heard it not.

[36:164] For a Physician was He, and to cure the madman had He come.

[36:165] As a Physician careth not what he may hear from the madman; but how the madman may recover and become sane; nor even if he receive a blow from the madman, careth he; but while he to him giveth new wounds, he cureth his old fever: so also the Lord came to the sick man, to the madman came He, that whatever He might hear, whatever He might suffer, He should despise; by this very thing teaching us humility, that being taught by humility, we might be healed from pride: from which he here prayeth to be delivered, saying, "Let not the foot of pride come against me; neither let the hand of the sinner remove me".

[36:166] For if the foot of pride come, the hand of the sinner removeth.

[36:167] What is the hand of the sinner? The working of him that adviseth ill.

[36:168] Hast thou become proud? Quickly he corrupteth thee who adviseth ill.

[36:169] Humbly fix thyself in God, and care not much what is said to thee.

[36:170] Hence is that which is elsewhere spoken, "From my secret sins cleanse Thou me; and from others' sins also keep Thy servant".

[36:171] What is, "From my secret sins"? "Let not the foot of pride come against me".

[36:172] What is, "From other men's sins also keep Thy servant"? "Let not the hand of the wicked remove me".

[36:173] Keep that which is within, and thou shalt not fear from without.

[36:174] But wherefore so greatly fearest thou this? Because it is said, "Thereby have fallen all that work iniquity" ; so that they have come into that abyss of which it is said, "Thy judgments are like the great abyss:" so that they have come even to that deep wherein sinners who despise have fallen.

[36:175] "Have fallen".

[36:176] Whereby did they first fall? By the foot of pride.

[36:177] Hear the foot of pride.

[36:178] "When they knew God, they glorified Him not as God".

[36:179] Therefore came against them the foot of pride, whereby they came into the depth.

[36:180] "God gave them over to their own hearts' lusts, to do those things which are not convenient".

[36:181] The root of sin, and the head of sin feared he who said, "Let not the foot of pride come against me".

[36:182] Wherefore said he, "the foot"? Because by walking proudly man deserted God, and departed from Him.

[36:183] His foot, called he his affection.

[36:184] "Let not the foot of pride come against me: let not the hand of the wicked remove me:" that is, let not the works of the wicked remove me from Thee, that I should wish to imitate them.

[36:185] But wherefore said he this against pride, "Thereby have fallen all that work iniquity"? Because those who now are ungodly, have fallen by pride.

[36:186] Therefore when the Lord would caution His Church, He said, "It shall watch thy head, and thou shalt watch his heel".

[36:187] The serpent watcheth when the foot of pride may come against thee, when thou mayest fall, that he may cast thee down.

[36:188] But watch thou his head: the beginning of all sin is pride "Thereby have fallen all that work iniquity: they are driven out, and are not able to stand".

[36:189] He first, who in the Truth stood not, then, through him, they whom God sent out of Paradise.

[36:190] Whence he, the humble, who said that he was not worthy to unloose His shoe's latchet, is not driven out, but standeth and heareth Him, and rejoiceth greatly because of the Bridegroom's voice; not because of his own, lest the foot of pride come against him, and he be driven out, and be not able to stand.

[36:191] Contents   Part  Part  Part.

[37:1] Psalm XXXVII  On the first part of the psalm.

[37:2] With terror do they hear of the coming of the last day, who will not be secure by living well: and who fain would live ill, long.

[37:3] But it was for useful purposes that God willed that day to remain unknown; that the heart may be ever ready to expect that of which it knows it is to come, but knows not when it is to come.

[37:4] Seeing, however, that our Lord Jesus Christ was sent to us to be our "Master," He said, that "of the day not even the Son of Man knew," because it was not part of His office as our Master that through Him it should become known to us.

[37:5] For indeed the Father knoweth nothing that the Son knoweth not; since that is the Very Knowledge of the Father Itself, which is His Wisdom; now His Son, His Word, is "His Wisdom".

[37:6] But because it was not for our good to know that, which however was known to Him who came indeed to teach us, though not to teach us that which it was not good for us to know, He not only, as a Master, taught us something, but also, as a Master, left something untaught.

[37:7] For, as a Master, He knew how both to teach us what was good for us, and not to teach us what was injurious.

[37:8] Now thus, according to a certain form of speech, the Son is said not to know what He does not teach: that is, in the same way that we are daily in the habit of speaking, He is said not to know what He causes us not to know.

[37:9] This it is that disturbs you who are a Christian; that you see men of bad lives prospering, and surrounded with abundance of things like these; you see them sound in health, distinguished with proud honours; you see their family unvisited by misfortune; the happiness of their relatives, the obsequious attendance of their dependants, their most commanding influence, their life uninterrupted by any sad event; you see their characters most profligate, their external resources most affluent; and your heart says that there is no Divine judgment; that all things are carried to and fro by accidents, and blown about in disorderly and irregular motions.

[37:10] For if God, thou sayest, regarded human affairs, would his iniquity flourish, and my innocence suffer? Every sickness of the soul hath in Scripture its proper remedy.

[37:11] Let him then whose  sickness is of that kind that he says in his heart things like these, let him drink this Psalm by way of potion.

[37:12] "Be not envious because of evil-doers, neither be envious against the workers of iniquity".

[37:13] "For they shall soon wither like the grass, and shall fade like the herbs of the meadow".

[37:14] That which to thee seemeth long, is "soon" in the sight of God.

[37:15] Conform thou thyself to God; and it will be "soon" to thee.

[37:16] That which he here calls "grass," that we understand by the "herbs of the meadow".

[37:17] They are some worthless things, occupying the surface only of the ground, they have no depth of root.

[37:18] In the winter then they are green; but when the summer sun shall begin to scorch, they will wither away.

[37:19] For now it is the season of winter.

[37:20] Thy glory doth not as yet appear.

[37:21] But if thy love hath but a deep root, like that of many trees during winter, the frost passes away, the summer (that is, the Day of Judgment) will come; then will the greenness of the grass wither away.

[37:22] Then will the glory of the trees appear.

[37:23] "For ye" (saith the Apostle) "are dead," even as trees seem to be in winter, as it were dead, as it were withered.

[37:24] What is our hope then, if we are dead? The root is within; where our root is, there is our life also, for there our love is fixed.

[37:25] "And your life is hid with Christ in God".

[37:26] When shall he wither who is thus rooted? But when will our spring be? When our summer? When will the honour of foliage clothe us around, and the fulness of fruit make us rich? When shall this come to pass? Hear what follows: "When Christ, who is our life, shall appear, then shall ye also appear with Him in glory".

[37:27] And what then shall we do now? "Be not envious because of the evil-doers, neither be envious against the workers of iniquity.

[37:28] For they shall soon wither like the grass, and fade like the herb of the meadow".

[37:29] What shouldest thou do then? "Trust in the Lord".

[37:30] For they too trust, but not "in the Lord".

[37:31] Their hope is perishable.

[37:32] Their hope is short-lived, frail, fleeting, transitory, baseless.

[37:33] "Trust thou in the Lord".

[37:34] "Behold," thou sayest, "I do trust; what am I to do?"  "And do good".

[37:35] Do not do that evil which thou beholdest in those men, who are prosperous in wickedness.

[37:36] "Do good, and dwell in the land".

[37:37] Lest haply thou shouldest be doing good without "dwelling in the land".

[37:38] For it is the Church that is the Lord's land.

[37:39] It is her whom He, the Father, the tiller of it, waters and cultivates.

[37:40] For there are many that, as it were, do good works, but yet, in that they do not "dwell in the land," they do not belong to the husbandman.

[37:41] Therefore do thou thy good, not outside of the land, but do thou "dwell in the land".

[37:42] And what shall I have?  "And thou shalt be fed in its riches".

[37:43] What are the riches of that land? Her riches are her Lord! Her riches are her God! He it is to whom it is said, "The Lord is the portion of mine inheritance, and of my cup".

[37:44] In a late discourse we suggested to you, dearly beloved, that God is our possession, and that we are at the same time God's possession.

[37:45] Hear how that He is Himself the riches of that land.

[37:46] "Delight thyself in the Lord".

[37:47] As if thou hadst put the question, and hadst said "Show me the riches of that land, in which thou biddest me dwell," he says, "Delight thyself in the Lord".

[37:48] "And He shall give thee the desires of thine heart".

[37:49] Understand in their proper signification, "the desires of thine heart".

[37:50] Distinguish the "desires of thine heart" from the desires of thy flesh; distinguish as much as thou canst.

[37:51] It is not without a meaning that it is said in a certain Psalm, "God is" (the strength) "of mine heart".
