[45:231] Hear Paul, that "least of the Apostles" (that "hem of that garment," which the woman with the issue of blood touched, and was healed), hear him saying: "We are a sweet savour of Christ, in every place, both in them that are saved, and in them that perish".

[45:232] He did not say, "We are a sweet savour in them that are saved, and a foul savour in them that are lost:" but, as far as relates to ourselves, "we are a sweet savour both in them that are saved, and in them that perish".

[45:233] They who loved him were saved by the odour of "sweet savour;" they who envied him, perished by means of that "sweet savour".

[45:234] To them that perished then he was not a foul "savour," but a "sweet savour".

[45:235] For it was for this very reason they the more envied him, the more excellent that grace was which reigned in him: for no man envies him who is unhappy.

[45:236] He then was glorious in the preaching of God's Word, and in regulating his life according to the rule of that "rod of direction;" and he was loved by those who loved Christ in him, who followed after and pursued the odour of sweet savour; who loved the friend of the bridegroom: that is to say, by the Bride Herself, who says in the Song of Songs,  "We will run after the sweet savour of thy perfumes".

[45:237] But the others, the more they beheld him invested with the glory of the preaching of the Gospel, and of an irreproachable life, were so much the more tortured with envy, and found that sweet savour prove death to them.

[45:238] "Out of thy ivory palaces, whereby kings' daughters have made Thee glad".

[45:239] Choose whichever you please, "ivory" palaces, or "magnificent," or "royal" palaces, it is out of these that the kings' daughters have made Christ glad.

[45:240] Would you understand the spiritual sense of "ivory palaces"? Understand by them the magnificent houses, and tabernacles of God, the hearts of the Saints; and by these self-same "kings" those who rule their flesh; who bring into subjection to themselves the rebellious commonalty of human affections, who chastise the body, and reduce it to bondage: for it is from these that the daughters of kings have made Him glad.

[45:241] For all the souls that have been born through their preaching and evangelizing are "daughters of kings:" and the Churches, as the daughters of Apostles, are daughters of kings.

[45:242] For He is "King of kings;" they themselves kings, of whom it was said, "Ye shall sit upon twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel".

[45:243] They preached the "Word of Truth;" and begat Churches not for themselves, but for Him.

[45:244] Therefore as "raising up seed to their brother," to as many as they begat, they gave the name not of "Paulians" or "Petrians," but of "Christians".

[45:245] Observe whether that sense is not wakefully kept in these verses.

[45:246] For when he said, "out of the ivory palaces, he spake of mansions royal, ample, honourable, peaceful, like the heart of the Saints; he added, "Whereby the kings' daughters have made Thee glad in Thine honour".

[45:247] They are indeed daughters of kings, daughters of thine Apostles, but still "in Thine honour:" for they raised up seed to their brother.

[45:248] Hence Paul, when he saw those whom he had raised up unto his Brother, running after his own name, exclaimed, "Was Paul crucified for you?"No; for he says, "Or were ye baptized in the name of Paul?"  "The daughters of kings have made Thee glad in Thine honour".

[45:249] Keep, hold fast this "in Thine honour".

[45:250] This is meant by having "a wedding garment;" seeking His honour, His glory.

[45:251] Understand moreover by "kings' daughters" the cities, which were founded by kings, and have received the faith: and out of the ivory palaces (palaces rich, the proud, the lifted up).

[45:252] "Kings' daughters have made Thee glad in Thine honour;" in that they sought not the honour of their founders, but have sought Thine honour.

[45:253] Show me at Rome a temple of Romulus held in so great honour as I can show you the Monument of Peter In Peter, who is honoured but He who died for us? For we are followers of Christ, not followers of Peter.

[45:254] And even if we were born from the brother of Him that is dead, yet are we named after the name of Him who is dead We were begotten by the one, but begotten to the other.

[45:255] Behold, Rome, Carthage, and several other cities are the daughters of kings, and yet have they "made glad the King in His honour:" and all these make up one single Queen.

[45:256] What a nuptial song! Behold in the midst of songs full of rejoicing, comes forth the Bride herself.

[45:257] For the Bridegroom was coming.

[45:258] It was He who was being described: it was on Him all our attention was fixed.

[45:259] "Upon Thy right hand did stand the Queen".

[45:260] She which stands on the left is no Queen.

[45:261] For there will be one standing on "the left" also, to whom it will be said, "Go into everlasting fire".

[45:262] But she shall stand on the right hand, to whom it will be said, "Come, ye blessed of My Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world".

[45:263] On Thy right hand did stand the Queen, "in a vesture of gold, clothed about with divers colours".

[45:264] What is the vesture of this Queen? It is one both precious, and also of divers colours: it is the mysteries of doctrine in all the various tongues: one African, one Syrian, one Greek, one Hebrew, one this, and one that; it is these languages that produce the divers colours of this vesture But just as all the divers colours of the vesture blend together in the one vesture, so do all the languages in one and the same faith.

[45:265] In that vesture, let there be diversity, let there be no rent.

[45:266] See we have "understood" the divers colours of the diversity of tongues; and the vesture to refer to unity: but in that diversity itself, what is meant by the "gold"? Wisdom itself.

[45:267] Let there be any diversity of tongues you please, but there is but one "gold" that is preached of: not a different gold, but a different form of that gold.

[45:268] For it is the same Wisdom, the same doctrine and discipline that every language preaches.

[45:269] In the languages there is diversity; gold in the thoughts.

[45:270] The Prophet addresses this Queen (for he delights in singing to her), and moreover each one of us, provided, however, we know where we are, and endeavour to belong to that body, and do belong to it in faith and hope, being united in the membership of Christ For it is us whom he addresses, saying, "Hearken, O daughter, and behold" , as being one of the "Fathers" (for they are "daughters of kings"), although it be a Prophet, or although it be an Apostle that is addressing her; addressing her, as a daughter, for we are accustomed to speak in this way, "Our fathers the Prophets, our fathers the Apostles;" if we address them as "fathers," they may address us as children: and it is one father's voice addressing one daughter.

[45:271] "Hearken, O daughter, and see".

[45:272] "Hear" first; afterward "see".

[45:273] For they came to us with the Gospel; and that has been preached to us, which as yet we do not see, and which on hearing of it we believed, which by believing it, we shall come to see: even as the Bridegroom Himself speaks in the Prophet, "A people whom I have not known served me.

[45:274] In the hearing of me with the ear it obeyed me".

[45:275] What is meant by on "hearing of me with the ear"? That they did not "see".

[45:276] The Jews saw Him, and crucified Him; the Gentiles saw Him not, and believed.

[45:277] Let the Queen who comes from the Gentiles come in "the vesture of gold, clothed with divers colours;" let her come from among the Gentiles clad in all languages, in the unity of Wisdom: let it be said unto her, "Hearken, O daughter, and see".

[45:278] If thou wilt not hear, thou shalt not "see".

[45:279] "And incline thine ear".

[45:280] It is not enough to "hearken;" hearken with humility: bow down thine ear.

[45:281] "Forget also thine own people, and thy father's house".

[45:282] There was a certain "people," and a certain house of thy father, in which thou wast born, the people of Babylon, having the devil for thy king.

[45:283] Whencesoever the Gentiles came, they came from their father the devil; but they have renounced their sonship to the devil.

[45:284] "Forget also thine own people, and thy father's house".

[45:285] He, in making thee a sinner, begat thee loathsome: the Other, in that "He justifies the ungodly," begetteth thee again in beauty.

[45:286] "For the King hath greatly desired thy beauty".

[45:287] What "beauty" is that, save that which is His own work? "Greatly desired the beauty"—Of whom? Of her the sinner, the unrighteous, the ungodly, such as she was with her "father," the devil, and among her own "people"? No, but hers of whom it is said, "Who is this that cometh up made white?" She was not white then at the first, but was "made" white afterwards.

[45:288] For "though your sins shall be as scarlet, I will make them white as snow".

[45:289] "The king has greatly desired thy beauty".

[45:290] What King is this? "For He is the Lord thy God".

[45:291] Now consider whether thou oughtest not to forego that thy father, and thy own people, and to come to this King, who is thy God? Thy God is "thy King," thy "King" is also thy Bridegroom.

[45:292] Thou weddest to thy King, who is thy God: being endowed by Him, being adorned by Him; redeemed by Him, and healed by Him.

[45:293] Whatever thou hast, wherewith to be pleasing to Him, thou hast from Him.

[45:294] "And the daughters of Tyre shall worship Him with gifts".

[45:295] It is that selfsame "King, who is thy God," that the daughters of Tyre shall worship with gifts.

[45:296] The daughters of Tyre are the daughters of the Gentiles; the part standing for the whole.

[45:297] Tyre, a city bordering on this country, where the prophecy was delivered, typified the nations that were to believe in Christ.

[45:298] Thence came that Canaanitish woman, who was at first called "a dog;" for that ye may know that she was from thence, the Gospel speaks thus.

[45:299] "He departed into the parts of Tyre and Sidon, and behold a woman of Canaan came out of the same coasts," with all the rest that is related there.

[45:300] She who at first, at the house of her "father," and among her "own people," was but "a dog," who by coming to, and crying after that "King," was made beautiful by believing in Him, what did she obtain to hear? "O woman, great is thy faith".

[45:301] "The King has greatly desired thy beauty.

[45:302] And the daughters of Tyre shall worship with gifts".

[45:303] With what gifts? Even so would this King be approached, and would have His treasuries filled: and it is He Himself who has given us that wherewith they may be filled, and may be filled by you.

[45:304] Let them come (He says) and "worship Him with gifts".

[45:305] What is meant by "with gifts"?"Give alms, and all things are clean unto you".

[45:306] Come with gifts to Him that saith, "I will have mercy rather than sacrifice".

[45:307] To that Temple that existed aforetime as a shadow of that which was to come, they used to come with bulls, and rams, and goats, with every different kind of animal for sacrifice: that with that blood one thing should be done, and another be typified by it.

[45:308] Now that very blood, which all these things used to figure, hath come: the King Himself hath come, and He Himself would have your "gifts".

[45:309] What gifts? Alms.

[45:310] For He Himself will judge hereafter, and will Himself hereafter account "gifts" to certain persons.

[45:311] "Come" (He says), "ye blessed of My Father".

[45:312] Why? "I was an hungred, and ye gave Me meat," etc.

[45:313] These are the gifts with which the daughters of Tyre worship the King; for when they said, "When saw we Thee?" He who is at once above and below (whence those "ascending" and "descending" are spoken of ), said, "Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of Mine, ye have done it unto Me".

[45:314] "The rich among the people shall entreat Thy face".

[45:315] Both they who shall entreat that face, and He whose face they will entreat, are all collectively but one Bride, but one Queen, mother and children belonging all together unto Christ, belonging unto their Head.

[45:316] "All the glory of her, the King's daughter, is from within".

[45:317] Not only is her robe, outwardly, "of gold, and of divers colours;" but He who loved her beauty, knew her to be also beautiful within What are those inward charms? Those of conscience.

[45:318] It is there Christ sees; it is there Christ loves her: it is there He addresses her, there punishes, there crowns.

[45:319] Let then thine alms be done in secret; for "all the glory of her, the King's daughter, is from within".

[45:320] "With fringes of gold, clothed with divers colours".

[45:321] Her beauty is from within; yet in the "fringes of gold" is the diversity of languages: the beauty of doctrine.

[45:322] What do these avail, if them be not that beauty "from within"? "The virgins shall be brought unto the King after her".

[45:323] It has been fulfilled indeed.

[45:324] The Church has believed; the Church has been formed throughout all nations.

[45:325] And to what a degree do virgins now seek to find favour in the eyes of that King! Whence are they moved to do so? Even because the Church preceded them.

[45:326] "The virgins shall be brought unto the King after her.

[45:327] Her near kinswomen  shall be brought unto Thee".

[45:328] For they that are brought unto Him are not strangers, but her "near kinswomen," that belong to her.

[45:329] And because he had said, "unto the King," he says, turning the discourse to Him, "her near kinswomen shall be brought unto Thee".

[45:330] "With gladness and rejoicing shall they be brought and shall be led into the Temple of the King".

[45:331] The "Temple of the King" is the Church itself: it is the Church itself that enters into "the Temple of the King".

[45:332] Whereof is that Temple constructed? Of the men who enter the Temple? Who but God's "faithful" ones are its "living stones"? "They shall be led into the Temple of the King".

[45:333] For there are virgins without the Temple of the King, the nuns among the heretics: they are virgins, it is true; but what will that profit them, unless they be led into the "Temple of the King"? The "Temple of the King" is in unity: the "Temple of the King" is not ruinous, is not rent asunder, is not divided.

[45:334] The cement of those living stones is "charity".

[45:335] "Instead of thy fathers, children are born to thee".

[45:336] Nothing can be more manifest.

[45:337] Now consider the "Temple of the King" itself, for it is on its behalf he speaks, on account of the unity of the body that is spread throughout all the world: for those very persons who have chosen to be virgins, cannot find favour with the King unless they be led into the Temple of the King.

[45:338] "Instead of thy fathers, are thy children born to thee".

[45:339] It was the Apostles begat thee: they were "sent:" they were the preachers: they are "the fathers".

[45:340] But was it possible for them to be with us in the body for ever? Although one of them said, "I desire to depart, and to be with Christ, which is far better: to abide in the flesh is necessary for your sakes".

[45:341] It is true he said this, but how long was it possible for him to remain here? Could it be till this present time, could it be to all futurity? Is the Church then left desolate by their departure? God forbid.

[45:342] "Instead of thy fathers, children have been born to thee".

[45:343] What is that? The Apostles were sent to thee as "fathers," instead of the Apostles sons have been born to thee: there have been appointed Bishops.

[45:344] For in the present day, whence do the Bishops, throughout all the world, derive their origin? The Church itself calls them fathers; the Church itself brought them forth, and placed them on the thrones of "the fathers".

[45:345] Think not thyself abandoned then, because thou seest not Peter, nor seest Paul: seest not those through whom thou wert born.

[45:346] Out of thine own offspring has a body of "fathers" been raised up to thee.

[45:347] "Instead of thy fathers, have children been born to thee".

[45:348] Observe how widely diffused is the "Temple of the King," that "the virgins that are not led to the Temple of the King," may know that they have nothing to do with that marriage.

[45:349] "Thou shalt make them princes over all the earth".

[45:350] This is the Universal Church: her children have been made "princes over all the earth:" her children have been appointed instead of the "fathers".

[45:351] Let those who are cut off own the truth of this, let them come to the One Body: let them be led into the Temple of the King.

[45:352] God hath established His Temple everywhere: hath laid everywhere "the foundations of the Prophets and Apostles".

[45:353] The Church has brought "forth sons;" has made them "instead of her fathers" to be "princes over all the earth".

[45:354] "They shall be mindful of thy name in every generation and generation; therefore shall the peoples confess unto Thee".

[45:355] What does it profit then to "confess" indeed and yet to confess out of "the Temple"? What does it profit to pray, and yet not to pray on the Mount? "I cried," says he, "unto the Lord with my voice: and He heard me out of His holy hill".

[45:356] Out of what "hill"? Out of that of which it is said, "A city set upon a hill cannot be hid".

[45:357] Of what "hill"? Out of that hill which Daniel saw "grow out of a small stone, and break all the kingdoms of the earth; and cover all the face of the earth".

[45:358] There let him pray, who hopes to receive: there let him ask, who would have his prayer heard: there let him confess, who wishes to be pardoned.

[45:359] "Therefore shall the peoples confess unto thee for ever, world without end".

[45:360] For in that eternal life it is true indeed there will no longer be the mourning over sins: but yet in the praises of God by that everlasting City which is above, there will not be wanting a perpetual  confession of the greatness of that happiness.

[45:361] For to that City itself, to which another Psalm sings, "Glorious things are spoken of thee, O City of God," to her who is the very Bride of Christ, the very Queen, a "King's daughter, and a King's consort;"the peoples shall for this very cause confess even to herself; the hearts of all, now enlightened by perfect charity, being laid bare, and made manifest, that she may know the whole of herself most completely, who here is, in many parts of her, unknown to herself.

[46:1] Psalm XLVI.

[46:2] It is called, "A Psalm, to the end, for the sons of Korah, for things secret".

[46:3] Secret is it then; but He Himself, who in the place of Calvary was crucified, ye know, hath rent the veil, that the secrets of the temple might be discovered.

[46:4] Furthermore since the Cross of our Lord was a key, whereby things closed might be opened; let us trust that He will be with us, that these secrets may be revealed.

[46:5] What is said, "To the end," always ought to be understood of Christ.

[46:6] For "Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth".

[46:7] But The End He is called, not because He consumeth, but because He perfecteth.

[46:8] For ended call we the food which is eaten, and ended the coat which is woven, the former to consumption, the latter to perfection.

[46:9] Because then we have not where to go farther when we have come to Christ, Himself is called the end of our course.

[46:10] Nor ought we to think, that when we have come to Him, we ought to strive any further to come also to the Father.

[46:11] For this thought Philip also, when he said to Him, "Lord, show us the Father, and it sufficeth us".

[46:12] When he said, "It sufficeth us," he sought the end of satisfaction and perfection.

[46:13] Then said He, "Have I been so long time with you, and hast thou not known Me, Philip: he that hath seen Me, hath seen the Father".

[46:14] In Him then have we the Father, because He is in the Father, and the Father in Him, and He and His Father are One.

[46:15] "Our God is a refuge and strength".

[46:16] There are some refuges wherein is no strength, whereto when any fleeth, he is more weakened than strengthened.

[46:17] Thou fleest, for example, to some one greater in the world, that thou mayest make thyself a powerful friend; this seemeth to thee a refuge.

[46:18] Yet so great are this world's uncertainties, and so frequent grow the ruins of the powerful day by day, that when to such refuge thou art come, thou beginnest to fear more than ever therein.

[46:19] Our refuge is not such, but our refuge is strength.

[46:20] When thither we have fled, we shall be firm.

[46:21] "A helper in tribulations, which find us out too much".

[46:22] Tribulations are many, and in every tribulation unto God must we flee; whether it be a tribulation in our estate, or in our body's health, or about the peril of those dearest to us, or any other thing necessary to the sustaining of this life, refuge ought there to be none at all to a Christian man, other than his Saviour, other than his God, to whom when he has fled, he is strong.

[46:23] For he will not in himself be strong, nor will he to himself be strength, but He will be his strength, who has become his refuge.

[46:24] But, dearly beloved, among all tribulations of the human soul is no greater tribulation than the consciousness of sin.

[46:25] For if there be no wound herein, and that be sound within man which is called conscience, wherever else he may suffer tribulation, thither will he flee, and there find God.

[46:26] Ye see, dearly beloved, when trees are cut down and proved by the carpenters, sometimes in the surface they seem as though injured and rotten; but the carpenter looks into the inner marrow as it were of the tree, and if within he find the wood sound, he promises that it will last in a building; nor will he be very anxious about the injured surface, when that which is within he declares sound.

[46:27] Furthermore, to man anything more inward than conscience is not found; what then profits it, if what is without is sound, and the  marrow of conscience has become rotton? These are close and vehement overmuch, and as this Psalm saith, too great tribulations; yet even in these the Lord hath become a helper by forgiving sin.

[46:28] For the consciences of the ungodly hateth nothing save indulgence; for if one saith he hath great tribulations, being a confessed debtor to the treasury, when he beholdeth the narrowness of his estate, and seeth that he cannot be solvent; if on account of the distrainers every year hanging over him, he saith that he suffereth great tribulations, and doth not breathe freely except in hope of indulgence, and that in things earthly; how much more the debtor of penalties out of the abundance of sins: when shall he pay what he owes out of his evil conscience, when if he pay, he perisheth? For to pay this debt, is to undergo the penalties.

[46:29] Remaineth then that of His indulgence, we may be secure, yet so that, indulgence received, we return not again to contract debts.

[46:30] Now then, such security received, what say they? "Therefore will not we fear, when the earth shall be confounded".

[46:31] Just before anxious, suddenly secure; out of too great tribulations set in great tranquillity.

[46:32] For in them Christ was sleeping, therefore were they tossed: Christ awoke (as but now we heard out of the Gospel), He commanded the winds, and they were still Since Christ is in each man's heart by faith, it is signified to us, that his heart as a ship in this world's tempest is tossed, who forgetteth his faith: as though Christ sleeping it is tossed, but Christ awaking cometh tranquillity.

[46:33] Nay, the Lord Himself, what said He? "Where is your faith?" Christ aroused, aroused up faith, that what had been done in the ship, might be done in their hearts.

[46:34] "A helper in tribulations, which found us out too much".

[46:35] He caused that therein should be great tranquillity.

[46:36] See what tranquillity: "Therefore will not we fear when the earth shall be confounded, and the mountains shall be carried into the heart of the sea".

[46:37] Then we shall find not fear.

[46:38] Let us seek mountains carried, and if we can find, it is manifest that this is our security.

[46:39] The Lord truly said to His disciples, "If ye have faith as a grain of mustard seed, ye shall say to this mountain, Be Thou removed, and be Thou cast into the sea, and it shall be done".

[46:40] Haply "to this mountain," He said of Himself; for He is called a Mountain: "It shall come to pass in the last days, that the mountain of the Lord shall be manifest".

[46:41] But this Mountain is placed above other mountains; because the Apostles also are mountains, supporting this Mountain.

[46:42] Therefore followeth, "In the last days the Mountain of the Lord shall be manifest, established in the top of the mountains".

[46:43] Therefore passeth It the tops of all mountains, and on the top of all mountains is It placed; because the mountains are preaching The Mountain.

[46:44] But the sea signifieth this world, in comparison of which sea, like earth seemed the nation of the Jews.

[46:45] For it was not covered over with the bitterness of idolatry, but, like dry land, was surrounded with the bitterness of the Gentiles as with sea.

[46:46] It was to be, that the earth be confounded, that is, that nation of the Jews; and that the mountains be carried into the heart of the sea, that is, first that great Mountain established in the top of the mountains.

[46:47] For He deserted the nation of the Jews, and came among the Gentiles.

[46:48] He was carried from the earth into the sea.

[46:49] Who carrying Him? The Apostles, to whom He had said, "If ye have faith as a grain of mustard seed, ye shall say to this mountain, Be thou removed, and be thou cast into the sea, and it shall be done:" that is, through your most faithful preaching it shall come to pass, that this mountain, that is, I Myself, be preached among the Gentiles, be glorified among the Gentiles, be acknowledged among the Gentiles, and that be fulfilled which was predicted of Me, "A people whom I have not known shall serve Me".

[46:50] "The waters thereof roared, and were troubled" : when the Gospel was preached, "What is this? He seemeth to be a setter forth of strange gods:" this the Athenians; but the Ephesians, with what tumult would they have slain the Apostles, when in the theatre, for their goddess Diana, they made such an uproar, as to be shouting, "Great is Diana of the Ephesians!" Amidst which waves and roaring of the sea, feared not they who to that refuge had fled.

[46:51] Nay, the Apostle Paul would enter in to the theatre, and was kept back by the disciples, because it was necessary that he should still abide in the flesh for their sakes.

[46:52] But yet, "the waters thereof roared, and were troubled: the mountains shook at the mightiness thereof".

[46:53] Whose might? The sea's? or rather God's, of whom was said, "refuge and strength, a helper in tribulations, which have found us out too much?" For shaken were the mountains, that is, the powers of this world.

[46:54] For one thing are the mountains of God, another the mountains of the world: the mountains of the world, they whose head is the devil, the mountains of God, they whose Head is Christ.

[46:55] But by these mountains were shaken those mountains.

[46:56] Then gave they their voices against Christians, when the mountains were shaken, the waters roaring; for the mountains were shaken, and there was made a great earthquake, with quaking of the sea.

[46:57] But against whom this? Against the City founded upon a rock.

[46:58] The waters roar, the mountains shake, the Gospel being preached.

[46:59] What then, the City of God? Hear what followeth.

[46:60] "The streams of the river make glad the City of God".

[46:61] When the mountains shake, when the sea rages, God deserteth not His City, by the streams of the river.

[46:62] What are these streams of the river? That overflowing of the Holy Spirit, of which the Lord said, "If any man thirst, let him come unto Me, and drink.

[46:63] He that believeth on Me, out of his bosom shall flow rivers of living water".

[46:64] These rivers then flowed out of the bosom of Paul, Peter, John, the other Apostles, the other faithful Evangelists.

[46:65] Since these rivers flowed from one river, many "streams of the river make glad the City of God".

[46:66] For that ye might know this to be said of the Holy Spirit, in the same Gospel next said the Evangelist, "But this spake He of the Spirit, which they that were to believe on Him should receive.

[46:67] For the Holy Ghost was not yet given, because that Jesus was not yet glorified".

[46:68] Jesus being glorified after His Resurrection, glorified after His Ascension, on the day of Pentecost came the Holy Spirit, and filled the believers, who spake with tongues, and began to preach the Gospel to the Gentiles.

[46:69] Hence was the City of God made glad, while the sea was troubled by the roaring of its waters, while the mountains were confounded, asking what they should do, how drive out the new doctrine, how root out the race of Christians from the earth.

[46:70] Against whom? Against the streams of the river making glad the City of God.

[46:71] For thereby showed He of what river He spake; that He signified the Holy Spirit, by "the streams of the river make glad the City of God".

[46:72] And what follows? "The Most High hath sanctified His tabernacle:" since then there followeth the mention of Sanctification, it is manifest that these streams of the river are to be understood of the Holy Spirit, by whom is sanctified every godly soul believing in Christ, that it may be made a citizen of the City of God.

[46:73] "God is in the midst of her: she shall not be moved".

[46:74] Let the sea rage, the mountains shake; "God is in the midst of her: she shall not be moved".

[46:75] What is, "in the midst of her"? That God stands in any one place, and they surround Him who believe in Him? Then is God circumscribed by place; and broad that which surroundeth, narrow that which is surrounded? God forbid.

[46:76] No such thing imagine of God, who is contained in no place, whose seat is the conscience of the godly: and so is God's seat in the hearts of men, that if man fall from God, God in Himself abideth, not falleth like one not finding where to be.

[46:77] For rather doth He lift up thee, that thou mayest be in Him, than so lean upon thee, as if thou withdraw thyself, to fall.

[46:78] Himself if He withdraw, fall wilt thou: thyself if thou withdraw, fall will not He.

[46:79] What then is, "God is in the midst of her"? It signifieth that God is equal to all, and accepteth not persons.

[46:80] For as that which is in the middle has equal distances to all the boundaries, so God is said to be in the middle, because He consulteth equally for all.

[46:81] "God is in the midst of her: she shall not be moved".

[46:82] Wherefore shall she not be moved? Because God is in the midst of her.

[46:83] He is "the Helper in tribulations that have found us out too much.

[46:84] God shall help her with His Countenance".

[46:85] What is, "with His Countenance"? With manifestation of Himself.

[46:86] How manifests God Himself, so as that we see His Countenance? I have already told you; ye have learned God's Presence; we have learned it through His works.

[46:87] When from Him we receive any help so that we cannot at all doubt that it was granted to us by the Lord, then God's Countenance is with us.

[46:88] "The heathen are troubled".

[46:89] And how troubled? why troubled? To cast down the City of God, in the midst whereof is God? To overthrow the tabernacle sanctified, which God helpeth with His Countenance? No: with a wholesome trouble are the heathen now troubled.

[46:90] For what followeth? "And the kingdoms are bowed".

[46:91] Bowed, saith He, are the kingdoms; not now erected that they may rage, but bowed that they may adore.

[46:92] When were the kingdoms bowed? When that came to pass which was predicted in another Psalm, "All kings shall fall down before Him, all nations shall serve Him".

[46:93] What cause made the kingdoms to bow? Hear the cause.

[46:94] "The Most High gave His Voice, and the earth was moved".

[46:95] The fanatics of idolatry, like frogs in the marshes, clamoured, the more tumultuously, the more sordidly, in filth and mire.

[46:96] And what is the brawling of frogs to the thunder of the clouds? For out of them "the Most High gave His Voice, and the earth was moved:" He thundered out of His clouds.

[46:97] And what are His clouds? His Apostles, His preachers, by whom He thundered in precepts, lightened in miracles.

[46:98] The same are clouds who are also mountains: mountains for their height and firmness, clouds for their rain and fruitfulness.

[46:99] For these clouds watered the earth, of which it was said, "The Most High gave His Voice, and the earth was moved".

[46:100] For it is of those clouds that He threateneth a certain barren vineyard, whence the mountains were carried into the heart of the sea; "I will command," saith He, "the clouds that they rain no rain upon it".

[46:101] This was fulfilled in that which I have mentioned, when the mountains were carried into the heart of the sea; when it was said, "It was necessary that the word of God should have been spoken first to you; but seeing ye put it from you, we turn to the Gentiles;" then was fulfilled, "I will command the clouds that they rain no rain upon it".

[46:102] The nation of the Jews hath just so remained as a fleece dry upon the ground.

[46:103] For this, ye know, happened in a certain miracle, the ground was dry, the fleece only was wet, yet rain in the fleece appeared not So also the mystery of the New Testament appeared not in the nation of the Jews.

[46:104] What there was the fleece, is here the veil.

[46:105] For in the fleece was veiled the mystery.

[46:106] But on the ground, in all the nations open lieth Christ's Gospel; the rain is manifest, the Grace of Christ is bare, for it is not covered with a veil.

[46:107] But that the rain might come out of it, the fleece was pressed.

[46:108] For by pressure they from themselves excluded Christ, and the Lord now from His clouds raineth on the ground, the fleece hath remained dry.

[46:109] But of them then "the Most High gave His Voice," out of those clouds; by which Voice the kingdoms were bowed and worshipped.

[46:110] "The Lord of Hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our taker up".

[46:111] Not any man, not any power, not, in short, Angel, or any creature either earthly or heavenly, but "the Lord of Hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our taker up".

[46:112] He who sent Angels, came after Angels, came that Angels might serve Him, came that men He might make equal to Angels.

[46:113] Mighty Grace! If God be for us, who can be against us? "The Lord of Hosts is with us".

[46:114] What Lord of Hosts is with us? "If" (I say) "God be for us, who can be against us? He that spared not His own Son, but delivered Him up for us all; how hath He not with Him also freely given us all things".

[46:115] Therefore be we secure, in tranquillity of heart nourish we a good conscience with the Bread of the Lord.

[46:116] "The Lord of Hosts is with us; the God of Jacob is our taker up".

[46:117] However great be thy infirmity, see who taketh thee up.

[46:118] One is sick, a physician is called to him.

[46:119] His own taken-up, the Physician calleth the sick man.

[46:120] Who hath taken him up? Even He.

[46:121] A great hope of salvation; a great Physician hath taken him up.

[46:122] What Physician?  Every Physician save He is man: every Physician who cometh to a sick man, another day can be made sick, beside Him.

[46:123] "The God of Jacob is our taker up".

[46:124] Make thyself altogether as a little child, such as are taken up by their parents.

[46:125] For those not taken up, are exposed; those taken up are nursed.

[46:126] Thinkest thou God hath so taken thee up, as when an infant thy mother took thee up? Not so, but to eternity.

[46:127] For thy voice is in that Psalm, "My father and my mother forsake me, but the Lord hath taken me up".

[46:128] "Come and see the works of the Lord".

[46:129] Now of this taking up, what hath the Lord done? Consider the whole world, come and see.

[46:130] For if thou comest not, thou seest not; if thou seest not, thou believest not; if thou believest not, thou standest afar off: if thou believest thou comest, if thou believest thou seest.

[46:131] For how came we to that mountain? Not on foot? Is it by ship? Is it on the wing? Is it on horses? For all that pertain to space and place, be not concerned, trouble not thyself, He cometh to thee.

[46:132] For out of a small stone He hath grown, and become a great mountain, so that He hath filled all the face of the earth.

[46:133] Why then wouldest thou by land come to Him, who filleth all lands? Lo, He hath already come: watch thou.

[46:134] By growing He waketh even sleepers; if yet there is not in them so deep sleep, as that they be hardened even against the mountain coming; but they hear, "Awake, thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall give thee light".

[46:135] For it was a great thing for the Jews to see the stone.

[46:136] For the stone was yet small: and small they deservedly despised it, and despising they stumbled, and stumbling they were broken; remains that they be ground to powder.

[46:137] For so was it said of the stone, "Whosoever shall fall upon that stone shall be broken; but on whomsoever it shall fall, it will grind him to powder".

[46:138] It is one thing to be broken, another to be ground to powder.

[46:139] To be broken is less than to be ground to powder: but none grindeth He coming exalted, save whom He brake lying low.

[46:140] For now before His coming He lay low before the Jews, and they stumbled at Him, and were broken; hereafter shall He come in His Judgment, glorious and exalted, great and powerful, not weak to be judged, but strong to judge, and grind to powder those who were broken stumbling at Him.

[46:141] For "A stone of stumbling and a rock of offence," is He to them that believe not.

[46:142] Therefore, brethren, no wonder if the Jews acknowledged not Him, whom as a small stone lying before their feet they despised.

[46:143] They are to be wondered at, who even now so great a mountain will not acknowledge.

[46:144] The Jews at a small stone by not seeing stumbled; the heretics stumble at a mountain.

[46:145] For now that stone hath grown, now say we unto them, Lo, now is fulfilled the prophecy of Daniel, "The stone that was small became a great mountain, and filled the whole earth".

[46:146] Wherefore stumble ye at Him, and go not rather up to Him? Who is so blind as to stumble at a mountain? Came He to thee that thou shouldest have whereat to stumble, and not have whereto to go up? "Come ye, and let us go up to the mountain of the Lord".

[46:147] Isaiah saith this: "Come ye, and let us go up".

[46:148] What is, "Come ye, and let us go up"? "Come ye," is, Believe ye.

[46:149] "Let us go up," is, Let us profit But they will neither come, nor go up, nor believe, nor profit.

[46:150] They bark against the mountain.

[46:151] Even now by so often stumbling on Him they are broken, and will not go up, choosing always to stumble.

[46:152] Say we to them, "Come ye, and see the works of the Lord:" what "prodigies He hath set forth through the earth".

[46:153] Prodigies are called, because they portend something, those signs of miracles which were done when the world believed.

[46:154] And what thereafter came to pass, and what did they portend?.

[46:155] "He maketh wars to cease unto the end of the earth".

[46:156] This not yet see we fulfilled: yet are there wars, wars among nations for sovereignty; among sects, among Jews, Pagans, Christians, heretics, are wars, frequent wars, some for the truth, some for falsehood contending.

[46:157] Not yet then is this fulfilled, "He maketh wars to cease unto the end of the earth;" but haply it shall be fulfilled.

[46:158] Or is it now also fulfilled? In some it is fulfilled; in the wheat it is fulfilled, in the tares it is not yet fulfilled.

[46:159] What is this then, "He maketh wars to cease unto the end of the earth"? Wars He calleth whereby it is warred against God.

[46:160] But who warreth against God? Ungodliness.

[46:161] And what to God can ungodliness do? Nothing.

[46:162] What doth an earthen vessel dashed against the rock, however vehemently dashed? With so much greater harm to itself it cometh, with how much the greater force it cometh.

[46:163] These wars were great, frequent were they.

[46:164] Against God fought ungodliness, and earthen vessels were dashed in pieces, even men by presuming on themselves, by too much prevailing by their own strength.

[46:165] This is that, the shield whereof Job also named concerning one ungodly.

[46:166] "He runneth against God, upon the stiff neck of his shield".

[46:167] What is, "upon the stiff neck of his shield"? Presuming too much upon his own protection.

[46:168] Were they such who said, "God is our refuge and strength, a Helper in tribulations which have found us out too much"? or in another Psalm, "For I will not trust in my bow, neither shall my sword save me".

[46:169] When one learneth that in himself he is nothing, and help in himself has none, arms in him are broken in pieces, wars are made to cease.

[46:170] Such wars then destroyed that Voice of the Most High out of His holy clouds, whereby the earth was moved, and the kingdoms were bowed.

[46:171] These wars hath He made to cease unto the end of the earth.

[46:172] "He shall break the bow, and dash in pieces the arms, and burn the shield with fire".

[46:173] Bow, arms, shield, fire.

[46:174] The bow is plots; arms, public warfare; shields, vain presuming of self-protection: the fire wherewith they are burned, is that whereof the Lord said, "I am come to send fire on the earth;" of which fire saith the Psalm, "There is nothing hid from the heat thereof".

[46:175] This fire burning, no arms of ungodliness shall remain in us, needs must all be broken, dashed in pieces, burned.

[46:176] Remain thou unharmed, not having any help of thine own; and the more weak thou art, having no arms thine own, the more He taketh thee up, of whom it is said, "The God of Jacob is our taker up".

[46:177] But when God taketh us up, doth He send us away unarmed? He armeth us, but with other arms, arms Evangelical, arms of truth, continence, salvation, faith, hope, charity.

[46:178] These arms shall we have, but not of ourselves: but the arms which of ourselves we had, are burnt up: yet if by that fire of the Holy Spirit we are kindled, whereof it is said, "He shall burn the shields with fire;" thee, who didst wish to be powerful in thyself, hath God made weak, that He may make thee strong in Him, because in thyself thou wast made weak.

[46:179] What then followeth? "Be still".

[46:180] To what purpose? "And see that I am God".

[46:181] That is, Not ye, but I am God.

[46:182] I created, I create anew; I formed, I form anew; I made, I make anew.

[46:183] If thou couldest not make thyself, how canst thou make thyself anew? This seeth not the contentious tumult of man's soul; to which contentious tumult is it said, "Be still".

[46:184] That is, restrain your souls from contradiction.

[46:185] Do not argue, and, as it were, arm against God.

[46:186] Else yet live thy arms, not yet burned up with fire.

[46:187] But if they are burned, "Be still;" because ye have not wherewith to fight.

[46:188] But if ye be still in yourselves, and from Me seek all, who before presumed on yourselves, then shall ye "see that I am God".

[46:189] "I will be exalted among the heathen, I will be exalted in the earth".

[46:190] Just before I said, by the name of earth is signified the nation of the Jews, by the name of sea the other nations.

[46:191] The mountains were carried into the heart of the sea; the nations are troubled, the kingdoms are bowed; the Most High gave His Voice, and the earth was moved.

[46:192] "The Lord of Hosts is with us, the God of Jacob is our taker up".

[46:193] Miracles are done among the heathen, full filled is the faith of the heathen; burned are the arms of human presumption.

[46:194] Still are they, in tranquillity of heart, to acknowledge God the Author of all their gifts.

[46:195] And after this glorifying, doth He yet desert the people of the Jews? of which saith the Apostle, "I say unto you, lest ye should be wise in your own conceits; that blindness in part is happened unto Israel, until the fulness of the Gentiles be come in".

[46:196] That is, until the mountains be carried hither, the clouds rain here, the Lord here bows the kingdoms with His thunder, "until the fulness of the Gentiles be come in".

[46:197] And what thereafter? "And so all Israel shall be saved".

[46:198] Therefore, here too observing the same order, "I will be exalted" (saith He) "among the heathen, I will be exalted in the earth;" that is, both in the sea, and in the earth, that now might all say what followeth: "the God of Jacob is our taker up".

[47:1] Psalm XLVII.

[47:2] The title of the Psalm goeth thus.

[47:3] "To the end: for the sons of Korah: a Psalm of David himself".

[47:4] These sons of Korah have the title also of some other Psalms, and indicate a sweet mystery, insinuate a great Sacrament: wherein let us willingly understand ourselves, and let us acknowledge in the title us who hear, and read, and as in a glass set before us behold who we are.

[47:5] The sons of Korah, who are they?Haply the sons of the Bridegroom.

[47:6] For the Bridegroom was crucified in the place of Calvary.

[47:7] Recollect the Gospel, where they crucified the Lord, and ye will find Him crucified in the place of Calvary.

[47:8] Furthermore, they who deride His Cross, by devils, as by beasts, are devoured.

[47:9] For this also a certain Scripture signified.

[47:10] When God's Prophet Elisha was going up, children called after him mocking, "Go up thou bald head, Go up thou bald head:" but he, not so much in cruelty as in mystery, made those children to be devoured by bears out of the wood.

[47:11] If those children had not been devoured, would they have lived even till now? Or could they not, being born mortal, have been taken off by a fever? But so in them had no mystery been shown, whereby posterity might be put in fear.

[47:12] Let none then mock the Cross of Christ.

[47:13] The Jews were possessed by devils, and devoured; for in the place of Calvary, crucifying Christ, and lifting on the Cross, they said as it were with childish sense, not understanding what they said, "Go up, thou bald head".

[47:14] For what is, "Go up"? "Crucify Him, Crucify Him".

[47:15] For childhood is set before us to imitate humility, and childhood is set before us to beware of foolishness.

[47:16] To imitate humility, childhood was set before us by the Lord, when He called children to Him, and because they were kept from Him, He said, "Suffer them to come unto Me, for of such is the Kingdom of Heaven".

[47:17] The example of childhood is set before us to beware of foolishness by the Apostle, "Brethren, be not children in understanding:" and again he proposeth it to imitate, "Howbeit in ma.

[48:1] lice be ye children, that in understanding ye may be men".

[48:2] "For the sons of Korah" the Psalm is sung; for Christians then is it sung.

[48:3] Let us hear it as sons of the Bridegroom, whom senseless children crucified in the place of Calvary.

[48:4] For they earned to be devoured by beasts; we to be crowned by Angels.

[48:5] For we acknowledge the humility of our Lord, and of it are not ashamed.

[48:6] We are not ashamed of Him called in mystery "the bald" (Calvus), from the place of Calvary.

[48:7] For on the very Cross whereon He was insulted, He permitted not our forehead to be bald; for with His own Cross He marked it.

[48:8] Finally, that ye may know that these things are said to us, see what is said.

[48:9] "O clap your hands, all ye nations".

[48:10] Were the people of the Jews all the nations? No, but blindness in part is happened to Israel, that senseless children might cry, "Calve," "Calve;" and so the Lord might be crucified in the place of Calvary, that by His Blood shed He might redeem the Gentiles, and that might be fulfilled which saith the Apostle, "Blindness in part is happened unto Israel, until the fulness of the Gentiles be come in".

[48:11] Let them insult, then, the vain, and foolish, and senseless, and say, "Calve," "Calve;" but ye redeemed by His Blood which was shed in the place of Calvary, say, "O clap your hands, all ye nations;" because to you hath come down the Grace of God.

[48:12] "O clap your hands".

[48:13] What is "O clap"? Rejoice.

[48:14] But wherefore with the hands? Because with good works.

[48:15] Do not rejoice with the mouth while idle with the hands.

[48:16] If ye rejoice, "clap your hands".

[48:17] The hands of the nations let Him see, who joys hath deigned to give them.

[48:18] What is, the hands of the nations? The acts of them doing good works.

[48:19] "O clap your hands, all ye nations: shout unto God with the voice of triumph".

[48:20] Both with voice and with hands.

[48:21] If with the voice only it is not well, because the hands are slow; if only with the hands it is not well, because the tongue is mute.

[48:22] Agree together must the hands and tongue.

[48:23] Let this confess, these work.

[48:24] "Shout unto God with the voice of triumph".

[48:25] "For the Lord Most High is terrible".

[48:26] The Most High in descending made like one ludicrous, by ascending into Heaven is made terrible.

[48:27] "A great King over all the earth".

[48:28] Not only over the Jews; for over them also He is King.

[48:29] For of them also the Apostles believed and of them many thousands of men sold their goods, and laid the price at the Apostles' feet, and in them was fulfilled what in the title of the Cross was written, "The King of the Jews".

[48:30] For He is King also of the Jews.

[48:31] But "of the Jews" is little "O clap your hands, all ye nations: for God is the King of all the earth".

[48:32] For it sufficeth not Him to have under Him one nation: therefore such great price gave He out of His side, as to buy the whole world.

[48:33] "He hath subdued the people under us, and the nations under our feet".

[48:34] Which subdued, and to whom? Who are they that speak? Haply Jews? Surely, if Apostles; surely, if Saints.

[48:35] For under these God hath subdued the people and the nations, that to-day are they honoured among the nations, who by their own citizens earned to be slain: as their Lord was slain by His citizens, and is honoured among the nations; was crucified by His own, is adored by aliens, but those by a price made His own.

[48:36] For therefore bought He us, that aliens from Him we might not be.

[48:37] Thinkest thou then these are the words of Apostles, "He hath subdued the people under us, and the nations under our feet"? I know not.

[48:38] Strange that Apostles should speak so proudly, as to rejoice that the nations were put under their feet, that is, Christians under the feet of Apostles.

[48:39] For they rejoice that we are with them under the feet of Him who died for us.

[48:40] For under Paul's feet ran they, who would be of Paul, to whom He said, "Was Paul crucified for you?" What then here, what are we to understand? "He hath subdued the people under us, and the nations under our feet".

[48:41] All pertaining to Christ's inheritance are among "all the nations," and all not pertaining to Christ's inheritance are among "all the nations:" and ye see so exalted in Christ's Name is Christ's Church, that all not yet believing in Christ lie under the feet of Christians.

[48:42] For what numbers now run to the Church; not yet being Christians, they ask aid of the Church; to be succoured by us temporally they are willing, though eternally to reign with us as yet they are unwilling.

[48:43] When all seek aid of the Church, even they who are not yet in the Church, hath He not "subdued the people under us, and the nations under our feet"?.

[48:44] "He hath chosen an inheritance for us, the excellency of Jacob, whom He loved".

[48:45] A certain beauty of Jacob He hath chosen for our inheritance.

[48:46] Esau and Jacob were two brothers; in their mother's womb both struggled, and by this struggle their mother's bowels were shaken; and while they two were yet therein, the younger was elected and preferred to the elder, and it was said, "Two peoples are in thy womb, and the elder shall serve the younger".

[48:47] Among all nations is the elder, among all nations the younger; but the younger is in good Christians, elect, godly, faithful; the elder in the proud, unworthy, sinful, stubborn, defending rather than confessing their sins: as was also the very people of the Jews, "being ignorant of God's righteousness, and going about to establish their own righteousness".

[48:48] But for that it is said, "The elder shall serve the younger;" it is manifest that under the godly are subdued the ungodly, under the humble are subdued the proud.

[48:49] Esau was born first, and Jacob was born last; but he who was last born, was preferred to the first-born, who through gluttony lost his birthright.

[48:50] So thou hast it written, He longed for the pottage, and his brother said to him, If thou wilt that I give it thee, give me thy birthright.

[48:51] He loved more that which carnally he desired, than that which spiritually by being born first he had earned: and he laid aside his birthright, that he might eat lentils.

[48:52] But lentils we find to be the food of the Egyptians, for there it abounds in Egypt.

[48:53] Whence is so magnified the lentil of Alexandria, that it comes even to our country, as if here grew no lentil.

[48:54] Therefore by desiring Egyptian food he lost his birthright.

[48:55] So also the people of the Jews, of whom it is said, "in their hearts they turned back again into Egypt".

[48:56] They desired in a manner the lentil, and lost their birthright.

[48:57] "God is gone up with jubilation".

[48:58] Even He our God, the Lord Christ, is gone up with jubilation; "the Lord with the sound of a trumpet".

[48:59] "Is gone up:" whither, save where we know? Whither the Jews followed Him not, even with their eyes.

[48:60] For exalted on the Cross they mocked Him, ascending into Heaven they did not see Him.

[48:61] "God hath gone up with jubilation".

[48:62] What is jubilation, but admiration of joy which cannot be expressed in words? As the disciples in joy admired, seeing Him go into Heaven, whom they had mourned dead; truly for the joy, words sufficed not: remained to jubilate what none could express.

[48:63] There was also the voice of the trumpet, the voice of Angels.

[48:64] For it is said, "Lift up thy voice like a trumpet".

[48:65] Angels preached the ascension of the Lord: they saw the Disciples, their Lord ascending, tarrying, admiring, confounded, nothing speaking, but in heart jubilant: and now was the sound of the trumpet in the clear voice of the Angels, "Ye men of Galilee, why stand ye gazing up into Heaven? this is Jesus".

[48:66] As if they knew not that it was the same Jesus.

[48:67] Had they not just before seen Him before them? Had they not heard Him speaking with them? Nay, they not only saw the figure of Him present, but handled also His limbs.

[48:68] Of themselves then knew they not, that it was the same Jesus? But they being by very admiration, from joy of jubilation, as it were transported in mind, the Angels said, "that same is Jesus".

[48:69] As though they said, If ye believe Him, this is that same Jesus, whom crucified, your feet stumbled, whom dead and buried, ye thought your hope lost.

[48:70] Lo, this is the same Jesus.

[48:71] He hath gone up before you, "He shall so come in like manner as ye have seen Him go into Heaven".

[48:72] His Body is removed indeed from your eyes, but God is not separated from your hearts: see Him going up, believe on Him absent, hope for Him coming; but yet through His secret Mercy, feel Him present.

[48:73] For He who ascended into Heaven that He might be removed from your eyes, promised unto you, saying, "Lo, I am with you always, even unto the end of the world".

[48:74] Justly then the Apostle so addressed us, "The Lord is at hand; be careful for nothing".

[48:75] Christ sitteth above the Heavens; the Heavens are far off, He who there sitteth is near.

[48:76] "Sing praises to our God, sing praises".

[48:77] Whom as Man mocked they, who from God were alienated.

[48:78] "Sing praises to our God".

[48:79] For He is not Man only, but God.

[48:80] Man of the seed of David, God the Lord of David, of the Jews having flesh.

[48:81] "Whose" (saith the Apostle) "are the fathers, of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came".

[48:82] Of the Jews then is Christ, but according to the flesh.

[48:83] But who is this Christ who is of the Jews according to the flesh? "Who is over all, God blessed for ever".

[48:84] God before the flesh, God in the flesh, God with the flesh.

[48:85] Nor only God before the flesh, but God before the earth whence flesh was made; nor only God before the earth whereof flesh was made, but even God before the Heaven which was first made; God before the day which was first made; God before Angels; the same Christ is God: for "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

[48:86] "For God is the King of all the earth".

[48:87] What? And before was He not God of all the earth? Is He not God of both heaven and earth, since by Him surely were all things made? Who can say that He is not his God? But not all men acknowledged Him their God; and where He was acknowledged, there only, so to say, He was God.

[48:88] "In Judah is God known".

[48:89] Not yet was it said to the sons of Korah, "O clap your hands, all ye nations".

[48:90] For that God known in Judah, is King of all the earth: now by all He is acknowledged, for that is fulfilled which Isaiah saith, "He is thy God who hath delivered thee, the God of the whole earth shall He be called".

[48:91] "Sing ye praises with understanding".

[48:92] He teacheth us and warneth us to sing praises with understanding, not to seek the sound of the ear, but the light of the heart.

[48:93] The Gentiles, whence ye were called that ye might be Christians, adored gods made with hands, and sang praises to them, but not with understanding.

[48:94] If they had sung with understanding, they had not adored stones.

[48:95] When a man sensible sang to a stone insensible, did he sing with understanding? But now, brethren, we see not with our eyes Whom we adore, and yet correctly we adore Much more is God commended to us, that with our eyes we see Him not.

[48:96] If with our eyes we saw Him, haply we might despise.

[48:97] For even Christ seen, the Jews despised; unseen, the Gentiles adored.

[48:98] "God shall reign over all nations".

[48:99] Who reigned over one nation, "shall reign" (saith He) "over all nations".

[48:100] When this was said, God reigned over one nation.

[48:101] It was a prophecy, the thing was not yet shown.

[48:102] Thanks be to God, we now see fulfilled what before was prophesied.

[48:103] A written promise God sent unto us before the time, the time fulfilled He hath repaid us.

[48:104] "God shall reign over all nations," is a promise.

[48:105] "God sitteth upon His Holy Seat".

[48:106] What then was promised to come, now being fulfilled, is acknowledged and held.

[48:107] "God sitteth upon His Holy Seat".

[48:108] What is His Holy Seat? Haply saith one, The Heavens, and he understandeth well.

[48:109] For Christ hath gone up, as we know, with the Body, wherein He was crucified, and sitteth at the right hand of the Father; thence we expect Him to come to judge the quick and the dead "God sitteth upon His Holy Seat".

[48:110] The Heavens are His Holy Seat.

[48:111] Wilt thou also be His Seat? think not that thou canst not be; prepare for Him a place in thy heart.

[48:112] He cometh, and willingly sitteth.

[48:113] The same Christ is surely "the Power of God, and the Wisdom of God:" and what saith the Scripture of Wisdom Herself? The soul of the righteous is the seat of Wisdom If then the soul of the righteous is the seat of Wisdom, be thy soul righteous, and thou shalt be a royal seat of Wisdom.

[48:114] And truly, brethren, all men who live well, who act well, converse in godly charity, doth not God sit in them, and Himself command? Thy soul obeyeth God sitting in it, and itself commandeth the members.

[48:115] For thy soul commandeth thy members, that so may move the foot, the hand, the eye, the ear, and itself commandeth the members as its servants, but yet itself serveth its Lord sitting within.

[48:116] It cannot well rule its inferior, unless its superior it have not disdained to serve.

[48:117] "The princes of the peoples are gathered together unto the God of Abraham".

[48:118] The God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob True it is, God said this, and thereupon the Jews prided themselves, and said, "We are Abraham's children;" priding themselves in their father's name, carrying his flesh, not holding his faith; by seed cleaving to Him, in manners degenerating.

[48:119] But the Lord, what said He to them so priding themselves? "If ye are Abraham's children, do the works of Abraham".

[48:120] Again"The princes of the peoples:" the princes of the nations: not the princes of one people, but the princes of all people have "gathered together unto the God of Abraham".

[48:121] Of these princes was that Centurion too, of whom but now when the Gospel was read ye heard.

[48:122] For he was a Centurion having honour and power among men, he was a prince among the princes of the peoples.

[48:123] Christ coming to him, he sent his friends to meet Him, nay unto Christ truly passing over to him he sent his friends, and asked that He would heal his servant who was dangerously sick.

[48:124] And when the Lord would come, he sent to Him this message: "I am not worthy that Thou shouldest enter under my roof, but say in a word only, and my servant shall be healed".

[48:125] "For I also am a man set under authority, having under me soldiers".

[48:126] See how he kept his rank! first he mentioned that he was under another, and afterwards that another was under him.

[48:127] I am under authority, and I am in authority; both under some I am, and over some I am.

[48:128] As though he said, If I being set under authority command those who are under me, Thou who art set under no man's authority, canst not Thou command Thy creature, since all things were made by Thee, and without Thee was nothing made.

[48:129] "Say," then, said he, "in a word, and my servant shall be healed.

[48:130] For I am not worthy that Thou shouldest enter under my roof".

[48:131] Admiring at his faith, Jesus reprobates the Jews' misbelief.

[48:132] For sound to themselves they seemed, whereas they were dangerously sick, when their Physician not knowing they slew.

[48:133] Therefore when He reprobated, and repudiated their pride what said he? "I say unto you, that many shall come from the east and west," not belonging to the kindred of Israel: many shall come to whom He said, "O clap your hands, all ye nations;" "and shall sit down with Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, in the kingdom of heaven".

[48:134] Abraham begat them not of his own flesh; yet shall they come and sit down with him in the kingdom of heaven, and be his sons.

[48:135] Whereby his sons? Not as born of his flesh, but by following his faith.

[48:136] "But the children of the kingdom," that is, the Jews, "shall be cast into outer darkness, there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth".

[48:137] They shall be condemned to outer darkness who are born of the flesh of Abraham, and they shall sit down with him in the kingdom of heaven, who have imitated Abraham's faith.

[48:138] And what they who belonged to the God of Abraham? "For the mighty gods of the earth are greatly lifted up".

[48:139] They who were gods, the people of God, the vineyard of God, whereof it is said, "Judge betwixt Me and My vineyard," shall go into outer darkness, shall not sit down with Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, are not gathered unto the God of Abraham.

[48:140] Wherefore? "For the mighty gods of the earth;" they who were mighty gods of the earth, presuming upon earth.

[48:141] What earth? Themselves; for every man is earth.

[48:142] For to man was it said, "Dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return".

[48:143] But man ought to presume upon God, and thence to hope for help, not from himself.

[48:144] For the earth raineth not upon itself, nor shineth for itself; but as the earth from heaven expecteth rain and light, so man from God ought to expect mercy and truth.

[48:145] They then, "the mighty gods of the earth, were greatly lifted up," that is, greatly prided themselves: they thought no physician necessary for themselves, and therefore remained in their sickness, and by their sickness were brought down even to death.

[48:146] The natural branches were broken off that the humble wild olive tree might be grafted in Hold we fast then, brethren, humility, charity, godliness: since we are called, on their proving reprobate, even by their example let us fear to pride ourselves.

[49:1] Psalm XLVIII.

[49:2] The title of this Psalm is, "A song of praise, to the sons of Korah, on the second day of the week".

[49:3] Concerning this what the Lord deigneth to grant receive ye like sons of the firmament.

[49:4] For on the second day of the week, that is, the day after the first which we call the Lord's day, which also is called the second week-day, was made the firmament of HeavenThe second day of the week then we ought not to understand but of the Church of Christ: but the Church of Christ in the Saints, the Church of Christ in those who are written in Heaven, the Church of Christ in those who to this world's temptations yield not.

[49:5] For they are worthy of the name of "firmament".

[49:6] The Church of Christ, then, in those who are strong, of whom saith the Apostle, "We that are strong ought to bear the infirmities of the weak,"  is called the firmament.

[49:7] Of this it is sung in this Psalm.

[49:8] Let us hear, acknowledge, associate, glory, reign.

[49:9] For Her called firmament, hear also in the Apostolic Epistles, "the pillar and firmament of the truth".

[49:10] "Great is the Lord, and greatly to be praised".

[49:11] That is, "in the city of our God, in His holy mountain".

[49:12] This is the city set upon an hill, which cannot be hid: this is the candle which is not hidden under a bushel, to all known, to all proclaimed.

[49:13] Yet are not all men citizens thereof, but they in whom "great is the Lord, and greatly to be praised".

[49:14] What then is that city: let us see whether perhaps, since it is said, "In the city of our God, in His holy mountain," we ought not to enquire for this mountain where also we may be heard.

[49:15] What then is that mountain, brethren? One is it with great care to be enquired for, with great solicitude investigated, with labour also to be occupied and ascended.

[49:16] But if in any part of the earth it is, what shall we do? Shall we go abroad out of our own country, that to that mountain we may arrive? Nay, then we are abroad, when in it we are not.

[49:17] For that is our city, if we are members of the King, who is the head of the same city.

[49:18] For there was a certain corner-stone contemptible, whereat the Jews stumbled, cut out of a certain mountain without hands, that is, coming of the kingdom of the Jews without hands, because human operation went not with Mary of whom was born Christ But if that stone, when the Jews stumbled thereat, had remained there, thou hadst not had whither to ascend.

[49:19] But what was done? What saith the prophecy of Daniel? What but that the stone grew, and became a great mountain? How great? So that it filled the whole face of the earth By growing, then, and by filling the whole face of the earth, that mountain came to us.

[49:20] Why then seek we the mountain as though absent, and not as being present ascend to it; that in us the Lord may be "great, and greatly to be praised"?.

[49:21] Further,when he had said, "in the city of our God, in His holy mountain," what added he? "Spreading abroad the joys of the whole earth, the mountains of Sion".

[49:22] Sion is one mountain, why then "mountains"? Is it that to Sion belonged also those which came from the other side, so as to meet together on the Corner Stone, and become two walls, as it were two mountains, one of the circumcision, the other of the uncircumcision; one of the Jews, the other of the Gentiles: no longer adverse, although diverse, because from different sides, now in the corner not even diverse.

[49:23] "For He is our peace, who hath made both one".

[49:24] The same Corner Stone "which the builders rejected, is become the Head Stone of the corner".

[49:25] The mountain hath joined in itself two mountains; one house there is, and two houses; two, because coming from different sides; one, because of the Corner Stone, wherein both are joined together.

[49:26] Hear also this, "the mountains of Sion: the sides of the North are the city of the great King".

[49:27] See the Gentiles; "the sides of the North:" the sides of the North are joined to the city of the great King.

[49:28] The North is wont to be contrary to Sion: Sion forsooth is in the South, the North over against the South.

[49:29] Who is the North, but He who said, "I will sit in the sides of the North, I will be like the Most High"? The devil had held dominion over the ungodly, and possessed the nations serving images, adoring demons; and all whatsoever there was of human kind anywhere throughout the world, by cleaving to Him, had become North.

[49:30] But since He who binds the strong man, taketh away his goods, and maketh them His own goods; men delivered from infidelity and superstition of devils, believing in Christ, are fitted on to that city, have met in the corner that wall that cometh from the circumcision, and that was made the city of the great King, which had been the sides of the North.

[49:31] Therefore also in another Scripture is it said, "Out of the North come clouds of golden colour: great is the glory and honour of the Almighty".

[49:32] For great is the glory of the physician, when from being despaired of the sick recovers.

[49:33] "Out of the North come clouds," and not black clouds, not dark clouds, not lowering, but "of golden colour".

[49:34] Whence but by grace illumined through Christ? See, "the sides of the North are the city of the great King".

[49:35] Let the Psalm then follow, and say, "God shall be known in her houses".

[49:36] Now in her "houses," because of the mountains, because of the two walls, because of the two sons.

[49:37] "God shall be known in her houses," but he commendeth grace, therefore he added, "when He shall take her up".

[49:38] For what would that city have been, unless He had taken her up? Would it not immediately have fallen, unless it had such foundation? For "other foundation can no man lay than that is laid, which is Jesus Christ".

[49:39] Let none then glory in his own merits; but "he that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord".

[49:40] The Lord then hath taken up this city, and is known therein, that is, His grace is known in that city: for whatever that city hath, which glorieth in the Lord, it hath not of itself.

[49:41] For because of this it is said, "What hast thou that thou didst not receive?".

[49:42] "For, lo, the kings of the earth are gathered together".

[49:43] Behold now those sides of the North, see how they come, see how they say, "Come ye, and let us go up to the mountain of the Lord: and He will teach us His way, and we will walk in it".

[49:44] "And have come together in one".

[49:45] In what one, but that "corner-stone"? "They saw it, and so they marvelled".

[49:46] After their marvelling at the miracles and glory of Christ, what followed? "They were troubled, they were moved" , "trembling took hold upon them".

[49:47] Whence took trembling hold upon them, but from the consciousness of sins? Let them run then, king after a king; kings, let them acknowledge the King.

[49:48] Therefore saith He elsewhere, "Yet have I been set by Him a King upon His holy hill of Sion".

[49:49] A King then was heard of, set up in Sion, to Him were delivered possessions even to the uttermost parts of the earth.

[49:50] Kings behoved to fear lest they should lose the kingdom, lest the kingdom be taken from them.

[49:51] As wretched Herod feared, and for the Child slew the children But fearing to lose his kingdom, he deserved not to know the King.

[49:52] Would that he too had adored the King with the Magi: not by ill-seeking the kingdom, slain the Innocents, and perished guilty.

[49:53] For as concerning him, he destroyed the Innocents: but as for Christ, even a Child, the children dying for Him did He crown.

[49:54] Therefore behoved kings to fear when it was said, "Yet have I been set a King by Him upon His holy hill of Sion," and inheritance to the uttermost parts of the earth shall He give Him, who set Him up King.

[49:55] Thence also this is said to them, "Understand now therefore, O ye kings; be instructed, ye judges of the earth.

[49:56] Serve the Lord with fear, and rejoice unto Him with trembling".

[49:57] And what did they? "There pains as of a woman in travail".

[49:58] What are the pains "as of a woman in travail," but the pangs of a penitent? See the same conception of pain and travail: "Of Thy fear" (saith Isaiah) "we have conceived, we have travailed of the Spirit of salvation".

[49:59] So then the kings conceived from the fear of Christ, that by travailing they brought forth salvation by believing on Him whom they had feared.

[49:60] "There pains as of a woman in travail:" when of travail thou hearest, expect a birth.

[49:61] The old man travaileth, but the new man is born.

[49:62] "With a strong wind Thou shalt break the ships of Tarshish".

[49:63] Briefly understood, this is, Thou shalt overthrow the pride of the nations.

[49:64] But where in this history is mentioned the overthrowing of the pride of the nations? Because of "the ships of Tarshish".

[49:65] Learned men have enquired for Tarshish a city, that is, what city was signified by this name: and to some it has seemed that Cilicia is called Tarshish, because its metropolis is called Tarsus.

[49:66] Of which city was the Apostle Paul, being born in Tarsus of Cilicia But some have understood by it Carthage, being haply sometimes so named, or in some language so signified.

[49:67] For in the Prophet Isaiah it is thus found: "Howl, ye ships of Carthage".

[49:68] But in Ezekiel by some interpreters the word is translated Carthage, by some Tarshish: and from this diversity it can be understood that the same which was called Carthage, is called Tharsus.

[49:69] But it is manifest, that in the beginning of its reign Carthage flourished with ships, and so flourished, that among other nations they excelled in trafficking and navigation.

[49:70] For when Dido, flying from her brother, escaped to the parts of Africa, where she built Carthage, the ships which had been prepared for commerce in his country she had taken with her for her flight, the princes of the country consenting to it; and the same ships also when Carthage was built failed not in traffic.

[49:71] And hence that city became too proud, so that justly by its ships may be understood the pride of the nations, presuming on things uncertain, as on the breath of the winds.

[49:72] Now let none presume on full sails, and on the seeming fair state of this life, as of the sea.

[49:73] Be our foundation in Sion: there ought we to be stablished, not to be "carried about with every wind of doctrine".

[49:74] Whoso then by the uncertain things of this life had been puffed up, let them be overthrown, and be all the pride of the nations subjected to Christ, who shall "with a strong wind break all the ships of Tarshish:" not of any city, but of "Tarshish".

[49:75] How "with a strong wind"? With very strong fear.

[49:76] For so all pride feared Him that shall judge, as on Him humble to believe, lest Him exalted it should fear.

[49:77] "As we have heard, so have we seen".

[49:78] Blessed Church! at one time thou hast heard, at another time thou hast seen.

[49:79] She heard in promises, seeth in performance: heard in Prophecy, seeth in the Gospel.

[49:80] For all things which are now fulfilled were before prophesied.

[49:81] Lift up thine eyes then, and stretch them over the world; see now His "inheritance even to the uttermost parts of the earth:"  see now is fulfilled what was said, "All kings shall fall down before Him: all nations shall serve Him:" see fulfilled what was said, "Be Thou exalted, O God, above the heavens, and Thy glory above all the earth".

[49:82] See Him whose feet and hands were pierced with nails, whose bones hanging on the tree were counted, upon whose vesture lots were cast: see reigning whom they saw hanging; see sitting in Heaven whom they despised walking on earth: see thus fulfilled, "All the ends of the earth shall remember, and turn to the Lord, and all the kindreds of the nations shall worship before Him".

[49:83] Seeing all this, exclaim with joy, "As we have heard, so have we seen".

[49:84] Justly the Church herself is so called out of the Gentiles.

[49:85] They to whom the Prophets were not sent, first heard and understood the Prophets: they who first heard not, afterwards hearing marvelled.

[49:86] They remained behind to whom they were sent, carrying the books, understanding not the truth: having the tables of the Testament, and not holding the inheritance.

[49:87] But we,"As we have heard, so have we seen".

[49:88] And where hearest thou? where seest thou? "In the city of the Lord of Hosts, in the city of our God.

[49:89] God hath founded it for ever".

[49:90] Let not heretics insult, divided into parties, let them not exalt themselves who say, "Lo, here is Christ, or lo, there".

[49:91] Whoso saith, "Lo, here is Christ, or lo, there," inviteth to parties.

[49:92] Unity God promised.

[49:93] The kings are gathered together in one, not dissipated through schisms.

[49:94] But haply that city which hath held the world, shall sometime be overthrown? Far be the thought! "God hath founded it for ever".

[49:95] If then God hath founded it for ever, why fearest thou lest the firmament should fall?.

[49:96] "We have received Thy mercy, O God, in the midst of Thy people".

[49:97] Who have received, and where received? Hath not the same Thy people received Thy mercy.
