[49:98] If Thy people hath received Thy mercy, how then, "in the midst of Thy people"? As if they who received were one party, they in the midst of whom they received another.

[49:99] A great mystery, but yet well known.

[49:100] When hence also, that is, out of these verses, hath been extracted and brought forth what ye know; it will be not ruder, but sweeter.

[49:101] Now forsooth all are reckoned the people of God, who carry His Sacraments, but not all belong to His Mercy.

[49:102] All forsooth receiving the Sacrament of the Baptism of Christ, are called Christians, but not all live worthily of that Sacrament.

[49:103] There are some of whom saith the Apostle, "Having a form of godliness, but denying the power thereof".

[49:104] Yet on account of this form of godliness they are named among God's people.

[49:105] As to the floor, until the corn is threshed, belongs not the wheat only, but the chaff.

[49:106] But will it also belong to the garner? In the midst then of an evil people is a good people, which hath received the Mercy of God.

[49:107] He liveth worthily of the Mercy of God who heareth, and holdeth, and doeth what the Apostle saith, "We beseech you that ye receive not the Grace of God in vain".

[49:108] Whoso then receiveth not the Grace of God in vain, the same receiveth not only the Sacrament, but also the Mercy of God as well.

[49:109] So those who have the Sacraments, and have not good manners, are both said to be of God, and not of God; are both said to be His, and to be strangers: His because of His own Sacraments, strangers because of their own vice.

[49:110] So also strange daughters: daughters, because of the form of godliness; strange, because of their loss of virtue.

[49:111] Be the lily there; let it receive the Mercy of God: hold fast the root of a good flower, be not ungrateful for soft rain coming from heaven.

[49:112] Be thorns ungrateful, let them grow by the showers: for the fire they grow, not for the garner.

[49:113] In the midst of Thy people not receiving Thy mercy, we have received Thy mercy.

[49:114] For "He came unto His own, and His own received Him not," yet, in the midst of them, "as many as received Him, to them gave He power to become the sons of God".

[49:115] For when he had said, "We have received Thy mercy in the midst of Thy people," he signified that there is a people not receiving the mercy of God, in the midst of whom some do receive the mercy of God: and then lest it should occur to men that there are so few, as to be nearly none, how did He console them in the words following? "According to Thy Name, O God, so is Thy praise unto the ends of the earth".

[49:116] What is this? That is, as Thou art known through all the earth, so Thou art also praised through all the earth, nor are there wanting who now praise Thee through all the earth.

[49:117] But they praise Thee who live well.

[49:118] For, "According to Thy Name, O God, so is Thy praise," not in a part, but "unto the ends of the earth".

[49:119] "Thy right hand is full of righteousness".

[49:120] That is, many are they also who shall stand at Thy right hand.

[49:121] Not only shall they be many who shall stand at Thy left hand, but there also shall be a full heap set at Thy right hand.

[49:122] "Let mount Zion rejoice, and the daughters of Judah be glad, because of Thy judgments, O Lord".

[49:123] O mount Zion, O daughters of Judah, ye labour now among tares, among chaff, among thorns ye labour: yet be glad because of God's judgments.

[49:124] God erreth not in judgment.

[49:125] Live ye separate, though separate ye were not born; not vainly hath a voice gone forth from your mouth and heart, "Destroy not my soul with sinners, nor my life with bloody men".

[49:126] He shall winnow with such art, carrying in His hand a fan, that not one grain of wheat shall fall into the heap of chaff prepared to be burned, nor one beard of chaff pass to the heap to be laid up in the garner Be glad, O ye daughters of Judaea, because of the judgments of God that erreth not, and do not yet judge rashly.

[49:127] To you let it belong to collect, to Him let it belong to separate.

[49:128] But think not that the "daughters of Judah" are Jews.

[49:129] Judah is confession; all the sons of confession are all the sons of Judah.

[49:130] For "salvation is of the Jews," is nothing else than that Christ is of the Jews.

[49:131] This saith also the Apostle, "He is not a Jew which is one outwardly; neither is that circumcision which is outward in the flesh: but he is a Jew which is one inwardly, and circumcision is that of the heart, in the spirit, and not in the letter, whose praise is not of men, but of God".

[49:132] Be such a Jew; glory in the circumcision of the heart, though thou hast not the circumcision of the flesh.

[49:133] Let the daughters of Judah be glad, because of Thy judgments, O Lord.

[49:134] "Walk about Zion, and embrace her".

[49:135] Be it said to them who live ill, in the midst of whom is the people, which hath received the mercy of God.

[49:136] In the midst of you is a people living well, "Walk about Zion".

[49:137] But how? "embrace her".

[49:138] Not with scandals, but with love go round about her: that so those who live well in the midst of you ye may imitate, and by imitation of them, be incorporate with Christ, whose members they are.

[49:139] "Walk about Zion, go round about her: speak in the towers thereof".

[49:140] In the height of her bulwarks, set forth the praises thereof.

[49:141] "Set your hearts upon her might".

[49:142] Not that ye may have the form of godliness, deny the power thereof, but, "upon her might set your hearts.

[49:143] Speak ye in her towers".

[49:144] What is the might of this city? Whoso would understand the might of this city, let him understand the force of love.

[49:145] That is a virtue which none conquereth.

[49:146] Love's flame no waves of the world, no streams of temptation, extinguish.

[49:147] Of this it is said, "Love is strong as death".

[49:148] For as when death cometh, it cannot be resisted; by whatever arts, whatever medicines, you meet it; the violence of death can none avoid who is born mortal; so against the violence of love can the world do nothing.

[49:149] For from the contrary the similitude is made of death; for as death is most violent to take away, so love is most violent to save.

[49:150] Through love many have died to the world, to live to God; by this love inflamed, the martyrs, not pretenders, not puffed up by vain-glory, not such as they of whom it is written, "Though I give my body to be burned, and have not charity, it profiteth me nothing," but men whom truly a love of Christ and of the truth led on to this passion; what to them were the temptations of the tormentors? Greater violence had the eyes of their weeping friends, than the persecutions of enemies.

[49:151] For how many were held by their children, that they might not suffer? to how many did their wives fall upon their knees, that they might not be left widows? How many have their parents forbidden to die; as we know and read in the Passion of the Blessed Perpetua! All this was done; but tears, however great, and with whatever force flowing, when did they extinguish the ardour of love? This is the might of Sion, to whom elsewhere it is said, "Peace be within thy walls, and prosperity within thy palaces".

[49:152] What here understand we, "Set your hearts upon her might, and distribute her houses"? That is, distinguish house from house.

[49:153] Do not confound.

[49:154] For there is a house having the form of godliness, and not having godliness; but there is a house having both form and godliness.

[49:155] Distribute, confound not.

[49:156] But then ye distribute and confound not, when ye "set your hearts upon her might;" that is, when through love ye are made spiritual.

[49:157] Then ye will not judge rashly, then ye will see that the evil harms not the good as long as we are in this floor.

[49:158] "Distribute her houses".

[49:159] There can be also another understanding.

[49:160] The two houses, one coming of the circumcision, one of the uncircumcision, it is commanded the Apostles to distribute.

[49:161] For when Saul was called, and made the Apostle Paul, agreeing in unity with his fellow Apostles, he so with thorn determined, that they should go to the circumcision, he to the uncircumcision.

[49:162] By that dispensation of their Apostleship, they distributed the houses of the city of the great King; and meeting in the corner, divided the Gospel in dispensation, in love united it.

[49:163] And truly this is rather to be understood; for it followeth and showeth that it is here said to the preachers, "distribute her houses: that ye may tell it to the generation following:" that is, that even to us, who were to come after them, their dispensation of the Gospel should reach: For not for those only they laboured, with whom they lived in the earth; nor the Lord for those Apostles only to whom He deigned to show Himself alive after His Resurrection, but for us also.

[49:164] For to them He spake, and signified us when He spake, "Lo, I am with you alway, even to the end of the world".

[49:165] Were they then to be here alway, even to the end of the world? Also He said, "Neither pray I for these alone, but for them also which shall believe on Me through their word".

[49:166] Therefore He considereth us, because He suffered on account of us.

[49:167] Justly then it is said, "That ye may tell it to the generation following".

[49:168] Tell what? "For this is God, even our God".

[49:169] The earth was seen, the earth's Creator was not seen; the flesh was held, God in the flesh was not acknowledged.

[49:170] For the flesh was held by those from whom had been taken the same flesh, for of the seed of Abraham was the Virgin Mary.

[49:171] At the flesh they stayed, the Divinity they did not understand.

[49:172] O Apostles, O mighty city, preach thou on the towers, and say, "This is God, even our God".

[49:173] So, even so as He was despised, as He lay a stone before the feet of the stumbling, that He might humble the hearts of the confessing; even so, "This is God, even our God".

[49:174] Certainly He was seen, as was said, "Afterward did He show Himself upon earth, and conversed with men".

[49:175] "This is God, even our God".

[49:176] He is also Man, and who is there will know Him? "This is God, even our God".

[49:177] But haply for a time as the false gods.

[49:178] For because they can be called gods, but cannot be so, for a time they are even called so.

[49:179] For what saith the Prophet, or what warneth He to be said to them? This shall ye say to them, "The gods that have not made the heavens and the earth, even they shall perish from the earth, and from those that are under the heavens".

[49:180] He is not such a god: for our God is above all gods.

[49:181] Above all what gods? "For all the gods of the nations are idols, but the Lord made the heavens".

[49:182] The same then is our God.

[49:183] "This is God, even our God".

[49:184] For how long? "For ever and ever: He shall rule us for ever".

[49:185] If He is our God, He is also our King.

[49:186] He protecteth us, being our God, lest we die; He ruleth us, being our King, lest we fall.

[49:187] But by ruling us He doth not break us; for whom He ruleth not, He breaketh.

[49:188] "Thou shalt rule them," saith He, "with a rod of iron, and dash them in pieces like a potter's vessel".

[49:189] But there are whom He ruleth not; these He spareth not, as a potter's vessel dashing them in pieces.

[49:190] By Him then let us wish to be ruled and delivered, "for He is our God for ever and ever, and He shall rule us for ever".

[49:191] Contents   Part  Part.

[50:1] Psalm XLIX  The First Part.

[50:2] "Hear ye these things, all ye nations".

[50:3] Not then you only who are here.

[50:4] For of what power is our voice so to cry out, as that all nations may hear? For Our Lord Jesus Christ hath proclaimed it through the Apostles, hath proclaimed it in so many tongues that He sent; and we see this Psalm, which before was only repeated in one nation, in the Synagogue of the Jews, now repeated throughout the whole world, throughout all Churches; and that fulfilled which is here spoken of, "Hear ye these words, all ye nations".

[50:5] Of whom ye are: "With ears ponder, all ye that dwell in the world".

[50:6] This He seemeth to have repeated a second time, lest to have said "hear," before, were too little.

[50:7] What I say, he saith, "hear, with ears ponder," that is, hear not cursorily.

[50:8] What is, "with ears ponder"? It is what the Lord said, "he that hath ears to hear, let him hear:"  for as all who were in His presence must have had ears, what ears did He require save those of the h eart, when He said, "he that hath ears to hear, let him hear"? The same ears also this Psalm doth smite.

[50:9] "With ears ponder, all ye that dwell in the world".

[50:10] Perhaps there is here some distinction.

[50:11] We ought not indeed to narrow our view, but there is no harm in explaining even this view of the sense.

[50:12] Perhaps there is some difference between the saying, "all nations," and the saying, "all ye that dwell in the world".

[50:13] For perchance he would have us understand the expression, "dwell in," with a further meaning, so as to take all nations for all the wicked, but the dwellers of the world all the just.

[50:14] For he doth inhabit who is not held fast: but he that is occupied is inhabited, and doth not inhabit.

[50:15] Just as he doth possess whatever he hath, who is master of his property: but a master is one who is not held in the meshes of covetousness: while he that is held fast by covetousness is the possessed, and not the possessor.

[50:16] Therefore let even the ungodly hear: "Hear ye this, all ye nations".

[50:17] Let the just also hear, who have not heard to no purpose, and who rather rule the world than are ruled by the world: "with ears ponder, all ye that dwell in the world".

[50:18] And again he saith, "both all ye earthborn, and sons of men".

[50:19] The expression "earthborn" he doth refer to sinners; the expression "sons of men" to the faithful and righteous.

[50:20] Ye see then that this distinction is observed.

[50:21] Who are the "earthborn"? The children of the earth.

[50:22] Who are the children of the earth? They who desire earthly inheritances.

[50:23] Who are the "sons of men"? They who appertain to the Son of Man.

[50:24] We have already before explained this distinction to your Sanctity,  and have concluded that Adam was a man, but not the son of man; that Christ was the Son of Man, but was God also.

[50:25] For whosoever pertain to Adam, are "earthborn:" whosoever pertain to Christ, are "sons of men".

[50:26] Nevertheless, let all hear, I withhold my discourse from no one.

[50:27] If one is "earthborn," let him hear, because of the judgment: another is a "son of man," let him hear for the kingdom's sake.

[50:28] "The rich and poor together".

[50:29] Again, the same words are repeated.

[50:30] The expression "rich" refers to the "earthborn;" but the word "poor" to the "sons of men".

[50:31] By the "rich" understand the proud, by the "poor" the humble.

[50:32] He saith in another Psalm, "The poor shall eat and be satisfied".

[50:33] How hath he commended the poor? "The poor shall eat and be satisfied".

[50:34] What eat they? That Food which the faithful know.

[50:35] How shall they be satisfied? By imitating the Passion of their Lord, and not without cause receiving their recompense.

[50:36] "The poor shall eat and be satisfied, and they shall praise the Lord who seek Him".

[50:37] What of the rich? Even they eat.

[50:38] But how eat they? "All the rich upon the earth have eaten and worshipped".

[50:39] He said not, "Have eaten and are satisfied;" but, "have eaten and worshipped".

[50:40] They worship God indeed, but they will not display brotherly humaneness.

[50:41] These eat and worship; those eat and are filled: yet both eat.

[50:42] Of the eater what he eateth is required: let him not be forbidden by the distributor to eat, but let him be admonished to fear him who doth require his account.

[50:43] Let these words then be heard by sinners and righteous, nations, and those who inhabit the world, "earthborn and sons of men, the rich and the poor together:" not divided, not separated.

[50:44] That is for the time of the harvest to do, the hand of the winnower will effect that Now together let rich and poor hear, let goats and sheep feed in the same pasture, until He come who shall separate the one on His right hand, the other on His left Let them all hear together the teacher, lest separated from one another they hear the voice of the Judge.

[50:45] And what is it they are now to hear? "My mouth shall speak of wisdom, and the meditation of my heart understanding".

[50:46] And this repetition is perhaps made, lest perchance if he had said only "my mouth," thou shouldest suppose that one spake to thee who had understanding but in his lips.

[50:47] For many have understanding in their lips, but have not in their heart, of whom the Scripture saith, "This people honoureth me with their lips, but their heart is far from me".

[50:48] What saith he then who speaketh to thee? when he hath said, "My mouth shall speak of wisdom," in order that thou mayest know that what is poured forth from the mouth floweth from the bottom of the heart, he hath added, "And the meditation of my heart of understanding".

[50:49] "I will incline mine ear to the parable, I will show my proposition upon the harp".

[50:50] And why "to a parable"? Because "now we see through a glass darkly," as saith the Apostle; "whilst we are at home in the body, we are absent from the Lord".

[50:51] For our vision is not yet that face to face, where there are no longer parables, where there no longer are riddles and comparisons.

[50:52] Whatever now we understand we behold through riddles.

[50:53] A riddle is a dark parable which it is hard to understand.

[50:54] Howsoever a man may cultivate his heart and apply himself to apprehend mysteries, so long as we see through the corruption of this flesh, we see but in part.

[50:55] But as He was seen by those who believed, and by those who crucified Him, when He was judged; so will He be seen, when He shall have begun to be judge, both by those whom He shall condemn, and by those whom He shall crown.

[50:56] But that vision of divinity, which He hath promised to them that love Him, when He saith, "He that loveth Me shall be loved of My Father, and he that loveth Me keepeth My commandments, and I will love him, and will manifest Myself to him:" this the ungodly shall not see.

[50:57] This manifestation is in a certain way familiar: He keepeth it for His own, He will not show it to the ungodly.

[50:58] Of what sort is the vision itself? Of what sort is Christ? Equal to the Father.

[50:59] Of what sort is Christ? "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

[50:60] For this vision we sigh now, and groan so long as we sojourn here; to this vision we shall be brought home at the last, this vision now we see but darkly.

[50:61] If then we see now darkly, let us "incline our ear to the parable," and then let us "show our proposition upon the harp:" let us hear what we say, do what we enjoin.

[50:62] And what hath he said? "And wherefore shall I fear in the evil day? The iniquity of my heel shall compass me".

[50:63] He beginneth something obscurely.

[50:64] Therefore he ought the rather to fear if the iniquity of his heel shall compass him.

[50:65] Nay, for let not man fear, he saith, who hath not power to escape.

[50:66] For example, he who feareth death, what shall he do to escape death? Let him tell me how he is to escape what Adam oweth, he who is born of Adam.

[50:67] But let him consider that he is born of Adam, and hath followed Christ, and ought to pay what Adam oweth, and obtain what Christ hath promised.

[50:68] Therefore, he who feareth death can no wise escape: but he who feareth the damnation which the ungodly shall hear, "Go ye into everlasting fire," hath an escape.

[50:69] Let him not fear then.

[50:70] For why should he fear? Will the iniquity of his heel compass him? If then he avoid "the iniquity of his heel," and walk in the ways of God, he shall not come to the evil day: the evil day, the last day, shall not be evil to him.

[50:71] Now while they live, let them take heed to themselves, let them put away iniquity from their heel: let them walk in that way, let them walk in the way of which He saith Himself, "I am the way, the truth, and the life:" and let them not fear in the evil day, for He giveth them safety who became "The Way".

[50:72] Therefore let them avoid the iniquity of their heel.

[50:73] With the heel a man slippeth.

[50:74] Let your Love observe.

[50:75] What was said by God to the Serpent? "She shall mark thy head, and thou shalt mark her heel".

[50:76] The devil marketh thy heel, in order that when thou slippest he may overthrow thee.

[50:77] He marketh thy heel, do thou mark his head.

[50:78] What is his head? The beginning of an evil suggestion.

[50:79] When he beginneth to suggest evil thoughts, then do thou thrust him away before pleasure ariseth, and consent followeth; and so shalt thou avoid his head, and he shall not grasp thy heel.

[50:80] But wherefore said He this to Eve? Because through the flesh man doth slip.

[50:81] Our flesh is an Eve within us.

[50:82] "He that loveth his wife," he saith, "loveth himself".

[50:83] What meaneth "himself"? He continueth, and saith, "For no man ever yet hath hated his own flesh".

[50:84] Because then the devil would make us slip through the flesh, just as he made that man Adam to slip, through Eve; Eve is bidden to mark the head of the devil, because the devil marketh her heel "If then the iniquity of our heel shall compass us, why fear we in the evil day," since being converted to Christ we are able not to do iniquity; and there will be nothing to compass us, and we shall joy and not sorrow in the last day?.

[50:85] But who are they whom the "iniquity of their heel shall compass"? "They who trust in their virtue, and in the abundance of their riches do glory".

[50:86] Therefore such sins will I avoid, and the "iniquity of my heel" shall never compass me.

[50:87] What is avoiding such sins? Let us not trust in our own virtue, let us not glory in the abundance of our own riches, but let us glory in Him who hath promised to us, being humble, exaltation, and hath threatened condemnation to men exalted; and then iniquity of our heel shall never compass us.

[50:88] There are some who rely on their friends, others rely on their virtue, others on their riches.

[50:89] This is the presumption of mankind which relieth not on God.

[50:90] He hath spoken of virtue, he hath spoken of riches, he speaketh of friends.

[50:91] "Brother redeemeth not, shall man redeem?".

[50:92] Dost thou expect that man shall redeem thee from the wrath to come? If brother redeem thee not, shall man redeem thee? Who is the brother, who if He hath not redeemed thee, no man will redeem? It is He who said after His resurrection, "Go, tell My brethren".

[50:93] Our Brother He hath willed to be: and when we say to God, "Our Father," this is manifested in us.

[50:94] For he that saith to God, "Our Father;" saith to Christ, "Brother".

[50:95] Therefore let him that hath God for his Father and Christ for his Brother, not fear in the evil day.

[50:96] "For the iniquity of his heel shall not compass him;" for he relieth not on his virtue, nor glorieth in the abundance of his riches, nor vaunteth himself of his powerful friends.

[50:97] Let him rely on Him who died for him, that he might not die eternally: who for his sake was humbled, in order that he might be exalted; who sought him ungodly, in order that He might be sought by him faithful.

[50:98] Therefore if He redeem not, shall man redeem? Shall any man redeem, if the Son of man redeem not? If Christ redeem not, shall Adam redeem? "Brother redeemeth not, shall man redeem?".

[50:99] "He shall not give to God his propitiation, and the price of the redemption of his soul".

[50:100] He trusteth in his virtue, and in the abundance of his riches doth glory, who "shall not give to God his propitiation:" that is, satisfaction whereby he may prevail with God for his sins: "nor the price of the redemption of his soul," who relieth on his virtue, and on his friends, and on his riches.

[50:101] But who are they that give the price of the redemption of their souls? They to whom the Lord saith, "Make to yourselves friends of the Mammon of unrighteousness, that they may receive you into everlasting habitations".

[50:102] They give the price of the redemption of their soul who cease not to do almsdeeds.

[50:103] So those whom the Apostle chargeth by Timothy he would not have to be proud, lest they should glory in the abundance of their riches.

[50:104] Lastly, what they possessed he would not have to grow old in their hands: but that something should be made of it to be for the price of the redemption of their souls.

[50:105] For he saith, "Charge them that are rich in this world, that they be not high-minded: nor trust in uncertain riches, but in the living God, who giveth us richly all things to enjoy".

[50:106] And as if they had said, "What shall we then make of our riches?" he continueth, "Let them be rich in good works, ready to distribute, willing to communicate," and they will not lose that.

[50:107] How know we? Hear what followeth.

[50:108] "Let them lay up for themselves a good foundation against the time to come, that they may lay hold on the true life".

[50:109] So shall they give the price of the redemption of their soul.

[50:110] And our Lord counselleth this: "Make for yourselves bags which wax not old, a treasure in the heavens that faileth not, where thief approacheth not, neither moth corrupteth".

[50:111] God would not have thee lose thy wealth, but He hath given thee counsel to change the place thereof.

[50:112] Let your love understand.

[50:113] Suppose thy friend were just now to enter thy house, and find thou hadst placed thy store of grain in a damp place, and he knew the natural proneness of grain to decay, which thou perchance knewest not, he would give thee counsel of this sort, saying, "Brother, thou art losing what with great toil thou hast gathered, thou hast placed it in a damp place, in a few days this grain will decay".

[50:114] "And what am I to do, brother? "Raise it into a higher place".

[50:115] Thou wouldest hearken to thy friend suggesting that thou shouldest raise grain from a lower to a higher chamber, and dost thou not hearken to Christ charging thee to lift thy treasure from earth to heaven, where not what thou keepest in store may be paid to thee, but that thou mayest keep in store earth, mayest receive heaven, mayest keep in store things mortal, mayest receive things everlasting, that while thou lendest Christ to receive at thy hands but a small loan upon earth, He may repay thee a great recompense in Heaven? Nevertheless, they whom "the iniquity of their heel shall compass," because they trust in their virtue, and in the abundance of their riches do glory, and rely on human friends who are able to help them in nothing, "shall not give to God their propitiation, and the price of the redemption of their souls".

[50:116] And what hath he said of such a man? "Yea, he hath laboured for ever, and shall live till the end".

[50:117] His labour shall be without end, his life shall have an end.

[50:118] Wherefore saith he, "He shall live till the end"? Because such men think life to be nought but daily enjoyments.

[50:119] So when many poor and needy men of our times, unstable, and not looking to what God doth promise them for their labours, see rich men in daily feastings, in the splendour and glitter of gold and of silver, they say what? "These are the only people; they really live!" This is a saying, be it said no longer: we both warn you, and it remains to warn you, that it be said by fewer persons than it would be said, if we had not warned you.

[50:120] For we do not presume to say that we so say these words, as that it be not said, but that it be said by fewer persons: for it will be said even unto the end of the world.

[50:121] It is too little that he saith, "he liveth;" he addeth and saith, he thundereth, thinkest thou that he alone liveth? Let him live! his life will be ended: because he giveth not the price of the redemption of his soul, his life will end, his labour will not end.

[50:122] "He laboured for ever, and shall live till the end".

[50:123] How shall he live till the end? As he lived that was "clothed with purple and fine linen, and fared sumptuously every day," who, being proud and puffed up, spurned the man full of sores lying before his gate, whose sores the dogs licked, and who longed for the crumbs which fell from his table.

[50:124] What did those riches profit him? Both changed places: the one was borne from the rich man's gate into Abraham's bosom, the other from his rich feasts was cast into the fire; the one was in peace, the other burned; the one was sated, the other thirsted; the one had laboured till the end, but he lived for ever; the other had lived till the end, but he laboured for ever.

[50:125] And what did it profit the rich man, who asked, while lying in torments in hell, that a drop of water should be poured upon his tongue from the finger of Lazarus, saying, "For I am burning here in this flame," and it was not granted to him? One longed for the drop from the finger, as the other had for the crumbs from the rich man's table; but the labour of the one is ended, and the life of the other is ended: the labour of this is for ever, the life of that is for ever.

[50:126] We who labour perchance here on the earth, have not our life here: and shall not be so placed hereafter, for our life shall be Christ for ever: while they who "will" have their life here, shall labour for ever and live till the end.

[50:127] "For he shall not see death, though he shall have seen wise men dying".

[50:128] The man who laboured for ever and shall live till the end, "shall not see death, though he shall have seen wise men dying".

[50:129] What is this? He shall not comprehend what death is, whenever he shall have seen wise men dying.

[50:130] For he saith to himself, "this fellow, for all he was wise and dwelled with wisdom and worshipped God with piety, is he not dead? Therefore I will enjoy myself while I live; for if they that are wise in other respects, could do anything, they would not have died".

[50:131] Just as the Jews saw Christ hanging on the Cross and despised Him, saying, "If this Man were the Son of God, He would come down from the Cross:" not seeing what death is.

[50:132] If they had seen what death is; if they had seen, I say He died for a time, that He might live again for ever: they lived for a time, that they might die for ever.

[50:133] But because they saw Him dying, they saw not death, that is to say, they understood not what was very death.

[50:134] What say they even in Wisdom? "Let us condemn Him with a most shameful death, for by His own sayings He shall be respected;" for if he is indeed the Son of God, He will deliver Him from the hands of His adversaries: He will not suffer His Son to die, if He is truly His Son.

[50:135] But when they saw themselves insulting Him upon the Cross, and Him not descending from the Cross, they said, He was indeed but a Man.

[50:136] Thus was it spoken: and surely He could have come down from the Cross, He that could rise again from the tomb: but He taught us to bear with those who insult us; He taught us to be patient of the tongues of men, to drink now the cup of bitterness, and afterwards to receive everlasting salvation.

[50:137] "The imprudent and unwise shall perish together".

[50:138] Who is "the imprudent"? He that looketh not out for himself for the future.

[50:139] Who is "the unwise"? He that perceiveth not in what evil case he is.

[50:140] But do thou perceive in what evil case thou art now, and look out that thou be in a good case for the future.

[50:141] By perceiving in what evil case thou art, thou wilt not be unwise: by looking out for thyself for the future, thou wilt not be imprudent.

[50:142] Who is he that looketh out for himself? That servant to whom his master gave what he should expend, and afterwards said to him, "Thou canst not be my steward, give an account of thy stewardship;" and who answered, "What shall I do? I cannot dig, to beg I am ashamed;" had, nevertheless, by even his master's goods made to himself friends, who might receive him when he was put out of his stewardship.

[50:143] Now he cheated his master in order that he might get to himself friends to receive him: fear not thou lest thou be cheating, the Lord Himself exhorteth thee to do so: He saith Himself to thee, "Make to thyself friends of the mammon of unrighteousness".

[50:144] Perhaps what thou hast got, thou hast gotten of unrighteousness: or perhaps this very thing is unrighteousness, that thou hast and another hath not, thou aboundest and another needeth.

[50:145] Of this mammon of unrighteousness, of these riches which the unrighteous call riches, make to thyself friends, and thou shalt be prudent: thou art gaining for thyself, and art not cheating.

[50:146] For now thou seemest to lose it.

[50:147] Wilt thou lose it if thou place it in a treasury? For boys, my brethren, no sooner find some money, wherewith to buy something, than they put it in a money-box, which they open not until afterwards: do they, because they see not what they have got, on that account lose it? Fear not: boys put in a money-box, and are secure: dost thou place it in the hand of Christ, and fear? Be prudent, and provide for thyself against the future in Heaven.

[50:148] Be therefore prudent, copy the ant, as saith the Scripture: "Store in summer, lest thou hunger in winter;" the winter is the last day, the day of tribulation; the winter is the day of offences and of bitterness: gather what may be there for thee for the future: but if thou doest not so, thou wilt perish both imprudent and unwise.

[50:149] But that rich man too died, and a like funeral was made for him.

[50:150] See to what men have brought themselves: they regard not what a wicked life he led while he lived, but what pomp followed him when he died! O happy he, whom so many lament! But the other lived in such sort, that few lament.

[50:151] For all ought to lament a man living so sadly.

[50:152] But there is the funeral train; he is received in a costly tomb, he is wound in costly robes, he is buried in perfumes and spices.

[50:153] Secondly, what a monument he hath! How marbled! Doth he live in that same monument? He is therein dead.

[50:154] Men deeming these to be good things, have strayed from God, and have not sought the true good things, and have been deceived with the false.

[50:155] To this end see what followeth.

[50:156] He who gave not the price of the redemption of his soul, who understood not death, because he saw wise men dying, he became imprudent and unwise, in order that he might die with them.

[50:157] And how shall they perish, who "shall leave their riches to aliens"?.

[50:158] But do those same aliens indeed serve them who are called their own? Hear in what they serve them, observe how they are ridiculed: why hath he said, "to strangers"? Because they can do them no good.

[50:159] Nevertheless, wherein do they seem to themselves to do good? "And their tombs shall be their house for ever".

[50:160] Now because these tombs are erected, the tombs are a house.

[50:161] For often thou hearest a rich man saying, I have a house of marble which I must quit, and I think not for myself of an eternal house, where I shall alway be.

[50:162] When he thinketh to make for himself a monument of marble or of sculpture, he is deeming as it were of an eternal house: as if therein this rich man would abide! If he would abide there, he would not burn in hell.

[50:163] We must consider that the place where the spirit of an evil doer abideth, is not where the mortal body is laid: but "their tombs shall be their house for ever.

[50:164] Their dwelling places are from generation to generation".

[50:165] "Dwelling places" are wherein they abode for a season: "house" is wherein they will abide as it were for ever, that is to say, their tombs.

[50:166] Thus they leave their dwelling places, where they abode while they lived, to their families, and they pass as it were to everlasting houses, to their tombs.

[50:167] What profit to them are "their dwelling places, from generation to generation"? Now suppose a generation and generation are sons, grandsons there will be, and great grandsons; what do their dwelling places, what do they profit them? What? Hear: "they shall invoke their names in their lands".

[50:168] What is this? They shall take bread and wine to their tombs, and there they shall invoke the names of the dead.

[50:169] Dost thou consider how loudly was invoked the name of the rich man after his death, when men drank them drunk at his monument, and there came down not one drop upon his own burning tongue? Men minister to their own belly, not to the ghosts of their friends.

[50:170] The souls of the dead nothing doth reach, but what they have done of themselves while alive: but if they have done nought of themselves while alive, nothing doth reach them dead.

[50:171] But what do the survivors? They will but "invoke their names in their lands".

[50:172] "And man though he was in honour perceived not, he was compared to the beasts without sense, and was made like to them".

[50:173] They ought, on the contrary, to have made ready for themselves an eternal house in good works, to have made ready for themselves everlasting life, to have sent before them expenditure, to have followed their works, to have ministered to a needy companion, to have given to him with whom they were walking, not to have despised Christ covered with sores before their gate, who hath said, "Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these My brethren, ye have done it unto Me".

[50:174] However, "man being in honour hath not understood".

[50:175] What is, "being in honour"? Being made after the image and likeness of God, man is preferred to beasts.

[50:176] For God hath not so made man as He made a beast: but God hath made man for beasts to minister to: is it to his strength then, and not to his understanding? Nay.

[50:177] But he "understood not;" and he who was made after the image of God, "is compared to the beasts without sense, and is made like unto them".

[50:178] Whence it is said elsewhere, "Be ye not like to horse and mule, in which there is no understanding".

[50:179] "This their own way is an offence to them".

[50:180] Be it an offence to them, not to thee.

[50:181] But when will it be so to thee too? If thou thinkest such men to be blessed.

[50:182] If thou perceivest that they be not blessed, their own way will be an offence to themselves; not to Christ, not to His Body, not to His members.

[50:183] "And afterwards they shall bless with their mouth".

[50:184] What meaneth, "Afterwards they shall bless with their mouth"? Though they have become such, that they seek nothing but temporal goods, yet they become hypocrites: and when they bless God, with lips they bless, and not with heart.

[50:185] Christians like these, when to them eternal life is commended, and they are told, that in the name of Christ they ought to be despisers of riches, do make grimaces in their hearts: and if they dare not do it with open face, lest they blush, or lest they should be rebuked by men, yet they do it in heart, and scorn; and there remaineth in their mouth blessing, and in their heart cursing.

[50:186] The Second Part.

[50:187] "Like sheep laid in hell, death is their shepherd".

[50:188] Whose? Of those whose way is a stumbling-block to themselves.

[50:189] Whose? Of those who mind only things present, while they think not of things future: of those who think not of any life, but of that which must be called death.

[50:190] Not without cause, then, like sheep in hell, have they death to their shepherd.

[50:191] What meaneth, "they have death to their shepherd"? For is death either some thing or some power? Yea, death is either the separation of the soul from the body, or a separation of the soul from God, and that indeed which men fear is the separation of the soul from the body: but the real death, which men do not fear, is the separation of the soul from God.

[50:192] And ofttimes when men fear that which doth separate the soul from the body, they fall into that wherein the soul is separated from God.

[50:193] This then is death.

[50:194] But how is "death their shepherd"? If Christ is life, the devil is death.

[50:195] But we read in many places in Scripture, how that Christ is life.

[50:196] But the devil is death, not because he is himself death, but because through him is death.

[50:197] For whether that (death) wherein Adam fell was given man to drink by the persuasion of him: or whether that wherein the soul is separated from the body, still they have him for the author thereof, who first falling through pride envied him who stood, and overthrew him who stood with an invisible death, in order that he might have to pay the visible death.

[50:198] They who belong to him have death to their shepherd: but we who think of future immortality, and not without reason do wear the sign of the Cross of Christ on the forehead, have no shepherd but life.

[50:199] Of unbelievers death is the shepherd, of believers life is the shepherd.

[50:200] If then in hell are the sheep, whose shepherd is death, in heaven are the sheep, whose shepherd is life.

[50:201] What then? Are we now in heaven? In heaven we are by faith.

[50:202] For if not in heaven, where is the "Lift up your heart"? If not in heaven, whence with the Apostle Paul, "For our conversation is in heaven"? In body we walk on earth, in heart we dwell in heaven.

[50:203] We dwell there, if thither we send anything which holdeth us there.

[50:204] For no one dwelleth in heart, save where thought is: but there his thought is, where his treasure is.

[50:205] He hath treasured on earth, his heart doth not withdraw from earth: he hath treasured in heaven, his heart from heaven doth not come down: for the Lord saith plainly, "Where thy treasure is, there will thy heart be also".

[50:206] They, then, whose shepherd is death, seem to flourish for a time, and the righteous to labour: but why? Because it is yet night.

[50:207] What meaneth, it is night? The merits of the righteous appear not, and the felicity of the unrighteous hath, as it were, a name.

[50:208] So long as it is winter, grass appeareth more verdant than a tree.

[50:209] For grass flourisheth through the winter, a tree is as it were dry through the winter: when in summer time the sun hath come forth with greater heat, the tree, which seemed dry through the winter, is bursting with leaves, and putteth forth fruits, but the grass withereth: thou wilt see the honour of the tree, the grass is dried.

[50:210] So also now the righteous labour, before that summer cometh.

[50:211] There is life in the root, it doth not yet appear in the branches.

[50:212] But our root is love.

[50:213] And what saith the Apostle? That we ought to have our root above, in order that life may be our shepherd, because our dwelling ought not to quit heaven, because in this earth we ought to walk as if dead; so that living above, below we may be dead; not so as that being dead above, we may live below.

[50:214] Our labour shall appear in the morning, and there shall be fruit in the morning: so that they that now labour shall hereafter reign, and they that now boast them and are proud, shall hereafter be brought under.

[50:215] For what followeth? "Like sheep laid in hell, death is their shepherd; and the righteous shall reign over them in the morning".

[50:216] Endure thou the night, yearn for the morning.

[50:217] Think not because the night hath life, the morning too hath not life.

[50:218] Doth then he that sleepeth live, and he that riseth live not? Is not he that sleepeth more like death? And who are they that sleep? They whom the Apostle Paul rouseth, if they choose but to awake.

[50:219] For to certain he saith, "Awake, thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall give thee light".

[50:220] They then that are lightened by Christ watch now, but the fruit of their watchings appeareth not yet: in the morning it shall appear, that is, when doubtful things of this world shall have passed away.

[50:221] For these are very night: for do they not appear to thee like darkness?But they on whom men have trampled, and who were ridiculed for believing, shall hear from Life Itself, whom they have for shepherd, "Come, ye blessed of My Father, receive the kingdom which was prepared for you from the foundation of the world".

[50:222] Therefore the righteous "shall reign over them," not now, but "in the morning".

[50:223] Let no one say, Wherefore am I a Christian? I rule no one, I would rule the wicked.

[50:224] Be not in haste, thou shalt reign, but "in the morning".

[50:225] "And the help of them shall grow old in hell from their glory".

[50:226] Now they have glory, in hell they shall grow old.

[50:227] What is "the help of them"? Help from money, help from friends, help from their own might.

[50:228] But when a man shall be dead, "in that day shall perish all his thoughts".

[50:229] How great glory he seemed to have among men, while he lived, so great oldness and decay of punishments shall he have, when he shall be dead in hell.

[50:230] "Nevertheless, God shall redeem my soul".

[50:231] Behold the voice of one hoping in the future: "Nevertheless, God shall redeem my soul".

[50:232] Perhaps it is the voice of one still wishing to be relieved from oppression.

[50:233] Some one is in prison, he saith, "God shall redeem my soul:" some one is in bond, "God shall redeem my soul:" some one is suffering peril by sea, is being tossed by waves and raging tempests, what saith he? "God shall redeem my soul".

[50:234] They would be delivered for the sake of this life.

[50:235] Not such is the voice of this man.

[50:236] Hear what followeth: "God shall redeem my soul from the hand of hell, when He shall have received me".

[50:237] He is speaking of this redemption, which Christ now showeth in Himself.

[50:238] For He hath descended into hell, and hath ascended into heaven.

[50:239] What we have seen in the Head we have found in the Body.

[50:240] For what we have believed in the Head, they that have seen, have themselves told us, and by themselves we have seen: "For we are" all "one body".

[50:241] But are they better that hear, we worse to whom it hath been told? Not so saith The Life Itself, Our Shepherd Himself.

[50:242] For He rebuketh a certain disciple of His, doubting and desiring to handle His scars, and when he had handled the scars and had cried out, saying, "My Lord and my God," seeing His disciple doubting, and looking to the whole world about to believe, "Because thou hast seen Me," He saith, "thou hast believed: blessed are they that see not, and believe".

[50:243] "But God shall redeem my soul from the land of hell, when He hath received me".

[50:244] Here then what? Labour, oppression, tribulation, temptation: expect nothing else.

[50:245] Where joy? In future hope.

[50:246] Perchance thy heart saith, Wretch that I am, I suppose to no purpose I have believed, God doth not regard things human.

[50:247] God therefore doth awaken us: and He saith what? "Fear not, though a man have become rich".

[50:248] For why didst thou fear, because a man hath become rich? Thou didst fear that thou hadst believed to no purpose, that perchance thou shouldest have lost the labour for thy faith, and the hope of thy conversion: because perchance there hath come in thy way gain with guilt, and thou couldest have been rich, if thou hadst seized upon that same gain with the guilt, and neededst not have laboured; and thou, remembering what God hath threatened, hast refrained from guilt, and hast contemned the gain: thou seest another man that hath made gain by guilt, and hath suffered no harm; and thou fearest to be good.

[50:249] "Fear not," saith the Spirit of God to thee, "though a man shall have become rich".

[50:250] Wouldest thou not have eyes but for things present? Things future He hath promised, who hath risen again; peace in this world, and repose in this life, He hath not promised.

[50:251] Every man doth seek repose; a good thing he is seeking, but not in the proper region thereof he is seeking it.

[50:252] There is no peace in this life; in Heaven hath been promised that which on earth we are seeking: in the world to come hath been promised that which in this world we are seeking.

[50:253] "Fear not, though a man be made rich, and though the glory of his house be multiplied".

[50:254] Wherefore "fear not"? "For when he shall die, he shall not receive anything".

[50:255] Thou seest him living, consider him dying.

[50:256] Thou markest what he hath here, mark what he taketh with him.

[50:257] What doth he take with him? He hath store of gold, he hath store of silver, numerous estates, slaves: he dieth, these remain, he knoweth not for whom.

[50:258] For though he leaveth them for whom he will, he keepeth them not for whom he will.

[50:259] For many have gained even what was not left them, and many have lost what was left them.

[50:260] All these things then remain, and he taketh with him what? Perhaps some one saith, He taketh that with him in which he is wound, and that which is expended upon him for a costly and marble tomb, to erect a monument, this he taketh with him.

[50:261] I say, not even this.

[50:262] For these things are presented to him without his feeling them.

[50:263] If thou deckest a man sleeping and not awake, he hath the decorations with him on the couch: perhaps the decorations are resting upon the body of him as he lieth, and perhaps he seeth himself in tatters during sleep.

[50:264] What he feeleth is more to him than what he feeleth not.

[50:265] Though even this when he shall have awaked will not be: yet to him sleeping, that which he saw in sleep was more than that which he felt not.

[50:266] Why then, brethren, should men say to themselves, Let money be spent at my death: why do I leave my heirs rich? Many things will they have of mine, let me too have something of my own for my body.

[50:267] What shall a dead body have? what shall rotting flesh have? what shall flesh not feeling have? If that rich man had anything, whose tongue was dry, then man hath something of his own.

[50:268] My brethren, do we read in the Gospel, that this rich man appeared in the fire with all-silken and fine-linen coverings? Was he of such sort in hell as he was in feastings at table? When he thirsted and desired a drop, all those things were not there.

[50:269] Therefore man carrieth not with him anything, nor doth the dead take with him that which the burial taketh.

[50:270] For where feeling is, there is the man; where is no feeling, the man is not.

[50:271] There lieth fallen the vessel which contained the man, the house which held the man.

[50:272] The body let us call the house, the spirit let us call the inhabitant of the house.

[50:273] The spirit is tormented in hell: what doth it profit him, that the body lieth in spices and perfumes, wound in costly linens? just as if the master of the house should be sent into banishment, and thou shouldest garnish the walls of his house.

[50:274] He in banishment is in need, and doth faint with hunger, he scarce findeth to himself one hovel where he may snatch a sleep, and thou sayest, "Happy is he, for his house hath been garnished".

[50:275] Who would not judge that thou wast either jesting or wast mad? Thou dost garnish the body, the spirit is tormented.

[50:276] Give something to the spirit, and ye have given something to the dead man.

[50:277] But what wilt thou give him, when he desired one drop, and received not? For the man scorned to send before him anything.

[50:278] Wherefore scorned? "because this their way is a stumbling-block to them".

[50:279] He minded not any but the present life, he thought not but how he might be buried, wound in costly vestments.

[50:280] His soul was taken from him, as the Lord saith: "Thou fool, this night thy soul shall be taken from thee, an d whose shall those things be which thou hast provided?" And that is fulfilled which this Psalm saith: "Fear not, though a man be made rich, and though the glory of his house be multiplied: for when he shall die he shall not receive anything, nor shall his glory descend together with him".

[50:281] Let your love observe: "For his soul shall be blessed in his life".

[50:282] As long as he lived he did well for himself.

[50:283] This all men say, but say falsely.

[50:284] It is a blessing from the mind of the blesser, not from the truth itself.

[50:285] For what sayest thou? Because he ate and drank, because he did what he chose, because he feasted sumptuously, therefore he did well with himself.

[50:286] I say, he did ill for himself.

[50:287] Not I say, but Christ.

[50:288] He did ill for himself.

[50:289] For that rich man, when he feasted sumptuously every day, was supposed to do well with himself: but when he began to burn in hell, then that which was supposed to be well was found to be ill.

[50:290] For what he had eaten with men above, he digested in hell beneath.

[50:291] Unrighteousness I mean, brethren, on which he used to feast.

[50:292] He used to eat costly banquets with the mouth of flesh, with his heart's mouth he used to eat unrighteousness.

[50:293] What he ate with his heart's mouth with men above, this he digested amid those punishments in the places beneath.

[50:294] And verily he had eaten for a time, he digested ill for everlasting.

[50:295] Is then unrighteousness eaten? perhaps some one saith: what is it that he saith? Unrighteousness eaten? It is not I that say: hear the Scripture: "As a sour grape is vexation to the teeth, and smoke to the eyes, so is unrighteousness to them that use it".

[50:296] For he that shall have eaten unrighteousness, that is, he that shall have had unrighteousness wilfully, shall not be able to eat righteousness.

[50:297] For righteousness is bread.

[50:298] Who is bread? "I am the living bread which came down from heaven".

[50:299] Himself is the bread of our heart.

[50:300] Is then even righteousness eaten? If it were not eaten, the Lord would not have said, "Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness".

[50:301] Therefore "since his soul shall be blessed in life," in life it "shall" be blessed, in death it shall be tormented.

[50:302] "He shall confess to Thee, when Thou shalt have done him good".

[50:303] Be not of such sort, brethren: see ye how that to this end we say these words, to this end we sing, to this end we treat, to this end toil—do not these things.

[50:304] Your business doth prove you: sometimes in your business ye hear the truth, and ye blaspheme.

[50:305] The Church ye blaspheme.

[50:306] Wherefore? Because ye are Christians.

[50:307] "If so it be, I betake myself to Donatus's party: I will be a heathen".

[50:308] Wherefore? Because thou hast eaten bread, and the teeth are in pain.

[50:309] When thou sawest the bread itself, thou didst praise; thou beginnest to eat, and the teeth are in pain; that is, when thou wast hearing the Word of God thou didst praise: when it is said to thee, "Do this," thou blasphemest: do not so ill: say this, "The bread is good, but I cannot eat it".

[50:310] But now if thou seest with the eyes, thou praisest: when thou beginnest to close the teeth thou sayest, "Bad is this bread, and like him that made it".

[50:311] So it cometh to pass that thou confessest to God, when God doeth thee good and thou liest when thou singest, "I will alway bless God, His praise is ever in my mouth".

[50:312] How alway? If alway gain, alway He is blessed: if sometime there is loss, He is not blessed, but blasphemed.

[50:313] Forsooth thou blessest alway, forsooth His praise is ever in thy mouth! Thou wilt be such as just now he describeth: "He will confess to Thee, when Thou shalt have done him good".

[50:314] "He shall enter even unto the generations of his fathers" : that is, he shall imitate his fathers.

[50:315] For the unrighteous, that now are, have brothers, have fathers.

[50:316] Unrighteous men of old, are the fathers of the present; and they that are now unrighteous, are the fathers of unrighteous posterity: just as the fathers of the righteous, the righteous of old, are the fathers of the righteous that now are; and they that now are, are the fathers of them that are to be.

[50:317] The Holy Spirit hath willed to show that righteousness is not evil when men murmur against her: but these men have their father from the beginning, even to the generation of their fathers.

[50:318] Two men Adam begat, and in one was unrighteousness, in one was righteousness: unrighteousness in Cain, righteousness in Abel Unrighteousness seemed to prevail over righteousness, because Cain unrighteous slew Abel righteous in the night.

[50:319] Is it so in the morning? Nay, "but the righteous shall reign over them in the morning".

[50:320] The morning shall come, and it shall be seen where Abel is, and where Cain.

[50:321] So all men who are after Cain, and so all who are after Abel, even unto the end of the world.

[50:322] "He shall enter even unto the generations of his fathers: even to eternity he shall not see light".

[50:323] Because even when he was here, he was in darkness, taking pleasure in false goods, and not loving real goods: even so he shall go hence into hell: from the darkness of his dreams the darkness of torments shall receive him.

[50:324] Therefore, "even to eternity he shall not see light".

[50:325] But wherefore this? What he hath written in the middle of the Psalm, the same also he hath writ at the end: "Man, though he was in honour, understood not, was compared to the beasts without sense, and was made like to them".

[50:326] But ye, brethren, consider that ye be men made after the image and likeness of God.

[50:327] The image of God is within, is not in the body; is not in these ears which ye see, and eyes, and nostrils, and palate, and hands, and feet; but is made nevertheless: wherein is the intellect, wherein is the mind, wherein the power of discovering truth, wherein is faith, wherein is your hope, wherein your charity, there God hath His Image: there at least ye perceive and see that these things pass away; for so he hath said in another Psalm, "Though man walketh in an image, yet he is disquieted in vain: he heapeth up treasures, and knoweth not for whom he shall gather them".

[50:328] Be not disquieted, for of whatsoever kind these things be, they are transitory, if ye are men who being in honour understand.

[50:329] For if being men in honour ye understand not, ye are compared to the beasts without sense, and are made like to them.

[51:1] Psalm L.

[51:2] How much availeth the Word of God to us for the correction of our life, both regarding His rewards to be expected, and His punishments to be feared, let each one measure in himself; and let him put his conscience without deceit before His eyes, and not flatter himself in a danger so great: for ye see that even our Lord God Himself doth flatter no one: though He comforteth us by promising His blessings, and by strengthening our hope; yet them that live ill and despise His word He assuredly spareth not.

[51:3] Let each one examine himself, while it is time, and let him see where he is, and either persevere in good, or be changed from evil.

[51:4] For as he saith in this Psalm, not any man whatever nor any angel whatever, but, "The Lord, the God of gods, hath spoken".

[51:5] But in speaking, He hath done what? "He hath called the earth from the rising of the sun unto the going down".

[51:6] He that "hath called the world from the rising of the sun unto the going down," is Our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, "the Word made Flesh," in order that He might dwell in us.

[51:7] Our Lord Jesus Christ then is the "God of gods;" because by Himself were all things made, and without Himself was nothing made.

[51:8] The Word of God, if He is God, is truly the God of gods; but whether He be God the Gospel answereth, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

[51:9] And if all things were made by Himself, as He saith in the sequel, then if any were made gods, by Himself were they made.

[51:10] For the one God was not made, and He is Himself alone truly God.

[51:11] But Himself the only God, Father and Son and Holy Ghost, is one God.

[51:12] But then who are those gods, or where are they, of whom God is the true God? Another Psalm saith, "God hath stood in the synagogue of gods, but in the midst He judgeth gods".

[51:13] As yet we know not whether perchance any gods be congregated in heaven, and in their  congregation, for this is "in the synagogue," God hath stood to judge.

[51:14] See in the same Psalm those to whom he saith, "I have said, Ye are gods, and children of the Highest all; but ye shall die like men, and fall like one of the princes".

[51:15] It is evident then, that He hath called men gods, that are deified of His Grace, not born of His Substance.

[51:16] For He doth justify, who is just through His own self, and not of another; and He doth deify who is God through Himself, not by the partaking of another.

[51:17] But He that justifieth doth Himself deify, in that by justifying He doth make sons of God.

[51:18] "For He hath given them power to become the sons of God".

[51:19] If we have been made sons of God, we have also been made gods: but this is the effect of Grace adopting, not of nature generating.

[51:20] For the only Son of God, God, and one God with the Father, Our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, was in the beginning the Word, and the Word with God, the Word God.

[51:21] The rest that are made gods, are made by His own Grace, are not born of His Substance, that they should be the same as He, but that by favour they should come to Him, and be fellow-heirs with Christ.

[51:22] For so great is the love in Him the Heir, that He hath willed to have fellow-heirs.

[51:23] What covetous man would will this, to have fellow-heirs? But even one that is found so to will, will share with them the inheritance, the sharer having less himself, than if he had possessed alone: but the inheritance wherein we are fellow-heirs of Christ, is not lessened by multitude of possessors, nor is it made narrower by the number of fellow-heirs: but is as great for many as it is for few, as great for individuals as for all.

[51:24] "See," saith the Apostle, "what love God hath bestowed upon us, that we should be called, and be, the sons of God".

[51:25] And in another place, "Dearly beloved, we are the sons of God, and it doth not yet appear what we shall be".

[51:26] We are therefore in hope, not yet in substance.

[51:27] "But we know," he saith, "that when He shall have appeared, we shall be like Him, for we shall see Him as He is".

[51:28] The Only Son is like Him by birth, we like by seeing.

[51:29] For we are not like in such sort as He, who is the same as He is by whom He was begotten: for we are like, not equal: He, because equal, is therefore like.

[51:30] We have heard who are the gods that being made are justified, because they are called the sons of God:  and who are the gods that are not Gods, to whom the God of gods is terrible? For another Psalm saith, "He is terrible over all gods".

[51:31] And as if thou shouldest enquire, what gods? He saith, "For all the gods of the nations are devils".

[51:32] To the gods of the nations, to the devils, terrible: to the gods made by Himself, to sons, lovely.

[51:33] Furthermore, I find both of them confessing the Majesty of God, both the devils confessed Christ, and the faithful confessed Christ.

[51:34] "Thou art Christ, the Son of the living God," said Peter.

[51:35] "We know who Thou art, Thou art the Son of God," said the devils.

[51:36] A like confession I hear, but like love I find not; nay even here love, there fear.

[51:37] To whom therefore He is lovely, the same are sons; to whom He is terrible, are not sons; to whom He is lovely, the same He hath made gods; those to whom He is terrible He doth prove not to be gods.

[51:38] For these are made gods, those are reputed gods; these Truth maketh gods, those error doth so account.

[51:39] "The God," therefore, "of gods, the Lord hath spoken".

[51:40] Hath spoken many ways.

[51:41] By Angels He hath Himself spoken, by Prophets He hath Himself spoken, by His own mouth He hath Himself spoken, by His faithful He doth Himself speak, by our lowliness, when we say anything true, He doth Himself speak.

[51:42] See then, by speaking diversely, many ways, by many vessels, by many instruments, yet He doth Himself sound everywhere, by touching, moulding, inspiring: see what He hath done.

[51:43] For "He hath spoken, and hath called the world".

[51:44] What world? Africa, perhaps! for the sake of those that say, the Church of Christ is the portion of Donatus.

[51:45] Africa indeed alone He hath not called, but even Africa He hath not severed.

[51:46] For He that "hath called the world from the rising of the sun unto the going down," leaving out no parts that He hath not called, in His calling hath found Africa.

[51:47] Let it rejoice therefore in unity, not pride itself in division.

[51:48] We say well, that the voice of the God of gods hath come even into Africa, hath not stayed in Africa.

[51:49] For "He hath called the world from the rising of the sun unto the going down".

[51:50] There is no place where may lurk the conspiracies of heretics, they have no place wherein they may hide themselves under the shadow of falsehood; for "there is none that can hide himself from the heat thereof".

[51:51] He that hath called the world, hath called even the whole world: He that hath called the world, hath called as much as He hath formed.

[51:52] Why do false christs and false prophets rise up against me? why is it that they strive to ensnare me with captious words, saying, "Lo! here is Christ, Lo! He is there!" I hear not them that point out portions: the God of gods hath pointed out the whole: "He" that "hath called the world from the rising of the sun unto the going down," hath redeemed the whole; but hath condemned them that lay false claim to portions.

[51:53] But we have heard the world called from the rising of the sun unto the going down: whence doth He begin to call, who hath called?  This thing also hear ye: "Out of Sion is the semblance of His beauty".

[51:54] Evidently the Psalm doth agree with the Gospel, which saith, "Throughout all nations, beginning at Jerusalem".

[51:55] Hear, "Throughout all nations:" He hath called the world from the rising of the sun unto the going down".

[51:56] Hear, "Beginning at Jerusalem:" "Out of Sion is the semblance of His beauty".

[51:57] Therefore, "He hath called the world from the rising of the sun unto the going down," agreeth with the words of the Lord, who saith, "It behoved Christ to suffer, and to rise from the dead the third day; and that repentance and remission of sins should be preached in His Name throughout all nations".

[51:58] For all nations are from the rising of the sun unto the going down.

[51:59] But that, "Out of Sion is the semblance of His beauty," that thence beginneth the beauty of His Gospel, that thence He began to be preached, being "beautiful in form beyond the sons of men," agreeth with the words of the Lord, who saith, "Beginning at Jerusalem".

[51:60] New things are in tune with old, old things with new: the two Seraphim say to one another, "Holy, holy, holy, Lord God of Sabaoth".

[51:61] The two Testaments are both in tune, and the two Testaments have one voice: let the voice of the Testaments in tune be heard, not that of pretenders disinherited.

[51:62] This thing then hath the God of gods done, "He hath called the world from the rising of the sun unto the going down, His semblance going before out of Sion".

[51:63] For in that place were His disciples, who received the Holy Ghost sent from heaven on the fiftieth day after His resurrection.

[51:64] Thence the Gospel, thence the preaching, thence the whole world filled, and that in the Grace of Faith.

[51:65] For when the Lord Himself had come, because He came to suffer, He came hidden: and though He was strong in Himself, He appeared in the flesh weak.

[51:66] For He must needs appear in order that He might not be perceived; be despised, in order that He might be slain.

[51:67] There was semblance of glory in divinity, but it lay concealed in flesh.

[51:68] "For if they had known, they would never have crucified the Lord of glory".

[51:69] So then He walked hidden among the Jews, among His enemies, doing marvels, suffering ills, until He was hanged on the tree, and the Jews seeing Him hanging both despised Him the more, and before the Cross wagging their heads they said, "If He be the Son of God, let Him come down from the Cross".

[51:70] Hidden then was the God of gods, and He gave forth words more out of compassion for us than out of His own majesty.

[51:71] For whence, unless assumed from us, were those words, "My God, My God, why hast Thou forsaken me?" But when hath the Father forsaken the Son, or the Son the Father? Are not Father and Son one God? Whence then, "My God, My God, why hast Thou forsaken Me," save that in the Flesh of infirmity there was acknowledged the voice of a sinner? For as He took upon Him the likeness of the flesh of sin, why should He not take upon Him the voice of sin? Hidden then was the God of gods, both when He walked among men, and when He hungered, and when He thirsted, and when fatigued He sat, and when with wearied body He slept, and when taken, and when scourged, and when standing before the judge, and when He made answer to him in his pride, "Thou couldest have no power against Me, except it had been given thee from above;" and while led as a victim "before His shearer He opened not His mouth," and while crucified, and while buried, He was always hidden God of gods.

[51:72] What took place after He rose again? The disciples marvelled, and at first believed not, until they touched and handled But flesh had risen, because flesh had been dead: Divinity which could not die, even still lay hid in the flesh of Him rising.

[51:73] Form could be seen, limbs held, scars handled: the Word by whom all things were made, who doth see? who doth hold? who doth handle? And yet "the Word was made flesh, and dwelled among us".

[51:74] And Thomas, that was holding Man, understood God as he was able.

[51:75] For when he had handled the scars, he cried out, "My Lord, and my God".

[51:76] Yet the Lord was showing that form, and that flesh, which they had seen upon the Cross, which had been laid in the sepulchre.

[51:77] He stayed with them forty days.

[51:78] But what was said to Thomas handling? "Because thou hast seen, thou hast believed; blessed are they that see not, and believe".

[51:79] We are foretold.

[51:80] That world called from the rising of the sun unto the going down seeth not, and believeth.

[51:81] Hidden then is the God of gods, both to those among whom He walked, and to those by whom He was crucified, and to those before whose eyes He rose, and to us who believe on Him in heaven sitting, whom we have not seen on earth walking.

[51:82] But even if we were to see, should we not see that which the Jews saw and crucified? It is more, that not seeing we believe Christ to be God, than that they seeing deemed Him only to be man.

[51:83] They in a word by thinking evil slew, we by believing well are made alive.

[51:84] What then, brethren? This God of gods, both then hidden, and now hidden, shall He ever be hidden? Evidently not: hear what followeth: "God shall come manifest".

[51:85] He that came hidden, shall come manifest.

[51:86] Hidden He came to be judged, manifest He shall come to judge: hidden He came that He might stand before a judge, manifest He shall come that He may be judge even of judges: "He shall come manifest, and shall not be silent".

[51:87] But why? Is He now silent? And whence are all the words that we say? whence those precepts? whence those warnings? whence that trumpet of terror? He is not silent, and is silent: is not silent from warning, is silent from avenging: is not silent from precept, is silent from judgment.

[51:88] For He suffereth sinners daily doing evil things, not caring for God, not in their conscience, not in heaven, not in earth: all these things escape Him not, and universally He doth admonish all; and whenever He chastiseth any on earth, it is admonition, not yet condemnation.

[51:89] He is silent then from judgment, He is hidden in heaven, as yet He intercedeth for us: He is long-suffering to sinners, not putting forth His wrath, but awaiting penitence.

[51:90] He saith in another place: "I have held my peace, shall I always hold my peace?" When then He shall not hold His peace, "God shall come manifest".

[51:91] What God? "Our God".

[51:92] And the God Himself, who is our God: for he is not God, who is not our God.

[51:93] For the gods of the nations are devils: the God of Christians is very God.

[51:94] Himself shall come, but "manifest," not still to be mocked, not still to be buffeted and scourged: He shall come, but "manifest," not still to be smitten with a reed upon the head, not still to be crucified, slain, buried: for all these things God being hidden hath willed to suffer.

[51:95] "He shall come manifest, and shall not be silent".

[51:96] But that He shall come to judgment, the following words teach.

[51:97] "Fire shall go before Him".

[51:98] Do we fear? Be we changed, and we shall not fear.

[51:99] Let chaff fear the fire: what doth it to gold? What thou mayest do is now in thy power, so thou mayest not experience, for want of being corrected, that which is to come even against thy will.

[51:100] For if we might so bring it about, brethren, that the day of judgment should not come; I think that even then it were not for us to live ill.

[51:101] If the fire of the day of judgment were not to come, and over sinners there impended only separation from the face of God, in whatever affluence of delights they might be, not seeing Him by whom they were created, and separated from that sweetness of His ineffable countenance, in whatever eternity and impunity of sin, they ought to bemoan themselves.

[51:102] But what shall I say, or to whom shall I say? This is a punishment to lovers, not to despisers.

[51:103] They that have begun to feel in any degree the sweetness of wisdom and truth, know what I say, how great a punishment it is to be only separated from the face of God: but they that have not tasted that sweetness, if not yet they yearn for the face of God, let them fear even fire; let punishments terrify those, whom rewards win not.

[51:104] Of no value to thee is what God promiseth, tremble at what He threateneth.

[51:105] The sweetness of His presence shall come; thou art not changed, thou art not awakened, thou sighest not, thou longest not: thou embracest thy sins and the delights of thy flesh, thou art heaping stubble to thyself, the fire will come.

[51:106] "Fire shall burn in His presence".

[51:107] This fire will not be like thy hearth-fire, into which nevertheless, if thou art compelled to thrust thy hand, thou wilt do whatsoever he would have thee who doth threaten this alternative.

[51:108] If he say to thee, "write against the life of thy father, write against the lives of thy children, for if thou do not, I thrust thy hand into thy fire:" thou wilt do it in order that thy hand be not burned, in order that thy member be not burned for a time, though it is not to be ever in pain.

[51:109] Thine enemy threateneth then but so light an evil, and thou doest evil; God threateneth eternal evil, and doest thou not good? To do evil not even menaces should compel thee: from doing good not even menaces should deter thee.

[51:110] But by the menaces of God, by menaces of everlasting fire, thou art dissuaded from evil, invited to good.

[51:111] Wherefore doth it grieve thee, except because thou believest not? Let each one then examine his heart, and see what faith doth hold there.

[51:112] If we believe a judgment to come, brethren, let us live well.

[51:113] Now is time of mercy, then will be time of judgment.

[51:114] No one will say, "Call me back to my former years".

[51:115] Even then men will repent, but will repent in vain: now let there be repentance, while there is fruit of repentance; now let there be applied to the roots of the tree a basket of dung, sorrow of heart, and tears; lest He come and pluck up by the roots.

[51:116] For when He shall have plucked up, then the fire is to be looked for.

[51:117] Now, even if the branches have been broken, they can again be grafted in: then, "every tree which bringeth not forth good fruit, shall be cut down, and shall be cast into the fire".

[51:118] "Fire shall burn in His presence".

[51:119] "And a mighty tempest round about Him".

[51:120] "A mighty tempest," in order to winnow so great a floor.

[51:121] In this tempest shall be that winnowing whereby from the saints shall be put away everything impure, from the faithful every unreality; from godly men and them that fear the Word of God, every scorner and every proud man.

[51:122] For now a sort of mixture doth lie there, from the rising of the sun unto the going down.

[51:123] Let us see then how He will do that is to come, what He will do with that tempest which "shall be a mighty tempest round about Him".

[51:124] Doubtless this tempest is to make a sort of separation.

[51:125] It is that separation which they waited not for, who brake the nets, before they came to land But in this separation there is made a sort of distinction between good men and bad men.

[51:126] There be some that now follow Christ with lightened shoulders without the load of the world's cares, who have not heard in vain, "If thou wilt be perfect, go and sell all that thou hast, and give to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven: and come, follow Me;" to which sort is said, "Ye shall sit upon twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel".

[51:127] Some then shall be judging with the Lord: but others to be judged, but to be placed on the right hand.

[51:128] For that there will be certain judging with the Lord, we have most evident testimony, which I have but now quoted: "Ye shall sit upon twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel".

[51:129] But what the Lord did after His resurrection, signified what is to be to us after our resurrection, in that number of the kingdom of heaven, where shall be no bad man.
