[66:45] Whence saith another Psalm, "Vow ye, and pay ye unto the Lord your God:" and, "to Thee shall it be paid in Jerusalem".

[66:46] For there shall we be whole, that is, entire in the resurrection of just men: there shall be paid our whole vow, not soul alone, but the very flesh also, no longer corruptible, because no longer in Babylon, but now a body heavenly and changed.

[66:47] What sort of change is promised? "For we all shall rise again," saith the Apostle, "but we shall not all be changed.

[66:48] Where is, O death, thy sting?" For now while there begin in use the first-fruits of the mind, from whence is the longing for Jerusalem, many things of corruptible flesh do contend against us, which will not contend, when death shall have been swallowed up in victory.

[66:49] Peace shall conquer, and war shall be ended.

[66:50] But when peace shall conquer, that city shall conquer which is called the vision of peace.

[66:51] On the part of death therefore shall be no contention.

[66:52] Now with how great a death do we contend! For thence are carnal pleasures, which to us even unlawfully do suggest many things: to which we give no consent, but nevertheless in giving no consent we contend.

[66:53] "Hearken," he saith, "to my prayer, unto Thee every flesh shall come".

[66:54] And we have the Lord saying, that there was given to Him "power over every flesh".

[66:55] That King therefore began even now to appear, when there was being said, "Unto Thee every flesh shall come".

[66:56] "To Thee," he saith, "every flesh shall come".

[66:57] Wherefore to Him shall "every" flesh come? Because flesh He hath taken to Him.

[66:58] Whither shall there come every flesh? He took the first-fruits thereof out of the womb of the Virgin; and now that the first-fruits have been taken to Him, the rest shall follow, in order that the holocaust may be completed.

[66:59] Whence then "every flesh"? Every man.

[66:60] And whence every man? Have all been foretold, as going to believe in Christ? Have not many ungodly men been foretold, that shall be condemned also? Do not daily men not believing die in their own unbelief? After what manner therefore do we understand, "Unto Thee every flesh shall come"? By "every flesh" he hath signified, "flesh of every kind:" out of every kind of flesh they shall come to Thee.

[66:61] What is, out of every kind of flesh? Have there come poor men, and have there not come rich men? Have there come humble men, and not come lofty men? Have there come unlearned men, and not come learned men? Have there come men, and not come women? Have there come masters, and not come servants? Have there come old men, and not come young men; or have there come young men, and not come youths; or have there come youths, and not come boys; or have there come boys, and have there not been brought infants? In a word, have there come Jews  (for thence were the Apostles, thence many thousands of men at first betraying, afterwards believing), and have there not come Greeks; or have there come Greeks, and not come Romans; or have there come Romans, and not come Barbarians? And who could number all nations coming to Him, to whom hath been said, "Unto Thee every flesh shall come"?.

[66:62] "The discourses of unjust men have prevailed over us, and our iniquities Thou shalt propitiate".

[66:63] Every man, in whatsoever place he is born, of that same land or region or city learneth the language, is habituated to the manners and life of that place.

[66:64] What should a boy do, born among Heathens, to avoid worshipping a stone, inasmuch as his parents have suggested that worship? from them the first words he hath heard, that error with his milk he hath sucked in; and because they that used to speak were elders, and the boy that was learning to speak was an infant, what could the little one do but follow the authority of elders, and deem that to be good which they recommended? Therefore nations that are converted to Christ afterwards, and taking to heart the impieties of their parents, and saying now what the prophet Jeremias himself said, "Truly a lie our fathers have worshipped, vanity which hath not profited them"—when, I say, they now say this, they renounce the opinions and blasphemies of their unjust parents.

[66:65] There have led us away men teaching evil things, citizens of Babylon they have made us, we have left the Creator, have adored the creature: have left Him by whom we were made, have adored that which we ourselves have made.

[66:66] For "the discourses of unjust men have prevailed over us:" but nevertheless they have not crushed us.

[66:67] Wherefore? "Our impieties Thou shalt propitiate," is not said except to some priest offering somewhat, whereby impiety may be expiated and propitiated.

[66:68] For impiety is then said to be propitiated, when God is made propitious to the impiety.

[66:69] What is it for God to be made propitious to impiety? It is, His becoming forgiving, and giving pardon.

[66:70] But in order that God's pardon may be obtained, propitiation is made through some sacrifice.

[66:71] There hath come forth therefore, sent from God the Lord, One our Priest; He took upon Him from us that which He might offer to the Lord; we are speaking of those same first-fruits of the flesh from the womb of the Virgin.

[66:72] This holocaust He offered to God.

[66:73] He stretched out His hands on the Cross, in order that He might say, "Let My prayer be directed as incense in Thy sight, and the lifting up of My hands an evening sacrifice".

[66:74] As ye know, the Lord about eventide hung on the Cross: and our impieties were propitiated; otherwise they had swallowed up: the discourses of unjust men had prevailed over us; there had led us astray preachers of Jupiter, and of Saturn, and of Mercury: "the discourses of ungodly men had prevailed over us".

[66:75] But what wilt Thou do? "Our impieties Thou wilt propitiate".

[66:76] Thou art the priest, Thou the victim; Thou the offerer, Thou the offering.

[66:77] "Blessed is he whom Thou hast chosen, and hast taken to Thee".

[66:78] Who is he that is chosen by Him and taken to Him? Was any one chosen by our Saviour Jesus Christ, or was Himself after the flesh, because He is man, chosen and taken to Him?Or hath not rather Christ Himself taken to Him some blessed one, and the same whom He hath taken to Him is not spoken of in the plural number but in the singular? For one man He hath taken to Him, because unity He hath taken to Him.

[66:79] Schisms He hath not taken to Him, heresies He hath not taken to Him: a multitude they have made of themselves, there is not one to be taken to Him.

[66:80] But they that abide in the bond of Christ and are the members of Him, make in a manner one man, of whom saith the Apostle, "Until we all arrive at the acknowledging of the Son of God, unto a perfect man, unto the measure of the age of the fulness of Christ".

[66:81] Therefore one man is taken to Him, to which the Head is Christ; because "the Head of the man is Christ".

[66:82] The same is that blessed man that "hath not departed in the counsel of ungodly men," and the like things which there are spoken of: the same is He that is taken to Him.

[66:83] He is not without us, in His own members we are, under one Head we are governed, by one Spirit we all live, one fatherland we all long for.

[66:84] And to us He will give what? "He shall inhabit," he saith, "in Thy courts".

[66:85] Jerusalem, that is, to which they sing that begin to go forth from Babylon: "He shall inhabit in Thy courts: we shall be filled with the good things of Thy House".

[66:86] What are the good things of the House of God? Brethren, let us set before ourselves some rich house, with what numerous good things it is crowded, how abundantly it is furnished, how many vessels there are there of gold and also of silver; how great an establishment of servants, how many horses and animals, in a word, how much the house itself delights us with pictures, marble, ceilings, pillars, recesses, chambers:—all such things are indeed objects of desire, but still they are of the confusion of Babylon.

[66:87] Cut off all such longings, O citizen of Jerusalem, cut them off; if thou wilt return, let not captivity delight thee.

[66:88] But hast thou already begun to go forth? Do not look back, do not loiter on the road.

[66:89] Still there are not wanting foes to recommend thee captivity and sojourning: no longer let there prevail against thee the discourses of ungodly men.

[66:90] For the House of God long thou, and for the good things of that House long thou: but do not long for such things as thou art wont to long for either in thy house, or in the house of thy neighbour, or in the house of thy patron.

[66:91] "Thy holy Temple is marvellous in righteousness".

[66:92] These are the good things of that House.

[66:93] He hath not said, Thy holy Temple is marvellous in pillars, marvellous in marbles, marvellous in glided ceilings; but is "marvellous in righteousness".

[66:94] Without thou hast eyes wherewith thou mayest see marbles, and gold: within is an eye wherewith may be seen the beauty of righteousness.

[66:95] If there is no beauty in righteousness, why is a righteous old man loved? What bringeth he in body that may please the eyes? Crooked limbs, brow wrinkled, head blanched with gray hairs, dotage everywhere full of plaints.

[66:96] But perchance because thine eyes this decrepit old man pleaseth not, thine ears he pleaseth: with what words? with what song? Even if perchance when a young man he sang well, all with age hath been lost.

[66:97] Doth perchance the sound of his words please thine ears, that can hardly articulate whole words for loss of teeth? Nevertheless, if righteous he is, if another man's goods he coveteth not, if of his own that he possesseth he distributeth to the needy, if he giveth good advice, and soundly judgeth, if he believeth the entire faith, if for his belief in the faith he is ready to expend even those very shattered limbs, for many Martyrs are even old men; why do we love him? What good thing in him do we see with the eyes of the flesh? Not any.

[66:98] There is therefore a kind of beauty in righteousness, which we see with the eye of the heart, and we love, and we kindle with affection: how much men found to love in those same Martyrs, though beasts tare their limbs! Is it possible but that when blood was staining all parts, when with the teeth of monsters their bowels gushed out, the eyes had nothing but objects to shudder at? What was there to be loved, except that in that hideous spectacle of mangled limbs, entire was the beauty of righteousness? These are the good things of the House of God, with these prepare thyself to be satisfied.

[66:99] "Blessed they which hunger and thirst after righteousness, for they shall be filled".

[66:100] "Thy holy Temple is marvellous in righteousness".

[66:101] And that same temple, brethren, do not imagine to be aught but yourselves.

[66:102] Love ye righteousness, and ye are the Temple of God.

[66:103] "Hearken to us, O God, our Saviour".

[66:104] He hath disclosed now Whom he nameth as God.

[66:105] The "Saviour" specially is the Lord Jesus Christ.

[66:106] It hath appeared now more openly of Whom he had said, "Unto Thee every flesh shall come".

[66:107] That One Man that is taken unto Him into the Temple of God, is both many and is One.

[66:108] In the person of One he hath said, "Hearken, O God, i-e:, to my hunger:" and because the same One of many is composed, now he saith, "Hearken to us, O God, our Saviour".

[66:109] Hear Him now more openly preached: "Hearken to us, O God, our Saviour, the Hope of all the ends of the earth and in the sea afar".

[66:110] Behold wherefore hath been said "Unto Thee every flesh shall come".

[66:111] From every quarter they come.

[66:112] "Hope of all the ends of the earth," not hope of one corner, not hope of Judaea alone, not hope of Africa alone, not hope of Pannonia, not hope of East or of West: but "Hope of all the ends of the earth, and in the sea afar:" of the very ends of the earth.

[66:113] "And in the sea afar:" and because in the sea, therefore afar.

[66:114] For the sea by a figure is spoken of this world, with saltness bitter, with storms troubled; where men of perverse and depraved appetites have become like fishes devouring one another.

[66:115] Observe the evil sea, bitter sea, with waves violent, observe with what sort of men it is filled.

[66:116] Who desireth an inheritance except through the death of another? Who desireth gain except by the loss of another? By the fall of others how many men wish to be exalted? How many, in order that they may buy, desire for other men to sell their goods? How they mutually oppress, and how they that are able do devour! And when one fish hath devoured, the greater the less, itself also is devoured by some greater.

[66:117] Because evil fishes that were taken within the nets they said they would not endure; they themselves have become more evil than they whom they said they could not endure.

[66:118] For those nets did take fishes both good and evil.

[66:119] The Lord saith, "The kingdom of Heaven is like to a sein cast into the sea, which gathereth of every kind, which, when it had been filled, drawing out, and sitting on the shore, they gathered the good into vessels, but the evil they cast out: so it shall be," He saith, "in the consummation of the world".

[66:120] He showeth what is the shore, He showeth what is the end of the sea.

[66:121] "The angels shall go forth, and shall sever the evil from the midst of the just, and shall cast them into the furnace of fire: there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth".

[66:122] Ha! ye citizens of Jerusalem that are within the nets, and are good fishes; endure the evil, the nets break ye not: together with them ye are in a sea, not together with them will ye be in the vessels.

[66:123] For "Hope" He is "of the ends of the earth," Himself is Hope "also in the sea afar".

[66:124] Afar, because also in the sea.

[66:125] "Preparing mountains in His strength".

[66:126] Not in their strength.

[66:127] For He hath prepared great preachers, and those same He hath called mountains; humble in themselves, exalted in Him.

[66:128] "Preparing mountains in His strength".

[66:129] What saith one of those same mountains? "We ourselves in our own selves have had the answer of death, in order that in ourselves we should not trust, but in God that raiseth the dead".

[66:130] He that in himself doth trust, and in Christ trusteth not, is not of those mountains which He hath prepared in His strength.

[66:131] "Preparing mountains in His strength: girded about in power".

[66:132] "Power," I understand: "girded about," is what? They that put Christ in the midst, "girded about" they make Him, that is on all sides begirt.

[66:133] We all have Him in common, therefore in the midst He is: all we gird Him about that believe in Him: and because our faith is not of our strength, but of His power; therefore girded about He is in His power; not in our own strength.

[66:134] "That troublest the bottom of the sea".

[66:135] He hath done this: it is seen what He hath done.

[66:136] For He hath prepared mountains in His strength, hath sent them to preach: girded about He is by believers in power: and moved is the sea, moved is the world, and it beginneth to persecute His saints.

[66:137] "Girded about in power: that troublest the bottom of the sea".

[66:138] He hath not said, that troublest the sea; but "the bottom of the sea".

[66:139] The bottom of the sea is the heart of ungodly men.

[66:140] For just as from the bottom more thoroughly all things are stirred, and the bottom holdeth firm all things: so whatsoever hath gone forth: by tongue, by hands, by divers powers for the persecution of the Church, from the bottom hath gone forth.

[66:141] For if there were not the root of iniquity in the heart, all those things would not have gone forth against Christ.

[66:142] The bottom He troubled, perchance in order that the bottom He might also empty: for in the case of cert ain evil men He emptied the sea from the bottom, and made the sea a desert place.

[66:143] Another Psalm saith this, "That turneth sea into dry land".

[66:144] All ungodly and heathen men that have believed were sea, have been made land; with salt waves at first barren, afterwards with the fruit of righteousness productive.

[66:145] "That troublest the bottom of the sea: the sound of its waves who shall endure?" "Who shall endure," is what? What man shall endure the sound of the waves of the sea, the behests of the high powers of the world? But whence are they endured? Because He prepareth mountains in His strength.

[66:146] In that therefore which he hath said "who shall" endure he saith thus: We ourselves of our own selves should not be able to endure those persecutions, unless He gave strength.

[66:147] "The nations shall be troubled".

[66:148] At first they shall be troubled: but those mountains prepared in the strength of Christ, are they troubled? Troubled is the sea, against the mountains it dasheth: the sea breaketh, unshaken the mountains have remained.

[66:149] "The nations shall be troubled, and all men shall fear".

[66:150] Behold now all men fear: they that before have been troubled do now all fear.

[66:151] The Christians feared not, and now the Christians are feared.

[66:152] All that did persecute do now fear.

[66:153] For He hath overcome that is girded about with power, to Him hath come every flesh in such sort, that the rest by their very minority do now fear.

[66:154] And all men shall fear, that inhabit the ends of the earth, because of Thy signs.

[66:155] For miracles the Apostles wrought, and thence all the ends of the earth have feared and have believed.

[66:156] "Outgoings in morning and in evening Thou shalt delight:" that is, Thou makest delightful.

[66:157] Already in this life what is there being promised to us? There are outgoings in morning, there are outgoings in the evening.

[66:158] By the morning he signifieth the prosperity of the world, by the evening he signifieth the trouble of the world.

[66:159] At first when he was promising gain, it was morning to thee: but now evening draweth on, sad thou hast become.

[66:160] But He that hath given thee an outgoing in the morning, will give one also in the evening.

[66:161] In the same manner as thou hast contemned the morning of the world by the light of the Lord, so contemn the evening also by the sufferings of the Lord, in saying to thy soul, What more will this man do to me, than my Lord hath suffered for me? May I hold fast justice, not consent to iniquity.

[66:162] Let him vent his rage on the flesh, the trap will be broken, and I will fly to my Lord, that saith to me, "Do not fear them that kill the body, but the soul are not able to kill".

[66:163] And for the body itself He hath given security, saying, "A hair of your head shall not perish".

[66:164] Nobly here he hath set down, "Thou wilt delight outgoings in morning and in evening".

[66:165] For if thou take not delight in the very outgoing, thou wilt not labour to go out thence.

[66:166] Thou runnest thy head into the promised gain, if thou art not delighted with the promise of the Saviour.

[66:167] And again thou yieldest to one tempting and terrifying, if thou find no delight in Him that suffered before thee, in order that He might make an outgoing for thee.

[66:168] "Thou hast visited the earth, and hast inebriated it".

[66:169] Whence hast inebriated the earth? "Thy cup inebriating how glorious it is!" "Thou hast visited the earth, and hast inebriated it".

[66:170] Thou hast sent Thy clouds, they have rained down the preaching of the truth, inebriated is the earth.

[66:171] "Thou hast multiplied to enrich it".

[66:172] Whence? "The river of God is filled with water".

[66:173] What is the river of God? The people of God.

[66:174] The first people was filled with water, wherewith the rest of the earth might be watered.

[66:175] Hear Him promising water: "If any man thirst, let him come to Me and drink: he that believeth on Me, rivers of living water from his belly shall flow:" if rivers, one river also; for in respect of unity many are one.

[66:176] Many Churches and one Church, many faithful and one Bride of Christ: so many rivers and one river.

[66:177] Many Israelites believed, and were fulfilled with the Holy Spirit; from thence they were scattered abroad through the nations, they began to preach the truth, and from the river of God that was filled with water, was the whole earth watered.

[66:178] "Thou hast prepared food for them: because thus is Thy preparing".

[66:179] Not because they have deserved of Thee, whom Thou hast forgiven sins: the merits of them were evil, but Thou for Thy mercy's sake, "because thus is Thy preparing," thus "Thou hast prepared food for them".

[66:180] "The furrows thereof inebriate Thou".

[66:181] Let there be made therefore at first furrows to be inebriated: let the hardness of our breast be opened with the share of the word of God, "The furrows thereof inebriate Thou: multiply the generations thereof".

[66:182] We see, they believe, and by them believing other men believe, and because of those others believe; and it is not sufficient for one man, that having become himself a believer, he should gain one.

[66:183] So is multiplied seed too: a few grains are scattered, and fields spring up.

[66:184] "In the drops thereof it shall rejoice, when it shall rise up".

[66:185] That is, before it be perchance enlarged to the bulk of a river, "when it shall rise up, in its drops," that is, in those meet for it, "it shall rejoice".

[66:186] For upon those that are yet babes, and upon the weak, are dropped some portions of the sacraments, because they cannot receive the fulness of the truth.

[66:187] Hear in what manner he droppeth upon babes, while they are rising up, that is, in their recent rising having small capacities: the Apostle saith, "To you I could not speak as if to spiritual, but as if to carnal, as if to babes in Christ".

[66:188] When he saith, "to babes in Christ," he speaketh of them as already risen up, but not yet meet to receive that plenteous wisdom, whereof he saith, "Wisdom we speak among perfect men".

[66:189] Let it rejoice in its drops, while it is rising up and is growing, when strengthened it shall receive wisdom also: in the same manner as an infant is fed with milk, and becometh fit for meat, and nevertheless at first out of that very meat for which it was not fit, for it milk is made.

[66:190] "Thou shalt bless the crown of the year of Thy goodness".

[66:191] Seed is now sowing, that which is sown is growing, there will be the harvest too.

[66:192] And now over the seed the enemy hath sown tares; and there have risen up evil ones among the good, false Christians, having like leaf, but not like fruit.

[66:193] For those are properly called tares, which spring up in the manner of wheat, for instance darnel, for instance wild oats, and all such as have the first leaf the same.

[66:194] Therefore of the sowing of the tares thus saith the Lord: "There hath come an enemy, and hath sown over them tares;" but what hath he done to the grain? The wheat is not choked by the tares, nay, through endurance of the tares the fruit of the wheat is increased.

[66:195] For the Lord Himself said to certain workmen desiring to root up the tares, "Suffer ye both to grow unto the harvest".

[66:196] Conquer the devil, and thou wilt have a crown.

[66:197] "Thou shalt bless the crown of the year of Thy goodness".

[66:198] Again he maketh reference to the goodness of God, lest any one boast of his own merits.

[66:199] "Thy plains shall be filled with abundance".

[66:200] "The ends of the desert shall grow fat, and the hills shall be encircled with exultation".

[66:201] Plains, hills, ends of the desert, the same are also men.

[66:202] Plains, because of the equality: because of equality, I say, from thence just peoples have been called plains.

[66:203] Hills, because of lifting up: because God doth lift up in Himself those that humble themselves.

[66:204] Ends of the desert are all nations.

[66:205] Wherefore ends of the desert? Deserted they were, to them no Prophet had been sent: they were in like case as is a desert where no man passeth by.

[66:206] No word of God was sent to the nations: to the people Israel alone the Prophets preached.

[66:207] We came to the Lord; the wheat believed among that same people of the Jews.

[66:208] For He said at that time to the disciples, "Ye say, far off is the harvest: look back, and see how white are the lands to harvest".

[66:209] There hath been therefore a first harvest, there will be a second in the last age.

[66:210] The first harvest was of Jews, because there were sent to them Prophets proclaiming a coming Saviour.

[66:211] Therefore the Lord said to His disciples, "See how white are the lands to harvest:"  the lands, to wit, of Judaea.

[66:212] "Other men," He saith, "have laboured, and into their labours ye have entered".

[66:213] The Prophets laboured to sow, and ye with the sickle have entered into their labours.

[66:214] There hath been finished therefore the first harvest, and thence, with that very wheat which then was purged, hath been sown the round world; so that there ariseth an other harvest, which at the end is to be reaped.

[66:215] In the second harvest have been sown tares, now here there is labour.

[66:216] Just as in that first harvest the Prophets laboured until the Lord came: so in that second harvest the Apostles laboured, and all preachers of the truth labour, even until at the end the Lord send unto the harvest His Angels.

[66:217] Aforetime, I say, a desert there was, "but the ends of the desert shall grow fat".

[66:218] Behold where the Prophets had given no sound, the Lord of the Prophets hath been received, "The ends of the desert shall grow fat, and with exultation the hills shall be encircled".

[66:219] "Clothed have been the rams of the sheep" : "with exultation" must be understood.

[66:220] For with what exultation the hills are encircled, with the same are clothed the rams of the sheep.

[66:221] Rams are the very same as hills.

[66:222] For hills they are because of more eminent grace; rams, because they are leaders of the flocks.

[66:223] "They shall shout:" thence they shall abound with wheat, because they shall shout.

[66:224] What shall they shout? "For a hymn they shall say".

[66:225] For one thing it is to shout against God, another thing to say a hymn; one thing to shout iniquities, another thing to shout the praises of God.

[66:226] If thou shout in blasphemy, thorns thou hast brought forth: if thou shoutest in a hymn, thou aboundest in wheat.

[67:1] Psalm LXVI.

[67:2] This Psalm hath on the title the inscription, "For the end, a song of a Psalm of Resurrection".

[67:3] When ye hear "for the end," whenever the Psalms are repeated, understand it "for Christ:" the Apostle saying, "For the end of the law is Christ, for righteousness to every one believing".

[67:4] In what manner therefore here Resurrection is sung, ye wilt hear, and whose Resurrection it is, as far as Himself deigneth to give and disclose.

[67:5] For the Resurrection we Christians know already hath come to pass in our Head, and in the members it is to be.

[67:6] The Head of the Church is Christ, the members of Christ are the Church.

[67:7] That which hath preceded in the Head, will follow in the Body.

[67:8] This is our hope; for this we believe, for this we endure and persevere amid so great perverseness of this world, hope comforting us, before that hope becometh reality.

[67:9] The Jews did hold the hope of the resurrection of the dead: and they hoped that themselves alone would rise again to a blessed life because of the work of the Law, and because of the justifications of the Scriptures, which the Jews alone had, and the Gentiles had not.

[67:10] Crucified was Christ, "blindness in part happened unto Israel, in order that the fulness of the Gentiles might enter in:" as the Apostle saith.

[67:11] The resurrection of the dead beginneth to be promised  to the Gentiles also that believe in Jesus Christ, that He hath risen again.

[67:12] Thence this Psalm is against the presumption and pride of the Jews, for the comfort of the Gentiles that are to be called to the same hope of resurrection.

[67:13] Thence he beginneth, "Be joyful in God".

[67:14] Who? "Every land".

[67:15] Not therefore Judaea alone.

[67:16] See, brethren, after what sort is set forth the universality of the Church in the whole world spread abroad: and mourn ye not only the Jews, who envied the Gentiles that grace, but still more for heretics wail ye.

[67:17] For if they are to be mourned, that have not been gathered together, how much more they that being gathered together have been divided? "Jubilate in God every land".

[67:18] What is "jubilate"? Into the voice of rejoicings break forth if ye cannot into that of words.

[67:19] For "jubilation" is not of words, but the sound alone of men rejoicing is uttered, as of a heart labouring and bringing forth into voice the pleasure of a thing imagined which cannot be expressed.

[67:20] "Be joyful in God every land:" let no one jubilate in a part: let every land be joyful, let the Catholic Church jubilate.

[67:21] The Catholic Church embraceth the whole: whosoever holdeth a part and from the whole is cut off, should howl, not jubilate.

[67:22] "But play ye to His name".

[67:23] What hath he said? By you "playing" let His name be blessed.

[67:24] But what it is to "play"? To play is also to take up an instrument which is called a psaltery, and by the striking and action of the hands to accompany voices.

[67:25] If therefore ye jubilate so that God may hear; play also something that men may both see and hear: but not to your own name.

[67:26] For if for the sake of yourselves being glorified ye do good works, we make the same reply as He made to certain of such men, "Verily I say unto you, they have received their reward:" and again, "Otherwise no reward ye will have with your Father that is in Heaven".

[67:27] Thou wilt say, ought I, then, to hide my works, that I do them not before men? No.

[67:28] But what saith He? "Let your works shine before men".

[67:29] In doubt then I shall remain.

[67:30] On one side Thou sayest to me, "Take heed that ye do not your righteousness before men:" on the other side Thou sayest to me, "Let your good works shine before men;" what shall I keep? what do? what leave undone? A man can as well serve two masters commanding different things as one commanding different things.

[67:31] I command not, saith the Lord, different things.

[67:32] The end observe, for the end sing: with what end thou doest it, see thou.

[67:33] If for this reason thou doest it, that thou mayest be glorified, I have forbidden it: but if for this reason, that God may be glorified, I have commanded it.

[67:34] Play therefore, not to your own name, but to the name of the Lord your God.

[67:35] Play ye, let Him be lauded: live ye well, let Him be glorified.

[67:36] For whence have ye that same living well? If for everlasting ye had had it, ye would never have lived ill; if from yourselves ye had had it, ye never would have done otherwise than have lived well.

[67:37] "Give glory to His praise".

[67:38] Our whole attention upon the praise of God he directeth, nothing for us he leaveth whence we should be praised.

[67:39] Let us glory thence the more, and rejoice: to Him let us cleave, in Him let us be praised.

[67:40] Ye heard when the Apostle was being read, "See ye your calling, brethren, how not many wise after the flesh, not many mighty, not many noble, but the foolish things of the world God hath chosen to confound the wise".

[67:41] But the Lord chose afterwards orators also; but they would have been proud, if He had not first chosen fishermen; He chose rich men; but they would have said that on account of their riches they had been chosen, unless at first He had chosen poor men: He chose Emperors afterwards; but better is it, that when an Emperor hath come to Rome, he should lay aside his crown, and weep at the monument of a fisherman, than that a fisherman should weep at the monument of an Emperor.

[67:42] "For the weak things of the world God hath chosen to confound the strong," etcAnd what followeth? The Apostle hath concluded, "That there might not glory before God any flesh".

[67:43] See ye how from us He hath taken away, that He might give glory: hath taken away ours, that He might give His own; hath taken away empty, that He might give full; hath taken away insecure, that He might give solid.

[67:44] "Say ye to God, How to be feared are Thy works!".

[67:45] Wherefore to be feared and not to be loved? Hear thou another voice of a Psalm: "Serve ye the Lord in fear, and exult unto Him with trembling".

[67:46] What meaneth this? Hear the voice of the Apostle: "With fear," he saith, "and trembling, your own salvation work ye out".

[67:47] Wherefore with fear and trembling? He hath subjoined the reason: "for God it is that worketh in you both to will and to work according to good will".

[67:48] If therefore God worketh in thee, by the Grace of God thou workest well, not by thy strength.

[67:49] Therefore if thou rejoicest, fear also: lest perchance that which was given to a humble man be taken away from a proud one.

[67:50] Brethren, if against the Jews of old, cut off from the root of the Patriarchs, we ought not to exalt ourselves, but rather to fear and say to God, "How to be feared are Thy works:" how much less ought we not to exalt ourselves against the fresh wounds of the cutting off! Before there had been cut off Jews, graffed in Gentiles; from the very graft there have been cut off heretics; but neither against them ought we to exalt ourselves; lest perchance he deserve to be cut off, that delighteth to revile them that are cut off.

[67:51] My brethren, a bishop's voice, however unworthy, hath sounded to you: we pray you to beware, whosoever ye are in the Church, do not revile them that are not within; but pray ye rather, that they too may be within.

[67:52] For God is able again to graft them in Of the very Jews the Apostle said this, and it was done in their case.

[67:53] The Lord rose again, and many believed: they perceived not when they crucified, nevertheless afterwards they believed in Him, and there was forgiven them so great a transgression.

[67:54] The shedding of the Lord's blood was forgiven the manslayers, not to say, God-slayers: "for if they had known, the Lord of glory they never would have crucified".

[67:55] Now to the manslayers hath been forgiven the shedding of the blood of Him innocent: and that same blood which through madness they shed, through grace they have drunk.

[67:56] O fulness of Gentiles, say thou to God, "How to be feared are Thy works!" and so rejoice thou as that thou mayest fear, be not exalted above the branches cut off.

[67:57] "In the multitude of thy power Thine enemies shall lie to Thee".

[67:58] For this purpose he saith, "to Thee thine enemies shall lie," in order that great may be Thy power.

[67:59] What is this? With more attention hearken.

[67:60] The power of  our Lord Jesus Christ most chiefly appeared in the Resurrection, from whence this Psalm hath received its title.

[67:61] And rising again, He appeared to His disciples He appeared not to His enemies, but to His disciples.

[67:62] Crucified He appeared to all men, rising again to believers: so that afterwards also he that would might believe, and to him that should believe, resurrection might be promised.

[67:63] Many holy men wrought many miracles; no one of them when dead did rise again: because even they that by them were raised to life, were raised to life to die.

[67:64] Because therefore the Jews might say, when the Lord did miracles, Moses hath done these things, Elias hath done, Eliseus hath done them: they might for themselves say these words, because those men also did raise to life dead men, and did many miracles: therefore when from Him a sign was demanded, of the peculiar sign making mention which in Himself alone was to be, He saith, "This generation crooked and provoking seeketh a sign, and a sign shall not be given to it, except the sign of Jonas the Prophet: for as Jonas was in the belly of the whale three days and three nights, so shall be also the Son of Man in the heart of the earth three days and three nights".

[67:65] In what way was Jonas in the belly of the whale? Was it not so that afterwards alive he was vomited out? Hell was to the Lord what the whale was to Jonas.

[67:66] This sign peculiar to Himself He mentioned, this is the most mighty sign.

[67:67] It is more mighty to live again after having been dead, than not to have been dead.

[67:68] The greatness of the power of the Lord as He was made Man, in the virtue of the Resurrection doth appear.

[67:69] Observe also the very lie of the false witnesses in the Gospel, and see how it is about Resurrection.

[67:70] For when to the Lord had been said, "What sign showest Thou to us, that Thou doest these things?" besides that which He had spoken about Jonah through another similitude of this same thing also He spake, that ye might know this peculiar sign had been especially pointed out: "Destroy this Temple," He saith, "and in three days I will raise it up".

[67:71] And they said, "In forty and six years was builded this temple, and wilt Thou in three days raise it up?" And the evangelist explaining what it was, "But this," he saith, "spake Jesus of the Temple of His Body".

[67:72] Behold this His power He said He would show to men in the same thing as that from whence He had given the similitude of a Temple, because of His flesh, which was the Temple of the Divinity hidden within.

[67:73] Whence the Jews outwardly saw the Temple, the Deity dwelling within they saw not.

[67:74] Out of those words of the Lord false witnesses made up a lie to say against Him, out of those very words wherein He mentioned His future Resurrection, in speaking of the Temple.

[67:75] For false witnesses, when they were asked what they had heard Him say, alleged against Him: "We heard Him saying, I will destroy this Temple, and after three days I will raise it up".

[67:76] "After three days I will raise up," they had heard: "I will destroy," they had not heard: but had heard "destroy ye".

[67:77] One word they changed and a few letters, in order to support their false testimony.

[67:78] But for whom changest thou a word, O human vanity, O human weakness? For the Word, the Unchangeable, dost thou change a word? Thou changest thy word, dost thou change God's Word?Wherefore said they that Thou hadst said, "I will destroy;" and said not that which Thou saidest, "destroy ye"? It was, as it were, in order that they might defend themselves from the charge of destroying the Temple without cause.

[67:79] For Christ, because He willed it, died: and nevertheless ye killed Him.

[67:80] Behold we grant you, O ye liars, Himself destroyed the Temple.

[67:81] For it hath been said by the Apostle, "That loved me, and gave up Himself for me".

[67:82] It hath been said of the Father, "That His own Son spared not, but gave Him up for us all".

[67:83] By all means be it that Himself destroyed the Temple, Himself destroyed that said, "Power I have to lay down My Soul, and power I have again to take it: no one taketh it from Me, but I Myself lay it down from Me, and again I take it".

[67:84] Be it that Himself hath destroyed the Temple in His Grace, in your malice.

[67:85] "In the multitude of Thy power thine enemies shall lie to Thee".

[67:86] Behold they lie, behold they are believed, behold Thou art oppressed, behold Thou art crucified, behold Thou art insulted, behold head is wagged at Thee, "If Son of God He is, let Him come down from the Cross".

[67:87] Behold when Thou wilt, life Thou layest down, and with lance in the side art pierced, and Sacraments from Thy side flow forth; Thou art taken down from the Tree, wound in linens, laid in the sepulchre, there are set guards lest Thy disciples take Thee away; there cometh the hour of Thy Resurrection, earth is shaken, tombs are cloven, Thou risest again in secret, appearest openly.

[67:88] Where then are those liars? Where is the false testimony of evil will? Have not Thine enemies in the multitude of Thy power lied to Thee?.

[67:89] Give them also those guards at the Tomb, let them recount what they have seen, let them take money and lie tooThey too were added to the lie of the enemies: increased was the number of liars, that increased might be the reward of believers.

[67:90] Therefore they lied, "in the multitude of Thy power" they lied: to confound liars Thou hast appeared to men of truth, and Thou hast appeared to those men of truth whom Thou hast made men of truth.

[67:91] Let Jews remain in their lies: to Thee, because in the multitude of Thy power they lied, let there be done that which followeth, "Let every land worship Thee, and play to Thee, play to Thy name, O Most Highest".

[67:92] A little before, Most Lowly, now Most Highest: Most Lowly in the hands of lying enemies; Most Highest above the head of praising Angels.

[67:93] O ye Gentiles, O most distant nations, leave lying Jews, come confessing.

[67:94] "Come ye, and see the works of the Lord: terrible in counsels above the sons of men".

[67:95] Son of Man indeed He too hath been called, and verily Son of Man He became: very Son of God in the form of God; very Son of Man in form of a servant: but do not judge of that form by the condition of others alike: "terrible" He is "in counsels above the sons of men".

[67:96] Sons of men took counsel to crucify Christ, being crucified He blinded the crucifiers.

[67:97] What then have ye done, sons of men, by taking keen counsels against your Lord, in whom was hidden Majesty, and to sight shown weakness? Ye were taking counsels to destroy, He to blind and save; to blind proud men, to save humble men: but to blind those same proud men, to the end that, being blinded they might be humbled, being humbled might confess, having confessed might be enlightened.

[67:98] "Terrible in counsels above the sons of men".

[67:99] Terrible indeed.

[67:100] Behold blindness in part to Israel hath happened: behold the Jews, out of whom was born Christ, are without: behold the Gentiles, that were against Judaea, in Christ are within.

[67:101] "Terrible in counsels above the sons of men".

[67:102] Wherefore what hath He done by the terror of His counsel? He hath turned the sea into dry land.

[67:103] For this followeth, "That hath turned the sea into dry land".

[67:104] A sea was the world, bitter with saltness, troubled with tempest, raging with waves of persecutions, sea it was: truly into dry land the sea hath been turned, now there thirsteth for sweet water the world that with salt water was filled.

[67:105] Who hath done this? He "that hath turned the sea into dry land".

[67:106] Now the soul of all the Gentiles saith what? "My soul is as it were land without water to Thee".

[67:107] "That hath turned the sea into dry land.

[67:108] In the river they shall pass over on foot".

[67:109] Those same persons that have been turned into dry land, though they were before sea, "in the river on foot shall pass over".

[67:110] What is the river? The river is all the mortality of the world.

[67:111] Observe a river: some things come and pass by, other things that are to pass by do succeed.

[67:112] Is it not thus with the water of a river, that from earth springeth and floweth? Every one that is born must needs give place to one going to be born: and all this order of things rolling along is a kind of river.

[67:113] Into this river let not the soul greedily throw herself, let her not throw herself, but let her stand still.

[67:114] And how shall she pass over the pleasures of things doomed to perish? Let her believe in Christ, and she will pass over on foot: she passeth over with Him for Leader, on foot she passeth over.

[67:115] "There we will be joyous in Him".

[67:116] O ye Jews, of your own works boast ye: lay aside the pride of boasting of yourselves, take up the Grace of being joyous in Christ.

[67:117] For therein we will be joyous, but not in ourselves: "there we will be joyous in Him".

[67:118] When shall we joy? When we shall have passed over the river on foot.

[67:119] Life everlasting is promised, resurrection is promised, there our flesh no longer shall be a river: for a river it is now, while it is mortality.

[67:120] Observe whether there standeth still any age.

[67:121] Boys desire to grow up; and they know not how by succeeding years the span of their life is lessened.

[67:122] For years are not added to but taken from them as they grow: just as the water of a river alway draweth near, but from the source it withdraweth.

[67:123] And boys desire to grow up that they may escape the thraldom of elders; behold they grow up, it cometh to pass quickly, they arrive at youth: let them that have emerged from boyhood retain, if they are able, their youth: that too passeth away.

[67:124] Old age succeedeth: let even old age be everlasting; with death it is removed.

[67:125] Therefore a river there is of flesh that is born.

[67:126] This river of mortality, so that it doth not by reason of concupiscence of things mortal undermine and carry him away, he easily passeth over, that humbly, that is on foot, passeth over, He being leader that first hath passed over, that of the flood in the way even unto death hath drunk, and therefore hath lifted up the head Passing over therefore on foot that river, that is, easily passing over that mortality that glideth along, "there we will be joyous in Him".

[67:127] But now in what save in Him, or in the hope of Him? For even if we are joyous now, in hope we are joyous; but then in Him we shall be joyous.

[67:128] And now in Him, but through hope: "but then face to face".

[67:129] "There we will be joyous in Him".

[67:130] In whom? "In Him that reigneth in His virtue for everlasting".

[67:131] For what virtue have we and is it everlasting? If everlasting were our virtue, we should not have slipped, should not have fallen into sin, we should not have deserved penal mortality.

[67:132] He, of His good pleasure, took up that whereunto our desert threw us down "That reigneth in His virtue for everlasting".

[67:133] Of Him partakers let us be made, in whose virtue we shall be strong, but He in His own.

[67:134] We enlightened, He a light enlightening: we, being turned away from Him, are in darkness; turned away from Himself He cannot be.

[67:135] With the heat of Him we are warmed; from whence withdrawing we had grown cold, to the Same drawing near again we are warmed.

[67:136] Therefore let us speak to Him that He may keep us in His virtue, because "in Him we will be joyous that reigneth in His virtue for everlasting".

[67:137] But this thing is not granted to believing Jews alone.

[67:138] "The eyes of Him do look upon the Gentiles".

[67:139] And what do we? The Jews will murmur; the Jews will say, "what He hath given to us, the same to them also; to us Gospel, to them Gospel; to us the Grace of Resurrection, and to them the Grace of Resurrection; doth it profit us nothing that we have received the Law, and that in the justifications of the Law we have lived, and have kept the commandments of the fathers? Nothing will it avail? The same to them as to us".

[67:140] Let them not strive, let them not dispute.

[67:141] "Let not them that are bitter be exalted in their own selves".

[67:142] O flesh miserable and wasting, art thou not sinful? Why crieth out thy tongue? Let the conscience be listened to.

[67:143] "For all men have sinned, and need the glory of God".

[67:144] Know thyself, human weakness.

[67:145] Thou didst receive the Law, in order that a transgressor also of the Law thou mightest be: for thou hast not kept and fulfilled that which thou didst receive.

[67:146] There hath come to thee because of the Law, not the justification which the Law enjoineth, but the transgression which thou hast done.

[67:147] If therefore there hath abounded sin, why enviest thou Grace more abounding.

[67:148] Be not bitter, for "let not them that are bitter be exalted in their own selves".

[67:149] He seemeth in a manner to have uttered a curse in "Let not them that are bitter be exalted;" yea, be they exalted, but not "in themselves".

[67:150] Let them be humbled in themselves, exalted in Christ.

[67:151] For, "he that humbleth himself shall be exalted; and he that exalteth himself shall be humbled".

[67:152] "Let not them that are bitter be exalted in their own selves".

[67:153] "Bless our God, ye nations".

[67:154] Behold, there have been driven back they that are bitter, reckoning hath been made with them: some have been converted, some have continued proud.

[67:155] Let not them terrify you that grudge the Gentiles Gospel Grace: now hath come the Seed of Abraham, in whom are blessed all nations Bless ye Him in whom ye are blessed, "Bless our God, ye nations: and hear ye the voice of His praise".

[67:156] Praise not yourselves, but praise Him.

[67:157] What is the voice of His praise? That by His Grace we are whatever of good we are.

[67:158] "Who hath set my Soul unto life"  Behold the voice of his praise: "Who hath set my Soul unto life".

[67:159] Therefore in death she was: in death she was, in thyself.

[67:160] Thence it is that ye ought not to have been exalted in yourselves.

[67:161] Therefore in death she was, in thyself: where will it be in life, save in Him that said, "I am the Way, the Truth, and the Life"? Just as to certain believers the Apostle saith, "Ye were sometime darkness, but now light in the Lord".

[67:162] "And hath not given unto motion my feet".

[67:163] He hath set my Soul unto life, He guideth the feet that they stumble not, be not moved and given unto motion; He maketh us to live, He maketh us to persevere even unto the end, in order that for everlasting we may live.

[67:164] "For thou hast proved us, O God; Thou hast fired us as silver is fired".

[67:165] Hast not fired us like hay, but like silver: by applying to us fire, Thou hast not turned us into ashes, but Thou hast washed off uncleanness, "Thou hast fired us, as silver is fired".

[67:166] And see in what manner God is wroth against them, whose Soul He hath set unto life.

[67:167] "Thou hast led us into a trap:" not that we might be caught and die, but that we might be tried and delivered from it.

[67:168] "Thou hast laid tribulations upon our back".

[67:169] For having been to ill purpose lifted up, proud we were: having been to ill purpose lifted up, we were bowed down, in order that being bowed down, we should be lifted up for good.

[67:170] "Thou hast laid tribulations on our back:" "Thou hast set men over our heads".

[67:171] All these things the Church hath suffered in sundry and divers persecutions: She hath suffered this in Her individual members, even now doth suffer it.

[67:172] For there is not one, that in this life could say that he was exempt from these trials.

[67:173] Therefore there are set even men over our heads: we endure those whom we would not, we suffer for our betters those whom we know to be worse.

[67:174] But if sins be wanting, a man is justly superior: but by how much there are more sins, by so much he is inferior.

[67:175] And it is a good thing to consider ourselves to be sinners, and thus endure men set over our heads: in order that we also to God may confess that deservedly we suffer.

[67:176] For why dost thou suffer with indignation that which He doeth who is just? "Thou hast laid tribulations upon our back: Thou hast set men over our heads".

[67:177] God seemeth to be wroth, when He doeth these things: fear not, for a Father He is, He is never so wroth as to destroy.

[67:178] When ill thou livest, if He spareth, He is more angry.

[67:179] In a word, these tribulations are the rods of Him correcting, lest there be a sentence from Him punishing.

[67:180] "We have passed through fire and water".

[67:181] Fire and water are both dangerous in this life.

[67:182] Certainly water seemeth to extinguish fire, and fire seemeth to dry up water.

[67:183] Thus also these are the trials, wherein aboundeth this life.

[67:184] Fire burneth, water corrupteth: both must be feared, both the burning of tribulation and the water of corruption.

[67:185] Whenever there is adversity, and anything which is called unhappiness in this world, there is as it were fire: whenever there is prosperity, and the world's plenty floweth about one, there is as it were water.

[67:186] See that fire burn thee not, nor water corrupt.

[67:187] Hasten not to the water: through fire pass over to the water, that thou mayest pass over the water also.

[67:188] Therefore also in the mystic rites and in catechising and in exorcising, there is first used fire.

[67:189] For whence ofttimes do the unclean spirits cry out, "I burn," if that is not fire? But after the fire of Exorcism we come to Baptism: so that from fire to water, from water unto refreshment.

[67:190] But as in the Sacraments, so it is in the temptations of this world: the straitness of fear draweth near first, in place of fire; afterwards fear being removed, we ought to be afraid lest worldly happiness corrupt.

[67:191] But when the fire hath not made thee burst, and when thou hast not sunk in the water, but hast swum out; through discipline thou passest over to rest, and passing over through fire and water, thou art led forth into a place of refreshment.

[67:192] For of those things whereof the signs are in the Sacraments, there are the very realities in that perfection of life everlasting.

[67:193] But we are not torpid there, but we rest: nor though it be called heat, shall we be hot there, but we shall be fervent in spirit.

[67:194] Observe that same heat in another Psalm: "nor is there any one that hideth himself from the heat thereof".

[67:195] What saith also the Apostle? "In spirit fervent".

[67:196] Therefore, "we have gone over through fire and water: and Thou hast led us forth into a cool place".

[67:197] Observe how not only concerning a cool place, but neither of that very fire to be desired he hath been silent: "I will enter into Thy House in holocausts".

[67:198] What is a holocaust? A whole sacrifice burned up, but with fire divine.

[67:199] For a sacrifice is called a holocaust, when the whole is burned.

[67:200] One thing are the parts of sacrifices, another thing a holocaust: when the whole is burned and the whole consumed by fire divine, it is called a holocaust: when a part, a sacrifice.

[67:201] Every holocaust indeed is a sacrifice: but not every sacrifice a holocaust.

[67:202] Holocausts therefore he is promising, the Body of Christ is speaking, the Unity of Christ is speaking, "I will enter into Thy House in holocausts".

[67:203] All that is mine let Thy fire consume, let nothing of mine remain to me, let all be Thine.

[67:204] But this shall be in the Resurrection of just men, "when both this corruptible shall be clad in incorruption, and this mortal shall be clad in immortality: then shall come to pass that which hath been written, 'Death is swallowed up in victory.

[67:205] '" Victory is, as it were, fire divine: when it swalloweth up our death also, it is a holocaust.

[67:206] There remaineth not anything mortal in the flesh, there remaineth not anything culpable in the spirit: the whole of mortal life shall be consumed, in order that in life everlasting it may be consummated, that from death we may be preserved in life These therefore will be the holocausts.

[67:207] And what shall there be "in the holocausts"?.

[67:208] "I will render to Thee my vows, which my lips have distinguished".

[67:209] What is the distinction in vows? This is the distinction, that thyself thou censure, Him thou praise: perceive thyself to be a creature, Him the Creator: thyself darkness, Him the Enlightener, to whom thou shouldest say, "Thou shalt light my lamp, O Lord my God, Thou shalt enlighten my darkness".

[67:210] For whenever thou shalt have said, O soul, that from thyself thou hast light, thou wilt not distinguish.

[67:211] If thou wilt not distinguish, thou wilt not render distinct vows.

[67:212] Render distinct vows, confess thyself changeable, Him unchangeable: confess thyself without Him to be nothing, but Himself without thee to be perfect; thyself to need Him, but Him not to need thee.

[67:213] Cry to Him, "I have said to the Lord, My God art Thou, for my good things Thou needest not".

[67:214] Now though God taketh thee to Him for a holocaust, He groweth not, He is not increased, He is not richer, He becometh not better furnished: whatsoever He maketh of thee for thy sake, is the better for thee, not for Him that maketh.

[67:215] If thou distinguishest these things, thou renderest the vows to thy God which thy lips have distinguished.

[67:216] "And my mouth hath spoken in my tribulation".

[67:217] How sweet ofttimes is tribulation, how necessary! In that case what hath the mouth of the same spoken in his tribulation? "Holocausts marrowed I will offer to Thee".

[67:218] What is "marrowed"? Within may I keep Thy love, it shall not be on the surface, in my marrow it shall be that I love Thee.

[67:219] For there is nothing more inward than our marrow: the bones are more inward than the flesh, the marrow is more inward than those same bones.

[67:220] Whosoever therefore on the surface loveth God, desireth rather to please men, but having some other affection within, he offereth not holocausts of marrow: but into whosesoever marrow He looketh, him He receiveth whole.

[67:221] "With incense and rams".

[67:222] The rams are the rulers of the Church: the whole Body of Christ is speaking: this is the thing which he offereth to God.

[67:223] Incense  is what? Prayer.

[67:224] "With incense and rams".

[67:225] For especially the rams do pray for the flocks.

[67:226] "I will offer to Thee oxen with he-goats".

[67:227] Oxen we find treading out corn, and the same are offered to God.

[67:228] The Apostle hath said, that of the preachers of the Gospel must be understood that which hath been written, "Of the ox treading out corn the mouth thou shalt not muzzle.

[67:229] Doth God care for oxen?" Therefore great are those rams, great the oxen.

[67:230] What of the rest, that perchance are conscious of certain sins, that perchance in the very road have slipped, and, having been wounded, by penitence are being healed? Shall they too continue, and to the holocausts shall they not belong? Let them not fear, he hath added he-goats also.

[67:231] "I will offer to Thee oxen with he-goats".

[67:232] By the very yoking are saved the he-goats; of themselves they have no strength, being yoked to bulls they are accepted.

[67:233] For they have made friends of the mammon of iniquity, that the same may receive them into everlasting tabernacles Therefore those he-goats shall not be on the left, because they have made to themselves friends of the mammon of iniquity.

[67:234] But what he-goats shall be on the left? They to whom shall be said, "I hungred, and ye gave me not to eat:" not they that have redeemed their sins by almsdeeds.

[67:235] Come ye, hear, and I will tell, all ye that fear God".

[67:236] Let us come, let us hear, what he is going to tell, "Come ye, hear, and I will tell".

[67:237] But to whom, "Come ye, and hear"? "All ye that fear God".

[67:238] If God ye fear not, I will not tell.

[67:239] It is not possible that it be told to any where the fear of God is not.

[67:240] Let the fear of God open the ears, that there may be something to enter in, and a way whereby may enter in that which I am going to tell.

[67:241] But what is he going to tell? "How great things He hath done to my soul".

[67:242] Behold, he would tell: but what is he going to tell? Is it perchance how widely the earth is spread, how much the sky is extended, and how many are the stars, and what are the changes of sun and of moon? This creation fulfilleth its course: but they have very curiously sought it out, the Creator thereof have not known This thing hear, this thing receive, "O ye that fear God, how great things He hath done to my soul:" if ye will, to yours also.

[67:243] "How great things He hath done to my soul".

[67:244] "To Him with my mouth I have cried".

[67:245] "And this very thing, he saith, hath been done to his soul; that to Him with his mouth he should cry, hath been done, he saith, to his soul.

[67:246] Behold, brethren, Gentiles we were, even if not in ourselves, in our parents.

[67:247] And what saith the Apostle? "Ye know, when Gentiles ye were, to idols without speech how ye went up, being led".

[67:248] Let the Church now say, "how great things He hath done to my soul".

[67:249] "To Him with my mouth I have cried".

[67:250] I a man to a stone was crying, to a deaf stock I was crying, to idols deaf and dumb I was speaking: now the image of God hath been turned to the Creator thereof.

[67:251] I that was "saying to a stock, My father thou art; and to a stone, Thou hast begotten me:" now say, "Our Father, which art in Heaven".

[67:252] "To Him with my mouth I have cried, and I have exalted Him under my tongue".

[67:253] See how in secret He would be uncorrupt that offereth marrowed holocausts.

[67:254] This do ye, brethren, this imitate, so that ye may say, "Come ye, see how great things He hath done to my soul".

[67:255] For all those things of which he telleth, by His Grace are done in our soul.

[67:256] See the other things of which he speaketh.

[67:257] "If I have beheld iniquity in my heart, may not the Lord hearken".

[67:258] Consider now, brethren, how easily, how daily men blushing for fear of men do censure iniquities; He hath done ill, He hath done basely, a villain the fellow is: this perchance for man's sake he saith.

[67:259] See whether thou beholdest no iniquity in thy heart, whether perchance that which thou censurest in another, thou art meditating to do, and therefore against him dost exclaim, not because he hath done it, but because he hath been found out.

[67:260] Return to thyself, within be to thyself a judge.

[67:261] Behold in thy hid chamber, in the very inmost recess of the heart, where thou and He that seeth are alone, there let iniquity be displeasing to thee, in order that thou mayest be pleasing to God.

[67:262] Do not regard it, that is, do not love it, but rather despise it, that is, contemn it, and turn away from it.

[67:263] Whatever pleasing thing it hath promised to allure thee to sin; whatever grievous thing it hath threatened, to drive thee on to evil doing; all is nought, all passeth away: it is worthy to be despised, in order that it may be trampled upon; not to be eyed lest it be accepted.

[67:264] "Therefore God hath hearkened to me".

[67:265] Because I have not beheld iniquity in my heart.

[67:266] "And He hath listened to the voice of my prayer".

[67:267] "Blessed be my God, that hath not thrust away my supplication and His mercy from me".

[67:268] Gather the sense from that place, where he saith, "Come ye, hear, and I will tell you, all ye that fear God, how great things He hath done to my soul:" he hath both said the words which ye have heard, and at the end thus he hath concluded: "Blessed be my God, that hath not thrust away my supplication and His mercy from me".

[67:269] For thus there arriveth at the Resurrection he that speaketh, where already we also are by hope: yea both it is we ourselves, and this voice is ours.

[67:270] So long therefore as here we are, this let us ask of God, that He thrust not from us our supplication, and His mercy, that is, that we pray continually, and He continually pity.

[67:271] For many become feeble in praying, and in the newness of their own conversion pray fervently, afterwards feebly, afterwards coldly, afterwards negligently: as if they have become secure.

[67:272] The foe watcheth: thou sleepest.

[67:273] The Lord Himself hath given commandment in the Gospel, how "it behoveth men always to pray and not to faint".

[67:274] And he giveth a comparison from that unjust judge, who neither feared God, nor regarded man, whom that widow daily importuned to hear her; and he yielded for weariness, that was not influenced by pity: and the naughty judge saith to himself, "Though neither God I fear, nor men I regard, even because of the weariness which this widow daily putteth upon me, I will hear her cause, and will avenge her".

[67:275] And the Lord saith, "If a naughty judge hath done this, shall not your Father avenge His chosen, that to Him do cry day and night? Yea, I say unto you, He shall make judgment of them speedily".

[67:276] Therefore let us not faint in prayer.

[67:277] Though He putteth off what He is going to grant, He putteth it not away: being secure of His promise, let us not faint in praying, and this is by His goodness.

[67:278] Therefore he hath said, "Blessed is my God, that hath not thrust away my supplication and His mercy from me".

[67:279] When thou hast seen thy supplication "not thrust away from thee," be secure, that His mercy hath not been thrust away from thee.

[68:1] Psalm LXVII.

[68:2] Your Love remembereth, that in two Psalms, which have been already treated of, we have stirred up our soul to bless the Lord, and with godly chant have said, "Bless thou, O my soul, the Lord ".

[68:3] If therefore we have stirred up our soul in those Psalms to bless the Lord, in this Psalm is well said, "May God have pity on us, and bless us".

[68:4] Let our soul bless the Lord, and let God bless us.

[68:5] When God blesseth us, we grow, and when we bless the Lord, we grow, to us both are profitable.

[68:6] He is not increased by our blessing, nor is He lessened by our cursing.

[68:7] He that curseth the Lord, is himself lessened: he that blesseth the Lord, is himself increased.

[68:8] First, there is in us the blessing of the Lord, and the consequence is that we also bless the Lord.

[68:9] That is the rain, this the fruit.

[68:10] Therefore there is rendered as it were fruit to God the Husbandman, raining upon and tilling us.

[68:11] Let us chant these words with no barren devotion, with no empty voice, but with true heart.

[68:12] For most evidently God the Father hath been called a Husbandman The Apostle saith, "God's husbandry ye are, God's building ye are".

[68:13] In things visible of this world, the vine is not a building, and a building is not a vineyard: but we are the vineyard of the Lord, because He tilleth us for fruit; the building of God we are, since He who tilleth us, dwelleth in us.

[68:14] And what saith the same Apostle? "I have planted, Apollos hath watered, but the increase God hath given.

[68:15] Therefore neither he that planteth is anything, nor he that watereth, but He that giveth the increase, even God".

[68:16] He it is therefore that giveth the increase.

[68:17] Are those perchance the husbandmen? For a husbandman he is called that planteth, that watereth: but the Apostle hath said, "I have planted, Apollos hath watered".

[68:18] Do we enquire whence himself hath done this? The Apostle maketh answer, "Yet not I, but the Grace of God with me".

[68:19] Therefore whithersoever thou turn thee, whether through Angels, thou wilt find God thy Husbandman; whether through Prophets, the Same is thy Husbandman; whether through Apostles, the very Same acknowledge to be thy Husbandman.

[68:20] What then of us? Perchance we are the labourers of that Husbandman, and this too with powers imparted by Himself, and by Grace granted by Himself.

[68:21] "Lighten His countenance upon us".

[68:22] Thou wast perchance going to enquire, what is "bless us"? In many ways men would have themselves to be blessed of God: one would have himself to be blessed, so that he may have a house full of the necessary things of this life; another desireth himself to be blessed, so that he may obtain soundness of body without flaw; another would have himself to be blessed, if perchance he is sick, so that he may acquire soundness; another longing for sons, and perchance being sorrowful because none are born, would have himself to be blessed so that he may have posterity.

[68:23] And who could number the divers wishes of men desiring themselves to be blessed of the Lord God? But which of us would say, that it was no blessing of God, if either husbandry should bring him fruit, or if any man's house should abound in plenty of things temporal, or if the very bodily health be either so maintained that it be not lost, or, if lost, be regained?.

[68:24] "Every soul that is blessed is simple," not cleaving to things earthly nor with glued wings grovelling, but beaming with the brightness of virtues, on the twin wings of twin love doth spring into the free air; and seeth how from her is withdrawn that whereon she was treading, not that whereon she was resting, and she saith securely, "The Lord hath given, the Lord hath taken away; as it hath pleased the Lord, so hath been done: be the name of the Lord blessed".

[68:25] But let not perchance any weak man say, when shall I be of so great virtue, as was holy Job? The mightiness of the tree thou wonderest at, because but now thou hast been born: this great tree, whereat thou wonderest, under the branches and shade whereof thou coolest thyself, hath been a switch.

[68:26] But dost thou fear lest there be taken away from thee these things, when such thou shalt have become? Observe that they are taken away from evil men also.

[68:27] Why therefore dost thou delay conversion? That which thou fearest when good to lose, perchance if evil thou wilt lose still.

[68:28] If being good thou shalt have lost them, there is by thee the Comforter that hath taken them away: the coffer is emptied of gold; the heart is full of faith: without, poor thou art, but within, rich thou art: thy riches with thee thou carriest, which thou wouldest not lose, even if naked from shipwreck thou shouldest escape.

[68:29] Why doth not the loss, that perchance, if evil, thou wilt lose, find thee good; forasmuch as thou seest evil men also suffer loss? But with greater loss they are stricken: empty is the house, more empty the conscience is.

[68:30] Whatsoever evil man shall have lost these things, hath nothing to hold by without, hath nothing within whereon he may rest.

[68:31] He fleeth when he hath suffered loss from the place where before the eyes of men with the display of riches he used to vaunt himself; now in the eyes of men to vaunt himself he is not able: to himself within he returneth not, because he hath nothing.

[68:32] He hath not imitated the ant, he hath not gathered to himself grains, while it was summer What have I meant by, while it was summer? While he had quietude of life, while he had this world's prosperity, when he had leisure, when happy he was being called by all men, his summer it was.

[68:33] He should have imitated the ant, he should have heard the Word of God, he should have gathered together grains, and he should have stored them within.

[68:34] There had come the trial of tribulation, there had come upon him a winter of numbness, tempest of fear, the cold of sorrow, whether it were loss, or any danger to his safety, or any bereavement of his family; or any dishonour and humiliation; it was winter; the ant falleth back upon that which in summer she hath gathered together; and within in her secret store, where no man seeth, she is recruited by her summer toils.

[68:35] When for herself she was gathering together these stores in summer, all men saw her: when on these she feedeth in winter, no one seeth.

[68:36] What is this? See the ant of God, he riseth day by day, he hasteneth to the Church of God, he prayeth, he heareth lection, he chanteth hymn, he digesteth that which he hath heard, with himself he thinketh thereon, he storeth within grains gathered from the threshing-floor.

[68:37] They that providently hear those very things which even now are being spoken of, do thus, and by all men are seen to go forth to the Church, go back from Church, to hear sermon, to hear lection, to choose a book, open and read it: all these things are seen, when they are done.

[68:38] That ant is treading his path, carrying and storing up in the sight of men seeing him.

[68:39] There cometh winter sometime, for to whom cometh it not? There chanceth loss, there chanceth bereavement: other men pity him perchance as being miserable, who know not what the ant hath within to eat, and they say, miserable he whom this hath befallen, or what spirits, dost thou think, hath he whom this hath befallen? how afflicted is he? He measureth by himself, hath compassion according to his own strength; and thus he is deceived: because the measure wherewith he measureth himself, he would apply to him whom he knoweth not.

[68:40] O sluggard, gather in summer while thou art able; winter will not suffer thee to gather, but to eat that which thou shalt have gathered.

[68:41] For how many men so suffer tribulation, that there is no opportunity either to read anything, or to hear anything, and they obtain no admittance, perchance, to those that would comfort them.

[68:42] The ant hath remained in her nest, let her see if she hath gathered anything in summer, whereby she may recruit herself in winter.

[68:43] There is a double interpretation, both must be given: "lighten," he saith, "Thy face upon us," show to us Thy countenance.

[68:44] For God doth not ever light His countenance, as if ever it had been without light: but He lighteth it upon us, so that what was hidden from us, is opened to us, and that which was, but to us was hidden, is unveiled upon us, that is, is lightened.

[68:45] Or else surely it is, "Thy image lighten upon us:" so that he said this, in "lighten Thy countenance upon us:" Thou hast imprinted Thy countenance upon us; Thou hast made us after Thine image and Thy likeness, Thou hast made us Thy coin; but Thine image ought not in darkness to remain: send a ray of Thy wisdom, let it dispel our darkness, and let there shine in us Thy image; let us know ourselves to be Thine image, let us hear what hath been said in the Song of Songs, "If Thou shalt not have known Thyself, O Thou fair one among women".

[68:46] For there is said to the Church, "If Thou shalt not have known Thyself".

[68:47] What is this? If Thou shalt not have known Thyself to have been made after the image of God.

[68:48] O Soul of the Church, precious, redeemed with the blood of the Lamb immaculate, observe of how great value Thou art, think what hath been given for Thee.

[68:49] Let us say, therefore, and let us long that He "may lighten His face upon us".

[68:50] We wear His face: in like manner as the faces of emperors are spoken of, truly a kind of sacred face is that of God in His own image: but unrighteous men know not in themselves the image of God.

[68:51] In order that the countenance of God may be lightened upon them, they ought to say what? "Thou shalt light my candle, O Lord my God, Thou shalt light my darkness".

[68:52] I am in the darkness of sins, but by the ray of Thy wisdom dispelled be my darkness, may Thy countenance appear; and if perchance through me it appeareth somewhat deformed, by Thee be there reformed that which by Thee hath been formed.

[68:53] "That we may know on earth Thy way".

[68:54] "On earth," here, in this life, "we may know Thy way".

[68:55] What is, "Thy way"? That which leadeth to Thee.

[68:56] May we acknowledge whither we are going, acknowledge where we are as we go; neither in darkness we can do.

[68:57] Afar Thou art from men sojourning, a way to us Thou hast presented, through which we must return to Thee.

[68:58] "Let us acknowledge on earth Thy way".

[68:59] What is His way wherein we have desired, "That we may know on earth Thy way"? We are going to enquire this ourselves, not of ourselves to learn it.

[68:60] We can learn of it from the Gospel: "I am the Way," the Lord saith: Christ hath said, "I am the Way".

[68:61] But dost thou fear lest thou stray? He hath added, "And the Truth".

[68:62] Who strayeth in the Truth? He strayeth that hath departed from the Truth.

[68:63] The Truth is Christ, the Way is Christ: walk therein.

[68:64] Dost thou fear lest thou die before thou attain unto Him? "I am the Life: I am," He saith, "the Way and the Truth and the Life".

[68:65] As if He were saying, "What fearest thou? Through Me thou walkest, to Me thou walkest, in Me thou restest".

[68:66] What therefore meaneth , "We may know on earth Thy Way," but "we may know on earth Thy Christ"? But let the Psalm itself reply: lest ye think that out of other Scriptures there must be adduced testimony, which perchance is here wanting: by repetition he hath shown what signified, "That we may know on earth Thy Way:" and as if thou wast inquiring, "In what earth, what way?" "In all nations Thy Salvation".

[68:67] In what earth, thou art inquiring? Hear: "In all nations".

[68:68] What way art thou seeking? Hear: "Thy Salvation".

[68:69] Is not perchance Christ his Salvation? And what is that which the old Symeon hath said, that old man, I say, in the Gospel, preserved full of years even unto the infancy of the Word? For that old man took in his hands the Infant Word of God.

[68:70] Would He that in the womb deigned to be, disdain to be in the hands of an old man? The Same was in the womb of the virgin, as was in the hands of the old man, a weak infant both within the bowels, and in the old man's hand, to give us strength, by whom were made all things; and if all things, even His very mother.

[68:71] He came humble, He came weak, but clothed with a weakness to be changed into strength,  because "though He was crucified of weakness, yet He liveth of the virtue of God," the Apostle saith.

[68:72] He was then in the hands of an old man.

[68:73] And what saith that old man? Rejoicing that now he must be loosed from this world, seeing how in his own hand was held He by whom and in whom his Salvation was upheld; he saith what? "Now Thou lettest go," he saith, "O Lord, Thy servant in peace, for mine eyes have seen Thy Salvation".

[68:74] Therefore, "May God bless us, and have pity on us; may He lighten His countenance upon us, that we may know on earth Thy Way!" In what earth? "In all nations".

[68:75] What Way? "Thy Salvation".

[68:76] What followeth because the Salvation of God is known in all nations? "Let the peoples confess to Thee, O God" ; "confess to Thee," he saith, "all peoples".

[68:77] There standeth forth a heretic, and he saith, In Africa I have peoples: and another from another quarter, And I in Galatia have peoples.

[68:78] Thou in Africa, he in Galatia: therefore I require one that hath them everywhere.

[68:79] Ye have indeed dared to exult at that voice, when ye heard, "Let the peoples confess to Thee, O God".

[68:80] Hear the following verse, how he speaketh not of a part: "Let there confess to Thee all peoples".

[68:81] Walk ye in the Way together with all nations; walk ye in the Way together with all peoples, O sons of peace, sons of the One Catholic Church, walk ye in the Way, seeing as ye walk.

[68:82] Wayfarers do this to beguile their toil.
