[76:8] But let us understand here the voice of the Israelites in the same manner as the Apostle saith, "For I also am an Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin".

[76:9] Here therefore let us understand that whereof the Prophets have spoken, "a remnant shall be saved".

[76:10] Of the remnant therefore saved let us hear in this place the voice; in order that there may speak that Synagogue which had received the Old Testament, and was intent upon carnal promises; and by this means it came to pass that their feet were shaken.

[76:11] For in another Psalm, where too the title hath Asaph, there is said what? "How good is the God of Israel to men right in heart.

[76:12] But my feet were almost moved".

[76:13] And as if we were saying, whence were thy feet moved? "Well nigh," he saith, "my steps were overthrown, because I was jealous in the case of sinners, looking on the peace of sinners".

[76:14] For while according to the promises of God belonging to the Old Testament he was looking for earthly felicity, he observed it to abound with ungodly men; that they who worshipped not God were enriched with those things which he was looking for from God: and as though without cause he had served God, his feet tottered.

[76:15] But opportunely it hath chanced not by our own but by God's dispensation, that just now we heard out of the Gospel, that "the Law was given by Moses, Grace and Truth came by Jesus Christ".

[76:16] For if we distinguish between the two Testaments, Old and New, there are not the same Sacraments nor the same promises; nevertheless, the same commandments for the most part.

[76:17] When examined they are either all found to be the same, or there are scarce any in the Gospel which have not been spoken by the Prophets.

[76:18] The Commandments are the same, the Sacraments are not the same, the Promises are not the same.

[76:19] Let us see wherefore the commandments are the same; because according to these we ought to serve God.

[76:20] The Sacraments are not the same, for some Sacraments there are giving Salvation, others promising a Saviour.

[76:21] The Sacraments of the New Testament give Salvation, the Sacraments of the Old Testament did promise a Saviour When therefore thou hast now the things promised, why dost thou seek the things promising, having now the Saviour?God through the New Testament hath taken out of the hands of His sons those things which are like the playthings of boys, in order that He might give something more useful to them growing up, on that account must He be supposed not to have given those former things Himself.

[76:22] He gave both Himself.

[76:23] But the Law itself through Moses was given, Grace and Truth came through Jesus Christ: Grace because there is fulfilled through love that which by the letter was being enjoined, Truth because there is being rendered that which was promised.

[76:24] This thing therefore this Asaph hath understood.

[76:25] In a word, all things which to the Jews had been promised have been taken away.

[76:26] Where is their kingdom? Where the Temple? Where the Anointing? Where is Priest? Where are now the Prophets among them? From what time there came He that by the Prophets was foretold, in that nation there is now nothing of these things; now she hath lost things earthly, and not yet doth seek things Heavenly.

[76:27] Thou shouldest not therefore hold fast things earthly, although God doth bestow them.

[76:28] See ye how that in fearing to lose things earthly, the Jews slew the King of Heaven.

[76:29] And what was done to them? They lost even those very things earthly: and in the place where they slew Christ, there they were slain: and when, being unwilling to lose the land, they slew the Giver of life, that same land being slain they lost; and at that very time when they slew Him, in order that by that very time they might be admonished of the reason wherefore they suffered these things.

[76:30] For when the city of the Jews was overthrown, they were celebrating the Passover, and with many thousands of men the whole nation itself had met together for the celebration of that festival In that place God (through evil men indeed, but yet Himself good; through unjust men, but Himself just and justly) did so take vengeance upon them, that there we re slain many thousands of men, and the city itself was overthrown.

[76:31] Of this thing in this Psalm "the understanding of Asaph" doth complain, and in the very plaint the understanding as it were doth distinguish things earthly from things heavenly, doth distinguish the Old Testament from the New Testament: in order that thou mayest see through what things thou art passing, what thou shouldest look for, what to forsake, to what to cleave.

[76:32] Thus then he beginneth.

[76:33] "Wherefore hast Thou repelled us, O God, unto the end?".

[76:34] "Hast repelled unto the end," in the person of the congregation which is properly called Synagogue.

[76:35] "Wherefore hast Thou repelled us, O God, unto the end?" He censureth not, but inquireth "wherefore," for what purpose, because of what hast Thou done this? What hast Thou done? "Thou hast repelled us unto the end".

[76:36] What is, "unto the end"? Perchance even unto the end of the world.

[76:37] Hast Thou repelled us unto Christ, who is the End to every one believing?  For, "Wherefore hast Thou repelled us, O God, unto the end?" "Thy spirit hath been wroth at the sheep of Thy flock".

[76:38] Wherefore wast Thou wroth at the sheep of Thy flock, but because to things earthly we were cleaving, and the Shepherd we knew not?.

[76:39] "Remember Thou Thy congregation, which Thou hast possessed from the beginning".

[76:40] Can this by any means be the voice of the Gentiles? Hath He possessed the Gentiles from the beginning? Nay, but He hath possessed the seed of Abraham, the people of Israel even according to the flesh, born of the Patriarchs our fathers: of whom we have become the sons, not by coming out of their flesh, but by imitating their faith.

[76:41] But those, possessed by God from the beginning, what befell them? "Remember Thy congregation which Thou hast possessed from the beginning.

[76:42] Thou hast redeemed the rod of Thine inheritance".

[76:43] That same congregation of Thine, being the rod of Thine inheritance, Thou hast redeemed.

[76:44] This same congregation he hath called "the rod of the inheritance".

[76:45] Let us look back to the first thing that was done, when He willed to possess that same congregation, delivering it from Egypt, what sign He gave to Moses, when Moses said to Him, "What sign shall I give that they may believe me, that Thou hast sent me? And God saith to him, What dost thou bear in thine hand? A rod.

[76:46] Cast it on to the ground," etc What doth it intimate? For this was not done to no purpose.

[76:47] Let us inquire of the writings of God.

[76:48] To what did the serpent persuade man? To death Therefore death is from the serpent.

[76:49] If death is from the serpent, the rod in the serpent is Christ in death Therefore also when by serpents in the desert they were being bitten and being slain, the Lord commanded Moses to exalt a brazen serpent in the desert, and admonish the people that whosoever by a serpent had been bitten, should look thereupon and be made whole Thus also it was done: thus also men, bitten by serpents, were made whole of the venom by looking upon a serpent To be made whole of a serpent is a great Sacrament.

[76:50] What is it to be made whole of a serpent by looking upon a serpent? It is to be made whole of death by believing in one dead.

[76:51] And nevertheless Moses feared and fled What is it that Moses fled from that serpent? What, brethren, save that which we know to have been done in the Gospel? Christ died and the disciples feared, and withdrew from that hope wherein they had beenBut, at that time some thousands of the Jews themselves, the crucifiers of Christ, believed: and because they had been found at hand, they so believed as that they sold all that they had, and the price of their goods before the feet of the Apostles they laid Because then this thing was hidden, and the redemption of the rod of God was to be more conspicuous in the Gentiles: he explaineth of what he saith that which he hath said, "Thou hast redeemed the rod of Thine inheritance".

[76:52] This he hath said not of the Gentiles in whom it was evident.

[76:53] But of what? "Mount Sion".

[76:54] Yet even Mount Sion can be otherwise understood.

[76:55] "That one which Thou hast dwelled in the same".

[76:56] In the place where the People was aforetime, where the Temple was set up, where the Sacrifices were celebrated, where at that time were all those necessary things giving promise of Christ.

[76:57] A promise, when the thing promised is bestowed is now become superfluous.

[76:58] "Lift up Thine hand upon their pride at the end".

[76:59] As Thou didst repel us at the end, so "lift up Thine hand upon the pride of them at the end".

[76:60] The pride of whom? Of those by whom Jerusalem was overthrown.

[76:61] But by whom was it, but by the kings of the Gentiles? Well was the hand of Him lifted up upon the pride of them at the end: for they too have now known Christ.

[76:62] "For the end of the Law is Christ for righteousness to every one believing".

[76:63] How well doth he wish for them! As if angry he is speaking, and he is seeming to speak evil: and O that there would come to pass the evil which he speaketh: nay now in the name of Christ that it is coming to pass let us rejoice.

[76:64] Now they holding the sceptre are being made subject to the Word of the Cross: now is coming to pass that which was foretold, "there shall adore Him all the kings of the earth, all nations shall serve Him".

[76:65] Now on the brows of kings more precious is the sign of the Cross, than the jewel of a crown.

[76:66] "Lift up Thine hand upon the pride of them at the end.

[76:67] How great things hath the enemy of malice wrought in Thy holy places!" In those which were Thy holy places, that is, in the temple, in the priesthood, in all those sacraments which were at that time.

[76:68] In good sooth the enemy at that time wrought.

[76:69] For the Gentiles at that time who did this, were worshipping false Gods, were adoring idols, were serving demons: nevertheless they wrought many evil things on the Saints of God.

[76:70] When could they if they had not been permitted? But when would they have been permitted, unless those holy things, at first promised, were no longer necessary, when He that had promised was Himself holden? Therefore, "how great things hath the enemy of malice wrought in Thy holy places!".

[76:71] "And all they have boasted, that hate Thee".

[76:72] Observe the servants of demons, the servants of idols: such as at that time the Gentiles were, when they overthrew the temple and city of God, "and they boasted".

[76:73] "In the midst of Thy festival".

[76:74] Remember what I said, that Jerusalem was overthrown at the time when the very festival was being celebrated: at which festival they crucified the Lord.

[76:75] Gathered together they raged, gathered together they perished.

[76:76] "They have set signs, their own signs, and they have not known".

[76:77] They had signs to place there, their standards, their eagles, their own dragons, the Roman signs; or even their statues which at first in the temple they placed; or perchance "their signs" are the things which they heard from the prophets of their demons.

[76:78] "And they have not known".

[76:79] Have not known what? How "thou shouldest have had no power against Me, except it had been given thee from above".

[76:80] They knew not how that not on themselves honour was conferred, to afflict, to take, or overthrow the city, but their ungodliness was made as it were the axe of God.

[76:81] They were made the instrument of Him enraged, not so as to be the kingdom of Him pacified.

[76:82] For God doth that which a man also ofttime doth.

[76:83] Sometimes a man in a rage catcheth up a rod lying in the way, perchance any sort of stick, he smiteth therewith his son, and then throweth the stick into the fire and reserveth the inheritance for his son: so sometime God through evil men doth instruct good men, and through the temporal power of them that are to be condemned He worketh the discipline of them that are to be saved.

[76:84] For why do you suppose, brethren, that discipline was even thus inflicted upon that nation, in order that it might perish utterly? How many out of this nation did afterwards believe, how many are yet to believe? Some are chaff, others grain; over both however there cometh in the threshing-drag; but under one threshing-drag the one is broken up, the other is purged.

[76:85] How great a good hath God bestowed upon us by the evil of Judas the traitor! By the very ferocity of the Jews how great a good was bestowed upon believing Gentiles! Christ was slain in order that there might be on the Cross One for him to look to who had been stung by the serpent.

[76:86] Now let us hasten over the verses following after the destruction of Jerusalem, for the reason that they are both evident, and it doth not please me to tarry over the punishment even of enemies.

[76:87] "As if in a forest of trees with axes, they have cut down the doors thereof at once; with mattock and hammer they have thrown Her down".

[76:88] That is, conspiring together, with firm determination, "with mattock and hammer" they have thrown Her down.

[76:89] "They have burned with fire Thy Sanctuary, they have defiled on the ground the Tabernacle of Thy name".

[76:90] "They have said in their heart (the kindred of them is in one)"—Have said what? "Come ye, let us suppress the solemnities of the Lord from the land".

[76:91] "Of the Lord," hath been inserted in the person of this man, that is, in the person of Asaph.

[76:92] For they raging would not have called Him the Lord whose temple they were overthrowing.

[76:93] "Come ye, let us suppress all the solemnities of the Lord from the land".

[76:94] What of Asaph? What understanding hath Asaph in these words? What? Doth he not profit even by the discipline accorded? Is not the mind's crookedness made straight? Overthrown were all things that were at first: nowhere is there priest, nowhere Altar of the Jews, nowhere victim, nowhere Temple.

[76:95] Is there then no other thing to be acknowledged which succeeded this departing? Or indeed would this promissory sign have been taken away, unless there had come that which was being promised? Let us see therefore in this place now the understanding of Asaph, let us see if he profiteth by tribulation.

[76:96] Observe what he saith: "Our signs we have not seen, no longer is there prophet, and us He will not know as yet".

[76:97] Behold those Jews who say that they are not known as yet, that is, that they are yet in captivity, that not yet they are delivered, do yet expect Christ.

[76:98] Christ will  come, but He will come as Judge; the first time to call, afterwards to sever.

[76:99] He will come, because He hath come, and that He will come is evident; but hereafter from above He will come.

[76:100] Before thee He was, O Israel.

[76:101] Thou wast bruised because thou didst stumble against Him lying down: that thou mayest not be ground to powder, observe Him coming from above.

[76:102] For thus it was foretold by the prophet: "Whoever shall stumble upon that stone shall be bruised, and upon whomsoever it shall have come, it shall grind him to powder".

[76:103] He doth bruise when little, He shall grind to powder when great.

[76:104] Now thy signs thou seest not, now there is no prophet: and thou sayest, "and us He will not know as yet:" because yourselves know not Him as yet.

[76:105] "No longer is there a prophet; and us He will not know as yet".

[76:106] "How long, O God, shall the enemy revile?".

[76:107] Cry out as if forsaken, as if deserted: cry out like a sick man, who hast chosen rather to smite the physician than to be made whole: not as yet doth He know thee.

[76:108] See what He hath done, who doth not know thee as yet.

[76:109] For they to whom there hath been no preaching of Him, shall see; and they that have not heard shall understand: and thou yet criest out, "No longer is there a prophet, and us He will not know as yet".

[76:110] Where is thine understanding? "The adversary doth provoke Thy name at the end".

[76:111] For this purpose the adversary doth provoke Thy name at the end, that being provoked Thou mayest reprove, reproving Thou mayest know them at the end: or certainly, "at the end," in the sense of even unto the end.

[76:112] "Wherefore dost Thou turn away Thine hand, and Thy right hand from the midst of Thy bosom unto the end?".

[76:113] Again, another sign which was given to Moses.

[76:114] For in like manner as above from the rod was a sign, so also from the right hand now.

[76:115] For when that thing had been done concerning the rod, God gave a second sign: "thrust," He saith, "thine hand into thy bosom, and he thrust it: draw it forth, and he drew it forth: and it was found white," that is, unclean.

[76:116] For whiteness on the skin is leprosy, not fairness of complexion.

[76:117] For the heritage of God itself, that is, His people, being cast out became unclean.

[76:118] But what saith He to him? Draw it back into thy bosom.

[76:119] He drew it back, and it was restored to its own colour.

[76:120] When doest Thou this, saith this Asaph? How long dost Thou alienate Thy right hand from Thy bosom, so that being without unclean it remaineth? Draw it back, let it return to its colour, let it acknowledge the Saviour.

[76:121] "Wherefore dost thou turn away Thine hand, and Thy right hand from the midst of Thy bosom unto the end?" These words he crieth, being blind, not understanding, and God doeth what He doeth.

[76:122] For wherefore came Christ? "Blindness in part happened unto Israel, in order that the fulness of the Gentiles might enter in, and so all Israel might be saved".

[76:123] Therefore now, O Asaph, acknowledge that which hath gone before, in order that thou mayest at least follow, if thou wast not able to go before.

[76:124] For not in vain came Christ, or in vain was Christ slain, or in vain did the corn fall into the ground; but it fell that it might rise manifold A serpent was lifted up in the desert, in order that it might cure of the poison him that was smitten Observe what was done.

[76:125] Do not think it to be a vain thing that He came: lest He find thee evil, when He shall have come a second time.

[76:126] Asaph hath understood, because on the Title of the Psalm there is, "understanding of Asaph".

[76:127] And what saith he? "But God, our King before the worlds, hath wrought Salvation in the midst of the earth".

[76:128] On the one hand we cry, "No longer is there prophet, and us He will not know as yet:" but on the other hand, "our God, our King, who is before the worlds" (for He is Himself in the beginning of the Word by whom were made the worlds), "hath wrought Salvation in the midst of the earth".

[76:129] "God therefore, our King before the worlds," hath done what? "hath wrought Salvation in the midst of the earth:" and I am yet crying as if forsaken!Now the Gentiles are awake, and we are snoring, and as though God hath forsaken us, in dreams we are delirious.

[76:130] "He hath wrought Salvation in the midst of the earth".

[76:131] Now therefore, O Asaph, amend thyself according to thy understanding, tell us what sort of Salvation God hath wrought in the midst of the earth.

[76:132] When that earthly Salvation of yours was overthrown, what did He do, what did He promise? "Thou didst confirm in Thy virtue the sea".

[76:133] As though the nation of the Jews were as it were dry land severed from the waves, the Gentiles in their bitterness were the sea, and on all sides they washed about that land: behold, "Thou hast confirmed in Thy virtue the sea," and the land remained thirsting for Thy rain.

[76:134] "Thou hast confirmed in Thy virtue the sea, Thou hast broken in pieces the heads of dragons in the water".

[76:135] Dragons' heads, that is, demons' pride, wherewith the Gentiles were possessed, Thou hast broken in pieces upon the water: for those persons whom they were possessing, Thou by Baptism hast delivered.

[76:136] What more after the heads of dragons? For those dragons have their chief, and he is himself the first great dragon.

[76:137] And concerning him what hath He done that hath wrought Salvation in the midst of the earth? Hear: "Thou hast broken the head of the dragon".

[76:138] Of what dragon? We understand by dragons all the demons that war under the devil: what single dragon then, whose head was broken, but the devil himself ought we to understand? What with him hath He done? "Thou hast broken the head of the dragon".

[76:139] That is, the beginning of sin.

[76:140] That head is the part which received the curse, to wit that the seed of Eve should mark the head of the serpent For the Church was admonished to shun the beginning of sin.

[76:141] Which is that beginning of sin, like the head of a serpent? The beginning of all sin is pride There hath been broken therefore the head of the dragon, hath been broken pride diabolical.

[76:142] And what with him hath He done, that hath wrought Salvation in the midst of the earth? "Thou hast given him for a morsel to the Ethiopian peoples".

[76:143] What is this? How do I understand the Ethiopian peoples? How but by these all nations? And properly by black men: for Ethiopians are black.

[76:144] They are themselves called to the faith who were black; the very same indeed, so that there is said to them, "for ye were sometime darkness, but now light in the Lord".

[76:145] Thence was also that calf which the people worshipped, unbelieving, apostate, seeking the gods of the Egyptians, forsaking Him who had delivered them from the slavery of the Egyptians: whence there was enacted that great Sacrament.

[76:146] For when Moses was thus wroth with them worshipping and adoring the idol, and, inflamed with zeal for God, was punishing temporally, in order that he might terrify them to shun death everlasting; yet the head itself of the calf he cast into the fire, and ground to powder, destroyed, strawed on the water, and gave to the people to drink: so there was enacted a great Sacrament.

[76:147] O anger prophetic, and mind not perturbed but enlightened! He did what? Cast it into the fire, in order that first the form itself may be obliterated; piece by piece grind it down, in order that little by little it may be consumed: cast it into the water, give to the people to drink! What is this but that the worshippers of the devil were become the body of the same? In the same manner as men confessing Christ become the Body of Christ; so that to them is said, "but ye are the Body of Christ and the members".

[76:148] The body of the devil was to be consumed, and that too by Israelites was to be consumed.

[76:149] For out of that people were the Apostles, out of that people the first Church.

[76:150] Thus the devil is being consumed with the loss of his members.

[76:151] This was figured also in the serpent of Moses.

[76:152] For the magicians did likewise, and casting down their rods they exhibited serpents: but the serpent of Moses swallowed up the rods of all those magicians Let there be perceived therefore even now the body of the devil: this is what is coming to pass, he is being devoured by the Gentiles who have believed, he hath become meat for the Ethiopian peoples.

[76:153] This again, may be perceived in, "Thou hast given him for meat to the Ethiopian peoples," how that now all men bite him.

[76:154] What is, bite him? By reproving, blaming, accusing.

[76:155] Just as hath been said, by way of prohibition indeed, but yet the idea expressed: "but if ye bite and eat up one another, take heed that ye be not consumed of one another".

[76:156] What is, bite and eat up one another? Ye go to law with one another, ye detract from one another, ye heap revilings upon one another.

[76:157] Observe therefore now how that with these bitings the devil is being consumed.

[76:158] What man, when angry with his servant, even a heathen, would not say to him, Satan? Behold the devil given for meat.

[76:159] This saith Christian, this saith Jew, this saith heathen: him he worshippeth, and with him he curseth!.

[76:160] "Thou hast cleft the fountains and torrents" : in order that they might flow with the stream of wisdom, might flow with the riches of the faith, might water the saltness of the Gentiles, in order that they might convert all unbelievers into the sweetness of the faith by their watering.

[76:161] In some men the Word of God becometh a well of water springing up unto life eternal; but others hearing the Word, and not so keeping it as that they live well, yet not keeping silence with tongue, they become torrents.

[76:162] For they are properly called torrents which are not perennial: for sometimes also in a secondary sense torrent is used for river: as hath been said, "with the torrent of Thy pleasures Thou shalt give them to drink".

[76:163] For that torrent shall not ever be dried up.

[76:164] But torrents properly are those rivers named, which in summer fail, but with winter rains are flooded and run.

[76:165] Thou seest therefore a man sound in faith, that will persevere even unto the end, that will not forsake God in any trial; for the sake of the truth, not for the sake of falsehood and error, enduring all difficulties.

[76:166] Whence is this man so vigorous, but because the Word hath become in him a well of water springing up unto life eternal? But the other receiveth the Word, he preacheth, he is not silent, he runneth: but summer proveth whether he be fountain or torrent.

[76:167] Nevertheless through both be the earth watered, by Him who hath wrought Salvation in the midst of the earth: let the fountains overflow, let the torrents run.

[76:168] "Thou hast dried up the rivers of Etham".

[76:169] What is Etham? For the word is Hebrew.

[76:170] What is Etham interpreted? Strong, stout.

[76:171] Who is this strong and stout one, whose rivers God drieth up? Who but that very dragon? For "no one entereth into the house of a strong man that he may spoil his vessels, unless first he shall have bound fast the strong man".

[76:172] This is that strong man on his own virtue relying, and forsaking God: this is that strong man, who saith, "I will set my seat by the north, and I will be like the Most High".

[76:173] Out of that very cup of perverse strength he hath given man to drink.

[76:174] Strong they willed to be, who thought that they would be Gods by means of the forbidden food.

[76:175] Adam became strong, over whom was reproachfully said, "Behold, Adam hath become like one of us".

[76:176] As though they were strong, "to the righteousness of God they have not been made subject".

[76:177] Observe ye that a man hath put out of the way his own strength, and remained weak, needy, standing afar off, not daring even to raise his eyes to Heaven; but smiting his breast, and saying, "O Lord, merciful be Thou to me a sinner".

[76:178] Now he is weak, now he confesseth his weakness, he is not strong: dry land he is, be he watered with fountains and torrents.

[76:179] They are as yet strong who rely on their own virtue.

[76:180] Be their rivers dried up, let there be no advancement in the doctrines of the Gentiles, of wizards, of astrologers, of magic arts: for dried up are the rivers of the strong man: "Thou hast dried up the rivers of Etham".

[76:181] Let there dry up that doctrine; let minds be flooded with the Gospel of truth.

[76:182] "Thine own is the day and Thine own is the night".

[76:183] Who is ignorant of this, seeing that He hath Himself made all these things; for by the Word were made all things? To that very One Himself who hath wrought Salvation in the midst of the earth, to Him is said, "Thine own is the night".

[76:184] Something here we ought to perceive which belongeth to that very Salvation which He hath wrought in the midst of the earth.

[76:185] "Thine own is the day".

[76:186] Who are these? The spiritual.

[76:187] "And Thine own is the night".

[76:188] Who are these? The carnal.

[76:189] "Thou hast made perfect sun and moon:" the sun, spiritual men, the moon, carnal men.

[76:190] As yet carnal he is, may he not be forsaken, and may he too be made perfect.

[76:191] The sun, as it were a wise man: the moon, as it were an unwise man: Thou hast not however forsaken.

[76:192] For thus it is written, "A wise man endureth as the sun, but a foolish man as the moon is changed".

[76:193] What then? Because the sun endureth, that is, because the wise man endureth as the sun, a foolish man is changed like the moon, is one as yet carnal, as yet unwise, to be forsaken? And where is that which hath been said by the Apostle, "To the wise and unwise a debtor I am"?.

[76:194] "Thou hast made all the ends of the earth".

[76:195] Behold in what manner He hath made the ends of the earth, that hath wrought Salvation in the midst of the earth.

[76:196] "Thou hast made all the ends of the earth.

[76:197] Summer and spring Thou hast made them".

[76:198] Men fervent in the Spirit are the summer.

[76:199] Thou, I say, hast made men fervent in the Spirit: Thou hast made also the novices in the Faith, they are the "spring".

[76:200] "Summer and Spring Thou hast made them".

[76:201] They shall not glory as if they have not received: "Thou hast made them".

[76:202] "Mindful be Thou of this Thy creature".

[76:203] Of what creature of Thine? "The enemy hath reviled the Lord".

[76:204] O Asaph, grieve over thine old blindness in understanding: "the enemy hath reviled the Lord".

[76:205] It was said to Christ in His own nation, "a sinner is this Man: we know not whence He is:" we know Moses, to him spake God; this Man is a Samaritan "And the unwise people hath provoked Thy name".

[76:206] The unwise people Asaph was at that time, but not the understanding of Asaph at that time.

[76:207] What is said in the former Psalm? "As it were a beast I have become unto Thee, and I am alway with Thee:" because He went not to the gods and idols of the Gentiles.

[76:208] Although he knew not, being like a beast, yet he knew again as a man.

[76:209] For he said, "alway I am with Thee, like a beast:" and what afterwards in that place in the same Psalm, where Asaph is? "Thou hast held the hand of my right hand, in Thy will Thou hast conducted me, and with glory Thou hast taken me up".

[76:210] In Thy will, not in my righteousness: by Thy gift, not by my work.

[76:211] Therefore here also, "the enemy hath reviled the Lord: and the unwise people hath provoked Thy name".

[76:212] Have they all then perished? Far be it.

[76:213] For even the Apostle Paul through unbelief had been broken, and through faith unto the root he was restored.

[76:214] So evidently "the unwise people provoked Thy name," when it was said, "If Son of God He is let Him come down from the Cross".

[76:215] But what sayest thou, O Asaph, now in understanding? "Deliver not to the beasts a soul confessing to Thee".

[76:216] To what beasts, save to those the heads whereof were broken in pieces upon the water? For the same devil is called, beast, lion, and dragon.

[76:217] Do not, he saith, give to the Devil and his Angels a soul confessing to Thee.

[76:218] Let the serpent devour, if still I mind things earthly, if for things earthly I long, if still in the promises of the Old Testament, after the revealing of the New, I remain.

[76:219] But forasmuch as now I have laid down pride, and my own righteousness I will not acknowledge, but Thy Grace; against me let proud beasts have no power.

[76:220] "The souls of Thy poor forget Thou not unto the end".

[76:221] Rich we were, strong we were: but Thou hast dried up the rivers of Etham: no longer we establish our own righteousness, but we acknowledge Thy Grace; poor we are, hearken to Thy beggars.

[76:222] Now we do not dare to lift our eyes to Heaven, but smiting our breasts we say, "O Lord, be Thou merciful to me a sinner".

[76:223] "Have regard unto Thy Testament".

[76:224] Fulfil that which Thou hast promised: the tables we have, for the inheritance we are looking.

[76:225] "Have regard unto Thy Testament," not that old one: not for the sake of the land of Canaan I ask, not for the sake of the temporal subduing of enemies, not for the sake of carnal fruitfulness of sons, not for the sake of earthly riches, not for the sake of temporal welfare: "Have regard unto Thy Testament," wherein Thou hast promised the kingdom of Heaven.

[76:226] Now I acknowledge Thy Testament: now understanding is Asaph, no beast is Asaph, now he seeth that which was spoken of, "Behold, the days come, saith the Lord, and I will accomplish with the House of Israel and of Juda a new Testament, not after the Testament which I ordered with their Fathers".

[76:227] "Have regard unto Thy Testament: for they that have been darkened have been filled of the earth of unrighteous houses:" because they had unrighteous hearts.

[76:228] Our "houses" are our hearts: therein gladly dwell they that are blessed with pure heart "Have regard," therefore, "unto Thy Testament:" and let the remnant be saved: for many men that give heed to earth are darkened, and filled with earth.

[76:229] For there hath entered into their eyes dust, and it hath blinded them, and they have become dust which the wind sweepeth from the face of the earth "They that have been darkened have been filled of the earth of unrighteous houses".

[76:230] For by giving heed to earth they have been darkened, concerning whom there is said in another Psalm, "Let their eyes be blinded, that they see not, and their back ever bow Thou down".

[76:231] With earth, then, "they that have been darkened have been filled, with the earth of unrighteous houses:" because they have unrighteous hearts.

[76:232] "Let not the humble man be turned away confounded".

[76:233] For them pride hath confounded.

[76:234] "The needy and helpless man shall praise Thy name".

[76:235] Ye see, brethren, how sweet ought to be poverty: ye see that poor and helpless men belong to God, but "poor in spirit, for of them is the Kingdom of Heaven".

[76:236] Who are the poor in spirit? The humble, men trembling at the words of God, confessing their sins, neither on their own merits, nor on their own righteousness relying.

[76:237] Who are the poor in spirit? They who when they do anything of good, praise God, when anything of evil, accuse themselves.

[76:238] "Upon whom shall rest My Spirit," saith the Prophet, "but upon the humble man, and peaceful, and trembling at My words?" Now therefore Asaph hath understood, now to the earth he adhereth not, now the earthly promises out of the Old Testament he requireth not.

[76:239] "Arise, O Lord, judge Thou my cause".

[76:240] Because I am not able to show my God, as if I were following an empty thing, they revile me.

[76:241] And not only Heathen, or Jew, or heretic; but sometimes even a Catholic brother doth make a grimace when the promises of God are being preached, when a future resurrection is being foretold And still even he, though already washed with the water of eternal Salvation, bearing the Sacrament of Christ, perchance saith, "and what man hath yet risen again?" And, "I have not heard my father speaking out of the grave, since I buried him!" "God hath given to His servants a law for time, to which let them betake themselves: for what man cometh back from beneath?" And what shall I do with such men? Shall I show them what they see not? I am not able: for not for the sake of them ought God to become visible.

[76:242] I see not, he saith: what am I to believe? Thy soul is seen then, I suppose? Fool, thy body is seen: thy soul who doth see? Since therefore thy body alone is seen, why art thou not buried? He marvelleth that I have said, If body alone is seen, why art thou not buried? And he answereth (for he knoweth as much as this), Because I am alive.

[76:243] How know I that thou art alive, of whom I see not the soul? How know I? Thou wilt answer, Because I speak, because I walk, because I work.

[76:244] Fool, by the operations of the body I know thee to be living, by the works of creation canst thou not know the Creator? And perchance he that saith, when I shall be dead, afterwards I shall be nothing; hath both learned letters, and hath learned this doctrine from Epicurus, who was a sort of doting philosopher, or rather lover of folly not of wisdom, whom even the philosophers themselves have named the hog: who said that the "chief good" was pleasure of body; this philosopher they have named the hog, wallowing in carnal mire.

[76:245] From him perchance this lettered man hath learned to say, I shall not be, after I have died.

[76:246] Dried be the rivers of Etham! Perish those doctrines of the Gentiles, flourish the plantations of Jerusalem! Let them see what they can, in heart believe what they cannot see! Certainly all those things which throughout the world now are seen, when God was working Salvation in the midst of the earth, when those things were being spoken of, they were not then as yet: and behold at that time they were foretold, now they are shown as fulfilled, and still the fool saith in his heart, "there is no God".

[76:247] Woe to the perverse hearts: for so will there come to pass the things which remain, as there have come to pass the things which at that time were not, and were being foretold as to come to pass.

[76:248] Hath God indeed performed to us all the things which He promised, and concerning the Day of Judgment alone hath He deceived us? Christ was not on the earth; He promised, He hath performed: no virgin had conceived; He promised, He hath performed: the precious Blood had not been shed whereby there should be effaced the handwriting of our death; He promised, He hath performed: not yet had flesh risen again unto life eternal; He promised, He hath performed: not yet had the Gentiles believed; He promised, He hath performed: not yet heretics armed with the name of Christ, against Christ were warring; He foretold, He hath performed: not yet the idols of the Gentiles from the earth had been effaced; He foretold, He hath performed: when all these things He hath foretold and performed, concerning the Day of Judgment alone hath He lied? It will come by all means as these things came; for even these things before they came to pass were future, and as future were first foretold, and afterwards they came to pass.

[76:249] It will come, my brethren.

[76:250] Let no one say, it will not come: or, it will come, but far off is that which will come.

[76:251] But to thyself it is near at hand to go hence.

[76:252] If thou shalt have done that which the devil doth suggest, and shalt have despised that which God hath commanded; there will come the Judgment Day, and thou wilt find that true which God hath threatened, and that false which the devil hath promised.

[76:253] "Remember Thy reproaches, those which are from the imprudent man all the day long".

[76:254] For still Christ is reviled: nor will there be wanting all the day long, that is, even unto the end of time, the vessels of wrath.

[76:255] Still is it being said, "Vain things the Christians do preach:" still is it being said, "A fond thing is the resurrection of the dead".

[76:256] "Remember Thy reproaches".

[76:257] But what reproaches, save those "which are from the imprudent man all the day long?" Doth a prudent man say this? Nay, for a prudent man is said to be one far-seeing.

[76:258] If a prudent man is one far-seeing, by faith he seeth afar: for with eyes scarce that before the feet is seen.

[76:259] "Forget not the voice of them that implore Thee".

[76:260] While they groan for and expect now that which Thou hast promised from the New Testament, and walk by that same Faith, "do Thou not forget the voice of them imploring Thee".

[76:261] But those still say, "Where is Thy God? Let the pride of them that hate Thee come up always to Thee".

[76:262] Do not forget even their pride.

[76:263] Nor doth He forget: no doubt He doth either punish or amend.

[77:1] Psalm LXXV.

[77:2] The Title of this Psalm thus speaketh: "At the end, corrupt not".

[77:3] What is, "corrupt not?" That which Thou hast promised, perform.

[77:4] But when? "At the end".

[77:5] To this then let the mind's eye be directed, "unto the end".

[77:6] Let all the things which have occurred in the way be passed over, in order that we may attain to the end.

[77:7] Let proud men exult because of present felicity, let them swell with honours, glitter in gold, overflow with domestics, be encircled with the services of clients: these things pass away, they pass away like a shadow.

[77:8] When that end shall have come, when all who now hope in the Lord are to rejoice, then to them shall come sorrow without end.

[77:9] When the meek shall have received that which the proud deride, then the vapouring of the proud shall be turned into mourning.

[77:10] Then shall there be that voice which we know in the Book of Wisdom: for they shall say at that time when they see the glory of the Saints, who, when they were in humiliation, endured them; who, when they were exalted, consented not—at that time then they shall say, "These are they whom sometime we have had in derision".

[77:11] Where they also say, "What hath pride profited us, and the boasting of riches hath bestowed upon us what?" All things have passed away like a shadow.

[77:12] Because on things corruptible they relied, their hope shall be corrupted: but our own hope at that time shall be substance.

[77:13] For in order that the promise of God may remain whole and sure and certain towards us, we have said out of a heart of faith, "at the end corrupt not".

[77:14] Fear not, therefore, lest any mighty man should corrupt the promises of God.

[77:15] He doth not corrupt, because He is truthful; He hath no one more mighty by whom His promise may be corrupted: let us  be then sure concerning the promises of God; and let us sing now from the place where the Psalm beginneth.

[77:16] "We will confess to Thee, O Lord, we will confess to Thee, and will invoke Thy name".

[77:17] Do not invoke, before thou confess: confess, and invoke.

[77:18] For Him whom thou art invoking, unto thyself thou callest.

[77:19] For what is it to invoke, but unto thyself to call? If He is invoked by thee, that is, if He is called to thee, unto whom doth He draw near? To a proud man He draweth not near.

[77:20] High indeed He is, one lifted up attaineth not unto Him.

[77:21] In order that we may reach all exalted objects, we raise ourselves, and if we are not able to reach them, we look for some appliances or ladders, in order that being exalted we may reach exalted objects: contrariwise God is both high, and by the lowly He is reached.

[77:22] It is written, "Nigh is the Lord to them that have bruised the heart".

[77:23] The bruising of the heart is Godliness, humility.

[77:24] He that bruiseth himself is angry with himself.

[77:25] Let him make himself angry in order that he may make Him merciful; let him make himself judge, in order that he may make Him Advocate.

[77:26] Therefore God doth come when invoked.

[77:27] Unto whom doth He come? To the proud man He cometh not.

[77:28] Take heed therefore what ye do: for if He knoweth, He is not unobservant It is better therefore that He be unobservant than known.

[77:29] For what is that same being unobservant, but not knowing? What is, not to know? Not to animadvert.

[77:30] For even as the act of one avenging animadversion is wont to be spoken of.

[77:31] Here one praying that He be unobservant: "Turn away Thy face from my sins".

[77:32] What then wilt thou do if He shall have turned away His face from thee? A grievous thing it is, and to be feared, lest He forsake thee.

[77:33] Again, if He turn not away His face, He animadverteth.

[77:34] God knoweth this thing, God can do this thing, namely, both turn away face from one sinning, and not turn away from one confessing.

[77:35] Confess therefore and invoke.

[77:36] For by confessing thou purgest the Temple, into which He may come, when invoked.

[77:37] Confess and invoke.

[77:38] May He turn away face from thy sins, not turn away from thee: turn away face from that which thou hast wrought, not turn away from that which He hath Himself wrought For thee, as man, He hath Himself wrought, thy sins thou hast thyself wrought.

[77:39] But that there is a strengthening of the sense in repetition, by many passages of the Scriptures we are taught.

[77:40] Thence is that which the Lord saith, "Verily, Verily".

[77:41] Thence in certain Psalms is, "So be it, So be it".

[77:42] To signify the thing, one "So be it" would have been sufficient: to signify confirmation, there hath been added another "So be it".

[77:43] Countless passages of such sort there are throughout all the Scriptures.

[77:44] With these it is sufficient that we have commended to your notice a way of speaking which ye may observe in all like cases: now to the substance attend: "We will confess to Thee," he saith, "and we will invoke".

[77:45] I have said why before invocation confession doth precede: because whom thou dost invoke, him thou dost invite.

[77:46] But he willeth not to come when invoked, if thou shalt have been lifted up: lifted up if thou shalt have been, thou wilt not be able to confess.

[77:47] And thou deniest not any things to God that He knoweth not.

[77:48] Therefore thy confession doth not teach Him, but it purgeth thee.

[77:49] Hear ye now the words of Christ.

[77:50] For these seemed not as it were to be His words, "We will confess to Thee, O God, we will confess to Thee, and will invoke Thy name".

[77:51] Now beginneth the discourse in the person of the Head.

[77:52] But whether Head speaketh or whether members speak, Christ speaketh: He speaketh in the person of the Head, He speaketh in the person of the Body.

[77:53] But what hath been said? There shall be two in one flesh "This is a great Sacrament:" "I," he saith, "speak in Christ and in the Church".

[77:54] And He Himself in the Gospel, "Therefore no longer two, but one flesh".

[77:55] For in order that ye may know these in a manner to be two persons, and again one by the bond of marriage, as one He speaketh in Isaiah, and saith, "As upon a Bridegroom he hath bound upon me a mitre, and as a Bride he hath clothed me with an ornament".

[77:56] A Bridegroom He hath called Himself in the Head, a Bride in the Body.

[77:57] He is speaking therefore as One, let us hear Him, and in Him let us also speak.

[77:58] Let us be the members of Him, in order that this voice may possibly be ours also.

[77:59] "I will tell forth," he saith, "all Thy marvellous things".

[77:60] Christ is preaching Himself, He is preaching Himself even in His members now existing, in order that He may guide unto Him others, and they may draw near that were not, and may be united with those members of Him, through which members of Him the Gospel hath been preached; and there may be made one Body under one Head, in one Spirit, in one Life.

[77:61] And he saith what? "When I shall have received," he saith, "the time, I will judge justices".

[77:62] When shall He judge justices? When He shall have received the time.

[77:63] Not yet is the precise time.

[77:64] Thanks to His mercy: He first preacheth justices, and then He judgeth justices.

[77:65] For if He willed to judge before He willed to preach, who would be found that should be delivered: who would meet Him that should be absolved? Now therefore is the time of preaching: "I will tell," he saith, "all Thy marvellous works".

[77:66] Hear Him telling, hear Him preaching: for if thou shalt have despised Him, "when I shall have received the time," He saith, "I will judge justices".

[77:67] I forgive, He saith, now sins to one confessing, I will not spare hereafter one despising.

[77:68] He hath received a time as Son of Man; He doth govern times as Son of God.

[77:69] Hear how as Son of Man He hath received the time of judging.

[77:70] He saith in the Gospel, "He hath given to Him power to execute judgment, because Son of Man He is".

[77:71] According to His nature as Son of God, He hath never received power of judging, because He never lacked the power of judging: according to His nature as Son of Man He hath received a time, as of being born, and of suffering, as of dying, and of rising again, and of ascending, so of coming and of judging.

[77:72] In Him His Body also saith these words, for not without them He will judge.

[77:73] For He saith in the Gospel, "Ye shall sit upon twelve thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel".

[77:74] Therefore whole Christ saith, that is, Head and Body in the Saints, "when I shall have received the time, I will judge justices".

[77:75] But now what? "The earth hath flowed down".

[77:76] If the earth hath flowed down, whence hath it flowed down except by sins? Therefore also they are called delinquencies.

[77:77] To delinquish is as it were by a kind of liquidity to slip down from the stability of firmness in virtue and righteousness.

[77:78] For it is through desire of lower things that every man sinneth: as he is strengthened by the love of higher things, so he falleth down and as it were melteth away by desire of lower things.

[77:79] This flux of things by the sins of man the merciful forgiver observing, being a merciful forgiver of sins, not yet an exactor of punishments, He observeth and saith: The earth herself indeed hath flowed down by them that dwell in her.

[77:80] That which followeth is an exposition, not an addition.

[77:81] As though thou wert saying, in what manner hath the earth flowed down? Have the foundations been withdrawn, and hath anything therein been swallowed up in a sort of gulf? What I mean by earth is all they that dwell therein.

[77:82] I have found, he saith, the earth sinful.

[77:83] And I have done what? "I have strengthened the pillars thereof".

[77:84] What are the pillars which He hath strengthened? Pillars He hath called the Apostles.

[77:85] So the Apostle Paul concerning his fellow-Apostles saith, "who seemed to be pillars".

[77:86] And what would those pillars have been, except by Him they had been strengthened? For on occasion of a sort of earthquake even these very pillars rocked: at the Passion of the Lord all the Apostles despaired.

[77:87] Therefore those pillars which rocked at the Passion of the Lord, by the Resurrection were strengthened.

[77:88] The Beginning of the building hath cried out through the pillars thereof, and in all those pillars the Architect Himself hath cried out.

[77:89] For the Apostle Paul was one pillar of them when he said, "Would ye receive a proof of Him that speaketh in me—Christ?" Therefore, "I," he saith, "have strengthened the pillars thereof:" I have risen again, I have shown that death is not to be feared, I have shown to them that fear, that not even the body itself doth perish in the dying.

[77:90] There terrified them wounds, there strengthened them scars.

[77:91] The Lord Jesus could have risen again without any scar: for what great matter were it for that power, to restore the frame of the body to such perfect soundness, as that no trace at all of past wound should appear? He had power whence He might make it whole even without scar: but He willed to have that whereby He might strengthen the rocking pillars.

[77:92] We have heard now, brethren, that which day by day is not kept secret: let us hear now what He hath cried through these pillars.

[77:93] He crieth what? "I have said to unjust men, Do not unjustly".

[77:94] But already they have done, and they are guilty: already there hath flowed down the earth, and all they that dwell therein.

[77:95] Pricked to the heart were they that crucified Christ, they acknowledged their sin, they learned something of the Apostle, that they might not despair of the pardon of the Preacher For as Physician He had come, and therefore had not come to the whole.

[77:96] "For there is no need," He saith, "to the whole of a physician, but to them that are sick.

[77:97] I have not come to call righteous men, but sinners to repentance".

[77:98] Therefore, "I have said to unjust men, Do not unjustly".

[77:99] They heard not.

[77:100] For of old to us it was spoken: we heard not, we fell, were made mortal, were begotten mortal: the earth flowed down.

[77:101] Let them hear the Physician even now in order that they may rise, Him that came to the sick man, Him whom they would not hear when whole in order that they might not fall, let them hear when lying down in order that they may rise.

[77:102] "I have said to unjust men, Do not unjustly; and to the delinquent, Do not exalt your horn".

[77:103] There shall be exalted in you the horn of Christ, if your horn be not exalted.

[77:104] Your horn is of iniquity, the horn of Christ is of majesty.

[77:105] "Be not therefore lifted up: speak not iniquity against God".

[77:106] What saith He in another Psalm? "These things thou hast done," having enumerated certain sins.

[77:107] "These things thou hast done," He saith, "and was silent".

[77:108] What is, "I was silent"? He is never silent with commandment, but meanwhile He is silent with punishment: He is keeping still from vengeance, He doth not pronounce sentence against the condemned.

[77:109] But this man saith thus, I have done such and such things, and God hath not taken vengeance; behold I am whole, nought of ill hath befallen me.

[77:110] "These things thou hast done, and I was silent: thou hast suspected iniquity, that I shall be like unto thee".

[77:111] What is, "that I shall be like unto thee"? Because thou art unjust, even Me thou hast deemed unjust; as though an approver of thy misdeeds, and no adversary, no avenger thereof.

[77:112] And what afterwards saith He to thee? "I will convict thee, and will set thee before thine own face"? What is this? Because now by sinning behind thy back thou settest thyself, seest not thyself, examinest not thyself; I will set thee before thyself, and will bring upon thee punishment from thyself.

[77:113] So also here, "Speak not iniquity against God".

[77:114] Attend.

[77:115] Many men speak this iniquity; but dare not openly, lest as blasphemers they be abhorred by godly men: in their heart they gnaw upon these things, within they feed upon such impious food; it delighteth them to speak against G od, and if they break not out with tongue, in heart they are not silent.

[77:116] Whence in another Psalm is said, "The fool hath said in his heart, There is no God".

[77:117] The fool hath said, but he hath feared men: he would not say it where men might hear; and he said it in that pl ace where He might Himself hear concerning whom he said it.

[77:118] Therefore here also in this Psalm (dearly beloved attend), whereas that which He said, "Do not speak iniquity against God," this He saw many men do in heart, He hath also added, "for neither from East, nor from West, nor from the deserts of the mountains , for God is Judge".

[77:119] Of thine iniquities God is Judge.

[77:120] If God He is, everywhere He is present.

[77:121] Whither wilt thou take thyself away from the eyes of God, so that in some quarter thou mayest speak that which He may not hear? If from the East God judgeth, withdraw into the West, and say what thou wilt against God: if from the West, go into the East, and there speak: if from the deserts of the mountains He judgeth, go into the midst of the peoples, where thou mayest murmur to thyself.

[77:122] From no place judgeth He that everywhere is secret, everywhere open; whom it is allowed no one to know as He is, and whom no one is permitted not to know.

[77:123] Take heed what thou doest.

[77:124] Thou art speaking iniquity against God.

[77:125] "The Spirit of the Lord hath filled the round world" (another Scripture saith this), "and that which containeth all things hath knowledge of the voice: wherefore he that speaketh unjust things cannot be hid".

[77:126] Do not therefore think God to be in places: He is with thee such an one as thou shalt have been.

[77:127] What is such an one as thou shalt have been? Good, if thou shalt have been good; and evil to thee He will seem, if evil thou shalt have been; but a Helper, if good thou shalt have been; an Avenger, if evil thou shalt have been.

[77:128] There thou hast a Judge in thy secret place.

[77:129] Willing to do something of evil, from the public thou retirest into thy house, where no enemy may see; from those places of thine house which are open and before the eyes of men, thou removest thyself into a chamber; thou fearest even in thy chamber some witness from some other quarter, thou retirest into thy heart, there thou meditatest: He is more inward than thy heart.

[77:130] Whithersoever therefore thou shalt have fled, there He is.

[77:131] From thyself whither wilt thou flee? Wilt thou not follow thyself whithersoever thou shalt flee? But since there is One more inward even than thyself, there is no place whither thou mayest flee from God angry, but to God reconciled.

[77:132] There is no place at all whither thou mayest flee.

[77:133] Wilt thou flee from Him? Flee to Him.

[77:134] What then shall we do now? "Let us come before His face," ἐν ἐξομολογήσει, come before in confession: He shall come gentle whom thou hadst made angry.

[77:135] "Neither from the deserts of the mountains, for God is Judge:" not from the East, not from the West, not from the deserts of the mountains.

[77:136] Wherefore? "For God is Judge".

[77:137] If in any place He were, He would not be God: but because God is Judge, not man, do not expect Him out of places.

[77:138] His place thou wilt be, if thou art good, if after having confessed thou shalt have invoked Him.

[77:139] "One He humbleth, and another He exalteth".

[77:140] Whom humbleth, whom exalteth this Judge? Observe these two men in the temple, and ye see whom He humbleth and whom He exalteth.

[77:141] "They went up into the Temple to pray," He saith, "the one a Pharisee, and the other a Publican.

[77:142] "Verily I say unto you, that Publican went down justified more than that Pharisee: for every one that exalteth himself shall be humbled; and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted".

[77:143] Thus hath been explained a verse of this Psalm.

[77:144] God the Judge doth what? "One He humbleth, and another He exalteth:" He humbleth the proud, He exalteth the humble.

[77:145] "For the cup in the hand of the Lord of pure wine is full of mixed".

[77:146] Justly so.

[77:147] "And He hath poured out of this upon this man; nevertheless, the dreg thereof hath not been emptied; there shall drink all the sinners of earth".

[77:148] Let us be somewhat recruited; there is here some obscurity.

[77:149] The first question that meeteth us is this, "of pure wine it is full of mixed".

[77:150] How "of pure," if "of mixed"? But when he saith, "the cup in the hand of the Lord" (to men instructed in the Church of Christ I am speaking), ye ought not indeed to paint in your heart God as it were circumscribed with a human form, lest, though the temples are shut up, ye forge images in your hearts.

[77:151] This cup therefore doth signify something.

[77:152] We will find out this.

[77:153] But "in the hand of the Lord," is, in the power of the Lord.

[77:154] For the hand of God is spoken of for the power of God.

[77:155] For even in reference to men ofttimes is said, in hand he hath it: that is, in his power he hath it, when he chooseth he doth it.

[77:156] "Of pure wine it is full of mixed".

[77:157] In continuation he hath himself explained: "He hath inclined," he saith, "from this unto this man; nevertheless the dreg thereof hath not been emptied".

[77:158] Behold how it was full of mixed wine.

[77:159] Let it not therefore terrify you that it is both pure and mixed: pure because of the genuineness thereof, mixed because of the dreg.

[77:160] What then in that place is the wine, and what the dreg? And what is, "He hath inclined from this unto this man," in such sort that the dreg thereof was not emptied?.

[77:161] Call ye to mind from whence he came to this: "one He humbleth, and another He exalteth".

[77:162] That which was figured to us in the Gospel through two men, a Pharisee and a Publican, this let us, taking in a wider sense, understand of two peoples, of Jews and of Gentiles: the people of the Jews that Pharisee was, the people of the Gentiles that Publican.

[77:163] As those by being proud have withdrawn, so these by confessing have drawn near.

[77:164] The cup therefore full of pure wine in the hand of the Lord, as far as the Lord giveth me to understand,the cup of pure wine full of the mixed, seemeth to me to be the Law, which was given to the Jews, and all that Scripture of the Old Testament, as it is called; there are the weights of all manner of sentences.

[77:165] For therein the New Testament lieth concealed, as though in the dreg of corporal Sacraments.

[77:166] The circumcision of the flesh is a thing of great mystery, and there is understood from thence the circumcision of the heart.

[77:167] The Temple of Jerusalem is a thing of great mystery, and there is understood from it the Body of the Lord.

[77:168] The land of promise is understood to be the Kingdom of Heaven.

[77:169] The sacrifice of victims and of beasts hath a great mystery: but in all those kinds of sacrifices is understood that one Sacrifice and only victim of the Cross, the Lord, instead of all which sacrifices we have one; because even those figured these, that is, with those these were figured.

[77:170] That people received the Law, they received commandments just and good What is so just as, thou shalt not kill, thou shalt not commit adultery, thou shalt not steal, thou shalt not speak false testimony, honour thy father and mother, thou shalt not covet the property of thy neighbour, one God thou shalt adore, and Him alone thou shalt serve, all these things belong to the wine.

[77:171] But those things carnal have as it were sunk down in order that they might remain with them, and there might be poured forth from thence all the spiritual understanding.

[77:172] But "the cup in the hand of the Lord," that is, in the power of the Lord: "of pure wine," that is, of the mere Law: "is full of mixed," that is, is together with the dreg of corporal Sacraments.

[77:173] And because the one He humbleth, the proud Jew, and the other He exalteth, the confessing Gentile; "He hath inclined from this unto this," that is, from the Jewish people unto the Gentile people.

[77:174] Hath inclined what? The Law.

[77:175] There hath distilled from thence a spiritual sense.

[77:176] "Nevertheless, the dreg thereof hath not been emptied," for all the carnal Sacraments have remained with the Jews.

[77:177] "There shall drink all the sinners of the earth".

[77:178] Who shall drink? "All the sinners of the earth".

[77:179] Who are the sinners of the earth? The Jews were indeed sinners, but proud: again, the Gentiles were sinners, but humble.

[77:180] All sinners shall drink, but see, who the dreg, who the wine.

[77:181] For those by drinking the dreg have come to nought: these by drinking the wine have been justified.

[77:182] I would dare to speak of them even as inebriated, and I shall not fear: and O that all ye were thus inebriated.

[77:183] Call to mind, "Thy cup inebriating, how passing beautiful!" But why? Do ye think, my brethren, that all those who by confessing Christ even willed to die, were sober? So drunk they were, that they knew not their friends.

[77:184] All their kindred, who strove to divert them from the hope of Heavenly rewards by earthly allurements, were not acknowledged, were not heard by them drunken.

[77:185] Were they not drunken, whose heart had been changed? Were they not drunken, whose mind had been alienated from this world? "There shall drink," he saith, "all the sinners of the earth".

[77:186] But who shall drink the wine? Sinners shall drink, but in order that they may not remain sinners; in order that they may be justified, in order that they may not be punished.

[77:187] "But I," for all  drink, but separately I, that is, Christ with His Body, "for ever will rejoice, I will Psalm to the God of Jacob" : in that promise to be at the end, whereof is said, "corrupt not".

[77:188] "And all the horns of sinners I will break, and there shall be exalted the horns of the Just".

[77:189] This is, the one He humbleth, the other He exalteth.

[77:190] Sinners would not have their horns to be broken, which without doubt will be broken at the end.

[77:191] Thou wilt not have Him then break them, do thou to-day break them.

[77:192] For thou hast heard above, do not despise it: "I have said to unjust men, Do not unjustly, and to the delinquents, Do not exalt the horn".

[77:193] When thou hast heard, do not exalt the horn, thou hast despised and hast exalted the horn: thou shalt come to the end, where there shall come to pass, "All the horns of sinners I will break, and there shall be exalted the horns of the Just".

[77:194] The horns of sinners are the dignities of proud men: the horns of the Just are the gifts of Christ.

[77:195] For by horns exultations are understood.

[77:196] Thou hatest on earth earthly exultation, in order that thou mayest have the heavenly.

[77:197] Thou lovest the earthly, He doth not admit thee to the Heavenly: and unto confusion will belong thy horn which is broken, just as unto glory it will belong, if thy horn is exalted.

[77:198] Now therefore there is time for making choice, then there will not be.

[77:199] Thou wilt not say, I will be let go and will make choice.

[77:200] For there have preceded the words, "I have said to the unjust".

[77:201] If I have not said, make ready an excuse, make ready a defence: but if I have said, seize first upon confession, lest thou come unto damnation; for then confession will be too late, and there will be no defence.

[78:1] Psalm LXXVI.

[78:2] The Jews are wont to glory in this Psalm which we have sung, saying, "Known in Judaea is God, in Israel great is the name of Him:" and to revile the Gentiles to whom God is not known, and to say that to themselves alone God is known; seeing that the Prophet saith, "Known in Judaea is God".

[78:3] In other places therefore He is unknown.

[78:4] But God is known in very deed in Judaea, if they understand what is Judaea.

[78:5] For indeed God is not known except in Judaea.

[78:6] Behold even we say this, that except a person shall have been in Judaea, known to him God cannot be.

[78:7] But what saith the Apostle? He that in secret is a Jew, he that is so in circumcision of the heart, not in letter but in spirit There are therefore Jews in circumcision of the flesh, and there are Jews in circumcision of the heart.

[78:8] Many of our holy fathers had both the circumcision of the flesh, for a seal of the faith, and circumcision of the heart, for the faith itself.

[78:9] From these fathers these men degenerating, who now in the name do glory, and have lost their deeds; from these fathers, I say, degenerating, they have remained Jews in flesh, in heart Heathens.

[78:10] For these are Jews, who are out of Abraham, from whom Isaac was born, and out of him Jacob, and out of Jacob the twelve Patriarchs, and out of the twelve Patriarchs the whole people of the Jews But they were generally called Jews for this reason, that Judah was one of the twelve sons of Jacob, a Patriarch among the twelve, and from his stock the Royalty came among the Jews.

[78:11] For all this people after the number of the twelve sons of Jacob, had twelve tribes.

[78:12] What we call tribes are as it were distinct houses and congregations of people.

[78:13] That people, I say, had twelve tribes, out of which twelve tribes one tribe was Judah, out of which were the kings; and there was another tribe, Levi, out of which were the priests.

[78:14] But because to the priests serving the temple no land was allotted, but it was necessary that among twelve tribes all the Land of promise should be shared: there having been therefore taken out one tribe of higher dignity, the tribe of Levi, which was of the priests, there would have remained eleven, unless by the adoption of the two sons of Joseph the number twelve were completed.

[78:15] What this is, observe.

[78:16] One of the twelve sons of Jacob was Joseph.

[78:17] This Joseph had two sons, Ephraim and Manasse.

[78:18] Jacob, dying, as though by will, received those his grandsons into the number of sons, and said to his son Joseph, "The rest that are born shall be to thee; but these to me, and they shall divide the land with their brethren".

[78:19] As yet there had not been given nor divided the land of promise, but he was speaking in the Spirit, prophesying.

[78:20] The two sons therefore of Joseph being added, there were made up nevertheless twelve tribes, since now there are thirteen.

[78:21] For instead of one tribe of Joseph, two were added, and there were made thirteen.

[78:22] There being taken out then the tribe of Levi, that tribe of priests which did serve the Temple, and lived by the tithes of all the rest unto whom the land was divided, there remain twelve.

[78:23] In these twelve was the tribe of Judah, whence the kings were.

[78:24] For at first from another tribe was given King Saul, and he was rejected as being an evil king; after there was given from the tribe of Judah King David, and out of him from the tribe of Judah were the Kings But Jacob had spoken of this, when he blessed his sons, "there shall not fail a prince out of Judah, nor a leader from his thighs, until there come He to whom the promise hath been made".

[78:25] But from the tribe of Judah there came Our Lord Jesus Christ.

[78:26] For He is, as the Scripture saith, and as ye have but now heard, out of the seed of David born of Mary But as regardeth the Divinity of our Lord Jesus Christ, wherein He is equal with the Father, He is not only before the Jews, but also before Abraham himself; nor only before Abraham, but also before Adam; nor only before Adam, but also before Heaven and earth and before ages: for all things by Himself were made, and without Him there was made nothing Because therefore in prophecy hath been said, "there shall not fail a prince out of Judah," etc.

[78:27] : former times are examined, and we find that the Jews always had their kings of the tribe of Judah, and had no foreign king before that Herod who was king when the Lord was born.

[78:28] Thence began foreign kings, from Herod Before Herod all were of the tribe of Judah, but only until there should come He to whom the promise had been made.

[78:29] Therefore when the Lord Himself came, the kingdom of the Jews was overthrown, and removed from the Jews.

[78:30] Now they have no king; because they will not acknowledge the true King.

[78:31] See now whether they must be called Jews.

[78:32] Now ye do see that they must not be called Jews.

[78:33] They have themselves with their own voice resigned that name, so that they are not worthy to be called Jews, except only in the flesh.

[78:34] When did they sever themselves from the name? They said, "We have no king but Caesar".

[78:35] O ye who are called Jews and are not, if ye have no king but Caesar, there hath failed a Prince of Judah: there hath come then He to whom the promise hath been made.

[78:36] They then are more truly Jews, who have been made Christians out of Jews: the rest of the Jews, who in Christ have not believed, have deserved to lose even the very name.

[78:37] The true Judaea, then, is the Church of Christ, believing in that King, who hath come out of the tribe of Judah through the Virgin Mary; believing in Him of whom the Apostle was just now speaking, in writing to Timothy, "Be thou mindful that Jesus Christ hath risen from the dead, of the seed of David, after my Gospel".

[78:38] For of Judah is David, and out of David is the Lord Jesus Christ.

[78:39] We believing in Christ do belong to Judah: and we acknowledge Christ.

[78:40] We, that with eyes have not seen, in faith do keep Him.

[78:41] Let not therefore the Jews revile, who are no longer Jews.

[78:42] They said themselves, "We have no king but Caesar".

[78:43] For better were it for them that their king should be Christ, of the seed of David, of the tribe of Judah.

[78:44] Nevertheless because Christ Himself is of the seed of David after the flesh, but God above all things blessed for ever, He is Himself our King and our God; our King, inasmuch as born of the tribe of Judah, after the flesh, was Christ the Lord, the Saviour; but our God, who is before Judah, and before Heaven and earth, by whom were made all things, both spiritual and corporal.

[78:45] For if all things by Himself were made; even Mary herself, out of whom He was born, by Himself was made.

[78:46] "Known in Judaea is God, in Israel great is the Name of Him".

[78:47] Concerning Israel also we ought so to take it as we have concerning Judaea: as they were not the true Jews, so neither was that the true Israel.

[78:48] For what is Israel said to be? One seeing God.

[78:49] And how have they seen God, among whom He walked in the flesh; and while they supposed Him to be man, they slew Him?"In Israel great is His Name".

[78:50] Wilt thou be Israel? Observe that man concerning whom the Lord saith, "Behold an Israelite indeed, in whom guile is not".

[78:51] If a true Israelite is he in whom guile is not, the guileful and lying are not true Israelites.

[78:52] Let them not say then, that with them is God, and great is His name in Israel.

[78:53] Let them prove themselves Israelites, and I grant that "in Israel great is His Name".

[78:54] "And there hath been made in peace a place for Him, and His habitation is in Sion".

[78:55] Again, Sion is as it were the country of the Jews; the true Sion is the Church of Christians.

[78:56] But the interpretation of the Hebrew names is thus handed down to us: Judaea is interpreted confession, Israel, one seeing God.

[78:57] After Judaea is Israel.

[78:58] Wilt thou see God? First do thou confess, and then in thyself there is made a place for God; because "there hath been made in peace a place for Him".

[78:59] So long as then thou confessest not thy sins, in a manner thou art quarrelling with God.

[78:60] For how art thou not disputing with Him, who art praising that which displeaseth Him? He punisheth a thief, thou dost praise theft: He doth punish a drunken man, thou dost praise drunkenness.

[78:61] Thou art disputing with God, thou hast not made for Him a place in thy heart: because in peace is His place.

[78:62] And how dost thou begin to have peace with God? Thou beginnest with Him in confession.

[78:63] There is a voice of a Psalm, saying, "Begin ye to the Lord in confession".

[78:64] What is, "Begin ye to the Lord in confession"? Begin ye to be joined to the Lord.

[78:65] In what manner? So that the same thing may displease you as displeaseth Him.

[78:66] There displeaseth Him thy evil life; if it please thyself, thou art disunited from Him; if it displease thee, through confession to Him thou art united.

[78:67] "There He hath broken the strength of bows, and the shield, and the sword, and the battle".

[78:68] Where hath He broken? In that eternal peace, in that perfect peace.

[78:69] And now, my brethren, they that have rightly believed see that they ought not to rely on themselves: and all the might of their own menaces, and whatsoever is in them whetted for mischief, this they break in pieces; and whatsoever they deem of great virtue wherewith to protect themselves temporally, and the war which they were waging against God by defending their sins, all these things He hath broken there.

[78:70] "Thou enlightening marvellously from the eternal mountains".

[78:71] What are the eternal mountains? Those which He hath Himself made eternal; which are the great mountains, the preachers of truth.

[78:72] Thou dost enlighten, but from the eternal mountains: the great mountains are first to receive Thy light, and from Thy light which the mountains receive, the earth also is clothed.

[78:73] But those great mountains the Apostles have received, the Apostles have receiv ed as it were the first streaks of the rising light.

[78:74] Wherefore also, in another place, a Psalm saith what? "I have lifted up mine eyes unto the mountains, whence there shall come help to me".

[78:75] What then, in the mountains is thy hope, and from thence to thee shall there come help? Hast thou stayed at the mountains? Take heed what thou doest.

[78:76] There is something above the mountains: above the mountains is He at whom the mountains tremble.

[78:77] "I have lifted up," he saith, "mine eyes unto the mountains, whence there shall come help to me".

[78:78] But what followeth? "My help," he saith, "is from the Lord, who hath made Heaven and earth".

[78:79] Unto the mountains indeed I have lifted up eyes, because through the mountains to me the Scriptures were displayed: but I have my heart in Him that doth enlighten all mountains.

[78:80] "There have been troubled all the unwise in heart".

[78:81] How have they been troubled? When the Gospel is preached.

[78:82] And what is life eternal? And who is He that hath risen from the dead? The Athenians wondered, when the Apostle Paul spake of the resurrection of the dead, and thought that he spake but fables But because he said that there was another life which neither eye hath seen, nor ear heard, nor hath it gone up into the heart of man, therefore the unwise in heart were troubled.

[78:83] But what hath befallen them? "They have slept their sleep, and all men of riches have found nothing in their hands".

[78:84] They have loved things present, and have gone to sleep in the midst of things present: and so these very present things have become to them delightful: just as he that seeth in a dream himself to have found treasure, is so long rich as he waketh not.

[78:85] The dream hath made him rich, waking hath made him poor.

[78:86] Sleep perchance hath held him slumbering on the earth, and lying on the hard ground, poor and perchance a beggar; in sleep he hath seen himself to lie on an ivory or golden bed, and on feathers heaped up; so long as he is sleeping, he is sleeping well, waking he hath found himself on the hard ground, whereon sleep had taken him.

[78:87] Such men also are these too: they have come into this life, and through temporal desires, they have as it were slumbered here; and them riches, and vain pomps that fly away, have taken, and they have passed away: they have not understood how much of good might be done therewith.

[78:88] For if they had known of another life, there they would have laid up unto themselves the treasure which here was doomed to perish: like as Zacchaeus, the chief of the Publicans, saw that good when he received the Lord Jesus in his house, and he saith, "The half of my goods I give to the poor, and if to any man I have done any wrong, fourfold I restore".

[78:89] This man was not in the emptiness of men dreaming, but in the faith of men awake.

[78:90] "By Thy chiding, O God of Jacob, there have slept all men that have mounted horses".
