[100:50] Now what will one who perchance presideth over such places, nay, who serveth his brethren, in what are called monasteries, tell me? I will be cautious: I will admit no wicked man.

[100:51] How wilt thou admit no evil one?Those who are about to enter, do not know themselves; how much less dost thou know them? For many have promised themselves that they were about to fulfil that holy life, which has all things in common, where no man calleth anything his own, who have one soul and one heart in God: they have been put into the furnace, and have cracked.

[100:52] How then knowest thou him who is unknown even to himself?Where then is security? Here nowhere; in this life nowhere, except solely in the hope of the promise of God.

[100:53] But there, when we shall reach thereunto, is complete security, when the gates are shut, and the bars of the gates of Jerusalem made fast; there is truly full jubilance, and great delight.

[100:54] Only do not thou feel secure in praising any sort of life: "judge no man blessed before his death".

[100:55] By this means men are deceived, so that they either do not undertake, or rashly attempt, a better life; because, when they choose to praise, they praise without mention of the evil that is mixed with the good: and those who choose to blame, do so with so envious and perverse a mind, as to shut their eyes to the good, and exaggerate only the evils which either actually exist there, or are imagined.

[100:56] Thus it happeneth, that when any profession hath been ill, that is, incautiously, praised, if it hath invited men by its own reputation, they who betake themselves thither discover some such as they did not believe to be there; and offended by the wicked recoil from the good.

[100:57] Brethren, apply this teaching to your life, and hear in such a manner that ye may live.

[100:58] The Church of God, to speak generally, is magnified: Christians, and Christians alone, are called great, the Catholic (Church) is magnified; all love each other; each and all do all they can for one another; they give themselves up to prayers, fastings, hymns; throughout the whole world, with peaceful unanimity God is praised.

[100:59] Some one perhaps heareth this, who is ignorant that nothing is said of the wicked who are mingled with them; he cometh, invited by these praises, findeth bad men mixed with them, who were not mentioned to him before he came; he is offended by false Christians, he flieth from true Christians.

[100:60] Again, men who hate and slander them, precipitately blame them: asking, what sort of men are Christians? Who are Christians? Covetous men, usurers.

[100:61] Are not the very persons who fill the Churches on holidays the same who during the games and other spectacles fill the theatres and amphitheatres? They are drunken, gluttonous, envious, slanderers of each other.

[100:62] There are such, but not such only.

[100:63] And this slanderer in his blindness saith nothing of the good: and that praiser in his want of caution is silent about the bad.

[100:64] Thus also in that common life of brethren, which exists in a monastery: great and holy men live therein, with daily hymns, prayers, praises of God; their occupation is reading; they labour with their own hands, and by this means support themselves; they seek nothing covetously; whatever is brought in for them by pious brethren, they use with contentedness and charity; no one claimeth as his own what another hath not; all love, all forbear one another mutually.

[100:65] Thou hast praised them; thou hast praised; he who knoweth not what is going on within, who knoweth not how, when the wind entereth, ships even in harbour dash against one another, entereth as if in hope of security, expecting to find no man to forbear; he findeth there evil brethren, who could not have been found evil, if they had not been admitted (and they must be at first tolerated, lest they should perchance reform; nor can they easily be excluded, unless they have first been endured): and becometh himself impatient beyond endurance.

[100:66] Who asked me here? I thought that love was here.

[100:67] And irritated by the perversity of some few men, since he hath not persevered in fulfilling his vow, he becometh a deserter of so holy a design, and guilty of a vow he hath never discharged.

[100:68] And then, when he hath gone forth himself too, he also becometh a reproacher, and a slanderer; and records those things only (sometimes real), which he asserts that he could not have endured.

[100:69] But the real troubles of the wicked ought to be endured for the society of the good.

[100:70] The Scripture saith unto him: "Woe unto those that have lost patience".

[100:71] And what is more, he belcheth abroad the evil savour of his indignation, as a means to deter them who are about to enter; because, when he had entered himself, he could not persevere.

[100:72] Of what sort are they? Envious, quarrelsome, men who forbear no man, covetous; saying, He did this there, and he did that there.

[100:73] Wicked one, why art thou silent about the good! Thou sayest enough of those whom thou couldest not endure: thou sayest nothing of those who endured thy wickedness.

[100:74] "O serve the Lord with gladness" : he addresseth you, whoever ye are who endure all things in love, and rejoice in hope.

[100:75] "Serve the Lord," not in the bitterness of murmuring, but in the "gladness of love".

[100:76] "Come before His presence with rejoicing".

[100:77] It is easy to rejoice outwardly: rejoice before the presence of God.

[100:78] Let not the tongue be too joyful: let the conscience be joyful.

[100:79] "Come before His presence with a song".

[100:80] "Be ye sure that the Lord He is God".

[100:81] Who knoweth not that the Lord, He is God? But He speaketh of the Lord, whom men thought not God: "Be ye sure that the Lord He is God".

[100:82] Let not that Lord become vile in your sight: ye have crucified Him, scourged Him, spit upon Him, crowned Him with thorns, clothed Him in a dress of infamy, hung Him upon the Cross, pierced Him with nails, wounded Him with a spear, placed guards at His tomb; He is God.

[100:83] "It is He that hath made us, and not we ourselves".

[100:84] It is He that hath made us: "and without Him was not anything made that was made".

[100:85] What reason have ye for exultation, what reason have ye for pride? Another made you; the Same who made you, suffereth from you.

[100:86] But ye extol yourselves, and glory in yourselves, as if ye were created by yourselves.

[100:87] It is good for you that He who made you, make you perfect.

[100:88] "We are His people, and the sheep of His pasture".

[100:89] Sheep and one sheep.

[100:90] These sheep are one sheep: and how loving a Shepherd we have! He left the ninety and nine, and descended to seek the one, He bringeth it back on His own shoulders ransomed by His own blood.

[100:91] That Shepherd dieth without fear for the sheep, who on His resurrection regaineth His sheep.

[100:92] "Enter into His gates w ith confession".

[100:93] A t the gates is the beginning: begin with confession.

[100:94] Thence is the Psalm entitled, "A Psalm of Confession:" there be joyful.

[100:95] Confess that ye were not made by yourselves, praise Him by whom ye were made.

[100:96] Let thy good come from Him, in departing from whom thou hast caused thine evil.

[100:97] "Enter into His gates with confession".

[100:98] Let the flock enter into the gates: let it not remain outside, a prey for wolves.

[100:99] And how is it to enter? "With confession".

[100:100] Let the gate, that is, the commencement for thee, be confession.

[100:101] Whence it is said in another Psalm, "Begin unto the Lord with confession".

[100:102] What he there calleth "Begin," here he calleth "Gates".

[100:103] "Enter into His gates in confession".

[100:104] What? And when we have entered, shall we not still confess? Always confess Him: thou hast always what to confess for.

[100:105] It is hard in this life for a man to be so far changed, that no cause for censure be discoverable in him: thou must needs blame thyself, lest He who shall condemn blame thee.

[100:106] Therefore even when thou hast entered His courts, then also confess.

[100:107] When will there be no longer confession of sins? In that rest, in that likeness to the Angels.

[100:108] But consider what I have said: there will there be no confession of sins.

[100:109] I said not, there will be no confession: for there will be confession of praise.

[100:110] Thou wilt ever confess, that He is God, thou a creature; that He is thy Protector, thyself protected.

[100:111] In Him thou shalt be as it were hid "Go into His courts with hymns; and confess unto Him".

[100:112] Confess in the gates; and when ye have entered the courts, confess with hymns.

[100:113] Hymn are praises.

[100:114] Blame thyself, when thou art entering; when thou hast entered, praise Him.

[100:115] "Open me the gates of righteousness," he saith in another Psalm, "that I may go into them, and confess unto the Lord".

[100:116] Did he say, when I have entered, I will no longer confess? Even after his entrance, he will confess.

[100:117] For what sins did our Lord Jesus Christ confess, when He said, "I confess unto Thee, O Father"? He confessed in praising Him, not in accusing Himself.

[100:118] "Speak good of His Name".

[100:119] "For the Lord is pleasant".

[100:120] Think not that ye faint in praising Him.

[100:121] Your praise of Him is like food: the more ye praise Him, the more ye acquire strength, and He whom ye praise becometh the more sweet.

[100:122] "His mercy is everlasting".

[100:123] For He will not cease to be merciful, after He hath freed thee: it belongeth to His mercy to protect thee even unto eternal life.

[100:124] "His mercy," therefore, "is to everlasting: and His truth from generation to generation".

[100:125] Understand by "from generation to generation," either every generation, or in two generations, the one earthly, the other heavenly.

[100:126] Here there is one generation which produceth mortals; another which maketh such as are everlasting.

[100:127] His Truth is both here, and there.

[100:128] Imagine not that His truth is not here, if His truth were not here, he would not say in another Psalm: "Truth is risen out of the earth;" nor would Truth Itself say, Lo, I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world".

[101:1] Psalm CI.

[101:2] In this Psalm, we ought to seek in the whole body of it what we find in the first verse: "Mercy and judgment will I sing unto Thee, O Lord".

[101:3] Let no man flatter himself that he will never be punished through God's mercy; for there is judgment also; and let no man who hath been changed for the better dread the Lord's judgment, seeing that mercy goeth before it.

[101:4] For when men judge, sometimes overcome by mercy, they act against justice; and mercy, but not justice, seemeth to be in them: while sometimes, when they wish to enforce a rigid judgment, they lose mercy.

[101:5] But God neither loseth the severity of judgment in the bounty of mercy, nor in judging with severity loseth the bounty of mercy.

[101:6] Suppose we distinguish these two, mercy and judgment, by time; for possibly, they are not placed in this order without a meaning, so that he said not "judgment and mercy," but "mercy and judgment:" so that if we distinguish them by succession in time, perhaps we find that the present is the season for mercy, the future for judgment.

[101:7] How is it that the season of mercy cometh first? Consider first how it is with God, that thou also mayest imitate the Father, in so far as He shall permit thee.

[101:8] "He maketh His sun to rise on the evil and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust".

[101:9] Behold mercy.

[101:10] When thou seest the just and the unjust behold the same sun, enjoy the same light, drink from the same founts, satisfied with the same rain, blessed with the same fruits of the earth, inhale this air in the same way, possess equally the world's goods; think not that God is unjust, who giveth these things equally to the just and the unjust.

[101:11] It is the season of mercy, not as yet of judgment.

[101:12] For unless God spared at first through mercy, He would not find those whom He could crown through judgment.

[101:13] There is therefore a season for mercy, when the long-suffering of God calleth sinners to repentance.

[101:14] Hear the Apostle distinguishing each season, and do thou also distinguish it.

[101:15] "Thinkest thou," he saith, "O man, that judgest them that do such things, and doest the same, that thou shalt escape the judgment of God?" And as if we were to reply, Why do I commit such sins daily, and no evil occurreth unto me? he goeth on to show to him the season of mercy: "Despisest thou the riches of His goodness, and forbearance, and long-suffering?" And he did indeed despise them; but the Apostle hath made him anxious.

[101:16] "Not knowing," he saith, "that the goodness of God leadeth thee to repentance?" Behold the season of mercy.

[101:17] But that he might not think this would last for ever, how did he in the next verse raise his fears? Now hear the season of judgment; thou hast heard the season of mercy, on which account, "mercy and judgment will I sing unto Thee, O Lord:" "But thou," saith the Apostle, "after thy hardness and impenitent heart, treasurest up unto thyself wrath against the day of wrath, and revelation of the righteous judgment of God, who will render to every man according to his deeds".

[101:18] Lo, "mercy and judgment".

[101:19] But he hath threatened concerning judgment: is therefore the judgment of God to be feared only, and not to be loved? To be feared by the wicked on account of punishment, to be loved by the good on account of the crown.

[101:20] Because then the Apostle hath alarmed the wicked in the testimony which I have quoted, hear where he giveth hope concerning judgment to the good.

[101:21] He puts forth himself, and shows in himself too the season of mercy.

[101:22] For unless he found a period of mercy, in what condition would judgment find him? A blasphemer, a persecutor, an injurer of others.

[101:23] For he thus speaketh, and praiseth the season of mercy, in which season we are now living: "I who was before," he saith, "a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and injurious: but I obtained mercy".

[101:24] But perhaps he only hath obtained mercy? Hear how he cheereth us: "That in me," he saith, "first, Christ Jesus might show forth all long-suffering, for a pattern to them which should hereafter believe on Him to life everlasting".

[101:25] What meaneth, "that He might show forth all long-suffering"? That every sinner and wicked man might see that Paul received pardon, and might not despair of himself? Lo, he hath instanced himself, and thereby cheered others also.

[101:26] But did Paul alone deserve this? For I had asserted, that as he raised our fears by the former testimony, so did he encourage us by the latter.

[101:27] When he said, "The Lord, the righteous Judge, shall render to me at that day:" he addeth, "and not to me only, but unto all them also that love His appearing" and His kingdom.

[101:28] Since therefore, brethren, we have a season of mercy, let us not on that account flatter, or indulge ourselves, saying, God spareth ever.

[101:29] "I will sing to the harp, and will have understanding, in the spotless way.

[101:30] When Thou shalt come unto me".

[101:31] Except in the spotless way, thou canst neither sing to the harp, nor understand.

[101:32] If thou dost wish to understand, sing in the spotless way, that is, work with cheerfulness before thy God.

[101:33] What is the spotless way? Hear what followeth: "I walked in innocence, in the midst of my house".

[101:34] This spotless way beginneth from innocence, and it endeth also in innocence.

[101:35] Why seek many words? Be innocent: and thou hast perfected righteousness.

[101:36] But who is innocent? He who while he hurteth not another, injureth not himself.

[101:37] For he who hurteth himself, is not innocent.

[101:38] Some one saith: Lo, I have not robbed any one, I have not oppressed any one: I will live happily on my own substance, the fruits of my virtuous toil; I wish to have fine banquets, I wish to spend as much as pleaseth me, to drink with those whom I like as much as I please; whom have I robbed, whom have I oppressed, who hath complained of me? He seemeth innocent.

[101:39] But if he corrupt himself, if he overthrow the temple of God within himself, why hope that he will act with mercy toward others, and spare the wretched? Can that man be merciful to others, who unto himself is cruel? The whole of righteousness, therefore, is reduced to the one word, innocence.

[101:40] But the lover of iniquity, hateth his own soul.

[101:41] When he loved iniquity, he fancied he was injuring others.

[101:42] But consider whether he was injuring others: "He who loveth iniquity," he saith, "hateth his own soul".

[101:43] He therefore who wishes to injure another, first injureth himself; nor doth he walk, since there is no room.

[101:44] For all wickedness suffereth from narrowness: innocence alone is broad enough to walk in.

[101:45] "I walked in the innocence of my heart, in the midst of my house".

[101:46] By the middle of his house, he either signifieth the Church herself; for Christ walketh in her: or his own heart; for our inner house is our heart: as he hath explained in the above words, "in the innocence of my heart".

[101:47] What is the innocence of the heart? The middle of his house? Whoever hath a bad house in this, is driven out of doors.

[101:48] For whoever is oppressed within his heart by a bad conscience, just as any man in consequence of the overflow of a waterspout or of smoke goeth out of his house, suffereth not himself to dwell therein; so he who hath not a quiet heart, cannot happily dwell in his heart.

[101:49] Such men go out of themselves in the bent of their mind, and delight themselves with things without, that affect the body; they seek repose in trifles, in spectacles, in luxuries, in all evils.

[101:50] Wherefore do they wish themselves well without? Because it is not well with them within, so that they may rejoice in a good conscience.

[101:51] "I set no wicked thing before my eyes".

[101:52] I did love no wicked thing.

[101:53] And he explaineth this same wicked thing: "I hated them that do unfaithfulness".

[101:54] Attend, my brethren.

[101:55] If ye walk with Christ in the midst of His house, that is, if either in your heart ye have a good repose, or in the Church herself proceed on a good journey in the way of godliness; ye ought not to hate those unfaithful only who are without, but whomsoever also ye may have found within.

[101:56] Who are the unfaithful? They who hate the law of God; who hear, and do it not, are called unfaithful.

[101:57] Hate the doers of unfaithfulness, repel them from thee.

[101:58] But thou shouldest hate the unfaithful, not men: one man who is unfaithful, hath, ye see, two names, man, and unfaithful: God made him man, he made himself unfaithful; love in him what God made, persecute in him what he made himself.

[101:59] For when thou shalt have persecuted his unfaithfulness, thou killest the work of man, and freest the work of God.

[101:60] "I hated the doers of unfaithfulness".

[101:61] "The wicked heart hath not cleaved unto me".

[101:62] The heart of a man, who wisheth not anything contrary to any that God wisheth, is called straight.

[101:63] If therefore the righteous heart followeth God, the crooked heart resisteth God.

[101:64] Suppose something untoward happeneth to him, he crieth out, "God, what have I done unto Thee? What sin have I committed?" He wisheth himself to appear just, God unjust.

[101:65] What is so crooked as this? It is not enough that thou art crooked thyself: thou must think thy rule crooked also.

[101:66] Reform thyself, and thou findest Him straight, in departing from whom thou hast made thyself crooked.

[101:67] He doth justly, thou unjustly; and for this reason thou art perverse, since thou callest man just, and God unjust.

[101:68] What man dost thou call just? Thyself.

[101:69] For when thou sayest, "What have I done unto Thee?" thou thinkest thyself just.

[101:70] But let God answer thee: "Thou speakest truth: thou hast done nothing to Me: thou hast done all things unto thyself; for if thou hadst done anything for Me, thou wouldest have done good.

[101:71] For whatever is done well, is done unto Me; because it is done according to My commandment; but whatever of evil is done, is done unto thee, not unto Me; for the wicked man doth nothing except for his own sake, since it is not what I command".

[101:72] When ye see such men, brethren, reprove them, convince and correct them: and if ye cannot reprove or correct them, consent not to them.

[101:73] "When the wicked man departed from me, I knew him not".

[101:74] I approved him not, I praised him not, he pleased me not.

[101:75] For we find the word "to know" occasionally used in Scripture, in the sense of "to be pleased".

[101:76] For what is hidden from God, brethren? Doth He know the just, and doth He not know the unjust? What dost thou think of, that He doth not know? I say not, what thinkest thou; but what wilt thou ever think, that He will not have seen beforehand? God knoweth all things, then; and yet in the end, that is in judgment after mercy, He saith of some persons: "I will profess unto them, I never knew you; depart from Me, ye workers of iniquity".

[101:77] Was there any one He did not know? But what meaneth, "I never knew you"? I acknowledge you not in My rule.

[101:78] For I know the rule of My righteousness: ye agree not with it, ye have turned aside from it, ye are crooked.

[101:79] Therefore He said here also: "When the wicked man departed from Me, I knew him not".

[101:80] Therefore, "when the wicked man departed from me," that is, when the wicked man was unlike me, and was unwilling to imitate my paths, was unwilling in his wickedness to live as I had proposed myself for his imitation; "I knew him not".

[101:81] What meaneth, "I knew him not"? Not that I was ignorant of him, but that I did not approve him.

[101:82] "Whoso privily slandered his neighbour, him I persecuted".

[101:83] Behold the righteous persecutor, not of the man, but of the sin.

[101:84] "With the proud eye, and the insatiable heart, I did not feed".

[101:85] What meaneth, "I did not feed with"? I did not eat in common with such.

[101:86] Attend, beloved; since ye are about to hear something wonderful.

[101:87] If he did not feed with this man, he did not eat with him; for to feed is to eat; how is it then that we find our Lord Himself eating with the proud? It was not only with those publicans and sinners, for they were humble: for they acknowledged their weakness, and asked for the physician.

[101:88] We find that He ate with the proud Pharisees themselves.

[101:89] A certain proud man had invited Him: it was the same who was displeased because a sinning woman, one of ill repute in the city, approached the feet of our Lord.

[101:90] That Pharisee was proud: the Lord ate with him; what is it therefore that he saith? "With such an one I did not eat".

[101:91] How doth He enjoin unto us what He hath not done Himself? He exhorteth us to imitate Himself: we see that He ate with the proud; how doth He forbid us to eat with the proud? We indeed, brethren, for the sake of reproof, abstain from communion with our brethren, and do not eat with them, that they may be reformed? We rather eat with strangers, with Pagans, than with those who hold with us, if we have seen that they live wickedly, that they may be ashamed, and amend; as the Apostle saith, "And if any man obey not our word by this Epistle, note that man, and have no company with him, that he may be ashamed.

[101:92] Yet count him not as an enemy, but admonish him as a brother".

[101:93] For the sake of healing others we usually do this; but nevertheless we often eat with many strangers and ungodly men.

[101:94] The pious heart hath its banquets, the proud heart hath its banquets: for it was on account of the food of the proud heart, that he said, "with an insatiable heart".

[101:95] How is the proud heart fed? If a man is proud, he is envious: otherwise it cannot be.

[101:96] Pride is the mother of enviousness: it cannot but generate it, and ever coexist with it.

[101:97] Every proud man is, therefore, envious: if envious, he feedeth on the misfortunes of others.

[101:98] Whence the Apostle saith, "But if ye bite and devour one another, take heed that ye be not consumed of one another".

[101:99] Ye see them, then, eating: eat not with these: fly such banquets: for they cannot satisfy themselves with rejoicing in others' evils, because their hearts are insatiable.

[101:100] Beware thou art not caught in their feasts by the devil's noose.

[101:101] Just as birds feed at the trap, or fishes at the hook, they were taken, when they fed.

[101:102] The ungodly therefore have their own feasts, the godly also have theirs.

[101:103] Hear the feasts of the godly: "Blessed are they who hunger and thirst after righteousness: for they shall be filled".

[101:104] If therefore the godly eateth the meat of righteousness, and the ungodly of pride; it is no wonder if he is insatiable in heart.

[101:105] He eateth the meat of iniquity: do not eat the meat of iniquity, and the proud in eye, and the insatiable in heart, eateth not with thee.

[101:106] And whence wast thou fed? And what pleased thee, when he did not eat with thee? "Mine eyes," he saith, "were upon such as are faithful in the land, that they might sit with me".

[101:107] That is, that with Me they might be seated In what sense are they "to sit"? "Ye shall sit on twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel".

[101:108] The faithful of the earth judge, for to them it is said, "Know ye not, that we shall judge angels?" "Whoso walketh in a spotless way, he ministered unto me".

[101:109] To "Me," he saith, not to himself.

[101:110] For many minister the Gospel, but unto themselves; because they seek their own things, not the things of Jesus Christ.

[101:111] "The proud man hath not dwelt in the midst of my house".

[101:112] Understand this of the heart.

[101:113] The proud did not dwell in my heart: no such dwelt in my heart: for he hurried away from me.

[101:114] None but the meek and peaceful dwelt in my heart; the proud dwelt not there, for the unrighteous one dwelleth not in the heart of the righteous.

[101:115] Let the righteous be distant from thee, I know not how many miles and stations: ye dwell together, if ye have one heart.

[101:116] "The proud doer hath not dwelt in the midst of my house: he that speaketh unjust things hath not directed in the sight of my eyes".

[101:117] This is the spotless way, where we understand when the Lord cometh unto us.

[101:118] "In the morning I destroyed all the ungodly that were in the land.

[101:119] That I may root out all wicked doers from the city of the Lord".

[101:120] This is obscure.

[101:121] There are then wicked doers in the city of the Lord, and they at present, seemingly, s pared.

[101:122] Why so? Because it is the season of mercy: but that of judgment will come; for the Psalm thus began, "Of mercy and judgment will I sing unto Thee, O Lord".

[101:123] He at present spareth, He will then judge.

[101:124] But when will He judge? When night shall have passed away.

[101:125] For this reason He hath said: "In the morning".

[101:126] When the day shall at last have arrived, night having passed by.

[101:127] Why doth He spare them until the dawn? Because it was night.

[101:128] What meaneth, it was night? Because it was the season for mercy: He was merciful, while the hearts of men were hidden.

[101:129] Thou seest some one living ill; thou endurest him: for thou knowest not of what sort he will prove to be; since it is night; whether he who to-day liveth ill, to-morrow may live well; and whether he who to-day liveth well, to-morrow may be wicked.

[101:130] For it is night, and God endureth all men, since He is of long-suffering: He endureth them, that sinners may be converted unto Him.

[101:131] But they who shall not have reformed themselves in that season of mercy, shall be slain.

[101:132] And wherefore? That they may be scattered abroad  from the city of the Lord, from the fellowship of Jerusalem, from the fellowship of the Saints, from the fellowship of the Church.

[101:133] But when shall they be slain? "At dawn".

[101:134] What meaneth, "at dawn"? When night shall have passed away.

[101:135] Wherefore now doth he spare? Because it is the season of mercy.

[101:136] Why doth He not always spare? Because, "Mercy and judgment will I sing unto Thee, O Lord".

[101:137] Brethren, let no man flatter himself: all the doers of iniquity shall be slain; Christ shall slay them at the dawn, and shall destroy them from His city.

[101:138] But now while it is the time of mercy, let them hear Him.

[101:139] Everywhere He crieth out by the Law, by the Prophets, by the Psalms, by the Epistles, by the Gospels: see that He is not silent; that He spareth; that He granteth mercy; but beware, for the judgment will come.

[102:1] Psalm CII.

[102:2] Behold, one poor man prayeth, and prayeth not in silence.

[102:3] We may therefore hear him, and see who he is: whether it be not perchance He, of whom the Apostle saith, "Though He was rich, yet for your sakes He became poor, that ye through His poverty might be rich".

[102:4] If it is He, then, how is He poor? For in what sense He is rich, who seeth not? What then is richer than He, by whom riches were made, even those which are not true riches? For through Him we have even these riches, ability, memory, character, health of body, the senses, and the conformation of our limbs: for when these are safe, even the poor are rich.

[102:5] Through Him also are those greater riches, faith, piety, justice, charity, chastity, good conduct: for no man hath these, except through Him who justifieth the ungodly.

[102:6] Behold, how rich! In one so rich, how are we to recognise these words? "I have eaten ashes as it were bread: and mingled my drink with weeping".

[102:7] Have these so great riches come to this? The former state is a very high one, this is a very lowly one.

[102:8] Yet still examine whether this poor man be He; since, "The Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us".

[102:9] Reflect also upon these words: "I am Thy servant, and the Son of Thine handmaid".

[102:10] Observe, this handmaid, chaste, a virgin, and a mother: for there He received our poverty, when He was clothed in the form of a servant, emptying Himself; lest thou shouldest dread His riches, and in thy beggarly state shouldest not dare approach Him.

[102:11] There, I say, He put on the form of a servant, there He was clothed with our poverty; there He made Himself poor, and us rich.

[102:12] We are now drawing near to understand these things of Him: nevertheless we may not as yet rashly pronounce.

[102:13] Let him add poverty then to poverty: let Him transfigure unto Himself our humble body: let Him be our Head, we His limbs, let there be two in one fleshFor He hath deigned to hold even us as His limbs.

[102:14] The penitent also are among His limbs.

[102:15] For they are not shut out, nor separated from His Church: nor would He make the Church His spouse, unless by words like these: "Repent ye, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand".

[102:16] Let us then hear what the head and the body prayeth, the bridegroom and bride, Christ and the Church, both one Person; but the Word and the flesh are not both one thing; the Father and the Word are both one thing; Christ and the Church are both one Person, one perfect man in the form of His own fulness.

[102:17] Let us hear therefore Christ, poor within us and with us, and for our sakes.

[102:18] For the title itself indicates the poor one.

[102:19] Lastly, remember that I conjectured who that poor one was: let us hear His prayer, and recognise His Person; and mistake not, when thou shalt have heard anything that cannot apply to His Head; it was for this reason that I have prefaced as I have, that whatever thou shalt hear of this description, thou mayest understand as sounding from the weakness of the body, and recognise the voice of the members in the head.

[102:20] The title is, "A Prayer of the afflicted, when he was tormented, and poured out his prayer before the Lord".

[102:21] It is the same poor one who elsewhere saith: "From the ends of the earth will I call upon Thee, when my heart is in heaviness".

[102:22] He is afflicted because He is also Christ; who in the Prophet's words calleth Himself both Bridegroom and Bride: "He hath bound on me the diadem as on a bridegroom, and as a bride hath adorned me with an ornament".

[102:23] He called Himself Bridegroom, He called Himself Bride; wherefore this, unless Bridegroom applieth to the Head, Bride to the body? They are one voice then, because they are one flesh.

[102:24] Let us hear, and recognise ourselves in these words; and if we see that we are without, let us labour to be there.

[102:25] "Hear my prayer, O Lord: and let my crying come unto Thee".

[102:26] "Hear my prayer, O Lord," is the same as, "Let my crying come unto Thee:" the feeling of the suppliant is shown by the repetition.

[102:27] "Turn not Thy face away from me".

[102:28] When did God turn away His Face from His Son? when did the Father turn away His Face from Christ? But for the sake of the poverty of my members, "Turn not away Thy face from me: whatsoever day I am troubled, incline Thine ear unto me".

[102:29] Thou art in trouble this day, I am in trouble; another is in trouble to-morrow, I am in trouble; after this generation other descendants, who succeed your descendants, are in trouble, I am in trouble; down to the end of the world, whoever are in trouble in My body, I am in trouble.

[102:30] Peter prayed, Paul prayed, the rest of the Apostles prayed; the faithful prayed in those times, the faithful prayed in the following times, the faithful prayed in the times of the Martyrs, the faithful pray in our times, the faithful will pray in the times of our descendants.

[102:31] "Right soon:" for I now ask that which Thou art willing to grant.

[102:32] I ask not earthly things, as an earthly man; but redeemed at last from my former captivity, I long for the kingdom of heaven; "Hear me right soon:" for it is only to such a longing that Thou hast said, "Even while Thou art speaking, I will say, Here I am".

[102:33] Wherefore dost thou call? in what tribulation? in what want? O poor one, before the gate of God all-rich, in what longing dost thou beg? from what destitution dost thou ask relief? from what want dost thou knock, that it may be opened unto thee?.

[102:34] "For my days are consumed away like smoke".

[102:35] O days! if days: for where day is heard of, light is understood.

[102:36] "My days," my times; wherefore, "like smoke," unless from the puffing up of pride?See smoke, like pride, ascending, swelling, vanishing: deservedly therefore failing, and not stedfast.

[102:37] "And my bones are scorched up as it were in an oven".

[102:38] Both my bones, and my strength, not without tribulation, not without burning.

[102:39] The bones of the body of Christ, the strength of His body, is it anywhere greater than in the Holy Apostles? And yet see that the bones are scorched.

[102:40] "Who is offended, and I burn not?" They are brave, faithful, able interpreters and preachers of the word, living as they speak, speaking as they hear; they are clearly brave, yet all who suffer offences, are an oven to them.

[102:41] For there is love there, and more so in the bones.

[102:42] The bones are within all the flesh, and support all the flesh.

[102:43] But if any man suffer any offence, and endanger his soul; the bone is scorched in proportion as it loveth.

[102:44] Look back to Adam, whence the human race sprung.

[102:45] For how but from him was misery propagated? whence but from him is this hereditary poverty? Let him then, who in his own body was at one time in despair, now that he is set in Christ's body, say with hope, "My heart is smitten down, and withered like grass".

[102:46] Deservedly, since all flesh is grass But how did this happen unto thee? "Since I have forgotten to eat my bread".

[102:47] For God had given His commandment for bread.

[102:48] For what is the bread of the soul? The serpent suggesting, and the woman transgressing, he touched the forbidden fruit, he forgot the commandment: his heart was smitten as it deserved, and withered like grass, since he forgot to eat his bread.

[102:49] Having forgotten to eat bread, he drinketh poison: his heart is smitten, and withered like grass.

[102:50] Now eat that bread which thou hadst forgotten.

[102:51] But this very Bread hath come, in whose body thou mayest remember the voice of thy forgetfulness, and cry out in thy poverty, so that thou mayest receive riches.

[102:52] Now eat: for thou art in His body, who saith, "I am the living bread which came down from heaven".

[102:53] Thou hadst forgotten to eat thy bread; but after His crucifixion, "all the ends of the earth shall be reminded, and be converted unto the Lord".

[102:54] After forgetfulness, let remembrance come, let bread be eaten from heaven, that we may live; not manna, as they did eat, and died; that bread, of which it is said, "Blessed are they who hunger and thirst after righteousness".

[102:55] "For the voice of my groaning, the bones cleave unto my flesh".

[102:56] For many groan, and I also groan; even for this I groan, because they groan for a wrong cause.

[102:57] That man hath lost a piece of money, he groaneth: he hath lost faith, he groaneth not: I weigh the money and the faith, and I find more cause for groaning for him who groaneth not as he ought, or doth not groan at all.

[102:58] He committeth fraud, and rejoiceth.

[102:59] With what gain, with what loss? He hath gained money, he hath lost righteousness.

[102:60] For the latter reason, he who knoweth how to groan, groaneth; he who is near the head, who righteously clingeth to Christ's body, groaneth for this reason.

[102:61] But the carnal do not groan for this reason, and they cause themselves to be groaned for, because they do not groan for this reason; nor can we despise them, whether they groan not at all, or groan for the wrong cause.

[102:62] For we wish to correct them, we wish to amend them, we wish to reform them, and when we cannot, we groan; and when we groan, we are not separated from them.

[102:63] "I am become like a pelican in the wilderness, and like an owl among ruined walls".

[102:64] Behold three birds and three places: the pelican, the owl, and the sparrow; and the three places are severally, the wilderness, the ruined walls, and the house-top.

[102:65] The pelican in the wilderness, the owl in the ruined walls, and the sparrow in the house-top.

[102:66] In the first place we must explain, what the pelican signifieth: since it is born in a region which maketh it unknown to us.

[102:67] It is born in lonely spots, especially  those of the river Nile in Egypt.

[102:68] Whatever kind of bird it is, let us consider what the Psalm intended to say of it.

[102:69] "It dwelleth," it saith, "in the w ilderness".

[102:70] Why enquire of its form, its limbs, its voice, its habits? As far as the Psalm telleth thee, it is a bird that dwelleth in solitude.

[102:71] The owl is a bird that loveth night.

[102:72] Parietinae, or ruins, as we call them, are walls standing without roof, without inhabitants, these are the habitation of the owl.

[102:73] And then as to the house-top and the sparrows, ye are familiar with them.

[102:74] I find, therefore, some one of Christ's body, a preacher of the word, sympathizing with the weak, seeking the gains of Christ, mindful of his Lord to come Let us see these three things from the office of His steward.

[102:75] Hath such a man come among those who are not Christians? He is a pelican in the wilderness.

[102:76] Hath he come among those who were Christians, and have relapsed? He is an owl in the ruined walls; for he forsaketh not even the darkness of those who dwell in night, he wisheth to gain even these.

[102:77] Hath he come among such as are Christians dwelling in a house, not as if they believed not, or as if they had let go what they had believed, but walking lukewarmly in what they believe? The sparrow crieth unto them, not in the wilderness, because they are Christians; nor in the ruined walls, because they have not relapsed; but because they are within the roof; under the roof rather, because they are under the flesh.

[102:78] The sparrow above the flesh crieth out, husheth not up the commandments of God, nor becometh carnal, so that he be subject to the roof.

[102:79] "What ye hear in the ear, that preach ye on the housetops".

[102:80] There are three birds and three places; and one man may represent the three birds, and three men may represent severally the three birds; and the three sorts of places, are three classes of men: yet the wilderness, the ruined walls, and the house-top, are but three classes of men.

[102:81] Let us not pass over what is said, or even read, of this bird, that is, the pelican; not rashly asserting anything, but yet not passing over what has been left to be read and uttered by those who have written it.

[102:82] Do ye so hear, that if it be true, it may agree; if false, it may not hold.

[102:83] These birds are said to slay their young with blows of their beaks, and for three days to mourn them when slain by themselves in the nest: after which they say the mother wounds herself deeply, and pours forth her blood over her young, bathed in which they recover life.

[102:84] This may be true, it may be false: yet if it be true, see how it agreeth with Him, who gave us life by His blood It agreeth with Him in that the mother's flesh recalleth to life her young with her blood; it agreeth well.

[102:85] For He calleth Himself a hen brooding over her youngIf, then, it be so truly, this bird doth closely resemble the flesh of Christ, by whose blood we have been called to life.

[102:86] But how may it agree with Christ, that the bird herself slays her own young? Doth not this agree with it? "I will slay, and I will make alive: I will wound, and I will heal".

[102:87] Would the persecutor Saul have died, unless he were wounded from heaven; or would the preacher be raised up, unless by life given him from His blood? But let those who have written on the subject see to this; we ought not to allow our understanding of it  to rest upon doubtful ground Let us rather recognise this bird in the wilderness; as the Psalm expresseth it, "A pelican in the solitude".

[102:88] I suppose that Christ born of a Virgin is here meant.

[102:89] He was born in loneliness, because He alone was thus born.

[102:90] After the nativity, we come to His Passion.

[102:91] Born in the wilderness, because alone so born; suffering in the darkness of the Jews as it were in night, in their sin, as it were in ruins: what next? "I have watched:" and "am become even as it were a sparrow, that sitteth alone upon the house-top".

[102:92] Thou hadst then slept amid the ruins, and hadst said, "I laid me down, and slept".

[102:93] What meaneth, "I slept"? Because I chose, I slept: I slept for love of night: but, "I rose again," followeth.

[102:94] Therefore "I watched," is here said.

[102:95] But after He watched, what did He? He ascended into heaven, He became as a sparrow by flying; that is, by ascending; "alone on the house-top;" that is, in heaven.

[102:96] He is therefore as the pelican by birth, as the owl by dying, as the sparrow by ascending again: there in the wilderness, as one alone; here in the ruined walls, as one slain by those who could not stand in the building; and here again watching and flying for our sakes alone on the house-top, He there intercedeth in our behalf For our Head is as the sparrow, His body as the turtle-dove.

[102:97] "For the sparrow hath found her an house".

[102:98] What house? In heaven, where He doth mediate for us.

[102:99] "And the turtle-dove a nest," the Church of God hath found a nest from the wood of His Cross, where "she may lay her young," her children.

[102:100] "Mine enemies revile me all day, and they that praised me are sworn together against me".

[102:101] With their mouth they praised, in their heart they were laying snares for me.

[102:102] Hear their praise: "Master, we know that Thou art true, and teachest the way of God in truth, neither carest Thou for any man.

[102:103] Is it lawful to give tribute unto Caesar, or not?" And whence this evil repute, except because I came to make sinners my members, that by repentance they may be in my body? Thence is all the calumny, thence the persecution.

[102:104] "Why eateth your Master with publicans and sinners? They that be whole need not a physician, but they that be sick".

[102:105] Would that ye were aware of your sickness, that ye might seek a physician; ye would not slay Him, and through your infatuated pride perish in a false health.

[102:106] "I have eaten ashes as it were bread: and mingled my drink with weeping".

[102:107] Because He chose to have among His members these kinds of men, that they should be healed and set free, thence is the evil repute.

[102:108] Now at this day what is the character of Pagan calumny against us? what, brethren, do ye conceive they tell us? Ye corrupt discipline, and pervert the morality of the human race.

[102:109] Why dost thou attack us; say why? what have we done? By giving, he replieth, to men room for repentance, by promising impunity for all sins: for this reason men do evil deeds, careless of consequences, because everything is pardoned them, when they are converted.

[102:110] And what is to become of thee, miserable man, if there shall be no harbour of impunity? If there is only licence for sinning, and no pardon for sins, where wilt thou be, whither wilt thou go? Surely even for thee did it happen, that that afflicted one ate ashes as it were bread, and mingled His drink with weeping.

[102:111] Doth not such a feast now please thee? But nevertheless, he replieth, men add to their sins under the hope of pardon.

[102:112] Nay, but they would add to them if they despaired of pardon.

[102:113] Dost thou not observe in what licentious cruelty gladiators live? whence this, except because, as destined for the sword and sacrifice, they choose to sate their lust, before they pour forth their blood?  Wouldest not thou also thus address thyself? I am already a sinner, already an unjust man, one already doomed to damnation, hope of pardon there is none: why should I not do whatever pleaseth me, although it be not lawful? why not fulfil, as far as I can, any longings I may have, if, after these, nothing but torments only be in store? Wouldest thou not thus speak unto thyself, and from this very despair become still worse? Rather than this, then, He who promiseth forgiveness, doth correct thee, saying, "As I live, saith the Lord, I have no pleasure in the death of the wicked; but that the wicked turn from his way and live".

[102:114] For in order that men might not live the worse from despair, He promised a harbour of forgiveness; again, that they might not live the worse from hope of pardon, He made the day of death uncertain: fixing both with the utmost providence, both as a refuge for the returning, and a terror to the loitering.

[102:115] Eat ashes as bread, and mingle thy drink with weeping; by means of this banquet thou shalt reach the table of God.

[102:116] Despair not; pardon hath been promised thee.

[102:117] Thanks be to God, he saith, because it is promised; I hold fast the promise of God.

[102:118] Now therefore live well.

[102:119] To-morrow, he replieth, I will live well.

[102:120] God hath promised the pardon; no one promised thee to-morrow.

[102:121] "And that because of thine indignation and wrath: because thou hast taken me up, thou hast cast me down".

[102:122] This is thy wrath, O Lord, in Adam: that wrath in which we were all born, which cleaveth unto us by our birth; the wrath froth the stock of iniquity, the wrath from the mass of sin: according to what the Apostle saith, "We also were once the children of wrath, even as others".

[102:123] For He saith not, the wrath of God shall come upon him: but, "abideth upon him:" because that wrath in which he was born is not taken away.

[102:124] Man set in honour, is made in the image of God: raised up to this honour, lifted up from the dust, from the earth, he hath received a reasonable soul; by the vivacity of that very reason, he is placed before all beasts, cattle, birds that fly, and fishes For which of these hath reason to understand? Because none of them is created in the image of God.

[102:125] Therefore, "Because Thou hast taken me up, Thou hast cast me down:" punishment followeth me, because Thou hast given me a free choice.

[102:126] For if Thou hadst not given me a free choice, and for this reason didst not make me better than cattle, just condemnation would not follow me when I sinned.

[102:127] Thus Thou hast taken me up in giving me freedom of choice, and by Thy judgment Thou hast cast me down.

[102:128] "My days have declined like a shadow".

[102:129] He had said above, "My days are consumed away like smoke;" and he now saith, "My days have declined like a shadow".

[102:130] In this shadow, day must be recognised; in this shadow, light must be discerned; lest afterward it be said in late and fruitless repentance, "What hath pride profited us? or what good hath riches with our vaunting brought us? All those things are passed away like a shadow".

[102:131] Say at this season, all things will pass away like a shadow, and thou mayest not pass away like a shadow.

[102:132] "My days have declined like a shadow, and I am withered like grass".

[102:133] For he had said above, "my heart is smitten down, and I am withered like grass".

[102:134] But the grass bedewed with the Saviour's blood will flourish afresh.

[102:135] "I have withered like grass;" I, that is, man, after that disobedience; this I have suffered from Thy just judgment: but what art Thou?.

[102:136] For not because I have fallen, hast Thou grown old: for Thou art strong to set me free, who hast been strong to humble me.

[102:137] "But Thou, O Lord, endurest for ever: and Thy remembrance throughout all generations".

[102:138] "Thy remembrance," because Thou dost not forget: "throughout all generations," forasmuch as we know the promise of life, both present and future.

[102:139] "Thou shalt arise, and have mercy upon Sion: for it is time that Thou have mercy upon her".

[102:140] What time? "But when the fulness of time was come, God sent forth His Son, made of a woman, made under the Law".

[102:141] And where is Sion? "To redeem them that were under the Law".

[102:142] First then were the Jews: for thence were the Apostles, thence those more than five hundred brethren, thence that later multitude, who had but one heart and one soul toward God Therefore, "the time is come".

[102:143] What time? "Behold, now is the accepted time: behold, now is the day of salvation".

[102:144] Who saith this? That Servant of God, that Builder, who said, "Ye are God's building".

[102:145] Here therefore what saith he? "For thy servants take pleasure in her stones".

[102:146] In whose stones? In the stones of Sion? But there are those there that are not stones.

[102:147] Not stones of what? What then followeth? "and pity the dust thereof".

[102:148] I understand by the stones of Sion all the Prophets: there was the voice of preaching sent before, thence the ministry of the Gospel assumed, through their preaching Christ became known.

[102:149] Therefore thy servants have taken pleasure in the stones of Sion.

[102:150] But those faithless apostates from God, who offended their Creator by their evil deeds, have returned to the earth, whence they were taken.

[102:151] They have become dust, they have become ungodly But wait, Lord; bear with us, Lord; be long-suffering, O Lord: let not the wind rush in, and sweep away this dust from the face of the earth.

[102:152] Let thy servants come, let them come, let them acknowledge in the stones thy voice, let them pity the dust of Sion, let them be formed in thy image: let the dust say, lest it perish, "Remember that we are but dust".

[102:153] This of Sion: was not that which crucified the Lord, dust? What is worse, it was dust from the ruined walls; altogether dust it was, but nevertheless it was not in vain said of this dust, "Father, forgive them".

[102:154] From this very dust there came a wall of so many thousands who believed, and who laid the price of their possessions at the Apostles' feet.

[102:155] From that dust then there arose a human nature formed and beautiful.

[102:156] Who among the heathen acted thus? How few are there whom we admire for having done thus, compared with the many thousands of these converts? At first suddenly three, afterwards five thousand; all living in unity, all laying the price of their possessions, when they had sold them, at the Apostles' feet, that it might be distributed to each, as each had need, who had one soul and one heart toward God Who made this even of that very dust, but He who created Adam himself out of dust? This then is concerning Sion, but not in Sion only.

[102:157] "The heathen shall fear Thy Name, O Lord; and all the kings of the earth Thy Majesty".

[102:158] Now that Thou hast pitied Sion, now that Thy servants have taken pleasure in her stones, by acknowledging the foundation of the Apostles and Prophets; now that they have pitied her dust; so that man is formed, or rather re-formed, in life out of dust; hence preaching hath increased among the heathen: let the heathen fear Thy Name, let another wall approach also from the heathen, let the Corner Stone be recognised, let the two who come from different regions, but who no longer differ in belief, meet in close union.

[102:159] "For the Lord shall build up Sion".

[102:160] This work is going on now.

[102:161] O ye living stones, run to the work of building, not to ruin.

[102:162] Sion is in building, beware of the ruined walls: the tower is building, the ark is in building; remember the deluge.

[102:163] This work is in progress now; but when Sion is built, what will happen? "And He will appear in His glory".

[102:164] That He might build up Sion, that He might be a foundation in Sion, He was seen by Sion, but not in His glory: "we have seen Him, and He had no form nor comeliness".

[102:165] But truly when He shall have come with His angels to judge, shall they not look then upon Him whom they have pierced? and they shall be put to confusion when too late, who refused confusion in early and healthful repentance.

[102:166] "He hath turned Him unto the prayer of the poor destitute, and despised not their desire".

[102:167] This is going on now in the building of Sion: the builders of Sion pray, they groan: He is the one poor, because the poor are many; because the thousands among so many nations are one in Him, because He is the unity of the peace of the Church, He is one, He is many: one, through love: many, on account of His extension.

[102:168] Therefore we now pray, we now run: now, if any man hath used to be otherwise, and lived differently, let him eat ashes as it were bread, and mingle his drink with weeping.

[102:169] Now is the time, when Sion is in building: now the stones are entering into the structure: when the building is finished, and the house dedicated, why dost thou run, to ask when too late, to beg in vain, to knock to no purpose, doomed to abide without with the five foolish virgins?  Therefore now run.

[102:170] "Let these things be written for those that come after".

[102:171] When these words were written, they profited not so much those among whom they were written for they were written to prophesy the New Testament, among men who lived according to the Old Testament.

[102:172] But God had both given that Old Testament, and had settled in that land of promise His own people.

[102:173] But since "Thy remembrance is from generation to generation," belongeth not to the ungodly, but to the righteous; "in our generation" belongeth to the Old Testament; while "in the other generation" belongeth to the New Testament; and since the New Testament announceth this that was prophesied, "Let these things be written for those that come after: and the people which shall be created, shall praise the Lord".

[102:174] Not the people which is created, but "the people which shall be created".

[102:175] What is clearer, my brethren? Here is prophesied that creation of which the Apostle saith: "Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature; old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new".

[102:176] "For he hath looked down from His lofty sanctuary".

[102:177] He hath looked down from on high, that He might come unto the humble: from on high He hath become humble, that He might exalt the humble.

[102:178] "Out of the heaven did the Lord look down upon the earth" : "that He might hear the mournings of such as are in fetters, and deliver the children of such as are put to death".

[102:179] We have found it said in another Psalm, "O let the sorrowful sighs of the fettered come before Thee;" and in a passage where the voice of the martyrs was meant.

[102:180] Whence are the martyrs in fetters?But God had bound them with these fetters, hard indeed and painful for a season, but endurable on account of His promises, unto whom it is said, "On account of the words of Thy lips, I have kept hard ways".

[102:181] We must indeed groan in these fetters in order to gain the mercy of God.

[102:182] These fetters must not be shunned, in order to gain a destructive freedom and the temporal and brief pleasure of this life, to be followed by perpetual bitterness.

[102:183] Accordingly Scripture, that we may not refuse the fetters of wisdom, thus addresseth us: "Then shall her fetters be a strong defence for thee, and her chains a robe of glory".

[102:184] Let the fettered therefore cry out, as long as they are in the chains of the discipline of God, in which the martyrs have been tried: the fetters shall be loosed, and they shall fly away, and these very fetters shall afterwards be turned into an ornament.

[102:185] This hath happened with the martyrs.

[102:186] For what have the persecutors effected by killing them, except that their fetters were thereby loosed, and turned into crowns?The remission of sins, is the loosing.

[102:187] For what would it have profited Lazarus, that he came forth from the tomb, unless it were said to him, "loose him, and let him go"? Himself indeed with His voice aroused him from the tomb, Himself restored his life by crying unto him, Himself overcame the mass of earth that was heaped upon the tomb, and he came forth bound hand and foot: not therefore with his own feet, but by the power of Him who drew him forth.

[102:188] This taketh place in the heart of the penitent: when thou hearest a man is sorry for his sins, he hath already come again to life; when thou hearest him by confessing  lay bare his conscience, he is already drawn forth from the tomb, but he is not as yet loosed.

[102:189] When is he loosed, and by whom is he loosed? "Whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth," He saith, "shall be loosed in Heaven".

[102:190] Forgiveness of sins may justly be granted by the Church: but the dead man himself cannot be aroused except by the Lord crying within him; for God doth this within him.

[102:191] We speak to your ears: how do we know what may be going on in your hearts? But what is going on within, is not our doing, but His.

[102:192] "That the name of the Lord may be declared in Sion".

[102:193] For at first, when the fettered were appointed unto death, the Church was oppressed: since these tribulations the Name of the Lord has been declared in Sion, with great freedom, in the Church herself.

[102:194] For she is Sion: not that one spot, at first proud, afterwards taken captive; but the Sion whose shadow was that Sion, which signifieth a watch-tower; because when placed in the flesh, we see into the things before us, extending ourselves not to the present which is now, but to the future.

[102:195] Thus it is a watch-tower: for every watcher gazes far.

[102:196] Places where guards are set, are termed watch-towers: these are set on rocks, on mountains, in trees, that a wider prospect may be commanded from a higher eminence.

[102:197] Sion therefore is a watch-tower, the Church is a watch-tower.

[102:198] If therefore the Church be a watch-tower, the Name of the Lord is already declared there.

[102:199] Not the Lord's Name only is declared in that Sion, but "His praise," He saith, "in Jerusalem".

[102:200] And how is it declared? "In the nations gathering together in one, and the kingdoms, that they may serve the Lord".

[102:201] How is this accomplished, unless by the blood of the slain? How accomplished, but by the groans of the fettered? Those therefore who were in tribulation and humility have been heard; that in our times the Church might be in the great glory which we see her in, so that the very kingdoms which then persecuted her, now serve the Lord.

[102:202] "She answered Him in the way of His strength".

[102:203] The preceding words show, that either "His praise," or "Jerusalem," answered: for it was said, "And His praise in Jerusalem; in the nations gathering together in one, and the kingdoms, that they may serve the Lord.

[102:204] Respondit ei".

[102:205] We cannot say, "the kingdoms answered," for he would have said responderunt.

[102:206] Respondit ei.

[102:207] We cannot say, "the nations answered," for he would have said, responderunt (in the plural).

[102:208] Since then it is Respondit ei, in the singular, we look for the singular number above, and find that the words, "His praise," and "Jerusalem," are the only words in which we find it.

[102:209] But since it is doubtful, whether it be "His praise," or "Jerusalem," let us expound it each way.

[102:210] How did "His praise" answer Him? When they who are called by Him thank Him.

[102:211] For He calleth, we answer; not by our voice, but by our faith; not by our tongue, but by our life.

[102:212] From His elect and holy men, Jerusalem also answereth Him.

[102:213] For Jerusalem also was called: and the first Jerusalem refused to hear, and it was said unto her, "Behold, thy house shall be left unto the desolate".

[102:214] But that Jerusalem, of whom it was written, "Sing, O barren, thou that didst not bear," "She hath answered Him".

[102:215] What meaneth, "She hath answered Him"? She despiseth Him not when He called.

[102:216] He sent rain, She gave fruit.

[102:217] "She answered Him:" but where? "in the path of His strength".

[102:218] The Church therefore answered Him not in the way of weakness; because after His resurrection He called the Church from the whole world, no longer weak upon the cross, but strong in heaven.

[102:219] For it is not the praise of the Christian faith that they believe that Christ died, but that they believe that He arose from the dead.

[102:220] Even the Pagan believeth that He died; and maketh this a charge against thee, that thou hast believed in one dead.

[102:221] What then is thy praise? It is that thou believest that Christ arose from the dead, and that thou dost hope that thou shalt rise from the dead through Christ: this is the praise of faith.

[102:222] "For if thou shalt confess with thy mouth that Jesus is the Lord, and shalt believe in thy heart that God hath raised Him from the dead, thou shalt be saved".

[102:223] This is the faith of Christians.

[102:224] In this faith then, in which the Church is gathered, "She hath answered Him," She gave Him worship according to His commandments: "in the path of His strength," not in the path of His weakness.

[102:225] How she answered Him, ye have already heard above.

[102:226] "In the gathering of the nations into one".

[102:227] Herein she answered Him, in unity: he who is not in unity, answereth Him not.

[102:228] For He is One, the Church is unity: none but unity answereth to Him who is One.

[102:229] Since some were destined to say against her, She hath existed, and no longer doth exist; "Show me," He saith, "the shortness of my days," what is it, that I know not what apostates from me murmur against me? why is it that lost men contend that I have perished? For they surely say this, that I have been, and no longer am: "Show me the shortness of my days".

[102:230] I do not ask from Thee about those everlasting days: they are without end, where I shall be; it is not those I ask of: I ask of temporal days; show unto me my temporal days; "show me the shortness," not the eternity, "of my days".

[102:231] Declare unto me, how long I shall be in this world: on account of those who say, "She hath been," and is no more: on account of those who say, The Scriptures are fulfilled, all nations have believed, but the Church hath become apostate, and hath perished from among all nations.

[102:232] Seest thou not that there are still nations among whom the Gospel hath not been preached? Since then it is needful that what the Lord spoke shall be fulfilled, declaring unto the Church the shortness of my days, that this Gospel be preached in all nations, and then that the end may come, why is it that thou sayest that the Church hath already perished from among all nations, when the Gospel is being preached for this purpose, that it may be in all nations? Therefore the Church remaineth even unto the end of the world, in all nations; and this is the shortness of Her days, because all that is limited is short; so that She may pass into eternity from this brief existence.

[102:233] May heretics be lost, may that which they are be lost, and may they be found, that they may be what they are not.

[102:234] Shortness of days will be unto the end of the world: shortness for this reason, because the whole of this season, I say not from this day unto the end of the world, but from Adam down to the end of the world, is a mere drop compared with eternity.

[102:235] Let not therefore heretics flatter themselves against me, because I said, "the shortness of my days," as if they would not last down to the end of the world.

[102:236] For what hath he added? "O my God, take me not away in the midst of my days".

[102:237] Deal Thou not with me according as heretics speak.

[102:238] Lead me on unto the end of the world, not only to the middle of my days; and finish my short days, that Thou mayest afterwards grant unto me eternal days.

[102:239] Wherefore then hast thou asked concerning the shortness of thy days? Wherefore? Dost thou wish to hear? "Thy years are in the generation of generations".

[102:240] This is why I asked concerning those short days, because although my days should endure unto the end of the world, yet they are short in comparison of Thy days.

[102:241] For "Thy years are in the generation of generations".

[102:242] Wherefore doth he not say, Thy years are unto worlds of worlds; for thus rather is eternity usually signified in the holy Scriptures; but he saith, "Thy years are in the generation of generations"? But what are thy years? what, but those which do not come, and then pass away? what, but they which come not, so as to cease again? For every day in this season so cometh as to cease again; every hour, every month, every year; nothing of these is stationary; before it hath come, it is to be; after it hath come, it will not be.

[102:243] Those everlasting years of thine, therefore, those years that are not changed, "are in the generation of generations".

[102:244] There is a "generation of generations;" in that shall thy years be.

[102:245] There is one such, and if we acknowledge it aright, we shall be in it, and the years of God shall be in us.

[102:246] How shall they be in us? Just as God Himself shall be in us: whence it is said, "That God may be all in all".

[102:247] For the years of God, and God Himself, are not different: but the years of God are the eternity of God: eternity is the very substance of God, which hath nothing changeable; there nothing is past, as if it were no longer: nothing is future, as if it existed not as yet.

[102:248] There is nothing there but, Is: there is not there, Was, and Will be; because what was, is now no longer: and what will be, is not as yet: but whatever is there, simply Is.

[102:249] Behold this great I Am! What is man's being to this? To this great I Am, what is man, whatever he be? Who can understand that To Be? who can share it? who can pant, aspire, presume that he may be there? Despair not, human frailty! "I am," He saith, "the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob".

[102:250] Thou hast heard what I am in Myself: now hear what I am on thy account.

[102:251] This eternity then hath called us, and the Word burst forth from eternity.

[102:252] It is now eternity, it is now the Word, and no longer time.

[102:253] From so many generations thou wilt gather together all the holy offspring of all generations, and wilt form one generation thence: "In" this "generation of generations are Thy years," that is, that eternity will be in that generation, which is collected from all generations, and reduced into one; this shall share in Thy eternity.

[102:254] Other generations are born for fulfilling their times, out of which this one is regenerated for ever; though changed it shall be endued with life, it shall be fitted to bear Thee, receiving strength from Thee.

[102:255] "Thou, Lord, in the beginning hast laid the foundation of the earth: and the Heavens are the work of Thy hands".

[102:256] God laid the foundation of the earth, we know: the heavens are the works of His hands.

[102:257] For do not imagine that God doth one thing with His hand, another by His word.

[102:258] What He doth by His word, He doth by His hand: for He hath not distinct bodily members, who said, "I Am That I Am".

[102:259] And perhaps His Word is His hand, assuredly His hand is His power.

[102:260] For inasmuch as it is said, "Let there be a firmament," and there was a firmament; He is understood to have created it by His Word; but when He said, "Let Us make man in Our image, after Our likeness;" He seemeth to have created him by His hand.

[102:261] Hear therefore: "The heavens are the work of Thy hands".

[102:262] Lo, what He created by His word, He created also by His hands; because He created them through His excellence, through His power.

[102:263] Observe rather what He created, and seek not to know in what manner He created them.

[102:264] It is much to thee to understand how He created them, since He created thyself so, that thou mayest first be a servant obeying, and afterwards perhaps a friend understanding.

[102:265] "They shall perish, but Thou shalt endure".

[102:266] The Apostle Peter saith this openly: "By the word of God the heavens were of old," etc He hath said then that the heavens have already perished by the flood: and we know that the heavens perished as far as the extent of this atmosphere of ours.

[102:267] For the water increased, and filled the whole of that space in which birds fly; thus perished the heavens that are near the earth; those heavens which are meant when we speak of the birds of heaven.

[102:268] But there are heavens of heavens higher than these in the firmament: but whether these also shall perish by fire, or those only which perished also by the flood, is a much harder question among the learned, nor can it easily, especially in a limited space of time, be explained.

[102:269] Let us therefore dismiss or put it off; nevertheless, let us know that these things perish, and that God endureth.

[102:270] Perhaps by the heavens we here may understand, without being far-fetched, the righteous themselves, the saints of God, abiding in whom God hath thundered in His commandments, lightened in His miracles, watered the earth with the wisdom of truth, for "The heavens have declared the glory of God".

[102:271] But shall they perish? Shall they in any sense perish? In what sense? As a garment What is, as a garment? As to the body.

[102:272] For the body is the garment of the soul; since our Lord called it a garment, when He said, "Is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment?" How then doth the garment perish? "Though our outward man perish, yet the inward man is renewed day by day".

[102:273] They then shall perish: but as to the body: "But Thou shalt endure".

[102:274] Such heavens therefore shall  perish; not, however, for ever; they shall perish, that they may be changed.

[102:275] Doth not the Psalm say this? Read the following: "They shall all wax old as doth a garment; and as a vesture shalt Thou change them, and they shall be changed".

[102:276] Thou hearest of the garment, of the vesture, and dost thou understand anything but the body? We may therefore hope for the change of our bodies also, but from Him who was before us, and abideth after us.

[102:277] "But Thou art the same, and Thy years shall not fail".

[102:278] But what are we to those years with these beggarly years? and what are they? Yet we ought not to despair.

[102:279] He had already said in His great and exceeding Wisdom, "I Am That I Am;" and yet He saith to console us, "I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob:" and we are Abraham's seed: even we, although abject, although dust and ashes, trust in Him.

[102:280] We are servants: but for our sakes our Lord took the garb of a servant: for us who are mortal the Immortal One deigned to die, for our sakes He showed His example of resurrection.

[102:281] Let us therefore hope that we may reach these lasting years, in which days are not spent in a revolution of the Sun, but what is abideth even as it is, because it alone truly Is.

[102:282] "The children of Thy servants shall dwell there: and their seed shall stand fast for ages" : for the age of ages, the age of eternity, the age that abideth.

[102:283] But, "the children," he saith, "of Thy servants:" is it to be feared lest we be the servants of God, and our children, and not ourselves, dwell there? Or if we are the children of the servants, inasmuch as we are the Apostles' children, what are we to say? Can those children rising after have so unhappy a presumption, as to boast in their late succession, and so to venture to say, We shall be there; the Apostles will not be there? May this be far from their piety as children, from their faith as little ones, from their understanding when of age! The Apostles also will be there: rams go before, lambs follow.

[102:284] Wherefore then, "the children of Thy servants;" and not in brief, "Thy servants"? Both they are Thy servants, and their children are Thy servants; and the children of these, their grandsons, what are they but Thy servants? Thou wouldest include them all briefly, if Thou shouldest say, Thy servants shall dwell therein.

[102:285] "The children of Thy servants," are the works of Thy servants; no one shall dwell there, but through his own works.

[102:286] What therefore meaneth, Their children shall dwell? Let no man boast that he shall dwell there, if he calleth himself God's servant, and hath not works; for none but children shall dwell there.

[102:287] What meaneth therefore, "The children of Thy servants shall dwell there"? Thy servants shall dwell there by their own works, Thy servants shall dwell there through their own children.

[102:288] Be not therefore barren, if thou dost wish to dwell there; send before the children whom thou mayest follow, by sending them before thee, not by burying them.

[102:289] Let thy children lead thee to the land of promise, the land of the living, not of the dying: whilst thou art living here in this pilgrimage, let them go before thee, let them receive thee.

[103:1] Psalm CIII.

[103:2] "Bless the Lord, O my soul! and all that is within me, His holy Name".

[103:3] I suppose that he speaketh not of what is within the body; I do not suppose him to mean this, that our lungs and liver, and so forth, are to burst forth into the voice of blessing of the Lord.

[103:4] There are lungs in our breast indeed, like a kind of bellows, which send forth successive breathings, which breathing forth of the air inhaled is pressed out into voice and sound, when the words are articulated; nor can any utterance sound forth from our mouth, but what the pressed lungs have given vent to; but this is not the meaning here; all this relateth to the ears of men.

[103:5] God hath ears: the heart also hath a voice.

[103:6] A man speaketh to the things within him, that they may bless God, and saith unto them, "all that is within me bless His holy Name!" Dost thou ask the meaning of what is within thee? Thy soul itself.

[103:7] In saying then, "all that is within me, bless His holy Name," it only repeateth the above, "Bless the Lord, O my soul:" for the word "Bless," is understood.

[103:8] Cry out with thy voice, if there be a man to hear; hush thy voice, when there is no man to hear thee; there is never wanting one to hear all that is within thee.

[103:9] Blessing therefore hath already been uttered from our mouth, when we were chanting these very words.

[103:10] We sung as much as sufficed for the time, and were then silent: ought our hearts within us to be silent to the blessing of the Lord? Let the sound of our voices bless Him at intervals, alternately, let the voice of our hearts be perpetual.

[103:11] When thou comest to church to recite a hymn, thy voice soundeth forth the praises of God: thou hast sung as far as thou couldest, thou hast left the church; let thy soul sound the praises of God.

[103:12] Thou art engaged in thy daily work: let thy soul praise God.

[103:13] Thou art taking food; see what the Apostle saith: "Whether ye eat or drink, do all to the glory of God".

[103:14] I venture to say; when thou sleepest, let thy soul praise the Lord.

[103:15] Let not thoughts of crime arouse thee, let not the contrivances of thieving arouse thee, let not arranged plans of corrupt dealing arouse thee.

[103:16] Thy innocence even when thou art sleeping is the voice of thy soul.

[103:17] "Bless the Lord, O my soul, and forget not all His rewards".

[103:18] But the rewards of the Lord cannot be before thine eyes unless thy sins are before thine eyes.

[103:19] Let not delight in past sin be before thine eyes, but let the condemnation of sin be before thine eyes: condemnation from thee, forgiveness from God.

[103:20] For thus God rewardeth thee, so that thou mayest say, "How shall I reward the Lord for all His rewards unto me?" This it was that the martyrs considering (whose memory we are this day celebrating), and all the saints who have despised this life, and as ye have heard in the Epistle of St.
