[103:21] John, laid down their lives for the brethren, which is the perfection of love, even as our Lord saith: "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends:" this the holy martyrs, then, considering, despised their lives here, that they might find them there, following our Lord's words when He said, "He that loveth his life, shall lose it; and he that loseth his life for My sake, shall keep it unto life eternal".

[103:22] "Forget not," he saith, "all His rewards:" not awards, but "rewards".

[103:23] For something else was due, and what was not due hath been paid.

[103:24] Whence also these words: "What," he asketh, "shall I reward the Lord for all His rewards unto me?" Thou hast rewarded good with evil; He rewardeth evil with good.

[103:25] How hast thou, O man, rewarded thy God with evil for good? Thou who hast once been a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and injurious, hast rewarded blasphemies.

[103:26] For what good things? First, because thou art: but a stone also is.

[103:27] Next, because thou livest: but a brute also liveth.

[103:28] What reward wilt thou give the Lord, for His having created thee above all the cattle; and above all the fowls of the air, in His image and likeness? Seek not how to reward Him: give back unto Him His own image: He requireth no more; He demandeth His own coin.

[103:29] Think thou, soul, of all the rewards of God, in thinking over all thy wicked deeds: for as many as are thy sins, so many are His rewards of good.

[103:30] And what present, what offering, what sacrifice, canst thou ever tender unto Him?What wilt thou reward the Lord with? For thou wast reflecting, and couldest not find: "I will receive the cup of salvation".

[103:31] What? hath not the Lord Himself given the cup of salvation? Reward Him from thine own, if thou canst.

[103:32] I would say, No, do it not; reward Him not from thine own; God doth not will to be rewarded from thine own.

[103:33] If thou rewardest Him from thine own, thou rewardest sin.

[103:34] For all that thou hast thou hast from Him: sins only thou hast of thine own.

[103:35] He doth not wish to be rewarded from thine, He doth will from His own.

[103:36] Just as, if thou shouldest bring to a husbandman, from the land which he hath sown, an ear of wheat, thou hast rewarded him from the husbandman's own produce; if thorns, that hast offered him of thine own.

[103:37] Reward truth, in truth praise the Lord: if thou shalt choose to reward Him from thine own, thou wilt lie.

[103:38] He who speaketh a lie, speaketh of his own If he who speaketh a lie, speaketh of his own: so he who speaketh truth, speaketh of the Lord's.

[103:39] But what is to receive the cup of salvation, but to imitate the Passion of our Lord?I will receive the cup of Christ, I will drink of our Lord's Passion.

[103:40] Beware that thou fail not.

[103:41] But, "I will call upon the Name of the Lord".

[103:42] They then who failed, called not upon the Lord; they presumed in their own strength.

[103:43] Do thou so return, as remembering that thou art returning what thou hast received.

[103:44] So then let thy soul bless the Lord, as not to forget all His rewards.

[103:45] Hear ye all His rewards.

[103:46] "Who forgiveth all thy sin: who healeth all thine infirmities".

[103:47] Behold His rewards.

[103:48] What, save punishment, was due unto the sinner? What was due to the blasphemer, but the hell of burning fire? He gave not these rewards: that thou mayest not shudder with dread: and without love fear Him.

[103:49] But thou art a sinner.

[103:50] Turn again, and receive these His rewards: He "forgiveth all thy sin".

[103:51] Yet even after remission of sins the soul herself is shaken by certain passions; still is she amid the dangers of temptation, still is she pleased with certain suggestions; with some she is not pleased, and sometimes she consenteth unto some of those with which she is pleased: she is taken.

[103:52] This is infirmity: but He "healeth all thine infirmities".

[103:53] All thine infirmities shall be healed: fear not.

[103:54] They are great, thou wilt say: but the Physician is greater.

[103:55] No infirmity cometh before the Almighty Physician as incurable: only suffer thou thyself to be healed: repel not His hands; He knoweth how to deal with thee.

[103:56] Be not only pleased when He cherisheth thee, but also bear with Him when He useth the knife: bear the pain of the remedy, reflecting on thy future health.

[103:57] Thou dost not endure in uncertainty: He who promised thee health, cannot be deceived.

[103:58] The physician is often deceived: and promiseth health in the human body.

[103:59] Why is he deceived? Because he is not healing his own creature.

[103:60] God made thy body, God made thy soul.

[103:61] He knoweth how to restore what He hath made, He knoweth how to fashion again what He hath already fashioned: do thou only be patient beneath the Physician's hands: for He hateth one who rejects His hands.

[103:62] This doth not happen with the hands of a human physician.

[103:63] "Who redeemeth thy life from corruption".

[103:64] Behold, "the body which is corrupted, weigheth down the soul".

[103:65] The soul then hath life in a corruptible body.

[103:66] What sort of life? It suffereth burdens, it beareth weights.

[103:67] How great obstacles are there to thinking of God Himself, as it is right that men should think of God, as if interrupting us from the necessity of human corruption? how many influences recall us, how many interrupt, how many withdraw the mind when fixed on high? what a crowd of illusions, what tribes of suggestions? All this in the human heart, as it were, teemeth with the worms of human corruption.

[103:68] We have set forth the greatness of the disease, let us also praise the Physician.

[103:69] Shall not He then heal thee, who made thee such as to be in health, hadst thou chosen to keep the law of health which thou hadst received?First think of thine own health.

[103:70] Sometimes a man is stricken in his own house, on his bed, with a more than usually manifest disorder; although this disorder too, which men dislike to contemplate, be plain; yet each man may be attacked with that sickness for which human physicians are sought, and may gasp with fever in his bed; perhaps he may wish to consider of his domestic affairs, to make some order or disposition relating to his estate or his house; at once he is recalled from such cares by the anxiety of his friends, plainly expressed around him, and he is advised to dismiss these subjects, and first to take thought for his health.

[103:71] This then is addressed unto thee, and to all men: if thou art not sick, think of other things: if thy very infirmity prove thee sick, first take heed of thy health.

[103:72] Christ is thy health: think therefore of Christ.

[103:73] Receive the cup of His saving Health, "who healeth all thine infirmities;" if thou shalt choose, thou shalt gain this Health.

[103:74] For thy life hath been redeemed from corruption: rest secure now: the contract of good faith hath been entered upon; no man deceives, no man circumvents, no man oppresses, thy Redeemer.

[103:75] He hath here made a barter, He hath already paid the price, He hath poured forth His blood.

[103:76] The only Son of God, I say, hath shed His blood for us: O soul, raise thyself, thou art of so great price.

[103:77] "He redeemeth thy life from corruption".

[103:78] "Who crowneth thee with mercy and loving-kindness".

[103:79] Thou hadst perhaps begun to be in a manner proud, when thou didst hear the words, "He crowneth thee".

[103:80] I am then great, I have then wrestled.

[103:81] By whose strength? By thine, but supplied by Him.

[103:82] He crowneth thee, because He is crowning His own gifts, not thy deservings.

[103:83] "I laboured more abundantly than they all," said the Apostle; but see what he addeth: "yet not I, but the grace of God which was with me".

[103:84] It is then by His mercy that thou art crowned; in nothing be proud; ever praise the Lord; forget not all His rewards.

[103:85] It is a reward when thou, a sinner and an ungodly man, hast been called, that thou mayest be justified.

[103:86] It is a reward, when thou art raised up and guided, that thou mayest not fall.

[103:87] It is a reward, when strength is given thee, that thou mayest persevere unto the end.

[103:88] It is a reward, that even that flesh of thine by which thou wast oppressed riseth again and that not even a hair of thy head perisheth.

[103:89] It is a reward, that after thy resurrection thou art crowned.

[103:90] It is a reward, that thou mayest praise God Himself for evermore without ceasing.

[103:91] After the battle, then, I shall be crowned; after the crown, what shall I do? "He who satisfieth thy longing with good things".

[103:92] Seek thy own good, O soul.

[103:93] For one thing is good to one creature, another to another, and all creatures have a certain good of their own, to the completeness and perfection of their nature.

[103:94] There is a difference as to what is essential to each imperfect thing, in order that it may be made perfect; seek for thy own good.

[103:95] "There is none good but One, that is, God".

[103:96] The highest good is thy good.

[103:97] What then is wanting unto him to whom the highest good is good? For there are inferior goods, which are good to different creatures respectively.

[103:98] What, brethren, is good unto the cattle, save to fill the belly, to prevent want, to sleep, to indulge themselves, to exist, to be in health, to propagate? This is good to them: and within certain bounds it hath an allotted measure of good, granted by God, the Creator of all things.

[103:99] Dost thou seek such a good as this? God giveth also this: but do not pursue it alone.

[103:100] Canst thou, a coheir of Christ, rejoice in fellowship with cattle? Raise thy hope to the good of all goods.

[103:101] He will be thy good, by whom thou in thy kind hast been made good, and by whom all things in their kind were made good.

[103:102] For God made all things very good.

[103:103] When shall my longing be satisfied with good things? when, dost thou ask? "Thy youth shall be renewed as the eagle's".

[103:104] Dost thou then ask when thy soul is to be satisfied with good things? When thy youth shall be restored.

[103:105] And he addeth, as an eagle's.

[103:106] Something here lieth hidden; what however is said of the eagle, we will not pass over silently, since it is not foreign to our purpose to understand it.

[103:107] Let this only be impressed upon our hearts, that it is not said without cause by the Holy Spirit.

[103:108] For it hath intimated unto us a sort of resurrection.

[103:109] And indeed the youth of the eagle is restored, but not into immortality, for a similitude hath been given, as far as it could be drawn from a thing mortal to signify a thing immortal, not to demonstrate it.

[103:110] The eagle is said, after it becometh overpowered with bodily age, to be incapable of taking food from the immoderate length of its beak, which is always increasing.

[103:111] For after the upper part of its beak, which forms a crook above the lower part, hath increased from old age to an immoderate length, the length of this increase will not allow of its opening its mouth, so as to form any interval between the lower beak and the crook above.

[103:112] For unless there be such an opening, it hath no power of biting like a forceps, by which to shear off what it may put within its jaws.

[103:113] The upper part therefore increasing, and being too far hooked over, it cannot open its mouth, and take any food.

[103:114] This old age doth to it, it is weighed down with the infirmity of age, and becometh too weak from want of power to eat; two causes of infirmity assaulting it, old age, and want.

[103:115] By a natural device, therefore, in order in some measure to restore its youth, the eagle is said to dash and strike against a rock the upper lip of its beak, by the too great increase of which the opening for eating is closed: and by thus rubbing it against the rock, it breaketh off the weight of its old beak, which impeded its taking food.

[103:116] It cometh to its food, and everything is restored: it will be after its old age like a young eagle; the vigour of all its limbs returneth, the lustre of its plumage, the guidance of its wings, it flieth aloft as before, a sort of resurrection taketh place in it.

[103:117] For this is the object of the similitude, like that of the Moon, which after waning and being apparently intercepted, again is renewed, and becometh full; and signifieth to us the resurrection; but when it is full it doth not remain so; again it waneth, that the signification may never cease.

[103:118] Thus also what hath here been said of the eagle: the eagle is not restored unto immortality, but we are unto eternal life; but the similitude is derived from hence, that the rock taketh away from us what hindereth us.

[103:119] Presume not therefore on thy strength: the firmness of the rock rubbeth off thy old age: for that Rock was Christ.

[103:120] In Christ our youth shall be restored like that of the eagle.

[103:121] "The Lord executeth mercy and judgment for all them that are oppressed with wrong".

[103:122] An adulterous woman is brought forward to be stoned according to the Law, but she is brought before the Lawgiver Himself.

[103:123] Our Lord, at the time she was brought before Him, bending His Head, began writing on the earth.

[103:124] When He bent Himself down upon the earth, He then wrote on the earth: before He bent upon the earth, He wrote not on the earth, but on stone.

[103:125] The earth was now something fertile, ready to bring forth from the Lord's letters.

[103:126] On the stone He had written the Law, intimating the hardness of the Jews: He wrote on the earth, signifying the productiveness of Christians.

[103:127] Then they who were leading the adulteress came, like raging waves against a rock: but they were dashed to pieces by His answer.

[103:128] For He said to them, "He that is without sin among you, let him first cast a stone at her".

[103:129] And again bending His head, He began writing on the ground.

[103:130] And now each man, when he asked his own conscience, came not forward.

[103:131] It was not a weak adulterous woman, but their own adulterate conscience, that drove them back.

[103:132] They wished to punish, to judge; they came to the Rock, their judges were overthrown by the Rock.

[103:133] Execute mercy to the wicked, not as being wicked.

[103:134] Do not receive the wicked, in so far forth as he is wicked: that is, do not receive him as if from inclination towards and love for his iniquity.

[103:135] For it is forbidden to give unto a sinner, and to receive sinners.

[103:136] Yet how is this, "Give unto every man that asketh of thee"? and this, "if thine enemy hunger, feed him"? This is seemingly contradictory: but it is opened to those who knock in the name of Christ, and will be clear unto those who seek.

[103:137] "Help not a sinner:" and, "give not to the ungodly;" and yet, "give unto every man that asketh of thee".

[103:138] But it is a sinner who asketh of me.

[103:139] Give, not as unto a sinner.

[103:140] When dost thou give as unto a sinner? When that which maketh him a sinner, pleaseth thee so that thou givestLet those who give to a man who fights with wild beasts, tell me why they give? Why doth he give to this man? He loveth that in him, in which consists his greatest sin; this he feedeth, this he clotheth in him, wickedness itself, made public by all witnessing it.

[103:141] Why doth the man give, who giveth to actors, or to charioteers, or to courtesans? Do not these very persons give to human beings? But it is not the nature of God's work that they attend to, but the iniquity of the human work.

[103:142] When therefore thou givest, thou givest to infamy, not to bravery.

[103:143] As then he who giveth to the fighter of beasts, giveth not to the man, but to a most infamous profession; for if he were only a man, and not a fighter of beasts, thou wouldest not give; thou honourest him in vice, not nature: so on the other hand, if thou give to the righteous, if thou give to the prophet, if thou give to the disciple of Christ anything of which he is in want, without thinking that he is Christ's disciple, that he is God's minister, that he is God's steward; but art thinking in that case of some temporal advantage, for instance, that when perchance he shall be needful to thy cause, he may be bought for thee, because thou hast given him something; thou hast no more given to the righteous, if thou hast thus given, than he gave to the man, when he gave to the beast-fighter.

[103:144] The matter, then, most beloved, is quite open to us, and I conceive, that although it was obscure, it is now clear.

[103:145] It was to this that the Lord bound thee, when He said, "He who hath received the righteous man".

[103:146] That were enough.

[103:147] But as the righteous may be received with another intention,He saith, "He who receiveth a righteous man in the name of a righteous man:" that is, receiving him in consideration of his righteousness:that is, because he is Christ's disciple, because he is a steward of the Mystery: "Verily I say unto you, he shall in no wise lose his reward".

[103:148] So understand, he who receiveth a sinner in the name of a sinner shall lose his reward.

[103:149] On this account therefore be merciful without fear, extend love even unto thine enemies: punish those who chance to belong to thy government, restrain them with affection, with charity, in regard to their eternal salvation; lest while thou sparest the flesh, the soul perish.

[103:150] Do this: and though thou have to endure many, over whom thou canst not exercise discipline, because thou hast no lawful authority over them; bear their injuries; be without apprehension.

[103:151] He will show mercy unto thee if thou shalt have been merciful: thou shalt be merciful, without the injuries thou sufferest losing their punishment; "To Me belongeth vengeance, I will repay," saith the Lord.

[103:152] "He made His ways known unto Moses".

[103:153] For the Law was given with this view, that the sick might be convinced of his infirmity, and pray for the physician.

[103:154] This is the hidden way of God.

[103:155] Thou hadst long ago heard, "Who healeth all thine infirmities".

[103:156] Their infirmities were as yet hidden in the sick; the five books were given to Moses: the pool was surrounded by five porches; he brought forth the sick, that they might lie there, that they might be made known, not that they might be healed.

[103:157] The five porches discovered, but healed not, the sick; the pool healed when one descended, and this when it was disturbed: the disturbance of the pool was in our Lord's Passion.

[103:158] Since therefore this is a mystery there, he teacheth that the Law was given that sinners might be convinced of their sin, and call upon the Physician in order to receive grace.

[103:159] Therefore, as I had begun to say, because this is a great mystery in the Law, that it was given with this view, that by the increase of sin, the proud might be humbled, the humbled might confess, the confessing might be healed; these are the hidden ways, which He made known to Moses, through whom He gave the Law, by which sin should abound, that grace might more abound.

[103:160] "He hath made known His good pleasure unto the children of Israel".

[103:161] To all the children of Israel? To the true children of Israel; yea, to all the children of Israel.

[103:162] For the treacherous, the insidious, the hypocrites, are not children of Israel.

[103:163] And who are the children of Israel? "Behold an Israelite indeed, in whom is no guile".

[103:164] "The Lord is full of compassion and mercy: long-suffering, and of great mercy".

[103:165] Why so long-suffering? Why so great in mercy? Men sin and live; sins are added on, life continueth: men blaspheme daily, and "He maketh His sun to rise over the good and the wicked".

[103:166] On all sides He calleth to amendment, on all sides He calleth to repentance, He calleth by the blessings of creation, He calleth by giving time for life, He calleth through the reader, He calleth through the preacher, He calleth through the innermost thought by the rod of correction, He calleth by the mercy of consolation: "He is long-suffering, and of great mercy".

[103:167] But take heed lest by ill using the length of God's mercy, thou treasure up for thyself, as the Apostle saith, wrath in the day of wrath.

[103:168] For some there are who prepare to turn, and yet put it off, and in them crieth out the raven's voice, "Cras! Cras!" The raven which was sent from the ark, never returned God seeketh not procrastination in the raven's voice, but confession in the wailing of the dove.

[103:169] The dove, when sent forth, returned.

[103:170] How long, To-morrow! To-morrow!? Look to thy last morrow: since thou knowest not what is thy last morrow, let it suffice that thou hast lived up to this day a sinner.

[103:171] Thou hast heard, often thou art wont to hear, thou hast heard to-day also; daily thou hearest, and daily thou amendest not.

[103:172] "He will not alway be chiding: neither keepeth He His anger for ever".

[103:173] Since it is in consequence of His anger that we live in the scourges and corruption of mortality: we have this in punishment for the first sin.

[103:174] Is it not through His anger, my brethren, that "in the sweat of thy face and in toil thou shalt eat bread, and the earth shall bear thorns and thistles unto thee"? This was said to our forefathers.

[103:175] Or if our life is different from this; if thou canst, turn unto some pleasure, where thou mayest not feel thorns.

[103:176] Choose what thou hast wished, whether thou art covetous or luxurious; to name these two alone; add a third passion, that of ambition; how great thorns are there in the desire of honours? in the luxury of lusts how great thorns? in the ardour of covetousness how great thorns? What troubles are there in base loves? What terrible anxieties here in this life? I omit hell.

[103:177] Beware lest thou even now become a hell unto thyself.

[103:178] The whole of this, my brethren, is the result of His anger: and when thou hast turned thyself unto works of righteousness, thou canst not but toil upon earth; and toil endeth not before life endeth.

[103:179] We must toil on the way, that we may rejoice in our country.

[103:180] He therefore consoleth by His promises thy toil, thy labours, thy troubles, saying to thee, "He will not alway be chiding".

[103:181] "He hath not dealt with us according to our sins".

[103:182] Thanks unto God, because He hath vouchsafed this.

[103:183] We have not received what we were deserving of: "He hath not dealt with us according to our sins, nor rewarded us according to our wickednesses".

[103:184] "For as the height of heaven above the earth, so hath the Lord confirmed His mercy toward them that fear Him".

[103:185] Observe the heaven: everywhere on every side it covereth the earth, nor is there any part of the earth not covered by the heaven.

[103:186] Men sin beneath heaven: they do all evil deeds beneath the heaven; yet they are covered by the heaven.

[103:187] Thence is light for the eyes, thence air, thence breath, thence rain upon the earth for the sake of its fruits, thence all mercy from heaven.

[103:188] Take away the aid of heaven from the earth: it will fail at once.

[103:189] As then the protection of heaven abideth upon the earth, so doth the Lord's protection abide upon them that fear Him.

[103:190] Thou fearest God, His protection is above thee.

[103:191] But perhaps thou art scourged, and conceivest that God hath forsaken thee.

[103:192] God hath forsaken thee, if the protection of heaven hath forsaken the earth.

[103:193] "Look, how wide the east is from the west; so far hath He set our sins from us".

[103:194] They who know the Sacraments know this; nevertheless, I only say what all may hear When sin is remitted, thy sins fall, thy grace riseth; thy sins are as it were on the decline, thy grace which freeth thee on the rise.

[103:195] "Truth springeth from the earth".

[103:196] What meaneth this? Thy grace is born, thy sins fall, thou art in a certain manner made new.

[103:197] Thou shouldest look to the rising, and turn away from the setting Turn away from thy sins, turn unto the grace of God; when thy sins fall, thou riseth and profitest.

[103:198] One region of the heaven falleth, another riseth: but the region which is now rising will set after twelve hours.

[103:199] Not like this is the grace which riseth unto us: both our sins fall for ever, and grace abideth for ever.

[103:200] "Yea, like as a father pitieth his own children, even so hath the Lord had mercy on them that fear Him".

[103:201] Let Him be as angry as He shall will, He is our Father.

[103:202] But He hath scourged us, and afflicted us, and bruised us: He is our Father.

[103:203] Son, if thou bewailest, wail beneath thy Father; do not so with indignation, do not so with the puffing up of pride.

[103:204] What thou sufferest, whence thou mournest, it is medicine, not punishment; it is thy chastening, not thy condemnation.

[103:205] Do not refuse the scourge, if thou dost not wish to be refused thy heritage: do not think of what punishment thou sufferest in the scourge, but what place thou hast in the Testament.

[103:206] "For He knoweth our forming" : that is, our infirmity.

[103:207] He knoweth what He hath created, how it hath fallen, how it may be repaired, how it may be adopted, how it may be enriched.

[103:208] Behold, we are made of clay: "The first man is of the earth, earthy: the second man is the Lord from heaven".

[103:209] He sent even His own Son, Him who was made the second man, Him who was God before all things.

[103:210] For He was second in His coming, first in His returning: He died after many, He arose before all.

[103:211] "He knoweth our forming".

[103:212] What forming? Ourselves.

[103:213] Why sayest thou that He knoweth? Because He hath pitied.

[103:214] "Remember that we are but dust".

[103:215] Addressing God Himself, he saith, "Remember," as if God could forget: He perceiveth, He knoweth in such a manner that He cannot forget.

[103:216] But what meaneth, "Remember"? Let thy mercy continue towards us.

[103:217] Thou knowest our forming; forget not our forming, lest we forget thy grace.

[103:218] "Man, his days are but as grass".

[103:219] Let man consider what he is; let not man be proud.

[103:220] "His days are but as grass".

[103:221] Why is the grass proud, that is now flourishing, and in a very short space dried up? Why is the grass proud that flourisheth only for a brief season, until the sun be hot? It is then good for us that His mercy be upon us, and from grass make gold.

[103:222] "For he flourisheth as a flower of the field".

[103:223] The whole splendour of the human race; honour, powers, riches, pride, threats, is the flower of the grass.

[103:224] That house flourisheth, and that family is great, that family flourisheth; and how many flourish, and how many years do they live! Many years to thee, are but a short season unto God.

[103:225] God doth not count, as thou dost.

[103:226] Compared with the length and long life of ages, all the flower of any house is as the flower of the field.

[103:227] All the beauty of the year hardly lasteth for the year.

[103:228] Whatever there flourisheth, whatever there is warmed with heat, whatever there is beautiful, lasteth not; nay, it cannot exist for one whole year.

[103:229] In how brief a season do flowers pass away, and these are the beauty of the herbs! This which is so very beautiful, this quickly falleth Inasmuch then as He knoweth as a father our forming, that we are but grass, and can only flourish for a time; He sent unto us His Word, and His Word, which abideth for evermore, He hath made a brother unto the grass which abideth not.

[103:230] Wonder not that thou shalt be a sharer of His Eternity; He became Himself first a sharer of thy grass.

[103:231] Will He who assumed from thee what was lowly, deny unto thee what is exalted in respect of thee?.

[103:232] "The wind shall go over on it, it shall not be; and the place thereof shall know it no more".

[103:233] For he is not speaking of grass, but of that for whose sake even the Word became grass.

[103:234] For thou art man, and on thy account the Word became man.

[103:235] "All flesh is grass:" "and the Word was made flesh".

[103:236] How great then is the hope of the grass, since the Word hath been made flesh? That which abideth for evermore, hath not disdained to assume grass, that the grass might not despair of itself.

[103:237] In thy reflections therefore on thyself, think of thy low estate, think of thy dust: be not lifted up: if thou art anything better, thou wilt be so by His Grace, thou wilt be so by His mercy.

[103:238] For hear what followeth: "but the mercy of the Lord endureth for ever and ever upon them that fear Him".

[103:239] Ye who fear not Him, will be grass, and in grass, and in torment with the grass: for the flesh shall arise unto the torment.

[103:240] Let those who fear Him rejoice, because His mercy is upon them.

[103:241] "And His righteousness upon children's children".

[103:242] He speaketh of reward, "upon children's children".

[103:243] How many servants of God are there who have not children, how much less children's children? But He calleth our works our children; the reward of works, our "children's children".

[103:244] "Even upon such as keep His covenant".

[103:245] Let men beware that all may not conceive what is here said to belong to themselves: let them choose, while they have the choice.

[103:246] "And keep in memory His commandments to do them".

[103:247] Thou wast already disposed to flatter thyself, and perhaps to recite to me the Psalter, which I have not by heart, or from memory to say over the whole Law.

[103:248] Clearly thou art better in point of memory than I, better than any righteous man who doth not know the Law word for word: but see that thou keep the commandments.

[103:249] But how shouldest thou keep them? Not by memory, but by life.

[103:250] "Such as keep in memory His commandments:" not, to recite them; but, "to do them".

[103:251] And now perhaps each man's soul is disturbed.

[103:252] Who remembereth all the commandments of God? who remembereth all the writings of God? Lo, I wish not only to hold them in my memory, but also to do them in my works: but who remembereth them all? Fear not: He burdeneth thee not: "on two commandments hang all the Law and the Prophets".

[103:253] "The Lord hath prepared His throne in heaven".

[103:254] Who but Christ hath prepared His throne in heaven? He who descended and ascended, He who died, and rose from the dead, He who lifted up to heaven the manhood He had assumed, hath Himself prepared His throne in heaven.

[103:255] The throne is the seat of the Judge: observe therefore ye who hear, that "He hath prepared His throne in heaven".

[103:256] The kingdom is the Lord's, and He shall be the Governor among the people "And His kingdom shall rule over all".

[103:257] "Bless ye the Lord, ye Angels of His, ye that are mighty in strength: ye that fulfil His word".

[103:258] By the word of God, then, thou art not righteous, nor faithful, unless when thou dost it.

[103:259] "Ye that are mighty in strength, ye that fulfil His commandment, and hearken unto the voice of His words".

[103:260] "Bless ye the Lord, all ye His hosts: ye servants of His that do His pleasure".

[103:261] All ye angels, all ye that are mighty in strength: ye that do His word: all ye His hosts, ye servants of His that do His pleasure, do ye, ye bless the Lord.

[103:262] For all they who live wickedly, though their tongues be silent, by their lips do curse the Lord.

[103:263] What doth it profit if thy tongue singeth a hymn, while thy life breatheth sacrilege? By living ill thou hast set many tongues to blasphemy.

[103:264] Thy tongue is given to the hymn, the tongues of those who behold thee, to blasphemy.

[103:265] If then thou dost wish to bless the Lord, do His word, do His will.

[103:266] "Bless ye the Lord, all ye works of His, in all places of His dominion".

[103:267] Therefore in every place.

[103:268] Let Him not be blessed where He ruleth not: "in all places of His dominion".

[103:269] Let no man perchance say: I cannot praise the Lord in the East, because He hath departed unto the West; or, I cannot praise Him in the West, because He is in the East.

[103:270] "For neither from the east, nor from the west, nor yet from the desert hills.

[103:271] And why? God is the Judge".

[103:272] He is everywhere, in such wise that everywhere He may be praised: He is in such wise on every side, that we may be joyful in Him on every side: He is in such wise blessed on every side, that on every side we may live well.

[103:273] "In every place of His dominion: bless thou the Lord, O my soul!" The last verse is the same as the first: blessing is at the head of the Psalm, blessing at the end; from blessing we set out, to blessing let us return, in blessing let us reign.

[104:1] Psalm CIV.

[104:2] "Bless the Lord, O my soul".

[104:3] Let the soul of us all, made one in Christ, say this.

[104:4] "O Lord my God, Thou art magnified exceedingly!".

[104:5] Where art Thou magnified? "Confession and beauty Thou hast put on".

[104:6] Confess ye, that ye may be beautified, that He may put you on.

[104:7] "Clothed with light as a garment".

[104:8] Clothed with His Church, because she is made "light" in Him, who before was darkness in herself, as the apostle saith: "Ye were sometime darkness, but now light in the Lord".

[104:9] "Stretching out the heaven like a skin:" either as easily as thou dost a skin, if it be "as easily," so that thou mayest take it after the letter; or let us understand the authority of the Scriptures, spread out over the whole world, under the name of a skin; because mortality is signified in a skin, but all the authority of the Divine Scriptures was dispensed unto us through mortal men, whose fame is still spreading abroad now they are dead.

[104:10] "Who covereth with waters the upper parts thereof".

[104:11] The upper parts of what? Of Heaven.

[104:12] What is Heaven? Figuratively only we said, the Divine Scripture.

[104:13] What are the upper parts of the Divine Scripture? The commandment of love, than which there is none more exalted But wherefore is love compared to waters? Because "the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Spirit who is given unto us".

[104:14] Whence is the Spirit Himself water? because "Jesus stood and cried, He that believeth on Me, out of his bosom shall flow rivers of living water".

[104:15] Whence do we prove that it was said of the Spirit? Let the Evangelist himself declare, who followeth it up, and saith, "But this spake He of the Spirit, which they were to receive, who should believe on Him".

[104:16] "Who walketh above the wings of the winds;" that is, above the virtues of souls.

[104:17] What is the virtue of a soul? Love itself.

[104:18] But how doth He walk above it? Because the love of God toward us is greater than ours toward God.

[104:19] "Who maketh spirits His angels, and flaming fire His ministers" : that is, those who are already spirits, who are spiritual, not carnal, He maketh His Angels, by sending them to preach His gospel.

[104:20] "And flaming fire His ministers".

[104:21] For unless the minister that preacheth be on fire, he enflameth not him to whom he preacheth.

[104:22] "He hath founded the earth upon its firmness".

[104:23] He hath founded the Church upon the firmness of the Church.

[104:24] What is the firmness of the Church, but the foundation of the Church.

[104:25] What is the foundation of the Church, but that of which the Apostle saith, "Other foundation can no man lay but that is laid, which is Christ Jesus".

[104:26] And therefore, grounded on such a foundation, what hath she deserved to hear? "It shall not be bowed forever and ever".

[104:27] "He founded the earth on its firmness".

[104:28] That is, He hath founded the Church upon Christ the foundation.

[104:29] The Church will totter if the foundation totter; but when shall Christ totter, before whose coming unto us, and taking flesh on Him, "all things were made by Him, and without Him was not anything made;" who holdeth all things by His Majesty, and us by His goodness? Since Christ faileth not, "she shall not be bowed for ever and ever".

[104:30] Where are they who say that the Church hath perished from the world, when she cannot even be bowed.

[104:31] "The deep, like a garment, is its clothing".

[104:32] Whose? Is it perchance God's? But he had already said of His clothing, "Clothed with light as with a garment".

[104:33] I hear of God clothed in light, and that light, if we will, are we.

[104:34] What is, if we will? if we are no longer darkness.

[104:35] Therefore if God is clothed with light, whose clothing, again, is the deep? For an immense mass of waters is called the deep.

[104:36] All water, all the moist nature, and the substance everywhere shed abroad through the seas, and rivers, and hidden caves, is all together called by one name, the Deep.

[104:37] Therefore we understand the earth, of which he said, "He hath founded the earth".

[104:38] Of it I believe he said, "The deep, like a garment is its clothing".

[104:39] For the water is as it were the clothing of the earth, surrounding it and covering it.

[104:40] "Above the mountains the waters shall stand:" that is, the clothing of the earth, which is the deep, so increased, that the waters stood even above the mountains.

[104:41] We read of this taking place in the deluge.

[104:42] The Prophet minding to foretell future things, not to relate the past, therefore said it, because he would have it understood that the Church should be in a deluge of persecutions.

[104:43] For there was a time when the floods of persecutors had covered God's earth, God's Church, and had so covered it, that not even those great ones appeared, who are the mountains.

[104:44] For when they fled everywhere, how did they but cease to appear? And perchance of those waters is that saying, "Save me, O God, for the waters are come in even unto my soul".

[104:45] Especially the waters which make the sea, stormy, unfruitful.

[104:46] For whatsoever earth the sea-water may have covered, it will not rather make it fruitful than bring it to barrenness.

[104:47] For there were also mountains beneath the waters, because above the mountains waters stoodWhy were the Apostles hidden by flight? Because "above the mountains the waters stood".

[104:48] The power of the waters was great, but how long? Hear what followeth.

[104:49] "From Thy rebuke they shall fly".

[104:50] And this was done, brethren; from God's rebuke the waters did fly; that is, they went back from pressing on the mountains.

[104:51] Now the mountains themselves stand forth, Peter and Paul: how do they tower! They who before were pressed down by persecutors, now are venerated by emperors.

[104:52] For the waters are fled from the rebuke of God; because "the heart of kings is in the hand of God, He hath bent it whither He would;" He commanded peace to be given by them to the Christians; the authority of the Apostles sprang up and towered high.

[104:53] The waters fled from the rebuke of God.

[104:54] "From the voice of Thy thunder they shall be afraid".

[104:55] Now who is there that would not be afraid, from the voice of God through the Apostles, the voice of God through the Scriptures, through His clouds? The sea is quieted, the waters have been made afraid, the mountains have been laid bare, the emperor hath given the order.

[104:56] But who would have given the order, unless God had thundered? Because God willed, they commanded, and it was done.

[104:57] Therefore let no one of men arrogate anything to himself.

[104:58] "The mountains ascend, and the plains go down, into the place which Thou hast founded for them".

[104:59] He is still speaking of waters.

[104:60] Let us not here understand mountains as of earth; nor plains, as of earth: but waves so great that they may be compared to mountains.

[104:61] The sea did sometime toss, and its waves were as mountains, which could cover those mountains the Apostles.

[104:62] But how long do the mountains ascend and the plains go down? They raged, and they are appeased.

[104:63] When they raged they were mountains: now they are appeased they are become plains: for He hath founded a place for them.

[104:64] There is a certain channel, as it were a deep place, into which all those lately raging hearts of mortals have retired.

[104:65] They were mountains formerly, now they are plains: yet, my brethren, even a dead calm is sea.

[104:66] For wherefore are they not now violent? wherefore do they not rage? Wherefore do they not try, if they cannot overthrow our earth, at least to cover it? Wherefore not?.

[104:67] Hear.

[104:68] "Thou hast set a bound which they shall not pass over, neither shall they turn again to cover the earth".

[104:69] What then, because now the bitterest waves have received a measure, that we must be allowed to preach such things even with freedom; because they have had their due limit assigned, because they cannot pass over the bound that is set, nor shall they return to cover the earth; what is doing in the earth itself? What workings take place therein, now that the sea hath left it bare? Although at its beach slight waves do make their noise, although Pagans still murmur round; the sound of the shores I hear, a deluge I dread not.

[104:70] What then; what is doing in the earth? "Who sendeth out springs in the little valleys".

[104:71] "Thou sendest out," he saith, "springs in the little valleys".

[104:72] Ye know what little valleys are, lower places among the lands.

[104:73] For to hills and mountains, valleys and little valleys are opposed in contrary shape.

[104:74] Hills and mountains are swellings of the land: but valleys and little valleys, lownesses of the lands.

[104:75] Do not despise low places, thence flow springs.

[104:76] "Thou sendest out springs in the little valleys".

[104:77] Hear a mountain.

[104:78] The Apostle saith, "I laboured more than they all".

[104:79] A certain greatness is brought before us: yet immediately, that the waters may flow, he hath made himself a valley: "Yet not I, but the grace of God with me".

[104:80] It is no contradiction that they who are mountains be also valleys: for as they are called mountains because of their spiritual greatness, so also valleys because of the humility of their spirit.

[104:81] "Not I," he saith, "but the grace of God with me".

[104:82] What is, "In the midst between the mountains the waters shall pass through"? We have heard who are the "mountains," the great Preachers of the word, the exalted Angels of God, though still in mortal flesh; lofty not by their own power, but by His grace; but as far as relates to themselves, they are valleys, in their humility they send forth springs.

[104:83] "In the midst," he saith, "between the mountains, the waters shall pass through".

[104:84] Let us suppose this said thus, "In the midst between the Apostles shall pass through the preachings of the Word of Truth".

[104:85] What is, in the midst between the Apostles? What is called in the midst, is common.

[104:86] A common property, from which all alike live, is in the midst, and belongs not to me, but neither belongs it to thee, nor yet to me.

[104:87] For if they are not in the midst, they are as it were private, they flow not for public use, and I have mine, and he has his own, it is not in the midst for both me and him to have it; but such is not the preaching of peace.

[104:88] Therefore, brethren, let what we have said to your Love serve to this purpose, because of the springs: that they may flow from you, be ye valleys, and communicate with all that which ye have from God.

[104:89] Let the waters flow in the midst, envy ye no one, drink, be filled, flow forth when ye are filled.

[104:90] Everywhere let the common water of God have the glory, not the private falsehoods of men.

[104:91] For it follows, "All the beasts of the wood shall drink".

[104:92] We do indeed see this also in the visible creation, that the beasts of the wood drink of springs, and of streams that run between the mountains: but now since it hath pleased God to hide His own wisdom in the figures of such things, not to take it away from earnest seekers, but to close it to them that care not, and open it to them that knock; it hath also pleased our Lord God Himself to exhort you by us to this, that in all these things which are said as if of the bodily and visible creation, we may seek something spiritually hidden, in which when found we may rejoice.

[104:93] The beasts of the wood, we understand the Gentiles, and Holy Scripture witnesses this in many places.

[104:94] These beasts, then, drink those waters, but passing; not staying, but passing; for all that teaching which in all this time is dispensed passeth.

[104:95] Unless perchance your love thinketh that in that city to which it is said, "Praise the Lord, O Jerusalem, praise thy God, O Sion; for He hath made strong the bars of thy gates;" when the bars are now strengthened and the city closed, whence, as we said some time since, no friend goeth out, no enemy entereth; that there we shall have a book to read, or speech to be explained as it is now explained to you.

[104:96] Therefore is it now treated, that there it may be held fast: therefore is it now divided by syllables, that there it may be contemplated whole and entire.

[104:97] The Word of God will not be wanting there: but yet not by letters, not by sounds, not by books, not by a reader, not by an expositor.

[104:98] How then? As, "In the beginning was the Word," etc For He did not so come to us as to depart from thence; because He was in this world, and the world was made by Him.

[104:99] Such a Word are we to contemplate.

[104:100] For "the God of gods shall appear in Zion".

[104:101] But this when? After our pilgrimage, when the journey is done: if however after our journey is done we be not delivered to the Judge, that the Judge may send us to prison.

[104:102] But if when our journey is ended, as we hope, and wish, and endeavour, we shall have reached our Country, there shall we contemplate What we shall ever praise; nor shall That fail which is present to us, nor we, who enjoy: nor shall he be cloyed that eateth, nor shall that fail which he eateth.

[104:103] Great and wonderful shall be that contemplation.

[104:104] "The onagers shall take for their thirst".

[104:105] By onagers he meaneth some great beasts.

[104:106] For who knoweth not that wild asses are called onagers? He meaneth, therefore, some great untrained ones.

[104:107] For the Gentiles had no yoke of the Law: many nations lived after their own customs, ranging in proud boastfulness as in a wilderness.

[104:108] And so indeed did all the beasts, but the wild asses are put to signify the greater sort.

[104:109] They too shall drink for their thirst, for for them too the waters flow.

[104:110] Thence drinks the hare, thence the wild ass: the hare little, the wild ass great; the hare timid, the wild ass fierce: either sort drinks thence, but each for his thirst.

[104:111] So faithfully and gently doth it flow, as at once to satisfy the wild ass, and not to alarm the hare.

[104:112] The sound of Tully's voice rings out, Cicero is read, it is some book, it is a dialogue of his, whether his own, or Plato's, or by whatever such writer: some hear that are unlearned, weak ones of less mind; who dareth to aspire to such a thing? It is a sound of water, and that perchance turbid, but certainly flowing so violently, that a timid animal dare not draw near and  drink.

[104:113] To whom soundeth a Psalm, and he saith, It is too much for me? Behold now what the Psalm soundeth; certainly they are hidden mysteries, yet so it soundeth, that even children are delighted to hear, and the unlearned come to drink, and when filled burst forth in singing.

[104:114] Then the Psalm goes on in its text, "Upon them the fowls of the heaven shall inhabit".

[104:115] Upon the mountains, then, the fowls of the air shall have their habitation.

[104:116] We see these birds dwell upon the mountains, but many of them dwell in plains, many in valleys, many in groves, many in gardens, not all upon mountains.

[104:117] There are some fowls that dwell not save on the mountains.

[104:118] Some spiritual souls doth this name denote.

[104:119] Fowls are spiritual hearts, which enjoy the free air.

[104:120] In the clearness of heaven these birds delight, yet their feeding is on the mountains, there will they dwell.

[104:121] Ye know the mountains, they have been already treated of.

[104:122] Mountains are Prophets, mountains are Apostles, mountains are all preachers of the truth.

[104:123] But think not that those "fowls of heaven" follow their own authority; see what the Psalm saith: "From the midst of the rocks they shall give their voice".

[104:124] Now, if I shall say to you, Believe, for this said Cicero, this said Plato, this said Pythagoras: which of you will not laugh at me? For I shall be a bird that shall send forth my voice not from the rock.

[104:125] What ought each one of you to say to me? what ought he who is thus instructed to say? "If any one shall have preached unto you a gospel other than that ye have received, let him be anathema".

[104:126] What dost thou tell me of Plato, and of Cicero, and of Virgil? Thou hast before thee the rocks of the mountains, from the midst of the rocks give me thy voice.

[104:127] Let them be heard, who hear from the rock: let them be heard, because also in those many rocks the One Rock is heard: for "the Rock was Christ".

[104:128] Let them therefore be willingly heard, giving their voice from the midst of the rocks.

[104:129] Nothing is sweeter than such a voice of birds.

[104:130] They sound, and the rocks resound: they sound; spiritual men discuss: the rocks resound, testimonies of Scripture give answer.

[104:131] Lo! thence the fowls give their voice from the midst of the rocks, for they dwell on the mountains.

[104:132] "Watering the mountains from the higher places".

[104:133] Now if a Gentile uncircumcised man comes to us, about to believe in Christ, we give him baptism, and do not call him back to those works of the Law.

[104:134] And if a Jew asks us why we do that, we sound from the rock, we say, This Peter did, this Paul did: from the midst of the rocks we give our voice.

[104:135] But that rock, Peter himself, that great mountain, when he prayed and saw that vision, was watered from above.

[104:136] "From the fruit of Thy works shall the earth be satisfied".

[104:137] What is, "From the fruit of Thy works"? Let no man glory in his own works: but "he that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord".

[104:138] With Thy grace he is satisfied, when he is satisfied: let him not say that grace was given for his own merits.

[104:139] If it is called grace, "it is gratuitously given;" if it is returned for works, wages are paid Freely therefore receive, because ungodly thou art justified.

[104:140] "Bringing forth grass for the cattle, and green herb for the service of men".

[104:141] This is true, I perceive; I recognise the creation: the earth doth bring forth grass for the cattle, and green herb for the service of men.

[104:142] But I perceive the words, "Thou shalt not muzzle the mouth of the ox which treadeth out the corn: Doth God take care for oxen? For our sakes therefore the Scripture saith it".

[104:143] How then doth the earth bring forth grass for the cattle? Because "the Lord hath ordained that they which preach the Gospel should live of the Gospel".

[104:144] He sent preachers, saying unto them, "Eat such things as are set before you of them: for the labourer is worthy of his hire".

[104:145] They give spiritual, they receive carnal things; they give gold, they receive grass.

[104:146] "If we have sown unto you spiritual things, is it a great matter if we shall reap your carnal things?" This the Apostle said, a preacher so laborious, so indefatigable, so well tried, that he giveth this very grass to the earth.

[104:147] "Nevertheless," he saith, "we have not used this power".

[104:148] He showeth that it is due to him, yet he received it not; nor hath he condemned those who have received what was due.

[104:149] For those were to be condemned who exact what is not due, not they who accept their recompense: yet he gave up even his own recompense.

[104:150] Thou dost not cease to owe to another, because one hath given up his dues, otherwise thou wilt not be the watered earth which bringeth forth grass for the cattle.

[104:151] Thou receivest spiritual things, give carnal things in return: to the soldier they are due, to the soldier thou returnest them; thou art the paymaster of Christ.

[104:152] "Who goeth a warfare any time at his own charges? who planteth a vineyard, and eateth not of the fruit thereof? or who feedeth a flock, and eateth not of the milk of the flock? I speak not thus, that it should be so done unto me".

[104:153] There has been such a soldier as gave up his rations of food even to the paymaster: yet let the paymaster pay the rations.

[104:154] "That it may bring forth bread out of the earth".

[104:155] What bread? Christ.

[104:156] Out of what earth? From Peter, from Paul, from the other stewards of the truth.

[104:157] Hear that it is from the earth: "We have," saith St.

[104:158] Paul, "this treasure in earthen vessels, that the excellency of the power may be of God, and not of us".

[104:159] He is the bread who descended from heaven, that He might be brought forth out of the earth, when He is preached through the flesh of His servants.

[104:160] The earth bringeth forth grass, that it may bring forth bread from the earth.

[104:161] What earth bringeth forth grass? Pious, holy nations.

[104:162] That bread may be brought forth out of what earth? The word of God out of the Apostles, out of the stewards of God's Sacraments, who still walk upon the earth, who still carry an earthly body.

[104:163] "And wine maketh glad the heart of man".

[104:164] Let no man prepare himself for intoxication; nay, let every man prepare him for intoxication.

[104:165] "How excellent is Thy cup which maketh inebriate!" We choose not to say, Let no man be drunk.

[104:166] Be inebriated; yet beware, from what source.

[104:167] If the excellent cup of the Lord doth saturate you, your ebriety shall be seen in your works, it shall be seen in the holy love of righteousness, it shall, lastly, be seen in the estrangement of your mind, but from things earthly to heavenly.

[104:168] "To make him a cheerful countenance with oil".

[104:169] What is the making the countenance cheerful with oil? The grace of God; a sort of shining for manifestation; as the Apostle saith, "The Spirit is given to every man for manifestation".

[104:170] A certain grace which men can clearly see in men, to conciliate holy love, is termed oil, for its divine splendour; and since it appeared most excellent in Christ, the whole world loveth Him; who though while here He was scorned, is now worshipped by every nation: "For the kingdom is the Lord's, and He shall be Governor among the people".

[104:171] For such is His grace, that many, who do not believe on Him, praise Him, and declare that they are unwilling to believe on Him, because no man can fulfil what He doth command.

[104:172] They who with reproaches once raged against Him, are hindered by His very praises.

[104:173] Yet by all is He loved, by all is He preached; because He is excellently anointed, therefore He is Christ: for He is called Christ from the Chrism or anointing which He had.

[104:174] Messiah in the Hebrew, Christ in the Greek, Unctus in the Latin: but He anointeth over His whole Body.

[104:175] All therefore who come, receive grace, that their countenances may be made glad with oil.

[104:176] "And bread strengtheneth man's heart".

[104:177] What is this, brethren? As it were, he hath forced us to understand what bread he was speaking of.

[104:178] For while that visible bread strengtheneth the stomach, feedeth the body, there is another bread which strengtheneth the heart, in that it is the bread of the heart.

[104:179] There is therefore a wine that truly maketh glad the heart, and knoweth not to do aught else than to gladden the heart.

[104:180] But that thou mayest not imagine that this indeed should be taken of the spiritual wine, but not of that spiritual bread; He hath shown this very point, that it is also spiritual: "and bread," he saith, "strengtheneth man's heart".

[104:181] So understand it therefore of the bread as thou dost understand it of the wine; hunger inwardly, thirst inwardly: "Blessed are they," saith our Lord, "who hunger and thirst after righteousness; for they shall be filled".

[104:182] That bread is righteousness, that wine is righteousness: it is truth, Christ is truth "I am," He said, "the living bread, who came down from heaven;" and, "I am the Vine, and ye are the branches".

[104:183] "The trees of the plain shall be satisfied" : but with this grace, brought forth out of the earth.

[104:184] "The trees of the plain," are the lower orders of the nations.

[104:185] "And the cedars of Libanus which He hath planted".

[104:186] The cedars of Libanus, the powerful in the world, shall themselves be filled.

[104:187] The bread, and wine, and oil of Christ hath reached senators, nobles, kings; the trees of the plain are filled.

[104:188] First the humble are filled; next also the cedars of Libanus, yet those which He hath planted; pious cedars, religious faithful; for such hath He planted.

[104:189] For the ungodly also are cedars of Libanus; for, "The Lord shall break the cedars of Libanus".

[104:190] For Libanus is a mountain: there are those trees, even according to the letter most long-lived and most excellent.

[104:191] But Libanus is interpreted, as we read in those who have written of these things, a brightness: and this brightness seemeth to belong to this world, which at present shineth and is refulgent with its pomps.

[104:192] There are the cedars of Libanus, which the Lord hath planted; those which the Lord hath planted shall be filled.

[104:193] "There shall the sparrows build their nests: their leader is the house of the coot".

[104:194] Where shall the sparrows build? In the cedars of Libanus.

[104:195] Who are the sparrows? Sparrows are birds indeed, and fowls of the air, but small fowls are wont to be called sparrows.

[104:196] There are therefore some spiritual ones that build in the cedars of Libanus: that is, there are certain servants of God who hear in the Gospel, "Sell all that thou hast, and give to the poor; and thou shalt have treasure in heaven; and come and follow Me".

[104:197] Let him who hath resigned many things, not be proud.

[104:198] We know that Peter was a fisherman: what then could he give up, to follow our Lord? Or his brother Andrew, or John and James the sons of Zebedee, themselves also fishermen; and yet what did they say? "Behold, we have forsaken all, and followed Thee".

[104:199] Our Lord said not to him, Thou hast forgotten thy poverty; what hast thou resigned, that thou shouldest receive the whole world? He, my brethren, who resigned not only what he had, but also what he longed to have, resigned much.

[104:200] But although the sparrows will build in the cedars of Libanus, "the house of the coot is their leader".

[104:201] What is the house of the coot? The coot, as we all know, is a water bird, dwelling either among the marshes, or on the sea.

[104:202] It hath rarely or never a home on the shore; but in places in the midst of the waters, and thus usually in rocky islets, surrounded by the waves.

[104:203] We therefore understand that the rock is the fit home of the coot, it never dwelleth more securely than on the rock.

[104:204] On what sort of rock? One placed in the sea.

[104:205] And if it is beaten by the waves, yet it breaketh the waves, is not broken by them: this is the excellency of the rock in the sea.

[104:206] How great waves beat on our Lord Jesus Christ? The Jews dashed against Him; they were broken, He remained whole.

[104:207] And let every one who doth imitate Christ, so dwell in this world, that is, in this sea, where he cannot but feel storms and tempests, that he may yield to no wind, to no wave, but remain whole, while he meets them all.

[104:208] The home of the coot, therefore, is both strong and weak.

[104:209] The coot hath not a home on lofty spots; nothing is more firm and nothing more humble than that home.

[104:210] Sparrows build indeed in cedars, on account of actual need: but they hold that rock as their leader, which is beaten by the waves, and yet not broken; for they imitate the sufferings of Christ.

[104:211] What then followeth? "The loftiest hills are for the stags".

[104:212] The stags are mighty, spiritual, passing in their course over all the thorny places of the thickets and woods.

[104:213] "He maketh my feet like harts' feet, and setteth me up on high".

[104:214] Let them hold to the lofty hills, the lofty commandments of God; let them think on sublime subjects, let them hold those which stand forth most in the Scriptures, let them be justified in the highest: for those loftiest hills are for the stags.

[104:215] What of the humble beasts? what of the hare? what of the hedgehog? The hare is a small and weak animal: the hedgehog is also prickly: the one is a timid animal, the other is covered with prickles.

[104:216] What do the prickles signify, except sinners? He who sinneth daily, although not great sins, is covered over with the smallest prickles.

[104:217] In his timidity he is a hare: in his being covered with the minutest sins, he is a hedgehog: and he cannot hold those lofty and perfect commandments.

[104:218] For "the loftiest hills are for the stags".

[104:219] What then? do these perish? No.

[104:220] For so "is the rock the refuge for the hedgehogs and the hares".

[104:221] For the Lord is a refuge for the poor.

[104:222] Place that rock upon the land, it is a refuge for hedgehogs, and for hares: place it on the sea, it is the home of the coot.

[104:223] Everywhere the rock is useful.

[104:224] Even in the hills it is useful: for the hills without the rock's foundation would fall into the deep.

[104:225] "He appointed the Moon for certain seasons".

[104:226] We understand spiritually the Church increasing from the smallest size, and growing old as it were from the mortality of this life; yet so, that it draweth nearer unto the Sun.

[104:227] I speak not of this moon visible to the eye, but of that which is signified by this name.

[104:228] While the Church was in the dark, while she as yet appeared not, shone not forth as yet, men were led astray, and it was said, This is the Church, here is Christ; so that "while the Moon was dark, they shot their arrows at the righteous in heart".

[104:229] How blind is he who now, when the Moon is full, wandereth astray? "He appointed the Moon for certain seasons".

[104:230] For here the Church temporarily is passing away: for this subjection to death will not remain for ever: there will some time be an end of waxing and waning; it is appointed for certain seasons.

[104:231] "And the sun knoweth his going down".

[104:232] And what sun is this, but that Sun of righteousness, whom the ungodly will lament on the day of judgment never having risen for them; they who will say on that day, "Therefore we wandered from the way of truth, and the light of righteousness shone not on us, and the sun did not arise upon us".

[104:233] That sun riseth for him who understandeth Christ.

[104:234] Nor think, brethren, that the sun ought to be worshipped by some men, because the sun doth sometimes in the Scriptures signify Christ.

[104:235] For such is the madness of men; as if we said that a creature should be worshipped, when it is said, the sun is an emblem of Christ.

[104:236] Then worship the rock also, for it also is a type of Christ "He was brought as a lamb to the slaughter:" worship the lamb also, since it is a type of Christ.

[104:237] "The Lion of the tribe of Judah hath prevailed;" worship the lion also, since it signifieth Christ.

[104:238] Observe how numerous are the types of Christ: all these are Christ in similitude, not in essence.

[104:239] What then, when the sun went down, when our Lord suffered? There was a sort of darkness with the Apostles, hope failed, in those to whom He at first seemed great, and the Redeemer of all men.

[104:240] How so? "Thou didst make darkness, and it became night; wherein all the beasts of the forest shall move".

[104:241] Here the beasts of the forest are used in different ways: for these things are always understood in varying senses; as our Lord Himself is at one time termed a lion, at another a lamb.

[104:242] What is so different as a lion and a lamb? But what sort of lamb? One that could overcome the wolf, overcome the lion.

[104:243] He is the Rock, He the Shepherd, He the Gate.

[104:244] The Shepherd entereth by the gate: and He saith, "I am the good Shepherd:" and, "I am the Door of the Sheep".

[104:245] Learn thus to understand, when these things are spoken figuratively; lest perchance when ye have read that the Rock signifieth Christ, ye may understand it to mean Him in every passage.

[104:246] In one place it meaneth one thing, another in another, just as we can only understand the meaning of a letter by seeing its position "The lion's whelps roaring after their prey, do seek their meat from God".

[104:247] Justly then our Lord, when nigh unto His going down, the very Sun of Righteousness recognising His going down, said to His disciples, as if darkness being about to come, the lion would roam about to seek whom he might devour, that that lion could devour no man, unless with leave: "Simon," said He, "this night Satan hath desired to have you, that he may sift you as wheat.

[104:248] But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not".

[104:249] When Peter thrice denied, was he not already between the lion's teeth?.

[104:250] "The Sun hath arisen, and they get them away together, and lay them down in their dens".

[104:251] More and more as the Sun riseth, so that Christ is recognised by the round world, and glorified therein, do the lion's whelps get them away together; those devils recede from the persecution of the Church, who instigated men to persecute the house of God, by working in the sons of unbelief.

[104:252] Now that none of them dareth persecute the Church, "the Sun hath arisen, and they get them away together".

[104:253] And where are they? "And they lay them down in their dens".

[104:254] Their dens are the hearts of the unbelieving.

[104:255] How many carry lions crouching in their hearts? They burst not forth thence, they make no assault upon the pilgrim Jerusalem.

[104:256] Wherefore do they not so? Because the Sun is already risen, and is shining over the whole world.

[104:257] What art thou doing, O man of God? thou, O Church of God? what art thou, O body of Christ, whose Head is in Heaven? what art thou doing, O man, His unity? "Man," he saith, "shall go forth to his work".

[104:258] Let therefore this man work good works in the security of the peace of the Church, let him work unto the end.

[104:259] For sometime there will be a sort of general darkening, and a sort of assault will be made, but in the evening, that is, in the end of the world: but now the Church doth work in peace and tranquillity; for "man shall go forth to his work, and to his labour, unto the evening".

[104:260] "O Lord, how great are made Thy works!".

[104:261] Justly great, justly sublime! where were those works made, that are so great? what was that station where God stood, or that seat whereupon He sat, when He did those works? what was the place where He worked thus? whence did those so beautiful works proceed at the first? To take it word for word, every ordained creation, running by ordinance, beautiful by ordinance, rising by ordinance, setting by ordinance, going through all seasons by ordinance, whence hath it proceeded? whence hath the Church herself received her rise, her growth, her perfection? In what manner is she destined to a consummation in immortality? with what heralding is she preached? by what mysteries is she recommended? by what types is she concealed? by what preaching is she revealed? where hath God done these things? I see great works.

[104:262] "How great are made Thy works, O Lord!" I ask where He hath made them: I find not the place: but I see what followeth: "In Wisdom hast Thou made them all".

[104:263] All therefore Thou hast made in Christ.

[104:264] "The earth is full of Thy creation".

[104:265] The earth is full of the creation of Christ.

[104:266] And how so? We discern how: for what was not made by the Father through the Son? Whatever walketh and doth crawl on earth, whatever doth swim in the waters, whatever flieth in the air, whatever doth revolve in heaven, how much more then the earth, the whole universe, is the work of God.

[104:267] But he seems to me to speak here of some new creation, of which the Apostle saith, "If any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things have passed away; behold, all things are become new.

[104:268] And all things are of God".

[104:269] All who believe in Christ, who put off the old man, and put on the new, are a new creature.

[104:270] "The earth is full of Thy works".

[104:271] On one spot of the earth He was crucified, in one small spot that seed fell into the earth, and died; but brought forth great fruit.

[104:272] "The earth is full of Thy creation".

[104:273] Of what creation of Thine is the earth full? Of all trees and shrubs, of all animals and flocks, and of the whole of the human race; the earth is full of the creation of God.

[104:274] We see, know, read, recognise, praise, and in these we preach of Him; yet we are not able to praise respecting these things, as fully as our heart doth abound with praise after the beautiful contemplation of them.

[104:275] But we ought rather to heed that creation, of which the Apostle saith, "If any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new".

[104:276] What "old things have passed away"? In the Gentiles, all idolatry; in the Jews themselves, all that servitude unto the Law, all those sacrifices that were harbingers of the present Sacrifice.

[104:277] The oldness of man was then abundant; One came to renovate His own work, to melt His silver, to form His coin, and we now see the earth full of Christians believing in God, turning themselves away from their former uncleanness and idolatry, from a past hope to the hope of a new age: and behold it is not yet realized, but is already possessed in hope, and through that very hope we now sing, and say, "The earth is full of Thy creation".

[104:278] We do not as yet sing this in our country, nor yet in that rest which is promised, the bars of the gates of Jerusalem not being as yet made fast; but still in our pilgrimage gazing upon the whole of this world, upon men who on every side are running unto the faith, fearing hell, despising death, loving eternal life, scorning the present, and filled with joy at such a spectacle, we say, "The earth is full of Thy creation".

[104:279] "So is the great and wide sea also; wherein are things creeping innumerable, both small and great beasts".

[104:280] He speaketh of the sea as terrible.

[104:281] Snares creep in this world, and surprise the careless suddenly; for who numbereth the temptations that creep? They creep, but beware, lest they snatch us away.

[104:282] Let us keep watch on the Wood; even in the water, even on the waves, we are safe: let not Christ sleep, let not faith sleep; if He hath slept, let Him be awakened; He will command the winds; He will calm the sea; the voyage will be ended, and we shall rejoice in our country.

[104:283] For I see in this terrible sea unbelievers still; for they dwell in barren and bitter waters: but they are both small and great.

[104:284] We know this: many little men of this world are still unbelievers, many great men of this world are so: there are living creatures, both small and great, in this sea.

[104:285] They hate the Church: the name of Christ is a burden to them: they rage not, because they are not permitted; the cruelty which cannot burst forth in deeds, is shut up within the heart.

[104:286] For all, whether small or great, "creeping things, both small and great," who at present grieve at the temples being shut, the altars overthrown, the images broken, the laws which make it a capital crime to sacrifice to idols; all who mourn on this account, are still in the sea.

[104:287] What then of us? And by what road then are we to journey unto our country? Through this very sea, but on the Wood.

[104:288] Fear not the danger; that wood which holdeth together the world doth bear thee up.

[104:289] "There shall go the ships".

[104:290] Lo, ships float upon that which alarmed you, and sink not.

[104:291] By ships we understand churches; they go among the storms, among the tempests of temptations, among the waves of the world, among the beasts, both small and great.

[104:292] Christ on the wood of His cross is the Pilot.

[104:293] "There shall go the ships".

[104:294] Let not the ships fear, let them not much mind where they float, but by Whom they are steered.

[104:295] "There shall go the ships".

[104:296] What voyage do they find tedious, when they feel that Christ is their Pilot? They will sail safely, let them sail diligently, they will reach their promised haven, they will be led to the land of rest.

[104:297] There is also in that sea somewhat which transcends all creatures, great and small.

[104:298] What is this? Let us hear the Psalm: "There is that Leviathan, whom Thou hast formed to make sport of him".

[104:299] There are creeping things innumerable, both small and great beasts; there shall the ships go, and shall not fear, not only the creeping things innumerable, and beasts both small and great, but not even the serpent which is there; "whom Thou," he speaketh unto God, "hast made to make sport of him".

[104:300] This is a great mystery; and yet I am about to utter what ye already know.

[104:301] Ye know that a certain serpent is the enemy of the Church: ye have not seen him with the eyes of the flesh, but ye see him with the eyes of faith.

[104:302] This serpent then, our ancient enemy, glowing with rage, cunning in his wiles, is in the mighty sea.

[104:303] "Here is that Leviathan, whom Thou hast formed to make sport of him".

[104:304] Do thou now make sport of the serpent: for for this end was this serpent made.

[104:305] He falling by his own sin from the sublime realms of the heavens, and made devil instead of angel, received a certain region of his own in this mighty and spacious sea.

[104:306] What thou thinkest his kingdom, is his prison.

[104:307] For many say: wherefore hath the devil received so great power, that he may rule in this world, and prevaileth so much, can do so much? How much prevaileth he? How much can he do? Unless by permission, he can do nothing.

[104:308] Do thou so act, that he may not be allowed to attack thee; or if he be allowed to tempt thee, he may depart vanquished, and may not gain thee.

[104:309] For he hath been allowed to tempt some holy men, servants of God: they overcame him, because they departed not from the way, they whose heel he watched, fell not.

[104:310] He then, my brethren, who doth wish to watch the serpent's head, and safely to pass this sea; for it must be that this serpent dwelleth here, and, as I had commenced saying, the devil when he fell from heaven received this region; let him watch his head, on the part of the fear of the world, and of the lusts of the world.

[104:311] For it is hence that he suggesteth some object of fear or of desire; he trieth thy love, or thy fear.

[104:312] If thou fearest hell, and lovest the kingdom of God, thou wilt watch his head.

[104:313] "There is no power but of God".

[104:314] What then fearest thou? Let the dragon be in the waters, let the dragon be in the sea: thou art to pass through it.

[104:315] He is made so as to be made sport of, he is ordained to inhabit this place, this region is given him.

[104:316] Thou thinkest that this habitation is a great thing for him, because thou knowest not the dwellings of the angels whence he fell: what seemeth to thee his glory, is his damnation.

[104:317] What then fearest thou? Perhaps he is about to try thy flesh: it is the scourge of thy Lord, not the power of thy tempter.

[104:318] His wish is to injure that salvation which is promised: but he is not allowed: but that he may not be allowed, have Christ for thy Head: repel the serpent's head: consent not unto his suggestion, slip not from thy path.

[104:319] "There is that Leviathan, whom Thou hast made to make sport of him".

[104:320] Dost thou wish to see how incapable he is of hurting thee, unless permitted? "These," he saith, "wait all upon Thee, that Thou mayest give them meat in due season".

[104:321] And this serpent wisheth to devour, but he devoureth not whom he wisheth.

[104:322] Thou hast heard what the serpent's meat is.

[104:323] Thou dost not wish that God give thee to be devoured by the serpent; because not the serpent's food: i-e: forsake not the Word of God.

[104:324] For where it is said to the serpent, "Dust thou shalt eat," it is said to the transgressor, "Dust thou art, and unto dust thou shalt return".

[104:325] Thou dost not wish to be the serpent's food? be not dust.

[104:326] How, thou repliest, shall I not be dust? If thou hast not a taste for earthly things.

[104:327] Hear the Apostle, that thou mayest not be dust.

[104:328] For the body which thou wearest is earth: but do thou refuse to be earth.

[104:329] What meaneth this? "Set your affection on things above, not on things on the earth".

[104:330] If thou dost not set thy affections on earthly things, thou art not earth: if thou art not earth, thou art not devoured by the serpent, whose appointed food is earth.

[104:331] The Lord giveth the serpent his food when He will, what He will: but He judgeth rightly, he cannot be deceived, He giveth him not gold for earth.

[104:332] "When Thou hast given it them, they gather it".

[104:333] "When thou openest Thy hand, they shall all be filled with good".

[104:334] What is it, O Lord, that Thou openest Thy hand? Christ is Thy hand.

[104:335] "To whom is the arm of the Lord revealed?" To whom it is revealed, unto him it is opened: for revelation is opening.

[104:336] "When Thou openest Thy hand, they shall all be filled with good".

[104:337] When Thou revealest Thy Christ, "they shall all be filled with good".
