For see what He addeth: "Because they rebelled against the words of the Lord through pride" , not knowing the righteousness of God, and wishing to establish their own, "and they were bitter against the counsel of the Most High".

[107:46] "And their heart was brought low in labour".

[107:47] And now fight against lust; if God cease to aid thou mayest strive, thou canst not conquer.

[107:48] And when thou shalt be pressed by thine evil, thy heart will be brought low in labour, so that now with humbled heart thou mayest learn to cry out, "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?"Freed, thou wilt confess the mercies of the Lord.

[107:49] "And they cried unto the Lord when they were troubled, and He delivered them out of their distresses".

[107:50] They were freed from the second temptation.

[107:51] There remains that of weariness and loathing.

[107:52] But first see what He did for them when freed.

[107:53] "And He led them out of darkness and the shadow of death, and brake their bonds asunder".

[107:54] "Let them confess to the Lord His mercies, and His wonders to the children of men".

[107:55] Wherefore? what difficulties hath He overcome? "Because He brake the gates of brass, and snapped the bars of iron".

[107:56] "He took them up from the way of their iniquity, for because of their unrighteousnesses they were brought low".

[107:57] Because they gave honour to themselves, not to God, because they were establishing their own righteousness, not knowing the righteousness of God, they were brought low.

[107:58] They found that they were helpless without His aid, who were presuming on their own strength alone.

[107:59] "Their soul abhorred all manner of meat".

[107:60] Now they suffer satiety.

[107:61] They are sick of satiety.

[107:62] They are in danger from satiety.

[107:63] Unless perchance thou thinkest they could be killed with famine, but cannot with satiety.

[107:64] See what followeth.

[107:65] When he had said, "Their soul abhorred all manner of meat," lest thou shouldest think them, as it were, safe of their fulness, and not rather see that they would die of satiety: "And they came near," he saith, "even unto the gates of death".

[107:66] What then remaineth? That even when the word of God delighteth thee, thou account it not to thyself; nor for this be puffed up with any sort of arrogance, and having an appetite for food, proudly spurn at those who are in danger from satiety.

[107:67] "And they cried out unto the Lord when they were in trouble, and He delivered them out of their distresses".

[107:68] And because it was a sickness not to be pleased, "He sent His Word, and healed them".

[107:69] See what evil there is in satiety; see whence He delivers, to whom he crieth that loathes his food.

[107:70] "He sent His Word, and healed them, and snatched them," from whence? not from wandering, not from hunger, not from the difficulty of overcoming sins, but "from their corruption".

[107:71] It is a sort of corruption of the mind to loathe what is sweet.

[107:72] Therefore also of this benefit, as of the others before, "Let them confess to the Lord His mercies, and His wonders unto the sons of men".

[107:73] "And sacrifice the sacrifice of praise".

[107:74] For now that He may be praised, the Lord is sweet, "and let them tell out His works with gladness".

[107:75] Not with weariness, not with sadness, not with anxiety, not with loathing, but "with gladness".

[107:76] "They who go down on the sea in ships, doing their business on the mighty waters" ; that is, amongst many peoples.

[107:77] For that waters are often put for peoples, the Apocalypse of John is witness, when on John's asking what those waters were, it was answered him, they are peoples.

[107:78] They then who do their business on mighty waters, "they have seen the works of the Lord, and His wonders in the deep".

[107:79] For what is deeper than human hearts? hence often break forth winds; storms of sedition, and dissensions, disturb the ship.

[107:80] And what is done in them? God, willing that both they who steer, and they who are conveyed, should cry unto Him, "He spake, and the breath of the storm stood".

[107:81] What is, stood? Abode, continued, still disturbeth, long tosseth; rageth, and passeth not away.

[107:82] "For He spake, and the breath of the storm stood".

[107:83] And what did that breath of the storm? "They go up even to the heavens," in daring; "They go down even into the deeps" , in fearing.

[107:84] "Their soul wasted in miseries".

[107:85] "They were disturbed, and moved like a drunken man".

[107:86] They who sit at the helm, and they who faithfully love the ship, feel what I say.

[107:87] Certainly, when they speak, when they read, when they interpret, they appear wise.

[107:88] Woe for the storm! "and all their wisdom," he saith, "was swallowed up".

[107:89] Sometimes all human counsels fail; whichever way one turns himself, the waves roar, the storm rageth, the arms are powerless: where the prow may strike, to what wave the side may be exposed, whither the stricken ship may be allowed to drift, from what rocks she must be kept back lest she be lost, is impossible for her pilots to see.

[107:90] And what is left but that which follows? "And they cried out unto the Lord when they were troubled, and He delivered them from their distresses".

[107:91] "And He commanded the storm, and it stood unto clear air" , "and the waves of it were still".

[107:92] Hear on this point the voice of a steersman, one that was in peril, was brought low, was freed.

[107:93] "I would not," he saith, "have you ignorant, brethren, of our distress, which befell us in Asia, that "we were pressed above strength, and above measure" (I see all his "wisdom swallowed up"), "so that we were weary," he saith, "even of life".

[107:94] "And they were glad, because they were still, and He brought them into the haven of their desire".

[107:95] "Let His mercies confess unto the Lord, and His wonders towards the sons of men".

[107:96] Everywhere, without exception, let not our merits, not our strength, not our wisdom, "confess unto the Lord," but, "His mercies".

[107:97] Let Him be loved in every deliverance of ours, who has been invoked in every distress.

[107:98] "And let them exalt Him in the assembly of the people, and praise Him in the seat of the elders".

[107:99] Let them exalt, let them praise, peoples and elders, merchants and pilots.

[107:100] For what hath He done in this assembly? What hath He established? Whence hath He rescued it? What hath He granted it? Even as He resisted the proud, and gave grace to the humble: the proud, that is, the first people of the Jews, arrogant, and extolling itself on its descent from Abraham, and because to that nation "were entrusted the oracles of God".

[107:101] These things did not avail them unto soundness, but unto pride of heart, rather to swelling than to greatness.

[107:102] What then did God, resisting the proud, but giving grace to the humble; cutting off the natural branches for their pride; grafting in the wild olive for its humility?  "He made the rivers a wilderness".

[107:103] Waters did run there, prophecies were in course.

[107:104] Seek now a prophet among the Jews; thou findest none.

[107:105] For "He made the outgoings of waters to be thirst".

[107:106] Let them say, "Now there is no prophet more, and He will not know us any more".

[107:107] "A fruitful land to be saltpools".

[107:108] Thou seekest there the faith of Christ, thou findest not: thou seekest a prophet, thou findest not: thou seekest a sacrifice, thou findest not: thou seekest a temple, thou findest none.

[107:109] Wherefore this? "From the wickedness of them that dwell therein".

[107:110] Behold how He resisteth the proud: hear how He giveth grace to the humble.

[107:111] "He made the wilderness to be a standing water, and the dry ground to be outgoings of waters".

[107:112] "And He caused the hungry to dwell there".

[107:113] Because to Him it was said, "Thou art a Priest for ever, after the order of Melchizedec".

[107:114] For thou seekest a sacrifice among the Jews; thou hast none after the order of Aaron.

[107:115] Thou seekest it after the order of Melchizedec; thou findest it not among them, but through the whole world it is celebrated in the Church.

[107:116] "From the rising of the sun to the setting thereof the name of the Lord is praised".

[107:117] "And they sowed fields, and planted vineyards, and gat fruit of corn" : at which that workman rejoiceth, who saith, "Not because I desire a gift, but I seek fruit".

[107:118] "And He blessed them, and they were multiplied exceedingly, and their cattle were not diminished".

[107:119] This standeth.

[107:120] For "the foundation of God standeth sure; because the Lord knoweth them that are His".

[107:121] They are called "beasts of burden," and "cattle," that walk simply in the Church, yet are useful; not much learned, but full of faith.

[107:122] Therefore, whether spiritual or carnal, "He blessed them".

[107:123] "And they became few, and were vexed".

[107:124] Whence this? From athwart? Nay, from within.

[107:125] For that they should "become few," "They went out from us, but they were not of us".

[107:126] But therefore he speaketh as of these, of whom he spake before, that they may be discerned with understanding; because he speaketh as if of the same, because of the sacraments they have in common.

[107:127] For they belong to the people of God, though not by the virtue, yet surely by the appearance of piety: for concerning them we have heard the Apostle, "In the last times there shall come grievous times, for there shall be men lovers of themselves".

[107:128] The first evil is, "lovers of themselves;" that is, as being pleased with themselves.

[107:129] Would that they were not pleasing to themselves, and were pleasing to God: would that they would cry out in their difficulties, and be freed from their distresses.

[107:130] But while they presumed greatly on themselves, "they were made few".

[107:131] It is manifest, brethren: all who separate themselves from unity become few.

[107:132] For they are many; but in unity, while they are not parted from unity.

[107:133] For when the multitude of unity hath begun no more to belong to them, in heresy and schism, they are few.

[107:134] "And they were vexed, from distress of miseries and grief".

[107:135] "Contempt was poured on princes".

[107:136] For they were rejected by the Church of God, and the more because they wished to be princes, therefore they were despised, and became salt that had lost its savour, cast out abroad, so that it is trodden under foot of men.

[107:137] "And He led them astray in the pathless place, and not in a way".

[107:138] Those above in the way, those directed to a city, and finally led thither, not led astray; but these, where there was no way, led astray.

[107:139] What is, "Led them astray"? God "gave them up to their own hearts' lusts".

[107:140] For "led astray" means this, gave them up to themselves.

[107:141] For if thou enquire closely, it is they that lead themselves astray.

[107:142] "And He helped the poor out of beggary".

[107:143] What meaneth this, brethren? Princes are despised, and the poor helped.

[107:144] The proud are cast aside, and the humble provided for.

[107:145] "And made him households like sheep".

[107:146] Thou understandest one poor man and one beggar of him concerning whom he said, "He hath helped the poor out of misery:" this poor man is now many households, this poor man is many nations; many Churches are one Church, one nation, one household, one sheep.

[107:147] These are great mysteries, great types, how profound, how full of hidden meanings; how sweetly discovered, since long hidden.

[107:148] Therefore, "the righteous will consider this, and rejoice: and the mouth of all wickedness shall be stopped".

[107:149] That wickedness that doth prate against unity, and compelleth truth to be made manifest, shall be convicted, and have its mouth stopped.

[107:150] "Who is wise? and he will consider these things; and will understand the mercies of the Lord".

[107:151] Not his own deservings, not his own strength, not his own power; but "the mercies of the Lord;" who, when he was wandering and in want, led him back to the path, and fed him; who, when he was struggling against the difficulties of his sins, and bound down with the fetters of habit, released and freed him; who, when he loathed the Word of God, and was almost dying with a kind of weariness, restored him by sending him the medicine of His Word; who, when he was endangered among the risks of shipwreck and storm, stilled the sea, and brought him into port; who, finally, placed him in that people, where He giveth grace to the humble; not in that where he resisteth the proud; and hath made him His own, that remaining within he may be multiplied, not that going out he may be minished.

[107:152] The righteous see this, and rejoice.

[107:153] "The mouth," therefore, "of all wickedness shall be stopped".

[108:1] Psalm CVIII.

[108:2] I have not thought that the CVIIIth Psalm required an exposition; since I have already  expounded it in the LVIIth Psalm, and in the LXth, of the last divisions of which this Psalm consisteth.

[108:3] For the last part of the LVIIth is the first of this, as far as the verse, "Thy glory is above all the earth".

[108:4] Henceforth to the end, is the last part of the LXth: as the last part of the CXXXVth is the same as that of the CXVth, from the verse, "The images of the heathen are but gold and silver:" as the XIVth and LIIId, with a few alterations in the middle, have everything the same from the beginning to the end.

[108:5] Whatever slight differences therefore occur in this CVIIIth Psalm, compared with those two, of parts of which it is composed, are easy to understand; just as we find in the LVIIth, "I will sing and give praise; awake, O my glory:" here," I will sing and give praise, with my glory".

[108:6] Awake, is said there, that he may sing and give praise therewith.

[108:7] Also, there, "Thy mercy is great" (or, as some translate, "is lifted up") "unto the heavens;" but here, "Thy mercy is great above the heavens".

[108:8] For it is great unto the heavens, that it may be great in the heavens; and this is what he wished to express by "above the heavens".

[108:9] Also in the LXth, "I will rejoice, I will divide Shechem:" here "I will be exalted, and will divide Shechem".

[108:10] Where is shown what is signified in the division of Shechem, which it was prophesied should happen after the Lord's exaltation, and that this joy doth refer to that exaltation; so that He rejoiceth, because He is exalted.

[108:11] Whence he elsewhere saith, "Thou hast turned my heaviness into joy; Thou hast put off my sackcloth and girded me with gladness".

[108:12] Also there "Ephraim, the strength of my head:" but here, "Ephraim the taking up of my head".

[108:13] But strength cometh from taking up, that is, He maketh men strong by taking up, causing fruit in us; for the interpretation of Ephraim is, bearing fruit.

[108:14] But "taking up" may be understood of us, when we take up Christ; or of Christ, when He, who is Head of the Church, taketh us up.

[108:15] And the words, "them that trouble us," in the former Psalm, are the same with "our enemies," in this.

[108:16] We are taught by this Psalm, that those titles which seem to refer to history are most rightly unders tood prophetically, according to the object of the composition of the Psalms.

[108:17] And yet this Psalm is composed of the latter portions of two, whose titles are different.

[108:18] Where it is signified that each concur in a common object, not in the surface of the history, but in the depth of pr ophecy, the objects of both being united in this one, the title of which is, "A Song or Psalm of David:" resembling neither of the former titles, otherwise than in the word David.

[108:19] Since, "in many places, and in diverse manners," as the Epistle to the Hebrews saith, "God spoke in former times to the fathers through the Prophets;" yet He spoke of Him whom He sent afterwards, that the words of the Prophets might be fulfilled: for "all the promises of God in Him are yea".

[109:1] Psalm CIX.

[109:2] Every one who faithfully readeth the Acts of the Apostles, acknowledgeth that this Psalm containeth a prophecy of Christ; for it evidently appeareth that what is here written, "let his days be few, and let another take his office," is prophesied of Judas, the betrayer of Christ.

[109:3] For as some things are said which seem peculiarly to apply to the Apostle Peter, and yet are not clear in their meaning, unless when referred to the Church, whom he is acknowledged to have figuratively represented, on account of the primacy which he bore among the Disciples; as it is written, "I will give unto thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven," and other passages of the like purport: so Judas doth represent those Jews who were enemies of Christ, who both then hated Christ, and now, in their line of succession, this species of wickedness continuing, hate Him.

[109:4] Of these men, and of this people, not only may what we read more openly discovered in this Psalm be conveniently understood, but also those things which are more expressly stated concerning Judas himself.

[109:5] The Psalm, then, beginneth thus: "O God, be not silent as to my praise; for the mouth of the ungodly, yea, the mouth of the deceitful is opened upon me".

[109:6] Whence it appeareth, both that the blame, which the ungodly and the deceitful is not silent of, is false, and that the praise, which God is not silent of, is true.

[109:7] "For God is true, but every man a liar;" for no man is true, except him in whom God speaketh.

[109:8] But the highest praise is that of the only-begotten Son of God, in which He is proclaimed even that which He is, the only-begotten Son of God.

[109:9] But this did not appear, but, when His weakness appeared, lay hid, when the mouth of the ungodly and deceitful was opened upon Him; and for this reason his mouth was opened, because His virtue was concealed: and he saith, "the mouth of the deceitful was opened," because the hatred which was covered by deceit burst out into language.

[109:10] "They have spoken against me with false tongues" : then chiefly when they praised him as a "good Master" with insidious adulation.

[109:11] Whence it is elsewhere said: "and they that praised me, are sworn together against me".

[109:12] Next, because they burst into cries, "Crucify Him, crucify Him;" he hath added, "They compassed me about also with words of hatred".

[109:13] They who with a treacherous tongue spoke words seemingly of love, and not of hatred, "against me," since they did this insidiously; afterwards "compassed me about with words" not of false and deceitful love, but of open "hatred, and fought against me without a cause".

[109:14] For as the pious love Christ for nought, so do the wicked hate Him for nought; for as truth is earnestly sought by the best men on its own account, without any advantage, external to itself, in view, so is wickedness sought by the worst men.

[109:15] Whence among secular authors it is said of a very bad man, "he was wicked and cruel for no object".

[109:16] "In place," saith he, "of loving me, they detracted from me".

[109:17] There are six different acts of this class, which may, when mentioned, very easily be borne in mind;  to return good for evil,  not to return evil for evil;  to return good for good,  to return evil for evil;  not to return good for good,  to return evil for good.

[109:18] The two first of these belong to the good, and the first of these two is the better; the two last belong to the wicked, and the latter of the two is the worse; the two middle to a sort of middle class of persons, but the first of these borders upon the good, the latter on the bad.

[109:19] We should remark these things in the holy Scriptures.

[109:20] Our Lord Himself returneth good for evil, who "justifieth the ungodly;" and who, when hanging upon the Cross, said, "Father, forgive them; for they know not what they do".

[109:21] But after he had said, "in place of loving me, they detracted from me;" what doth he add? "But I gave myself unto prayer".

[109:22] He said not indeed what he prayed, but what can we better understand than for them themselves? For they were detracting greatly from Him whom they crucified, when they ridiculed Him as if He were a man, whom in their opinion they had conquered; from which Cross He said, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do;" so that while they in the depth of their malignity were rendering evil for good, He in the height of His goodness was rendering good for evil.

[109:23] The divine words then teach us by our Lord's example, that when we feel others ungrateful to us, not only in that they do not repay us with good, but even return evil for good, we should pray; He indeed for others who were raging against Him, or in sorrow, or endangered in faith; but we for ourselves in the first place, that we may by the mercy and aid of God conquer our own mind, by which we are borne on to the desire of revenge, when any detraction is made from us, either in our presence or our absence.

[109:24] He addeth, "Thus have they rewarded me evil for good".

[109:25] And as if we asked, what evil? for what good? "And hatred," he saith, "for my good will".

[109:26] This is the sum total of their great guilt.

[109:27] For how could the persecutors injure Him who died of His own free-will, and not by compulsion? But this very hatred is the greatest crime of the persecutor, although it be the willing atonement of the sufferer.

[109:28] And he hath sufficiently explained the sense of the above words, "In place of loving me," since they owed love not as a general duty only, but in return for His love: in that he hath here added, "for my good will".

[109:29] This love He mentioneth in the Gospel, when He saith, "How often would I have gathered thy children together, and thou wouldest not!".

[109:30] He then beginneth to prophesy what they should receive for this very impiety; detailing their lot in such a manner, as if he wished its realization from a desire of revenge.

[109:31] Some not understanding this mode of predicting the future, under the appearance of wishing evil, suppose hatred to be returned for hatred, and an evil will for an evil will, since in truth it belongeth to few to distinguish, in what way the punishment of the wicked pleaseth the accuser, who longeth to satiate his enmity; and in how widely different a way it pleaseth the judge, who with a righteous mind punisheth sins.

[109:32] For the former returneth evil for evil: but the judge when he punisheth doth not return evil for evil, since he returneth justice to the unjust; and what is just, is surely good.

[109:33] He therefore punisheth not from delight in another's misery, which is evil for evil: but from love of justice, which is good for evil.

[109:34] "Set thou an ungodly man to be ruler over him; and let Satan sta nd at his right hand".

[109:35] Though the complaint had been before concerning many, the Psalm is now speaking of one.

[109:36] Since therefore he is here speaking of the traitor Judas, who, according to the Scripture in the Acts of the Apostles, was to be punished with the penalty due to him, what meaneth, "set thou an ungodly man over him," save him whom in the next verse he mentioneth by name, when he saith, "and let Satan stand at his right hand"? He therefore who refused to be subject unto Christ, deserved this, that he should have the devil set over him, that is, that he should be subject unto the devil.

[109:37] For this reason also it is said of those who, preferring the pleasures of this world to God, styled the people blessed who have such and such things, "their right hand is a right hand of iniquity".

[109:38] "When sentence is given upon him, let him be condemned, and let his prayer be turned into sin".

[109:39] For prayer is not righteous except through Christ, whom he sold in his atrocious sin: but the prayer which is not made through Christ, not only cannot blot out sin, but is itself turned into sin.

[109:40] But it may be inquired on what occasion Judas could have so prayed, that his prayer was turned into sin.

[109:41] I suppose that before he betrayed the Lord, while he was thinking of betraying Him; for he could no longer pray through Christ.

[109:42] For after he betrayed Him, and repented of it, if he prayed through Christ, he would ask for pardon; if he asked for pardon, he would have hope; if he had hope, he would hope for mercy; if he hoped for mercy, he would not have hanged himself in despair.

[109:43] "Let his days be few".

[109:44] By "his days," he meant the days of his apostleship, which were few; since before the Passion of our Lord, they were ended by his crime and death.

[109:45] And as if it were asked, What then shall become of that most sacred number twelve, within which our Lord willed, not without a meaning, to limit His twelve first Apostles? he at once addeth, "and let another take his office".

[109:46] As much as to say, let both himself be punished according to his desert, and let his number be filled up.

[109:47] "Let his children be fatherless, and his wife a widow".

[109:48] After his death, both his children were fatherless, and his wife a widow.

[109:49] "Let his children be vagabonds, and be carried away, and beg their bread".

[109:50] By "vagabonds" he meaneth, uncertain whither to go, destitute of all help.

[109:51] "Let them be driven from their habitations".

[109:52] He here explaineth what he had said above, "Let them be carried away".

[109:53] How all this happened to his wife and children, the following verses explain.

[109:54] "Let the extortioner search out all his substance, and let the strangers spoil his labour".

[109:55] "Let there be no man to help him" : that is, to guard his posterity; wherefore followeth, "nor to have compassion on his fatherless children".

[109:56] But as even orphans may, without one to help them, and without a guardian, nevertheless increase amid trouble and want, and preserve their race by descent; he next saith, "Let his posterity be destroyed; and in the next generation let his name be clean put out" : that is, let what hath been generated by him generate no more, and quickly pass away.

[109:57] But what is it that he next addeth? "Let the wickedness of his fathers be had in remembrance in the sight of the Lord, and let not the sin of his mother be done away".

[109:58] Is it to be understood, that even the sins of his fathers shall be visited upon him? For upon him they are not visited, who hath been changed in Christ, and hath ceased to be the child of the wicked, by not having imitated their conduct.

[109:59] And to these words, "I will visit the sins of the fathers upon the children," is added, "who hate Me;" that is, hate Me as their fathers hated Me: so that as the effect of imitating the good is that even their own sins are blotted out, so the imitation of the wicked causeth men to suffer not their own deservings only, but those also of those whom they have imitated.

[109:60] "Let them alway be against the Lord".

[109:61] "Against the Lord," meaneth in the Lord's sight: for other translators have rendered this line, "let them be always in the sight of the Lord;" while others have rendered it, "let them be before the Lord alway;" as it is elsewhere said, "Thou hast set our misdeeds in Thy sight".

[109:62] By "alway," he meaneth that this great crime should be without pardon, both here, and in a future life.

[109:63] "Let the memorial of them perish from off the earth:" that is, of his father and of his mother.

[109:64] By memorial of them, he meaneth, that which is preserved by successive generations: this he prophesied should perish from the earth, because both Judas himself, and his sons, who were the memorial of his father and mother, without any succeeding offspring, as it is said above, were consumed in the short space of one generation.

[109:65] "And that, because he remembered not to act mercifully" ; either Judas, or the people itself.

[109:66] But "remembered not" is better understood of the people: for if they slew Christ, they might well remember the deed in penitence, and act mercifully towards His members, whom they most perseveringly persecuted.

[109:67] For this reason he saith, "but persecuted the poor man and the beggar".

[109:68] It may indeed be understood of Judas; for the Lord did not disdain to become poor, when He was rich, that we might be enriched by His poverty But how shall I understand the word "beggar," save perhaps because He said to the Samaritan woman, "Give me to drink," and on the Cross He said, "I thirst".

[109:69] But as to what followeth, I do not see how it can be understood of our Head Himself, that is, the Saviour of His own body, whom Judas persecuted.

[109:70] For after saying, "He persecuted the poor man and the beggar:" he addeth, "and to slay," that is, "that he might slay Him," for some have so rendered it, "Him that was pricked at the heart".

[109:71] This expression is not commonly used except of the stings of past sins in the sorrows of penitence; as it is said of those who, when they had heard the Apostles after our Lord's ascension, were "pricked in heart," even they who had slain the Lord.

[109:72] The Psalm then continueth: "His delight was in cursing, and it shall happen to him".

[109:73] Although Judas loved cursing, both in stealing from the money bag, and selling and betraying the Lord: nevertheless, that people more openly loved cursing, when they said, "His blood be on us, and on our children".

[109:74] "He loved not blessing, therefore it shall be far from him".

[109:75] Such was Judas indeed, since he loved not Christ, in whom is everlasting blessing; but the Jewish people still more decidedly refused blessing, unto whom he who had been enlightened by the Lord said, "Will ye also be His disciples?" "He clothed himself with cursing, like as with a raiment:" either Judas, or that people.

[109:76] "And it came into his bowels like water".

[109:77] Both without, then, and within; without, like a garment; within, like water: since he hath come before the judgment-seat of Him "who hath power to destroy both body and soul in hell;" the body without, the soul within.

[109:78] "And like oil into his bones".

[109:79] He showeth that he worketh evil with delight, and storeth up cursing for himself, that is, everlasting punishment; for blessing is eternal life.

[109:80] For at present evil deeds are his delight, flowing like water into his bowels, like oil into his bones; but it is styled cursing, because God hath appointed torments for such men.

[109:81] "Let it be unto him as the cloak which covereth him".

[109:82] Since he hath before spoken of the cloak, why doth he repeat it? When he said, "He clothed himself with cursing as with a raiment;" doth the raiment with which he is "covered" differ from that with which he is "clothed"? For every man is clothed with his tunic, covered with his cloak; and what is this, save boasting in iniquity, even in the sight of men? "and as the girdle," he saith, "that he is alway girded withal".

[109:83] Men are girded chiefly that they may be better fit for toil, that they may not be hindered by the folds of their dress.

[109:84] He therefore girdeth himself with curses, who designeth an evil which he hath carefully contrived, not on a sudden impulse, and who learneth in such a manner to do evil, that he is always ready to commit it.

[109:85] "This is the work of them that slander me before the Lord".

[109:86] He said not, "their reward," but, "their work:" for it is clear that by the clothing, covering, water, oil, and girdle, he was describing the very works by which eternal curses are procured.

[109:87] It is not then one Judas, but many, of whom it is said, "This is the work of them that slander me before the Lord".

[109:88] Although indeed the plural number might have been put for the singular; even as, when Herod died, it was said by the Angel, "They are dead which sought the young Child's life".

[109:89] But who slander Christ more before the Lord, than they who slander the very words of the Lord, by declaring that it is not He whom the Law of the Lord and His Prophets announced beforehand? "And of those that speak evil against my soul:" by denying that He, when He had willed, could have arisen: though He saith, "I have power to lay down My life, and I have power to take it again".

[109:90] "But work Thou with me, O Lord God".

[109:91] Some have thought "mercifully" should be understood, some have actually added it; but the best copies have the words thus: "But work Thou with me, O Lord God, for Thy Name's sake".

[109:92] Whence a higher sense should not be passed over, supposing the Son to have thus addressed the Father, "Deal Thou with Me," since the works of the Father and of the Son are the same.

[109:93] Where although we understand mercy,—for these words follow, "for sweet is Thy mercy,"—because he said not, "In me," or, "over me;" or anything of this sort: but, "work Thou with Me;" we rightly understand that the Father and Son together work mercifully towards the vessels of mercy "Work with me," may also be understood to mean, help me.

[109:94] We use this expression in our daily language, when we are speaking of anything which is in our favour; "It works with us".

[109:95] For the Father aideth the Son, as far as the Deity aideth Man, on account of His having assumed the "form of a servant," to which Man, God, and to which "Form of a servant," the Lord too is Father.

[109:96] For in the "form of God," the Son needeth not aid, for He is equally all-powerful with the Father, on which account He also is the helper of men.

[109:97] And because when he had said, "Work Thou with me," he added, "for Thy Name's sake," he hath commended grace.

[109:98] For without previous deserving works, human nature was raised to such a height, that the whole in one, the Word and Flesh, that is, God and Man, was styled the Only-begotten Son of God.

[109:99] And this was done that that which had been lost might be sought by Him who had created it, through that which had not been lost; whence the following words, "For Thy mercy is sweet".

[109:100] "O deliver me, for I am needy and poor".

[109:101] Need and poverty is that weakness, through which He was crucified "And my heart is disturbed within me".

[109:102] This alludeth to those words which He spoke when His Passion was drawing near, "My soul is exceeding sorrowful, even unto death".

[109:103] "I go hence like a shadow that declineth".

[109:104] By this he signified death itself.

[109:105] For as night comes of the shadow's declining, so death comes of mortal flesh.

[109:106] "And am driven away as the locusts".

[109:107] This I think would be more suitably understood of His members, that is, of His faithful disciples.

[109:108] That he might make it much plainer, he preferred writing "locusts" in the plural number: although many may be understood where the singular number is used, as in that passage, "He spake, and the locust came;"  but it would have been more obscure.

[109:109] His disciples, then, were driven away, that is, were put to flight by persecutors, either the multitude of whom He wished to be signified by the word locusts, or their passing from one place to another.

[109:110] "My knees are weak through fasting".

[109:111] We read, that our Lord Christ underwent a fast of forty days: but had fasting so great power over Him, that His knees were weakened? Or is this more suitably understood of His members, that is, of His saints? "And my flesh is changed because of the oil;" because of spiritual grace.

[109:112] Whence Christ was so called from the Greek word, chrisma, which signifies unction.

[109:113] But the flesh was changed through the oil, not for the worse, but for the better, that is, rising from the dishonour of death to the glory of immortality.

[109:114] His flesh was not yet changed.

[109:115] But whether the Holy Spirit be represented by water through the notion of ablution or irrigation, or by oil through that of exultation and the inflaming of charity; It doth not differ from Itself, because Its types are different.

[109:116] For there is a great difference between the lion and the lamb, and yet Christ is represented by both.

[109:117] "I became also a reproach unto them" : through the death of the Cross.

[109:118] "For Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us".

[109:119] "They looked upon Me, and shaked their heads".

[109:120] Because they beheld His crucifixion, without beholding His resurrection: they saw when His knees were weakened, they saw not when His flesh was changed.

[109:121] "Help me, O Lord my God: O save me according to Thy mercy".

[109:122] This may be referred to the whole, both to the Head and to the body: to the Head, owing to His having taken the form of a servant; to the body, on account of the servants themselves.

[109:123] For He might even in them have said unto God, "Help Me:" and, "O save Me:" as in them He said unto Paul, "Why persecutest thou Me"?  The following words, "according to Thy mercy," describe grace given gratuitously, not according to the merit of works.

[109:124] "And let them know how that this is Thy Hand, and that Thou, Lord, hast made it".

[109:125] He said, "Let them know," of those for whom He even prayed while they were raging; for even those who afterwards believed in Him were among the crowd who shook their heads in mockery of Him.

[109:126] But let those who ascribe unto God the shape of the human body, learn in what sense God hath a hand.

[109:127] Let us therefore understand, that the Hand of God meaneth Christ: whence it is elsewhere said, "Unto whom is the arm of the Lord revealed?".

[109:128] "Though they curse, yet bless Thou".

[109:129] Vain therefore and false is the cursing of the sons of men, that have pleasure in vanity, and seek a lie; but when God blesseth, He doth what He saith.

[109:130] "Let them be confounded that rise up against me".

[109:131] For their imagining that they have some power against Me, is the reason that they rise up against Me; but when I shall have been exalted above the heavens, and My glory shall have commenced spreading over the whole earth, they shall be confounded.

[109:132] "But Thy servant shall rejoice:" either on the right hand of the Father, or in His members when they rejoice, both in hope among temptations, and after temptations for evermore.

[109:133] "Let my slanderers be clothed with shame" : that is, let it shame them to have slandered me.

[109:134] But this may also be understood as a blessing, in that they are amended.

[109:135] "And let them cover themselves with their own confusion, as with a double cloak;" for diplois is a double cloak; that is, let them be confounded both within and without: both before God and before men.

[109:136] "As for me, I will confess greatly unto the Lord with my mouth".

[109:137] Is He said to "praise among the multitude" because He is with His Church here even unto the end of the world; so that we may understand by "among the multitude," that He is honoured by this very multitude? For he is said to be in the midst, unto whom the chief honour is paid.

[109:138] But if the heart is, as it were, that which is mid-most of a man, no better construction can be put on this passage than this, I will praise Him in the hearts of many.

[109:139] For Christ dwelleth through faith in our hearts; and therefore he saith, "with my mouth," that is, with the mouth of my body, which is the Church.

[109:140] "For He stood at the right hand of the poor".

[109:141] It was said of Judas, "Let Satan stand at his right hand;" since he chose to increase his riches by selling Christ; but here the Lord stood at the right hand of the poor, that the Lord Himself might be the poor man's riches.

[109:142] "He stood at the right hand of the poor," not to multiply the years of a life that one day must end, nor to increase his stores, nor to render him strong in the strength of the body, or secure for a time; "but," he saith, "to save my soul from the persecutors".

[109:143] Now the soul is rendered safe from the persecutors, if we do not consent to them unto evil; but there is no such consent to them when the Lord standeth at the right hand of the poor, that he may not give way through his very poverty, that is, weakness.

[109:144] This aid was given to the Body of Christ in the case of all the holy Martyrs.

[110:1] Psalm CX.

[110:2] This Psalm is one of those promises, surely and openly prophesying our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ; so that we are utterly unable to doubt that Christ is announced in this Psalm, since we are now Christians, and believe the Gospel.

[110:3] For when our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ asked of the Jews, whose Son they alleged Christ to be, and they had replied, "the Son of David;" He at once replied to their answer, "How then doth David in spirit call Him Lord, saying, The Lord said unto My Lord?" etc.

[110:4] "If then,"  He asked, "David in the spirit call Him Lord, how is He his son?" With this verse this Psalm beginneth.

[110:5] "The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit Thou on My right hand, until I make Thine enemies Thy footstool".

[110:6] We ought, therefore, thoroughly to consider this question proposed to the Jews by the Lord, in the very commencement of the Psalm.

[110:7] For if what the.

[110:8] Jews answered be asked of us, whether we confess or deny it; God forbid that we should deny it.

[110:9] If it be said to us, Is Christ the Son of David, or not? if we reply, No, we contradict the Gospel for the Gospel of St.

[110:10] Matthew thus beginneth, "The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the Son of David".

[110:11] The Evangelist declareth, that he is writing the book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the Son of David.

[110:12] The Jews, then, when questioned by Christ, whose Son they believed Christ to be, rightly answered, the Son of David.

[110:13] The Gospel agreeth with their answer.

[110:14] Not only the suspicion of the Jews, but the faith of Christians, doth declare this.

[110:15] "If then David in the spirit called Him Lord, how is He his son?" The Jews were silent at this question: they found no further reply: yet they did not seek Him as the Lord, for they did not acknowledge Him to be Himself that Son of David.

[110:16] But let us, brethren, both believe and declare: for, "with the heart we believe unto righteousness: but with the mouth confession is made unto salvation;" let us believe, I say, and let us declare both the Son of David, and the Lord of David.

[110:17] Let us not be ashamed of the Son of David, lest we find the Lord of David angry with us.

[110:18] We know that Christ sitteth at the right hand of the Father, since His resurrection from the dead, and ascent into heaven.

[110:19] It is already done: we saw not it, but we have believed it: we have read it in the Scripture, have heard it preached, and hold it by faith.

[110:20] So that by the very circumstance that Christ was David's Son, He became His Lord also.

[110:21] For That which was born of the seed of David was so honoured, that It was also the Lord of David.

[110:22] Thou wonderest at this, as if the same did not happen in human affairs.

[110:23] For if it should happen, that the son of any private person be made a king, will he not be his father's lord? What is yet more wonderful may happen, not only that the son of a private person, by being made a king, may become his father's lord; but that the son of a layman, by being made a Bishop, may become his father's father.

[110:24] So that in this very circumstance, that Christ took upon Him the flesh, that He died in the flesh, that He rose again in the same flesh, that in the same He ascended into Heaven, and sitteth on the right hand of His Father, in this same flesh so honoured, so brightened, so changed into a heavenly garb, He is both David's Son, and David's Lord.

[110:25] Christ, therefore, sitteth at the right hand of God, the Son is on the right hand of the Father, hidden from us.

[110:26] Let us believe.

[110:27] Two things are here said: that God said, "Sit Thou on My right hand;" and added, "until I make Thy enemies Thy footstool;" that is, beneath Thy feet.

[110:28] Thou dost not see Christ sitting at the right hand of the Father: yet thou canst see this, how His enemies are made His footstool.

[110:29] While the latter is fulfilled openly, believe the former to be fulfilled secretly.

[110:30] What enemies are made His footstool? Those to whom imagining vain things it is said, "Why do the heathen so furiously rage together: and why do the people imagine a vain thing?" etcHe therefore sitteth at the right hand of God, till His enemies be placed beneath His feet.

[110:31] This is going on, this is taking place: although it is accomplished by degrees, it is going on without end.

[110:32] For though the heathen rage, will they, taking counsel together against Christ, prevent the fulfilment of these words: "I will give thee the heathen for thine inheritance, and the utmost parts of the earth for thy possession"?"Their memorial is perished with a cry;" but, "The Lord shall endure for ever:" as another Psalm, but not another Spirit, saith.

[110:33] And what followeth? "The Lord shall send the rod of Thy power out of Sion".

[110:34] It appeareth, brethren, it most clearly appeareth, that the Prophet is not speaking of that kingdom of Christ, in which He reigneth for ever with His Father, Ruler of the things which are made through Him: for when doth not God the Word reign, who is in the beginning with God? For it is said, "Now unto the King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God, be honour and glory for ever and ever".

[110:35] To what eternal King? To one invisible, incorruptible.

[110:36] For in this, that Christ is with the Father, invisible and incorruptible, because He is His Word, and His Power, and His Wisdom, and God with God, through whom all things were made; He is "King eternal;" but, nevertheless, that reign of temporal government, by which, through the mediation of His flesh, He called us into eternity, beginneth with Christians; but of His reign there shall be no end.

[110:37] His enemies therefore are made His footstool, while He is sitting on the right hand of His Father, as it is written; this is now going on, this will go on unto the end.

[110:38] When therefore He hath sent the rod of His power out of Sion: what shall happen? "Be Thou ruler, even in the midst among Thine enemies".

[110:39] First, "Be Thou ruler in the midst of Thine enemies:" in the midst of the raging heathen.

[110:40] For shall He rule "in the midst of His enemies" at a later season, when the Saints have received their reward, and the ungodly their condemnation? And what wonder if He shall then rule, when the righteous reign with Him for ever, and the ungodly burn with eternal punishments? What wonder, if He shall then? Now "in the midst of Thine enemies," now in this transition of ages, in this propagation and succession of human mortality, now while the torrent of time is gliding by, unto this is the rod of Thy power sent out of Sion, "that Thou mayest be Ruler in the midst of Thine enemies".

[110:41] Rule Thou, rule among Pagans, Jews, heretics, false brethren.

[110:42] Rule Thou, rule, O Son of David, Lord of David, rule in the midst of Pagans, Jews, heretics, false brethren.

[110:43] "Be Thou Ruler in the midst of Thine enemies".

[110:44] We understand not this verse aright, if we do not see that it is already going on.

[110:45] "With Thee the beginning on the day of Thy power".

[110:46] What is this day of His power, when is there beginning with Him, or what beginning, or in what sense is there beginning with Him, since He is the Beginning?.

[110:47] What meaneth, "With Thee is the beginning"? Suppose anything you please as the beginning.

[110:48] Of Christ Himself, it would rather have been said, Thou art the Beginning, than, With Thee is the beginning.

[110:49] For He answered to those who asked Him, "Who art Thou?" and said, "Even the same that I said unto you, the Beginning;" since His Father also is the Beginning, of whom is the only-begotten Son, in which Beginning was the Word, for the Word was with God.

[110:50] What then, if both the Father and the Son are the beginning, are there two beginnings? God forbid! For as the Father is God, and the Son is God, but the Father and the Son are not two Gods, but one God: so is the Father Beginning and the Son Beginning, but the Father and the Son are not two, but one Beginning.

[110:51] "With Thee is the beginning".

[110:52] Then it shall appear in what sense the beginning is with Thee.

[110:53] Not that the beginning is not with Thee here also.

[110:54] For hast Thou not also said, "Behold, ye shall be scattered, every man to his own, and shall leave Me alone; but I am not alone, because the Father is with Me"? Here therefore also, the beginning is with Thee.

[110:55] For Thou hast said elsewhere also, "But the Father that dwelleth in Me, He doeth His works".

[110:56] "With Thee is the beginning:" nor was the Father ever separated from Thee.

[110:57] But when the Beginning shall appear to be with Thee, then shall it be manifest unto all who are made like Thee; since they shall see Thee as Thou art; for Philip saw Thee here, and sought the Father Then therefore shall be seen what now is believed: then shall "the beginning be with Thee" in the sight of the righteous, in the sight of saints; the ungodly being removed, that they may not see the brightness of the Lord.

[110:58] Explain of what power thou speakest.

[110:59] Because here also, as is said, His power is mentioned, when the rod of His power is sent forth out of Sion, that He may be Ruler in the midst of His enemies.

[110:60] Of what power speakest thou, "In the splendour of the saints"? "In the splendour," he saith, "of the saints".

[110:61] He speaketh of that power when the saints shall be in splendour; not when still carrying about their earthly flesh, and groaning in a mortal and corruptible body.

[110:62] But this is put off, this will be granted afterwards: what is there now? "From the womb I have begotten Thee, before the morning star".

[110:63] What is here? If God hath a Son, hath He also a womb? Like fleshly bodies, He hath not; for He hath not a bosom either; yet it is said, "He who is in the bosom of the Father, hath declared Him".

[110:64] But that which is the womb, is the bosom also: both bosom and womb are put for a secret place.

[110:65] What meaneth, "from the womb"? From what is secret, from what is hidden; from Myself, from My substance; this is the meaning of "from the womb;" for, "Who shall declare His generation?" Let us then understand the Father saying unto the Son, "From My womb before the morning star have I brought Thee forth".

[110:66] What then meaneth, "before the morning star"? The morning star is put for the stars, as if the Scripture signified the whole from a part, and from one conspicuous star all the stars.

[110:67] But how were those stars created? "That they may be for signs, and for seasons, and for days, and years".

[110:68] This expression also, "before the morning star," is used both figuratively and literally, and was thus fulfilled.

[110:69] For the Lord was born at night from the womb of the Virgin Mary; the testimony of the shepherds doth assert this, who were "keeping watch over their flock".

[110:70] So David: O Thou, my Lord, who sittest at the right hand of my Lord, whence art Thou my Son, except because, "From the womb before the morning star I have begotten Thee"?.

[110:71] And unto what art Thou born? "The Lord hath sworn, and will not repent: Thou art a Priest for ever after the order of Melchizedec".

[110:72] For unto this wast Thou born from the womb before the morning star, that Thou mightest be a Priest for ever after the order of Melchizedec.

[110:73] For in that character in which He was born of the Father, God with God, coeternal with Him who begot Him, He is not a Priest; but He is a Priest on account of the flesh which He assumed, on account of the victim which He was to offer for us received from us.

[110:74] "The Lord," then, "hath sworn".

[110:75] What then meaneth, the Lord hath sworn? Doth the Lord, who forbiddeth men to swear, Himself swear? Or doth He possibly forbid man to swear chiefly on this account, that he may not fall into perjury, and for this reason the Lord may swear, since He cannot be forsworn.

[110:76] For man, who, through a habit of swearing, may slip into perjury, is rightly forbidden to swear: for he will be farther from perjury in proportion as he is far from swearing.

[110:77] For the man who sweareth, may swear truly or falsely: but he who sweareth not, cannot swear falsely; for he sweareth not at all.

[110:78] Why then should not the Lord swear, since the Lord's oath is the seal of the promise? Let Him swear by all means.

[110:79] What then dost thou, when thou swearest? Thou callest God to witness: this is to swear, to call God to witness; and for this reason there must be anxiety, that thou mayest not call God to witness anything false.

[110:80] If therefore thou by an oath dost call God to witness, why then should not God also call Himself to witness with an oath? "I live, saith the Lord," this is the Lord's oath.

[110:81] "The Lord sware," then, that is, confirmed: "He will not repent," He will not change.

[110:82] What? "Thou art a Priest for ever.

[110:83] "For ever," for He will not repent.

[110:84] But Priest, in what sense? Will there be those victims, victims offered by the Patriarchs, altars of blood, and tabernacle, and those sacred emblems of the Old Covenant? God forbid! These things are already abolished; the temple being destroyed, that priesthood taken away, their victim and their sacrifice having alike disappeared, not even the Jews have these things.

[110:85] They see that the priesthood after the order of Aaron hath already perished, and they do not recognise the Priesthood after the order of Melchizedec.

[110:86] I speak unto believers.

[110:87] If catechumens understand not something, let them lay aside sloth, and hasten unto knowledge.

[110:88] It is not therefore needful for me to disclose mysteries here:  let the Scriptures intimate to you what is the Priesthood after the order of Melchizedec.

[110:89] "The Lord on Thy right hand".

[110:90] The Lord had said, "Sit Thou on My right hand;" now the Lord is on His right hand, as if they changed seats.

[110:91] That very Christ, the "Lord on Thy right hand," unto whom Thou hast sworn, and it will not repent Thee: what doth He, Priest for evermore? What doth He, who is at the right hand of God, and intercedeth for us, like a priest entering into the inner places, and into the holy of holies, into the mysteries of heaven, He alone being without sin, and therefore easily purifying from sins He therefore "on Thy right hand shall wound even kings in the day of His wrath".

[110:92] What kings, dost thou ask? Hast thou forgotten? "The kings of the earth stood up, and the rulers took counsel together against the Lord, and against His Anointed".

[110:93] These kings He wounded by His glory, and by the weight of His Name made kings weak, so that they had not power to effect what they wished.

[110:94] For they strove amain to blot out the Christian name from the earth, and could not; for "Whosoever shall fall on this stone shall be broken".

[110:95] Kings therefore fall on this "stone of offence," and are therefore wounded, when they say, Who is Christ? I know not what Jew or what Galilean He may have been, who died, who was slain in such a manner! The stone is before thy feet, lying, so to speak, mean and humble: therefore by scorning thou dost stumble, by stumbling thou fallest, by falling thou art wounded.

[110:96] "But on whomsoever it shall fall, it will grind him to powder".

[110:97] When therefore any one falleth upon it, it lieth as it were low; it then woundeth: but when it shall grind him to powder, then it will come from above.

[110:98] See how in these two words, it shall wound him and grind him to powder: he striketh upon it, and it shall come down upon him: are distinguished the two seasons, of the humiliation and the majesty of Christ, of hidden punishment and future judgment.

[110:99] He will not crush, when He cometh, that man whom He doth not wound when He lieth in a contemptible appearance.

[110:100] "He shall judge among the heathen: He shall fill up what hath fallen".

[110:101] Whoever thou art who art obstinate against Christ, thou hast raised on high a tower that must fall.

[110:102] It is good that thou shouldest cast thyself down, become humble, throw thyself at the feet of Him who sitteth on the right hand of the Father, that in thee a ruin may be made to be built up.

[110:103] For if thou abidest in thy evil height, thou shalt be cast down when thou canst not be built up.

[110:104] For of such the Scripture saith in another passage: "Therefore shall He break down, and not build them up".

[110:105] Beyond doubt he would not say this of some, unless there were some whom He broke down so as to build them up again.

[110:106] And this is going on at this time, while Christ is judging among the heathen in such a manner as to fill up what hath fallen.

[110:107] "He shall smite many heads over the earth".

[110:108] Here upon the earth in this life He shall smite many heads.

[110:109] He maketh them humble instead of proud; and I dare to say, my brethren, that it is more profitable to walk here humbly with the head wounded, than with the head erect to fall into the judgment of eternal death.

[110:110] He will smite many heads when he causeth them to fall, but He will fill them up and build them up again.

[110:111] "He shall drink of the brook in the way, therefore shall he lift up his head".

[110:112] Let us consider Him drinking of the brook in the way: first of all, what is the brook? the onward flow of human mortality: for as a brook is gathered together by the rain, overflows, roars, runs, and by running runs down, that is, finishes its course; so is all this course of mortality.

[110:113] Men are born, they live, they die, and when some die others are born, and when they die others are born, they succeed, they flock together, they depart and will not remain.

[110:114] What is held fast here? what doth not run? what is not on its way to the abyss as if it was gathered together from rain? For as a river suddenly drawn together from rain from the drops of showers runneth into the sea, and is seen no more, nor was it seen before it was collected from the rain; so this hidden rain is collected together from hidden sources, and floweth on; at death again it travelleth where it is hidden: this intermediate state soundeth and passeth away.

[110:115] Of this brook He drinketh, He hath not disdained to drink of this brook; for to drink of this brook was to Him to be born and to die.

[110:116] What this brook hath, is birth and death; Christ assumed this, He was born, He died.

[110:117] "Therefore hath He lifted up His head;" that is, because He was humble, and "became obedient unto death, even the death of the Cross: therefore God also hath highly exalted Him, and given Him a Name which is above every name; that at the Name of Jesus every knee shall bow, of things in Heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth; and that every tongue shall confess that Jesus Christ the Lord is in the glory of God the Father".

[111:1] Psalm CXI.

[111:2] The days have come for us to sing AllelujahNow these days come only to pass away, and pass away to come, again, and typify the day which does not come and pass away, because it is neither preceded by yesterday to cause it to come, nor pressed upon by the morrow to cause it to pass.

[111:3] For as these days succeed in regular season, with a joyful cheerfulness, the past days of Lent, whereby the misery of this life before the Resurrection of the Lord's body is signified; so that day which after the Resurrection shall be given to the full body of the Lord, that is, to the holy Church, when all the troubles and sorrows of this life have been shut out, shall succeed with perpetual bliss.

[111:4] But this life demandeth from us self-restraint, that although groaning and weighed down with our toil and struggles, and desiring to be clothed upon with our house which is from heaven, we may refrain from secular pleasures: and this is signified by the number of forty, which was the period of the fasts of Moses, and Elias, and our Lord Himself.

[111:5] But by the number fifty after our Lord's resurrection, during which season we sing Allelujah, not the term and passing away of a certain season is signified, but that blessed eternity; because the denary added to forty signifieth the reward paid to the faithful who toil in this life, which our Father hath prepared an equal share of for the first and for the last.

[111:6] Let us there fore hear the heart of the people of God full of divine praises.

[111:7] He representeth in this Psalm some one exulting in happy joyfulness, he prefigureth the people whose hearts are overflowing with the love of God, that is, the body of Christ, freed from all evil.

[111:8] "I will make confession unto Thee, O Lord," he saith, "with my whole heart".

[111:9] Confession is not always confession of sins, but the praise of God is poured forth in the devotion of confession.

[111:10] The former mourneth, the latter rejoiceth: the former showeth the wound to the physician, the latter giveth thanks for health.

[111:11] The latter confession signifieth some one, not merely freed from every evil, but even separate from all the ill-disposed.

[111:12] And for this reason let us consider the place where he confesseth unto the Lord with all his heart.

[111:13] "In the counsel," he saith, "of the upright, and in the congregation:" I suppose, of those who shall "sit upon the twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel".

[111:14] For there will be no longer an unjust man among them, the thefts of no Judas are allowed, no Simon Magus is baptized, wishing to buy the Spirit, whilst he designeth to sell it; no coppersmith like Alexander doth many evil deeds, no man covered with sheep's clothing creepeth in with feigned fraternity; such as those among whom the Church must now groan, and such as she must then shut out, when all the righteous shall be gathered together.

[111:15] "These are the great works of the Lord, sought out unto all His wills" : through which mercy forsaketh none who confesseth, no man's wickedness is unpunishedLet man choose for himself what he listeth: the works of the Lord are not so constituted, that the creature, having free discretion allowed him, should transcend the will of the Creator, even though he act contrary to His will.

[111:16] God willeth not that thou shouldest sin; for He forbiddeth it: yet if thou hast sinned, imagine not that the man hath done what he willed, and that hath happened to God which He willed not.

[111:17] For as He would that man would not sin, so would He spare the sinner, that he may return and live; He so willeth finally to punish him who persisteth in his sin, that the rebellious cannot escape the power of justice.

[111:18] Thus whatever choice thou hast made, the Almighty will not be at a loss to fulfil His will concerning thee.

[111:19] "Confession and glorious deeds are His work".

[111:20] What is a more glorious deed than to justify the ungodly? But perhaps the work of man preventeth that glorious work of God, so that when he hath confessed his sins, he deserveth to be justified.

[111:21] This is the glorious work of the Lord: for he loveth most, to whom most is forgiven This is the glorious work of the Lord: for "where sin abounded, there did grace much more abound".

[111:22] But perhaps a man would deserve justification from works.

[111:23] "Not," saith he, "of works, lest any man boast.

[111:24] For we are His workmanship, created in Christ Jesus unto good works".

[111:25] For a man worketh not righteousness save he be justified: but by "believing on Him that justifieth the ungodly," he beginneth with faith; that good may not by preceding show what he hath deserved, but by following what he hath received.

[111:26] "He hath made His wonderful works to be remembered" : by abasing this man, exalting that.

[111:27] Reserving unusual miracles for a fit season, that thus human weakness, intent upon novelty, may remember them, although His daily miracles be greater.

[111:28] He created so many trees throughout the whole earth, and no one wondereth: He dried up one with a word, and the hearts of mortals were thunderstruck For that miracle, which hath not through its frequency become common, will cling most firmly to the heart.

[111:29] But of what use were the miracles, save that He might be feared? What too would fear profit, unless "the gracious and merciful Lord" gave "meat unto them that fear Him"? ; meat that doth not spoil, "bread that cometh down from heaven," which He gave to no deservings of ours.

[111:30] For "Christ died for the ungodly".

[111:31] No one then would give such food, save a gracious and merciful Lord.

[111:32] But if He gave so much to this life, if the sinner who was to be justified received the Word made flesh; what shall he receive when glorified in a future world? For, "He shall ever be mindful of His covenant".

[111:33] Nor hath He who hath given a pledge, given the whole.

[111:34] "He shall show His people the power of His works".

[111:35] Let not the holy Israelites, who have left all their possessions and have followed Him, be saddened; let them not be sorrowful and say, "Who then can be saved?" For "it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God".

[111:36] For "with men these things are impossible, but with God all things are possible".

[111:37] "That He may give them the heritage of the heathen".

[111:38] For they went to the heathen, and enjoined the rich of this world "not to be high-minded, nor to trust in uncertain riches, but in the living God," to whom that is easy which is difficult for men.

[111:39] For thus many were called, thus the heritage of the heathen has been occupied, thus it hath happened, that even many who have not abandoned all their possessions in this life in order to follow Him, have despised even life itself for the sake of confessing His Name; and like camels humbling themselves to bear the burden of troubles, have entered as it were through a needle's eye, through the piercing straits of suffering.

[111:40] He hath wrought these effects, unto whom all things are possible.

[111:41] "The works of His hands are verity and judgment".

[111:42] Let verity be held by those who are judged here.

[111:43] Martyrs are here sentenced, and brought to the judgment-seat, that they may judge not only those by whom they have been judged, but even give judgment on angels, against whom was their struggle here, even when they seemed to be judged by men.

[111:44] Let not tribulation, distress, famine, nakedness, the sword, separate from Christ.

[111:45] For "all His commandments are true;" He deceiveth not, He giveth us what He promised.

[111:46] Yet we should not expect here what He promised; we should not hope for it: but "they stand fast for ever and ever, and are done in truth and equity".

[111:47] It is equitable and just that we should labour here and repose there; since "He sent redemption unto His people".

[111:48] But from what are they redeemed, save from the captivity of this pilgrimage? Let not therefore rest be sought, save in the heavenly country.

[111:49] God indeed gave the carnal Israelites an earthly Jerusalem, "which is in bondage with her children:" but this is the Old Covenant, pertaining unto the old man.

[111:50] But they who there understood the figure, even then were heirs of the New Covenant; for "Jerusalem which is above is free, which is our everlasting mother in heaven".

[111:51] But that transitory promises were given in that Old Testament is proved by the fact itself: however, "He hath commended His covenant for ever".

[111:52] But what, but the New? Whosoever dost wish to be heir of this, deceive not thyself, and think not of a land flowing with milk and honey, nor of pleasant farms, nor of gardens abounding in fruits and shade: desire not how to gain anything of this sort, such as the eye of covetousness is wont to lust for.

[111:53] For since "covetousness is the root of all evils," it must be cut off, that it may be consumed here; not be put off, that it may be satisfied there.

[111:54] First escape punishments, avoid hell; before thou longest for a God who promiseth, beware of one who threateneth.

[111:55] For "holy and reverend is His Name".

[111:56] "The fear of the Lord," therefore, "is the beginning of wisdom".

[111:57] "Understanding is good".

[111:58] Who gainsayeth? But to understand, and not to do, is dangerous.

[111:59] It is "good," therefore, "to those that do thereafter".

[111:60] Nor let it lift up the mind unto pride; for, "the praise of Him," the fear of whom is the beginning of wisdom, "endureth for ever:" and this will be the reward, this the end, this the everlasting station and abode.

[111:61] There are found the true commandments, made fast for ever and ever; here is the very heritage of the New Covenant commanded for ever.

[111:62] "One thing," he saith, "I have desired of the Lord, which I will require: even that I may dwell in the house of the Lord all the days of my life".

[111:63] For, "blessed are they that dwell in the house" of the Lord: "they will be alway praising" Him; for "His praise endureth for ever".

[112:1] Psalm CXII.

[112:2] I believe, brethren, that ye remarked and committed to memory the title of this Psalm.

[112:3] "The conversion," he saith, "of Haggai and Zechariah".

[112:4] These prophets were not as yet in existence, when these verses were sungBut both, the one within a year after the other, began to prophesy that which seemeth to pertain to the restoration of the temple, as was foretold so long before"For the temple of God is holy, which temple ye are".

[112:5] Whoever therefore converteth himself to the work of this building together, and to the hope of a firm and holy edifice, like a living stone from the miserable ruin of this world, understandeth the title of the Psalm, understandeth "the conversion of Haggai and Zechariah".

[112:6] Let him therefore chant the following verses, not so much with the voice of his tongue as of his life.

[112:7] For the completion of the building will be that ineffable peace of wisdom, the "beginning" of which is the "fear of the Lord:" let him therefore, whom this conversion buildeth together, begin thence.

[112:8] "Blessed is the man that feareth the Lord: he will have great delight in His commandments".

[112:9] God, who alone judgeth both truthfully and mercifully, will see how far he obeyeth His commandments: since "the life of man on earth is a temptation," as holy Job saith.

[112:10] But "He who judgeth us is the Lord".

[112:11] He therefore will see how far each man profiteth in His commandments; yet he who loveth the peace of this building together, shall have great delight in them; nor ought he to despair, since there is "peace on earth for men of good will".

[112:12] Next follows, "His seed shall be mighty upon earth".

[112:13] The Apostle witnesseth, that the works of mercy are the seed of the future harvest, when he saith, "Let us not be weary in well doing, for in due season we shall reap;" and again, "But this I say, He which soweth sparingly, shall reap also sparingly".

[112:14] But what, brethren, is more mighty than that not only Zacchaeus should buy the kingdom of Heaven by the half of his goods, but even the widow for two mites, and that each should possess an equal share there? What is more mighty, than that the same kingdom should be worth treasures to the rich man, and a cup of cold water to the poor?"Glory and riches shall be in his house".

[112:15] For his house is his heart; where, with the praise of God, he liveth in greater riches with the hope of eternal life, than with men flattering, in palaces of marble, with splendidly adorned ceilings, with the fear of everlasting death.

[112:16] "For his righteousness endureth for ever:" this is his glory, there are his riches.

[112:17] While the other's purple, and fine linen, and grand banquets, even when present, are passing away; and when they have come to an end, the burning tongue shall cry out, longing for a drop of water from the finger's end.

[112:18] "Unto the right-hearted there ariseth up light in the darkness".

[112:19] Justly do the godly direct their heart unto their God, justly do they walk with their God, preferring His will to themselves; and having no proud presumption in their own.

[112:20] For they remember that they were some time in darkness, but are now light in the Lord "Merciful, pitying, and just is the Lord God".

[112:21] It delighteth us that He is "merciful and pitying," but it perhaps terrifieth us that the Lord God is "just".

[112:22] Fear not, despair not at all, happy man, who fearest the Lord, and hast great delight in His commandments; be thou sweet, be merciful and lend.

[112:23] For the Lord is just in this manner, that He judgeth without mercy him who hath not shown mercy; but, "Sweet is the man who is merciful and lendeth" : God will not spew him out of His mouth as if he were not sweet.

[112:24] "Forgive," He saith, "and ye shall be forgiven; give, and it shall be given unto you".

[112:25] Whilst thou forgivest that thou mayest be forgiven, thou art merciful; whilst thou givest that it may be given unto thee, thou lendest.

[112:26] For though all be called generally mercy where another is assisted in his distress, yet there is a difference where thou spendest neither money, nor the toil of bodily labour, but by forgiving what each man hath sinned against thee, thou gainest free pardon for thine own sins also.

[112:27] He who is unwilling to give to the poor, seeketh riches; listen to what is written, "Thou shalt have treasure in heaven".

[112:28] Thou wilt not then lose honour by forgiving: for it is a very laudable triumph to conquer anger: wilt not grow poor by giving; for a heavenly treasure is a more safe possession.

[112:29] The former verse, "Riches and plenteousness shall be in his house," was pregnant with this verse.

[112:30] He therefore who doth these things, "shall guide his words with discretion".

[112:31] His deeds themselves are the words whereby he shall be defended at the Judgment; which shall not be without mercy unto him, since he hath himself shown mercy.

[112:32] "For he shall never be moved" : he who, called to the right hand, shall hear these words, "Come, ye blessed of My Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world".

[112:33] For no works of theirs, save works of mercy, are there mentioned.

[112:34] He therefore shall hear, "Come, ye blessed of My Father;" for, "the generation of the right ones shall be blessed".

[112:35] Thus, "the righteous shall be had in everlasting remembrance".

[112:36] "He will not be afraid of any evil hearing; for his heart standeth fast and believeth in the Lord".

[112:37] Such as the words which he will hear addressed to those on the left hand, "Depart into everlasting fire, prepared for the devil and his angels".

[112:38] He therefore who seeketh here not his own things, but those of Jesus Christ, most patiently endureth sufferings, waiteth for the promises with faith.

[112:39] Nor is he broken down by any temptations: "His heart is established, and will not shrink, until he see beyond his enemies".

[112:40] His enemies wished to see good things here, and when invisible blessings were promised them, used to say, "Who will show us any good?" Let our heart therefore be established, and shrink not, until we see beyond our enemies.

[112:41] For they wish to see good things of men in the land of the dying; we trust to see the good things of the Lord in the land of the living.

[112:42] But it is a great thing to have the heart established, and not to be moved, while they rejoice who love what they see, and mock at him who hopeth for what he seeth not; "what the Lord hath prepared for them that love Him".

[112:43] How great is the value of this which is not seen, and it is bought for so much as each man is able to give for it.

[112:44] On this account he also "dispersed abroad, and gave to the poor" : he saw not, yet he kept buying; but He was storing up the treasure in heaven, who deigned to hunger and thirst in the poor on earth.

[112:45] It is no wonder then if "his righteousness remaineth for ever:" He who created the ages being his guardian.

[112:46] "His horn," whose humility was scorned by the proud, "shall be exalted with honour".

[112:47] "The ungodly shall see it, and he shall be angered" : this is that late and fruitless repentance.

[112:48] For with whom rather than himself is he "angered," when he shall say, "Our pride, what hath it profited us? the boastfulness of our riches, what hath it given us?" seeing the horn of him exalted with honour, who "dispersed abroad, and gave to the poor".

[112:49] "He shall gnash with his teeth, and consume away:" for "there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth".

[112:50] For he will no more bring forth leaves and bloom, as would happen if he had repented in season: but he will then repent, when "the desire of the ungodly shall perish," no consolation succeeding.

[112:51] "The desire of the ungodly shall perish," when "all things shall pass away like a shadow," when the flower shall fall down on the withering of the grass.

[112:52] "But the word of the Lord that endureth for ever," as it is mocked by the vanity of the falsely happy, so will laugh at the perdition of the same when truly miserable.

[113:1] Psalm CXIII.

[113:2] When ye hear sung in the Psalms, "Praise the Lord, ye children" ; imagine not that that exhortation pertaineth not unto you, because having already passed the youth of the body, ye are either blooming in the prime of manhood, or growing gray with the honours of old age: for unto all of you the Apostle saith, "Brethren, be not children in understanding; howbeit, in malice be ye children, but in understanding be men".

[113:3] What malice in particular, save pride? For it is pride that, presuming in false greatness, suffereth not man to walk along the narrow path, and to enter by the narrow gate; but the child easily entereth through the narrow entrance; and thus no man, save as a child, entereth into the kingdom of heaven.

[113:4] "Praise the Name of the Lord".

[113:5] Let Him therefore be alway proclaimed: "Blessed be the Name of the Lord, from this time forth for evermore".

[113:6] Let Him be proclaimed everywhere: "From the rising up of the sun unto the going down of the same, praise ye the Name of the Lord".
