[128:18] He seemeth to speak perversely to those who understand not: for he should have said, thou shalt eat the fruit of thy labours.

[128:19] For many eat the fruit of their labours.

[128:20] They labour in the vineyard; they eat not the toil itself; but what ariseth from their labour they eat.

[128:21] They labour about trees that bear fruit: who would eat labours? But the fruit of these labours, the produce of these trees; it is this that delighteth the husbandman.

[128:22] What meaneth, "Thou shalt eat the labours of thy fruits"? At present we have toils: the fruits will come afterwards.

[128:23] But since their labours themselves are not without joy, on account of the hope whereof we have a little before spoken, "Rejoicing in hope, patient in tribulation;"  at present those very labours delight us, and make us joyful in hope.

[128:24] If therefore our toil has been what could be eaten, and could also delight us; what will be the fruit of our labour when eaten? "They who went weeping on their way, scattering their seed," did eat their labours; with how much greater pleasure will they eat the fruits of their labours, who "shall come again with joy, bearing their sheaves with them"?"Blessed art thou, and well shall it be with thee".

[128:25] "Blessed art thou," is of the present: "well shall it be with thee," is of the future.

[128:26] When thou eatest the labours of thy fruits, "blessed art thou;" when thou hast reached the fruit of thy labours, "well shall it be with thee".

[128:27] What hath he said? For if it be well with thee, thou wilt be happy: and if thou wilt be happy, thou wilt also have all well with thee.

[128:28] But there is a difference between hope and attainment.

[128:29] If hope be so sweet, how much sweeter will reality be?.

[128:30] Let us now come to the words, "Thy wife" : it is said unto Christ.

[128:31] His wife, therefore, is the Church: His Church, His wife, we ourselves are.

[128:32] "As a fruitful vineyard".

[128:33] But in whom is the vineyard fruitful? For we see many barren ones entering those walls; we see that many intemperate, usurious persons, slave dealers, enter these walls, and such as resort to fortune-tellers, go to enchanters and enchantresses when they have a headache.

[128:34] Is this the fruitfulness of the vine? Is this the fecundity of the wife? It is not.

[128:35] These are thorns, but the vineyard is not everywhere thorny.

[128:36] It hath a certain fruitfulness, and is a fruitful vine; but in whom? "Upon the sides of thy house".

[128:37] Not all are called the sides of the house.

[128:38] For I ask what are the sides.

[128:39] What shall I say? Are they walls, strong stones, as it were? If he were speaking of this bodily tenement, we should perhaps understand this by sides.

[128:40] We mean by the sides of the house, those who cling unto Christ.

[128:41] "Thy children".

[128:42] The wife and the children are the same.

[128:43] In these carnal marriages and wedlocks, the wife is one, the children other: in the Church, she who is the wife, is the children also.

[128:44] For the Apostles belonged to the Church, and were among the members of the Church.

[128:45] They were therefore in His wife, and were His wife according to their own portion which they held in His members.

[128:46] Why then is it said concerning them, "When the Bridegroom shall be taken from them, then shall the children of the Bridegroom fast"? She who is the wife, then, is the children also.

[128:47] I speak a wonderful thing, my brethren.

[128:48] In the words of the Lord, we find the Church to be both His brethren, and His sisters, and His motherFor Mary was among the sides of His House, and His relatives coming of the kindred of the Virgin Mary, who believed on Him, were among the sides of His House; not in respect of their carnal consanguinity, but inasmuch as they heard the Word of God, and obeyed it.

[128:49] He added; "For whosoever shall do the will of My Father which is in heaven, the same is My brother, and sister, and mother".

[128:50] "Brother," perhaps, on account of the male sex whom the Church hath: "sister," on account of the women whom Christ hath here in His members.

[128:51] How "mother," save that Christ Himself is in those Christians, whom the Church daily bringeth forth Christians through baptism? In those therefore in whom thou understandest the wife, in them thou understandest the mother, in them the children.

[128:52] Such children ought therefore to be "around" the Lord's "table, like olive-branches".

[128:53] A complete Vine it is, a great bliss: who would now refuse to be there? When thou seest any blasphemer have a wife, children, grandchildren, and thyself perchance without them, envy them not; discern that the promise hath been fulfilled in thee also, but spiritually.

[128:54] If therefore we have, why have we? Because we fear the Lord.

[128:55] "Lo, thus shall the man be blessed that feareth the Lord".

[128:56] He is the man, who is also the men; and the men are one man; because many are one, because Christ is One.

[128:57] "The Lord from out of Sion bless thee: and mayest thou see thee good things that are of Jerusalem".

[128:58] Even to the birds was it said, "Be fruitful and multiply".

[128:59] Dost thou wish to hold as a great blessing what was given unto birds? Who can be ignorant, that it was given indeed by the voice of God? But use these goods, if thou receive them; and rather think how thou mayest nourish those who have been born, than that others may be born.

[128:60] For it is not happiness to have children, but to have good ones.

[128:61] Labour in the task of nourishing them, if they be born; but if they be not born, give thanks unto God.

[128:62] Thy children are infants: thou dost caress the infants: the infants caress thee: do they abide thus? But thou wishest they may grow, thou wishest that their age may increase.

[128:63] But consider that when one age cometh, another dieth.

[128:64] When boyhood cometh, infancy dieth; when youth cometh, boyhood dieth: when manhood cometh, youth dieth; when old age cometh, manhood dieth: when death cometh, all age dieth.

[128:65] As many successions of ages as thou wishest for, so many deaths of ages dost thou wish for.

[128:66] These things therefore "are" not.

[128:67] Finally, are children born unto thee to share life with thee on earth, or rather to shut thee out and to succeed thee? Rejoicest thou in those born to exclude thee? Boys when born speak somewhat like this to their parents: "Now then, begin to think of removing hence, let us too play our parts on the stage".

[128:68] For the whole life of temptation in the human race is a stage play; for it is said, "Every man living is altogether vanity".

[128:69] Nevertheless, if we rejoice in children who will succeed us; how much must we rejoice in children with whom we shall remain, and in that Father for whom we are born, who will not die, but that we may evermore live with Him? These are the good things of Jerusalem: for they "are".

[128:70] And how long shall I see the good things of Jerusalem? "All thy life long".

[128:71] If thy life be for ever, thou wilt see the good things of Jerusalem for evermore.

[128:72] For, "if in this life only," saith the Apostle, "we have hope in Christ, we are of all men most miserable".

[128:73] For what reason were the Martyrs condemned to beasts? What is that good? Can it be declared? by what means, or what tongue can tell it? or what ears can hear it? That indeed, "Neither ear hath heard, nor hath it entered into man's heart:" only let us love, only let us grow in grace: ye see, then, that battles are not wanting, and that we fight with our lusts.

[128:74] We fight outwardly with unbelieving and disobedient men; we fight inwardly with carnal suggestions and perturbations: we everywhere as yet fight.

[128:75] What sort of peace then is this? One from Jerusalem, for Jerusalem is interpreted, A vision of Peace.

[128:76] Thus then "mayest thou see the good things that are of Jerusalem," and that, "all thy life long—and mayest thou see," not only thy children, but, "thy children's children".

[128:77] What meaneth, Thy children? Thy works which thou here dost.

[128:78] Who are thy children's children? The fruits of thy works.

[128:79] Thou givest alms: these are thy children: for the sake of thine alms thou receivest everlasting life, these are thy children's children.

[128:80] "Mayest thou see thy children's children;" and there shall be "peace upon Israel" , the last words of the Psalm.

[129:1] Psalm CXXIX.

[129:2] The Psalm which we have sung is short: but as it is written in the Gospel of Zacchaeus that he was "little of stature," but mighty in works; as it is written of that widow who cast two mites into the treasury, little was the money, but great was her charity; thus also this Psalm, if thou count the words, is short; if thou weigh the sentiments, is great.

[129:3] Let the Spirit of God speak, let It speak to us, let It sing to us; whether we wish or wish not to dance, let It sing.

[129:4] For as he who danceth, moveth his limbs to the time; so they who dance according to the commandment of God, in their works obey the sound.

[129:5] What therefore saith the Lord in the Gospel to those who refuse to do this? "We have piped unto you, and ye have not danced: we have mourned unto you, and ye have not lamented".

[129:6] Let Him therefore sing; we trust in God's mercy, for there will be those by whom He consoleth us.

[129:7] For they who are obstinate, continuing in wickedness, al though they hear the Word of God, by their offences daily disturb the Church.

[129:8] Of such this Psalm speaketh; for thus it beginneth.

[129:9] "Many a time have they fought against me from my youth up".

[129:10] The Church speaketh of those whom She endureth: and as if it were asked, "Is it now?" The Church is of ancient birth: since saints have been so called, the Church hath been on earth.

[129:11] At one time the Church was in Abel only, and he was fought against by his wicked and lost brother Cain At one time the Church was in Enoch alone: and he was translated from the unrighteous At one time the Church was in the house of Noah alone, and endured all who perished by the flood, and the ark alone swam upon the waves, and escaped to shore At one time the Church was in Abraham alone, and we know what he endured from the wicked.

[129:12] The Church was in his brother's son, Lot, alone, and in his house, in Sodom, and he endured the iniquities and perversities of Sodom, until God freed him from amidst them The Church also began to exist in the people of Israel: She endured Pharaoh and the Egyptians.

[129:13] The number of the saints began to be also in the Church, that is, in the people of Israel; Moses and the rest of the saints endured the wicked Jews, the people of Israel.

[129:14] We come unto our Lord Jesus Christ: the Gospel was preached in the PsalmsFor this reason, lest the Church wonder now, or lest any one wonder in the Church, who wisheth to be a good member of the Church, let him hear the Church herself his Mother saying to him, Marvel not at these things, my son: "Many a time have they fought against me from my youth up".

[129:15] "Now may Israel say".

[129:16] She now seemeth to be speaking of herself: for she seemed not to have commenced herself, but to have answered.

[129:17] But to whom hath she replied? To them that think and say, How great evils do we endure, how great are the scandals that every day thicken, as the wicked enter into the Church, and we have to endure them? But let the Church reply through some, that is, through the voice of the stronger, let her reply to the complaints of the weak, and let the stable confirm the unstable, and the full-grown the infant, and let the Church say, "Many a time have they vexed me from my youth up".

[129:18] Let the Church say this: let her not fear it.

[129:19] For what is the meaning of this addition, "From my youth up," after the words, "Many a time have they fought against me"? At present the old age of the Church is assailed: but let her not fear.

[129:20] Hath she then failed to arrive at old age, because they have not ceased to fight against her from her youth up? have they been able to blot her out? Let Israel comfort herself, let the Church console herself with past examples.

[129:21] Why have they fought against me? "For they could not prevail against me".

[129:22] "Upon my back have sinners built; they have done their iniquity afar off".

[129:23] Why have they fought against me? Because "they could not prevail upon me".

[129:24] What is this? They could not build upon me.

[129:25] I consented not with them unto sin.

[129:26] For every wicked man persecuteth the good on this account, because the good man consenteth not with him to evil.

[129:27] Suppose he do some evil, and the Bishop censure him not, the Bishop is a good man: suppose the Bishop censure him, the Bishop is a bad man.

[129:28] Suppose he carry off anything, let the man robbed be silent, he is a good man: let him only speak and rebuke, even though he doth not reclaim his goods, he is everything bad.

[129:29] He is bad then who blameth the robber, and he is good who robbeth!Heed not that such an one speaketh to thee: it is a wicked man through whom It speaketh to thee; but the word of God, that speaketh to thee, is not wicked.

[129:30] Accuse God: accuse Him, if thou canst!.

[129:31] Thou accusest a man of avarice, and he accuseth God on the ground that He made gold.

[129:32] Be not covetous.

[129:33] And God, thou repliest, should not make gold.

[129:34] This now remaineth, because thou canst not restrain thine evil deeds, thou accusest the good works of God: the Creator and Architect of the world displeaseth thee.

[129:35] He ought not to make the sun either; for many contend concerning the lights of their windows, and drag each other before courts of law.

[129:36] O if we could restrain our vices! for all things are good, because a good God made all things: and His works praise Him, when their goodness is considered by him who hath the spirit of considering them, the spirit of piety and wisdom.

[129:37] Lend not money at interest.

[129:38] Thou accusest Scripture which saith, "He that hath not given his money upon usury".

[129:39] I wrote not this: it went not forth first from my mouth: hear God.

[129:40] He replieth: let not the clergy lend upon usury.

[129:41] Perchance he who speaketh to thee, lendeth not at interest: but if he do so lend, suppose that he doth so lend; doth He who speaketh through him lend at interest? If he doth what he enjoineth thee, and thou dost it not; thou wilt go into the flame, he into the kingdom.

[129:42] If he doth not what he enjoineth thee, and equally with thee doth evil deeds, and preaches duties which he doth not; ye will both equally go into the flames.

[129:43] The hay will burn; but "the word of the Lord abideth for evermore".

[129:44] "The righteous Lord shall hew the necks of the sinners".

[129:45] Which of us doth not fix his eyes upon the earth, like the Publican, and say, "Lord, be merciful unto me a sinner"? If therefore all are sinners, and none is found without sin; all must fear the sword that hangs above their neck, because "the righteous Lord shall hew the necks of the sinners".

[129:46] I do not imagine, my brethren, of all sinners; but in the member which He striketh, He marks what sinners He striketh.

[129:47] For it is not said, The righteous Lord will hew the hands of the sinners; or their feet; but because proud sinners were meant to be understood, and all proud men carry lofty necks, and not only do evil deeds, but even refuse to acknowledge them to be such, and when they are rebuked, justify themselves:as it is written in Job (he was speaking of an ungodly sinner), "he runneth against God, even upon his neck, upon the thick bosses of his bucklers;" so he here nameth the neck, because it is thus thou exaltest thyself, and dost not fix thine eyes upon the ground, and beat thy breast.

[129:48] Thou shouldest cry unto Him, as it is cried in another Psalm, "I said, Lord, be merciful unto me, for I have sinned against Thee".

[129:49] Since thou dost not choose to say this, but justifiest thy deeds against the Word of God; what followeth in Scripture cometh upon thee: the righteous Lord shall hew the necks of sinners.

[129:50] "Let them be confounded and turned backward, as many as have evil will at Sion".

[129:51] They who hate Sion, hate the Church: Sion is the Church.

[129:52] And they who hypocritically enter into the Church, hate the Church.

[129:53] They who refuse to keep the Word of God, hate the Church: "Upon my back have they built:" what will the Church do, save endure the burden even unto the end?.

[129:54] But what saith he of them? The next words are, "Let them be even as the grass of the house tops: that withereth before it be plucked up".

[129:55] The grass of the house tops is that which groweth on house tops, on a tiled roof: it is seen on high, and hath not a root.

[129:56] How much better would it be if it grew lower, and how much more joyfully would it bloom? As it is, it riseth higher to a quicker withering.

[129:57] It hath not yet been plucked up, yet hath it withered: not yet have they received sentence from the judgment of God, and already they have not the sap of bloom.

[129:58] Observe their works, and see that they have withered.

[129:59] The reapers will come, but they fill not their sheaves from these.

[129:60] For the reapers will come, and will gather the wheat into the barn, and will bind the tares together, and cast them into the fire.

[129:61] Thus also is the grass of the house tops cleared off, and whatever is plucked from it, is thrown into the fire; because it had withered even before it was plucked up.

[129:62] The reaper filleth not his hands thence.

[129:63] His next words are, "Whereof the reaper filleth not his hand; neither he that bindeth up the sheaves his bosom".

[129:64] And, "the reapers are the angels," the Lord saith.

[129:65] "So that they who go by say not so much as, The blessing of the Lord be upon you: we have blessed you in the name of the Lord".

[129:66] For ye know, brethren, when men pass by others at work, it is customary to address them, "The blessing of the Lord be upon you".

[129:67] And this was especially the custom in the Jewish nation.

[129:68] No one passed by and saw any one doing any work in the field, or in the vineyard, or in harvest, or anything of the sort; it was not lawful to pass by without a blessing.

[129:69] Who are the passers by? They who have already passed hence to their country through this road, that is, through this life: the Apostles were passers by in this life, the Prophets were passers by.

[129:70] Whom did the Prophets and Apostles bless? Those in whom they saw the root of charity? But those whom they found lifted on high on their house tops, and proud in the bosses of their bucklers, they declared against these what they were doomed to become, but they gave them no blessing.

[129:71] Ye therefore who read in the Scriptures, find all those wicked men whom the Church beareth, who are declared cursed, pertain unto Antichrist, pertain unto the devil, pertain to the chaff, pertain to the tares.

[129:72] But they who say, None save God sanctifieth, nor is any man good save by the gift of God; they bless in the name of the Lord, not in their own name: because they are the friends of the bridegroom, they refuse to be adulterers of the bride.

[130:1] Psalm CXXX.

[130:2] "Out of the deep have I called unto Thee, O Lord: Lord, hear my voice".

[130:3] Jonas cried from the deep; from the whale's belly He was not only beneath the waves, but also in the entrails of the beast; nevertheless, those waves and that body prevented not his prayer from reaching God, and the beast's belly could not contain the voice of his prayer.

[130:4] It penetrated all things, it burst through all things, it reached the ears of God: if indeed we ought to say that, bursting through all things, it reached the ears of God, since the ears of God were in the heart of him who prayed.

[130:5] For where hath not he God present, whose voice is faithful? Nevertheless, we also ought to understand from what deep we cry unto the Lord.

[130:6] For this mortal life is our deep.

[130:7] Whoever hath understood himself to be in the deep, crieth out, groaneth, sigheth, until he be delivered from the deep, and come unto Him who sitteth above all the deeps.

[130:8] For they are very deep in the deep, who do not even cry from the deep.

[130:9] The Scripture saith, "When the wicked hath reached the depth of evils, he despiseth".

[130:10] Now consider, brethren, what sort of deep that is, where God is despised.

[130:11] When each man seeth himself overwhelmed with daily sins, pressed down by heaps and weights, so to speak, of iniquities: if it be said unto him, Pray unto God, he laughs.

[130:12] In what manner? He first saith, If crimes were displeasing unto God, should I live? If God regarded human affairs, considering the great crimes which I have committed, should I not only live, but be prosperous? For this is wont to happen to those who are far in the deep, and are prosperous in their iniquities: and they are the more plunged in the deep, in proportion as they seem to be more happy; for a deceitful happiness is itself a greater unhappiness.

[130:13] "Lord, hear my voice.

[130:14] O let Thine ears consider well the voice of my complaint".

[130:15] Whence doth he cry? From the deep.

[130:16] Who is it then who crieth? A sinner.

[130:17] And with what hope doth he cry? Because He who came to absolve from sins, gave hope even to the sinner down in the deep.

[130:18] What therefore followeth after these words: "If Thou, Lord, wilt be extreme to mark what is amiss, O Lord, who may abide it?".

[130:19] So, he hath disclosed from what deep he cried out.

[130:20] For he crieth beneath the weights and billows of his iniquities.

[130:21] He said not, I may not abide it: but, "who may abide it?" For he saw that nigh the whole of human life on every side was ever bayed at by its sins, that all consciences were accused by their thoughts, that a clean heart trusting in its own righteousness could not be found.

[130:22] But wherefore is there hope? "For there is propitiation with Thee".

[130:23] And what is this propitiation, except sacrifice? And what is sacrifice, save that which hath been offered for us? The pouring forth of innocent blood blotted out all the sins of the guilty: so great a price paid down redeemed all captives from the hand of the enemy who captured them.

[130:24] "With Thee," then, "there is propitiation".

[130:25] For if there were not mercy with Thee, if Thou chosest to be Judge only, and didst refuse to be merciful, Thou wouldest mark all our iniquities, and search after them.

[130:26] Who could abide this? Who could stand before Thee, and say, I am innocent? Who could stand in Thy judgment? There is therefore one hope: "for the sake of Thy law have I borne Thee, O Lord".

[130:27] What law? That which made men guilty.

[130:28] For a "law, holy, just, and good,"  was given to the Jews; but its effect was to make them guilty.

[130:29] A law was not given that could give life, but which might show his sins to the sinner.

[130:30] For the sinner had forgotten himself, and saw not himself; the law was given him, that he might see himself.

[130:31] The law made him guilty, the Lawgiver freed him: for the Lawgiver is the Supreme PowerThere is therefore a law of the mercy of God, a law of the propitiation of God The one was a law of fear, the other is a law of love.

[130:32] The law of love giveth forgiveness to sins, blotteth out the past, warneth concerning the future; forsaketh not its companion by the way, becometh a companion to him whom it leadeth on the way.

[130:33] But it is needful to agree with the adversary, whilst thou art with him in the way For the Word of God is thine adversary, as long as thou dost not agree with it.

[130:34] But thou agreest, when it has begun to be thy delight to do what God's Word commandeth.

[130:35] Then he who was thine adversary becometh thy friend: so, when the way is finished, there will be none to deliver thee to the Judge.

[130:36] Therefore, "For the sake of Thy law I have waited for Thee, O Lord," because thou hast condescended to bring in a law of mercy, to forgive me all my sins, to give me for the future warnings that I may not offend.

[130:37] "For the sake," therefore, "of" this "law I have waited for Thee, O Lord".

[130:38] I have waited until Thou mayest come and free me from all need, for in my very need Thou hast not forsaken the law of mercy.

[130:39] "My soul hath waited for Thy word".

[130:40] We therefore trust without fear on the word of Him who cannot deceive.

[130:41] "My soul hath trusted in the Lord, from the morning watch even unto night".

[130:42] This morning watch is the end of night.

[130:43] We must therefore understand it so that we may not suppose we are to trust in the Lord for one day only.

[130:44] What do you conceive to be the sense, then, brethren? The words mean this: that the Lord, through whom our sins have been remitted, arose from the dead at the morning watch, so that we may hope that what went before in the Lord will take place in us.

[130:45] For our sins have been already forgiven: but we have not yet risen again: if we have not risen again, not as yet hath that taken place in us which went before in our Head.

[130:46] What went before in our Head? Because the flesh of that Head rose again; did the Spirit of that Head die? What had died in Him, rose again.

[130:47] Now He arose on the third day; and the Lord as it were thus speaketh to us: What ye have seen in Me, hope for in yourselves; that is, because I have risen from the dead, ye also shall rise again.

[130:48] But there are who say, Behold, the Lord hath risen again; but must I hope on that account that I also may rise again? Certainly, on that account: for the Lord rose again in that which He assumed from thee.

[130:49] For He would not rise again, save He had died; and He could not have died, except He bore the flesh.

[130:50] What did the Lord assume from thee? The flesh.

[130:51] What was He that came Himself? The Word of God, who was before all things, through whom all things were made.

[130:52] But that He might receive something from thee, "The Word became flesh, and dwelt among us".

[130:53] He received from thee, what He might offer for thee; as the priest receiveth from thee, what he may offer for thee, when thou wishest to appease God for thy sins.

[130:54] It hath already been done, it hath been done thus.

[130:55] Our Priest received from us what He might offer for us: for He received flesh from us, in the flesh itself He was made a victim, He was made a holocaust, He was made a sacrifice.

[130:56] In the Passion He was made a sacrifice; in the Resurrection He renewed that which was slain, and offered it as His first-fruits unto God, and saith unto thee, All that is thine is now consecrated: since such first-fruits have been offered unto God from thee; hope therefore that that will take place in thyself which went before in thy first-fruits.

[130:57] Since He then rose with the morning watch, our soul began to hope from hence: and how far? "Even unto night;" until we die; for all our carnal death is as it were sleep.

[130:58] And he returns to this, "From the morning watch let Israel hope in the Lord".

[130:59] Not only "let Israel hope," but "from the morning watch let Israel hope".

[130:60] Do I then blame the hope of the world, when it is placed in the Lord? No; but there is another hope belonging to Israel.

[130:61] Let not Israel hope for riches as his highest good, not for health of body, not for abundance of earthly things: he will indeed have to suffer tribulation here, if it should be his lot to suffer any troubles for the sake of the truth.

[130:62] "For with the Lord there is mercy, and with Him is plenteous redemption".

[130:63] Admirable! This could not have been better said in its own place, on account of the words, "From the morning watch".

[130:64] Wherefore? Because the Lord rose again from the morning watch; and the body ought to hope for that which went before in the Head.

[130:65] But, lest this thought should be suggested: The Head might rise again, because It was not weighed down with sins, there was no sin in Him; what shall we do? Shall we hope for such a resurrection, as went before in the Lord, whilst we are weighed down by our sins? But see what followeth: "And He shall redeem Israel from all his sins".

[130:66] Though therefore he was weighed down with his sins, the mercy of God is present to him.

[130:67] For this reason, He went before without sin, that He may blot out the sins of those that follow Him.

[130:68] Trust not in yourselves, but trust from the morning watch.

[131:1] Psalm CXXXI.

[131:2] In this Psalm, the humility of one that is a servant of God and faithful is commended unto us, by whose voice it is sung; which is the whole body of Christ For we have often warned you, beloved, that it ought not to be received as the voice of one man singing, but of all who are in Christ's Body.

[131:3] And since all are in His Body, as it were one man speaketh: and he is one who also is many.

[131:4] Now he prayeth in the temple of God, who prayeth in the peace of the Church, in the unity of Christ's Body; which Body of Christ consisteth of many who believe in the whole world: and therefore he who prayeth in the temple, is heard.

[131:5] For he prayeth in the spirit and in truth, who prayeth in the peace of the Church; not in that temple, wherein was the figure.

[131:6] "Lord, my heart is not lifted up".

[131:7] He hath offered a sacrifice.

[131:8] Whence do we prove that he hath offered a sacrifice? Because humility of heart is a sacrifice.

[131:9] If there is no sacrifice, there is no Priest.

[131:10] But if we have a High Priest in Heaven, who intercedeth with the Father for us (for He hath entered into the Holy of Holies, within the veil),we are safe, for we have a Priest; let us offer our sacrifice there.

[131:11] Let us consider what sacrifice we ought to offer; for God is not pleased with burnt-offerings, as ye have heard in the Psalm.

[131:12] But in that place he next showeth what he offereth: "The sacrifice of God is a troubled spirit: a broken and a contrite heart, O God, shalt Thou not despise.

[131:13] "Lord, my heart was not lifted up, neither were mine eyes raised on high" ; "I have not exercised myself in great matters, nor in wonderful things which are too high for me".

[131:14] Let this be more plainly spoken and heard.

[131:15] I have not been proud: I have not wished to be known among men as for wondrous powers; nor have I sought anything beyond my strength, whereby I might boast myself among the ignorant.

[131:16] As that Simon the sorcerer wished to advance into wonders above himself, on that account the power of the Apostles more pleased him, than the righteousness of Christians.

[131:17] What is above my strength, he saith, I have not sought; I have not stretched myself out there, I have not chosen to be magnified there.

[131:18] How deeply this self-exaltation in the abundance of graces is to be feared, that no man may pride himself in the gift of God, but may rather preserve humility, and may do what is written: "The greater thou art, the more humble thyself, and thou shalt find favour before the Lord:" how deeply pride in God's gift should be feared, we must again and again impress upon you.

[131:19] "If I had not lowly thoughts, but have lifted up my soul, as one taken from his mother's breast, such the reward for my soul".

[131:20] He seemeth as it were to have bound himself by a curse:as though he had been going to say, Let it so happen to me.

[131:21] "As one taken away from his mother's breast, may be my soul's reward".

[131:22] Ye know that the Apostle saith to some weak brethren, "I have fed you with milk, and not with meat; for hitherto ye were not able to bear it, neither yet now are ye able".

[131:23] There are weak persons who are not fit for strong meat; they wish to grasp at that which they cannot receive: and if they ever do receive, or seem to themselves to receive what they have not received, they are puffed up thereby, and become proud thereupon; they seem to themselves wise men.

[131:24] Now this happeneth to all heretics; who since they were animal and carnal, by defending their depraved opinions, which they could not see to be false, were shut out of the Catholic Church.

[131:25] Another opinion indeed hath been entertained, and another sense in these words.

[131:26] It has been evidently explained, my brethren, where God would have us to be humble, where lofty.

[131:27] Humble, in order to provide against pride; lofty, to take in wisdom.

[131:28] Feed upon milk, that thou mayest be nourished; be nourished, so that thou mayest grow; grow, so that thou mayest eat bread.

[131:29] But when thou hast begun to eat bread, thou wilt be weaned, that is, thou wilt no longer have need of milk, but of solid food.

[131:30] This he seemeth to have meant: "If I had not lowly thoughts, but have lifted up my soul:" that is, if I was not an infant in mind, I was in wickedness.

[131:31] In this sense, he said before, "Lord, my heart was not lifted up, nor mine eyes raised on high: I do not exercise myself in great matters, nor in wonderful things above me".

[131:32] Behold, in wickedness I am an infant.

[131:33] But since I am not an infant in understanding, "If I had not lowly thoughts, but have lifted up my soul," may that reward be mine which is given unto the infant that is weaned from his mother, that I may at length be able to eat bread.

[131:34] This interpretation, also, brethren, displeaseth me not, since it doth not militate against the faith.

[131:35] Yet I cannot but remark that it is not only said, "As one taken away from milk, such may be my soul's reward;" but with this addition, "As one taken away from milk when upon his mother's breast, such may be my soul's reward".

[131:36] Here there is somewhat that induces me to consider it a curse.

[131:37] For it is not an infant, but a grown child that is taken away from milk; he who is weak in his earliest infancy, which is his true infancy, is upon his mother's breast: if perchance he hath been taken away from the milk, he perisheth.

[131:38] It is not without a reason then that it is added, "Upon his mother's breast".

[131:39] For all may be weaned by growing.

[131:40] He who groweth, and is thus taken away from milk, it is good for him; but hurtful for him who is still upon his mother's breast.

[131:41] We must therefore beware, my brethren, and be fearful, lest any one be taken away from milk before his time.

[131:42] Let him not therefore wish to lift up his soul, when perchance he is not fit to take meat, but let him fulfil the commandments of humility.

[131:43] He hath wherein he may exercise himself: let him believe in Christ, that he may understand Christ.

[131:44] He cannot see the Word, he cannot understand the equality of the Word with the Father, he cannot as yet see the equality of the Holy Spirit with the Father and the Word; let him believe this, and suck it.

[131:45] He is safe, because, when he hath grown, he will eat, which he could not do before he grew by sucking: and he hath a point to stretch towards.

[131:46] Seek not out the things that are too hard for thee, and search not the things that are above thy strength; that is, things which thou art not as yet fit to understand.

[131:47] And what am I to do? thou repliest.

[131:48] Shall I remain thus? "But what things the Lord hath commanded thee, think thereupon always".

[131:49] What hath the Lord commanded thee? Do works of mercy, part not with the peace of the Church, place not thy trust in man, tempt not God by longing for miracles.

[131:50] For if ye be not exalted, if ye raise not your heart on high, if ye tread not in great matters that are too high for you, but preserve humility, God will reveal unto you what ye are otherwise minded in But if ye choose to defend this very thing, which ye are otherwise minded about, and with pertinacity assert it, and against the peace of the Church; this curse which he hath described is entailed upon you; when ye are upon your mother's breast, and are removed away from the milk, ye shall die of hunger apart from your mother's breast.

[131:51] But if ye continue in Catholic peace, if perchance ye are in anything otherwise minded than ye ought to be, God will reveal it to you, if ye be humble.

[131:52] Wherefore? Because "God resisteth the proud, and giveth grace unto the humble".

[131:53] This Psalm therefore concludeth to this purpose: "O Israel, trust in the Lord, from this time forth and even unto eternity".

[131:54] But the word seculum doth not always mean this world, but sometimes eternity; since eternity is understood in two ways; until eternity, that is, either evermore without end, or until we arrive at eternity.

[131:55] How then is it to be understood here? Until we arrive at eternity, let us trust in the Lord God; because when we have reached eternity, there will be no longer hope, but the thing itself will be ours.

[132:1] Psalm CXXXII.

[132:2] It was right indeed, most beloved, that we should rather hear our Brother, my colleague, when present before all of us.

[132:3] And just now he refused not, but put us off; for he extorted from me that he might now listen to me, on the condition that I also may listen to him, for in charity itself we are all listening unto Him, who is our One Master in heaven.

[132:4] Attend therefore to the Psalm, entitled A Song of Degrees; considerably longer than the rest under the same title.

[132:5] Let us not therefore linger, save where necessity shall compel us: that we may, if the Lord permit, explain the whole.

[132:6] For ye also ought not to hear everything as men untaught; ye ought in some degree to aid us from your past listenings, so that it may not be needful that everything should be declared to you as though new.

[132:7] "Lord, remember David, and all his meekness".

[132:8] David according to the truth of history was one man, king of Israel, son of Jesse.

[132:9] He was indeed meek, as the Divine Scriptures themselves mark and command him, and so meek that he did not even render evil for evil to his persecutor Saul.

[132:10] He preserved towards him so great humility, that he acknowledged him a king, and himself a dog: and answered the king not proudly nor rudely, though he was more powerful in God; but he rather endeavoured to appease him by humility, than to provoke him by pride.

[132:11] Saul was even given into his power, and this by the Lord God, that he might do to him what he listed: but since he was not commanded to slay him, but had it only placed in his power (now a man is permitted to use his power), he rather turned towards mercy what God gave him.

[132:12] The humility of David is therefore commended, the meekness of David is commended; and it is said to God, "Lord, remember David, and all his meekness".

[132:13] For what purpose? "How he sware unto the Lord, and vowed a vow unto the Almighty God of Jacob".

[132:14] Therefore remember for this, that he may fulfil what he hath promised.

[132:15] David himself vowed as though he had it in his power, and he prayeth God to fulfil his vow: there is devotion in the vow, but there is humility in the prayer.

[132:16] Let no one presume to think he fulfilled by his own strength what he hath vowed.

[132:17] He who exhorteth thee to vow, Himself aideth thee to fulfil.

[132:18] Let us therefore see what he vowed, and hence we comprehend how David should be understood in a figure.

[132:19] "David" is interpreted, "Strong of hand," for he was a great warrior.

[132:20] Trusting indeed in the Lord his God, he despatched all wars, he laid low all his enemies, God helping him, according to the dispensation of that kingdom; prefiguring nevertheless some One strong of hand to destroy His enemies, the devil and his angels.

[132:21] These enemies the Church warreth against, and conquereth.

[132:22] What then doth he mean, "How he sware," etc.

[132:23] ? Let us see what vow is this.

[132:24] We can offer God nothing more pleasing than to swear Now to swear is to promise firmly Consider this vow, that is, with what ardour he vowed what he vowed, with what love, with what longing; nevertheless, he prayeth the Lord to fulfil it in these words, "O Lord, remember David, and all his meekness".

[132:25] In this temper he vowed his vow, and there should be a house of God: "I will not come within the tabernacle of mine house, nor climb up into my bed".

[132:26] "I will not suffer mine eyes to sleep, nor mine eyelids to slumber".

[132:27] This seemeth not enough; he adds, "Neither the temples of my head to take any rest, until I find out a place for the Lord; an habitation for the God of Jacob".

[132:28] Where did he seek a place for the Lord? If he was meek, he sought it in himself.

[132:29] For how is one a place for the Lord? Hear the Prophet: "Upon whom shall My Spirit rest? Even upon him that is poor and of a contrite spirit, and trembleth at My words".

[132:30] Dost thou wish to be a place for the Lord? Be thou poor in spirit, and contrite, and trembling at the word of God, and thou wilt thyself be made what thou seekest.

[132:31] For if what thou seekest be not realized in thyself, what doth it profit thee in another.

[132:32] How many thousands believed, my brethren, when they laid down the price of their possessions at the Apostles' feet! But what saith Scripture of them? Surely they are become a temple of God; not only each respectively a temple of God, but also all a temple of God together.

[132:33] They have therefore become a place for the Lord.

[132:34] And that ye may know that one place is made for the Lord in all, Scripture saith, They were of one heart and one soul toward God.

[132:35] But many, so as not to make a place for the Lord, seek their own things, love their own things, delight in their own power, are greedy for their private interests.

[132:36] Whereas he who wisheth to make a place for the Lord, should rejoice not in his private, but the common good.

[132:37] Let us therefore, brethren, abstain from the possession of private property; or from the love of it, if we may not from its possession; and we make a place for the Lord.

[132:38] It is too much for me, saith some one.

[132:39] But consider who thou art, who art about to make a place for the Lord.

[132:40] If any senator wished to be entertained at your house, I say not senator, the deputy of some great man of this world, and should say, something offends me in thy house; though thou shouldest love it, thou wouldest remove it, nevertheless, lest thou shouldest offend him, whose friendship thou wast courting.

[132:41] And what doth man's friendship profit thee?Desire the friendship of Christ without fear: He wishes to be entertained at thy house; make room for Him.

[132:42] What is, make room for Him? Love not thyself, love Him.

[132:43] If thou love thyself, thou shuttest the door against Him; if thou love Him, thou openest unto Him: and if thou open and He enter, thou shalt not be lost by loving thyself, but shalt find thyself with Him who loveth thee.

[132:44] "Lo, we heard of the same at Ephrata".

[132:45] What? A place for the Lord.

[132:46] "We heard of it at Ephrata: and found it in the plains of the forests".

[132:47] Did he hear it where he found it? or did he hear it in one place, find it in another? Let us therefore enquire what Ephrata is, where he heard it; let us also enquire what mean the plains of the forests, where he found it.

[132:48] Ephrata, a Hebrew word, is rendered in Latin by Speculum, as the translators of Hebrew words in the Scriptures have handed down to us, that we might understand them.

[132:49] They have translated from Hebrew into Greek, and from Greek we have versions into Latin.

[132:50] For there have been who watched in the Scriptures.

[132:51] If therefore Ephrata meaneth a mirror, that house which was found in the woodland plains, was heard of in a mirror.

[132:52] A mirror hath an image: all prophecy is an image of things future.

[132:53] The future house of God, therefore, was declared in the image of prophecy.

[132:54] "We have found it in the plains of the forests".

[132:55] What are the "plains of the forests"? Saltus is not here used in its common sense, as a plot of ground of so many hundred acres; saltus properly signifies a spot as yet untilled and woody.

[132:56] For some copies read, in the plains of the wood.

[132:57] What then were the woodland plains, save nations yet untilled? what were they, save regions yet covered with the thorns of idolatry? Thus, though there were thorns of idolatry there, still we find a place for the Lord there, a tabernacle for the God of Jacob.

[132:58] What was declared in the image to the Jews, was manifested in the faith of the Gentiles.

[132:59] "We will go into His tabernacles".

[132:60] Whose? Those of the Lord God of Jacob.

[132:61] They who enter to dwell therein, are the very same who enter that they may be dwelt in.

[132:62] Thou enterest into thy house, that thou mayest dwell therein; into the house of God, that thou mayest be dwelt in.

[132:63] For the Lord is better, and when He hath begun to dwell in thee, He will make thee happy.

[132:64] For if thou be not dwelt in by Him, thou wilt be miserable.

[132:65] That son who said, "Father, give me the portion of the goods," etc.

[132:66] , wished to be his own master.

[132:67] It was well kept in his father's hands, that it might not be wasted with harlots.

[132:68] He received it, it was given into his own power; going to a far country, he squandered it all with harlots.

[132:69] At length he suffered hunger, he remembered his father; he returned, that he might be satisfied with bread.

[132:70] Enter therefore, that thou mayest be dwelt in; and mayest be not thine own, so to speak, but His: "We will go into His tabernacles.

[132:71] We will worship on the spot where His feet stood".

[132:72] Whose feet? The Lord's, or those of the house of the Lord itself? For that is the Lord's house, wherein he saith He ought to be worshipped.

[132:73] Beside His house, the Lord heareth not unto eternal life; for he belongeth to God's house, who hath in charity been built in with living stones.

[132:74] But he who hath not charity, falleth; and while he falls, the house stands.

[132:75] But if ye incline to understand it of the house itself, where the feet of that house have stood; let thy feet stand in Christ.

[132:76] They will then stand, if thou shalt persevere in Christ.

[132:77] For what is said of the devil? "He was a murderer from the beginning, and stood not in the truth".

[132:78] The feet of the devil therefore stood not.

[132:79] Also what saith he of the proud? "O let not the foot of pride come against me; and let not the hand of the ungodly cast me down.

[132:80] There are they fallen, all that work wickedness: they are cast down, and were not able to stand".

[132:81] That then is the house of God, whose feet stand.

[132:82] Whence John rejoicing, saith: what? "He that hath the bride is the bridegroom: but the friend of the bridegroom standeth and heareth him".

[132:83] If he stand not, he heareth him not.

[132:84] Justly he standeth, because "he rejoiceth on account of the bridegroom's voice".

[132:85] Now therefore ye see why they fell, who rejoice because of their own voice That friend of the Bridegroom said, "The same is He which baptizeth".

[132:86] Some say, We baptize: rejoicing in their own voice, they could not stand; and belong not to that house of which it is said, "where His feet stood".

[132:87] "Arise, O Lord, into Thy resting place".

[132:88] He saith unto the Lord sleeping, "Arise".

[132:89] Ye know already who slept, and who rose again.

[132:90] "Thou, and the ark of Thy sanctification:" that is, Arise, that the ark of Thy sanctification, which Thou hast sanctified, may arise also.

[132:91] He is our Head; His ark is His Church: He arose first, the Church will arise also.

[132:92] The body would not dare to promise itself resurrection, save the Head arose first.

[132:93] The Body of Christ, that was born of Mary, hath been understood by some to be the ark of sanctification; so that the words mean, Arise with Thy Body, that they who believe not may handle.

[132:94] "Let Thy priests be clothed with righteousness, and let Thy saints sing with joyfulness".

[132:95] When Thou risest from the dead, and goest unto Thy Father, let that royal Priesthood be clothed with faith, since "the righteous liveth by faith;" and, receiving the pledge of the Holy Spirit, let the members rejoice in the hope of resurrection, which went before in the Head: for to them the Apostle saith, "Rejoicing in hope".

[132:96] "For Thy servant David's sake, turn not away the face of Thine Anointed".

[132:97] These words are addressed unto God the Father.

[132:98] "For Thy servant David's sake, turn not away the face of Thine Anointed".

[132:99] The Lord was crucified in Judaea; He was crucified by the Jews; harassed by them, He slept.

[132:100] He arose to judge those among whose savage hands He slept: and He saith elsewhere, "Raise Thou Me up again, and I shall reward them".

[132:101] He both hath rewarded them, and will reward them.

[132:102] The Jews well know themselves how great were their sufferings after the Lord's death.

[132:103] They were all expelled from the very city, where they slew Him.

[132:104] What then? have all perished even from the root of David and from the tribe of Judah? No: for some of that stock believed, and in fact many thousands of men of that stock believed, and this after the Lord's resurrection.

[132:105] They raged and crucified Him: and afterwards began to see miracles wrought in the Name of Him Crucified; and they trembled still more that His Name should have so much power, since when in their hands He seemed unable to work any; and pricked at heart, at length believing that there was some hidden divinity in Him whom they had believed like other men, and asking counsel of the Apostles, they were answered, "Repent, and be baptized every one of you in the Name of our Lord Jesus Christ".

[132:106] Since then Christ arose to judge those by whom He had been crucified, and turned away His Presence from the Jews, turning His Presence towards the Gentiles; God is, as it seemeth, besought in behalf of the remnant of Israel; and it is said unto Him, "For Thy servant David's sake, turn not away the presence of Thine Anointed".

[132:107] If the chaff be condemned, let the wheat be gathered together.

[132:108] May the remnant be saved, as Isaiah saith, "And the remnant hath" clearly "been saved:"  for out of them were the twelve Apostles, out of them more than five hundred brethren, to whom the Lord showed Himself after His Resurrection: out of their number were so many thousands baptized, who laid the price of their possessions at the Apostles' feet.

[132:109] Thus then was fulfilled the prayer here made to God: "For Thy servant David's sake, turn not away the presence of Thine Anointed".

[132:110] "The Lord hath made a faithful oath unto David, and He shall not repent".

[132:111] What meaneth, "hath made an oath"? Hath confirmed a promise through Himself.

[132:112] What meaneth, "He shall not repent"? He will not change.

[132:113] For God suffereth not the pain of repentance, nor is He deceived in any matter, so that He would wish to correct that wherein He hath erred.

[132:114] But as when a man repents of anything, he wisheth to change what he hath done; thus where thou hearest that God repenteth, look for an actual change.

[132:115] God doth it differently from thee, although He calleth it by the name of repentance; for thou dost it, because thou hadst erred; while He doth it, because He avengeth, or freeth.

[132:116] He changed Saul's kingdom, when He repented, as it is said: and in the very passage where the Scripture saith, "It repented Him;" it is said a little after, "for He is not a man that He should repent".

[132:117] When therefore He changeth His works through His immutable counsel, He is said to repent on account of this very change, not of His counsel, but of His work.

[132:118] But He promised this so as not to change it.

[132:119] Just as this passage also saith: "The Lord sware, and will not repent, Thou art a Priest for ever after the order of Melchizedec;" so also since this was promised so that it should not be changed, because it must needs happen and be permanent; he saith, "The Lord hath made a faithful oath unto David, and He shall not repent; Of the fruit of thy body shall I set upon thy seat".

[132:120] He might have said, "of the fruit of thy loins," wherefore did He choose to say, "Of the fruit of thy body"? Had He said that also, it would have been true; but He chose to say with a further meaning, Ex fructu ventris, because Christ was born of a woman without the man.

[132:121] What then? "The Lord hath made a faithful oath unto David, and He shall not shrink from it; Of the fruit of thy body shall I set upon thy seat.

[132:122] If thy children will keep My covenant and My testimonies that I shall learn them, their children also shall sit upon thy seat for evermore".

[132:123] If thy children keep My covenant, their children also shall sit for evermore.

[132:124] The parents establish a desert on behalf of their children.

[132:125] What if his children should keep the covenant, and their children should not keep it? Why is the happiness of the children promised in relation to their parents' deservings? For what saith He, "If thy children will keep My covenant, their children also shall sit for evermore"—He saith not, if thy children keep My covenant, they shall sit upon thy seat; and if their children keep My covenant, they also shall sit upon thy seat: but he saith, "If thy children keep My covenant, their children also shall sit upon thy seat for evermore"—except because He here wished their fruit to be understood by their children? "If thy children," He saith, "will keep My covenant, and if thy children shall keep My testimonies that I shall learn them; their children also shall sit upon thy seat:" that is, this will be their fruit, that they sit upon thy seat.

[132:126] For in this life, brethren, do all of us who labour in Christ, all of us who tremble at His words, who in any way endeavour to execute His will, and groan while we pray His help that we may fulfil what He commandeth; do we already sit in those seats of bliss which are promised us? No: but holding His commandments, we hope this will come to pass.

[132:127] This hope is spoken of under the figure of sons; because sons are the hope of man living in this life, sons are his fruit.

[132:128] For this reason also men, when excusing their avarice, allege that they are reserving for their children what they hoard up; and, unwilling to give to the destitute, excuse themselves under the name of piety, because their children are their hope.

[132:129] For all men who live according to this world, declare it to be their hope, to be fathers of children they may leave behind them.

[132:130] Thus then He describes hope generally under the name of children, and saith, "If thy children will keep My covenant and My testimonies that I shall learn them, their children also shall sit upon thy seat for evermore:" that is, they shall have such fruits, that their hope shall not deceive them, that they may come there where they hope to come.

[132:131] At present therefore they are as fathers, men of hope for the future; but when they have attained what they hope, they are children; because they have brought forth and produced in their works that which they gain.

[132:132] And this is preserved unto them for the future, because futurity itself commonly signifieth children.

[132:133] Or if thou understand actual men to be meant by children, the words, "If thy children will keep My covenant and My testimonies that I shall teach them," may mean, "If thy children will keep My covenant and testimonies that I shall teach them, and their children also;" that is, if they too keep My covenant; so that here thou must make a slight pause, and then infer that "they shall sit upon thy seat for evermore;" that is, both thy children and their children, but all if they keep My covenant.

[132:134] What then, if they keep it not? Hath the promise of God failed? No: but it is said and promised for this reason, that God foresaw: what, save that they would believe? But that no man should as it were threaten God's promises, and prefer to place in his own power the fulfilment of what God promised: for this reason he saith, "He made an oath:" whereby he showeth that it will without doubt take place.

[132:135] How then hath He said here, "If they will keep My covenant"? Glory not in the promises, and leave out thy failing to keep the covenant.

[132:136] Then wilt thou be the son of David, if thou shalt keep the covenant; but if thou dost not keep it, thou wilt not be David's son.

[132:137] God promised to the sons of David.

[132:138] Say not, I am David's son if thou degenerate.

[132:139] If the Jews, who were born of this very stock, say not this (nay, they say it, but they are under a delusion.

[132:140] For the Lord saith openly, "If ye were Abraham's children, ye would do the works of Abraham".

[132:141] He thereby denied them to be children, because they did not the works), how do we call ourselves David's children, who are not of his race according to the flesh? It follows then that we are not children, save by imitating his faith, save by worshipping God, as he worshipped.

[132:142] If therefore what thou hopest not through descent, thou wilt not endeavour to obtain by works; how shall the sitting upon David's seat be fulfilled in thee? And if it shall not be fulfilled in thee, thinkest thou that it shall not be fulfilled at all? And how hath He found it in the woodland tracts? and how did His feet stand? Whatsoever then thou mayest be, that house will stand.

[132:143] "For the Lord hath chosen Sion to be an habitation for Himself".

[132:144] Sion is the Church Herself; She is also that Jerusalem unto whose peace we are running, who is in pilgrimage not in the Angels, but in us, who in her better part waiteth for the part that will return; whence letters have come unto us, which are every day read.

[132:145] This city is that very Sion, whom the Lord hath chosen.

[132:146] "This shall be My rest for ever".

[132:147] These are the words of God.

[132:148] "My rest:" I rest there.

[132:149] How greatly doth God love us, brethren, since, because we rest, He saith that He also resteth! For He is not sometimes Himself disturbed, nor doth He rest as we do; but He saith that He resteth there, because we shall have rest in Him.

[132:150] "Here will I dwell: for I have a delight therein".

[132:151] "I will bless her widow with blessings, and will satisfy her poor with bread".

[132:152] Every soul that is aware that it is bereft of all help, save of God alone, is widowed.

[132:153] For how doth the Apostle describe a widow? "She that is a widow indeed and desolate, trusteth in God".

[132:154] He was speaking of those whom we all call Widows in the Church.

[132:155] He saith, "She that liveth in pleasure, is dead while she liveth;" and he numbereth her not among the widows.

[132:156] But in describing true widows, what saith he? "She that is a widow indeed and desolate, trusteth in God, and continueth in supplications and prayers night and day".

[132:157] Here he addeth, "but she that liveth in pleasure, is dead while she liveth".

[132:158] What then makes a widow? That she hath no aid from any other source, save from God alone.

[132:159] They that have husbands, take pride in the protection of their husbands: widows seem desolate, and their aid is a stronger one.

[132:160] The whole Church therefore is one widow, whether in men or in women, in married men or married women, in young men or in old, or in virgins: the whole Church is one widow, desolate in this world, if she feel this, if she is aware of her widowhood: for then is help at hand for her.

[132:161] Do ye not recognise this widow in the Gospel, my brethren, when the Lord declared "that men ought always to pray and not to faint"? "There was in a city a judge," He said, "which feared not God, neither regarded man.

[132:162] And there was a widow in that city; and she came unto him day by day, saying, Avenge me of mine adversary".

[132:163] The widow, by daily importunity, prevailed with him: for the judge said within himself, "Though I fear not God; neither regard man, yet because this woman troubleth me, I will avenge her".

[132:164] If the wicked judge heard the widow, that he might not be molested; heareth not God His Church, whom He exhorteth to pray?.

[132:165] Also, "I will satisfy her poor with bread;" what meaneth this, brethren? Let us be poor, and we shall then be satisfied.

[132:166] Many who trust in the world, and are proud, are Christians; they worship Christ, but are not satisfied; for they have been satisfied, and abound in their pride.

[132:167] Of such it is said, "Our soul is filled with the scornful reproof of the wealthy, and with the despitefulness of the proud:" these have abundance, and therefore eat, but are not satisfied.

[132:168] And what is said of them in the Psalm? "All such as be fat upon the earth have eaten and worshipped".

[132:169] They worship Christ, they venerate Christ, they pray unto Christ; but they are not satisfied with His wisdom and righteousness.

[132:170] Wherefore? Because they are not poor.

[132:171] For the poor, that is the humble in heart, the more they hunger, the more they eat; and the more empty they are of the world, the more hungry they are.

[132:172] He who is full refuseth whatsoever thou wilt give him, because he is full.

[132:173] Give me one who hungereth; give me one of whom it is said, "Blessed are they that hunger and thirst after righteousness, for they shall be filled:" and these will be the p oor of whom he hath just said, "And will satisfy her poor with bread".

[132:174] For in the very Psalm where it is said, "All such as be fat upon the earth have eaten and worshipped;" this is said of the poor also, and exactly in the same manner as in this Psalm, "The poor shall eat, and be satisfied: they that seek after the Lord shall praise Him".

[132:175] Where it is said, "All such as be fat upon earth have eaten and worshipped:" it is said, "the poor shall eat, and be satisfied".

[132:176] Why, when the rich are said to have worshipped, are they not said to be satisfied; yet when the poor are mentioned, they are said to be satisfied? And whence are they satisfied? What is the nature, brethren, of this satisfying? God Himself is their bread.

[132:177] The bread came down upon the earth, that He might become milk unto us; and said to His own, "I am the Living Bread which came down from heaven".

[132:178] Hence these words in the Psalm, "The poor shall eat, and be satisfied".

[132:179] From what source shall they be satisfied? Hear what followeth: "And they that seek after the Lord shall praise Him".

[132:180] Be ye therefore poor, be ye among the members of that widow, let your help be solely in God alone.

[132:181] Money is nought; not thence will ye have aid.

[132:182] Many have been cast headlong down for money's sake, many have perished on account of money; many for the sake of their riches have been marked out by plunderers; they would have been safe, had they not had what made men hunt for them.

[132:183] Many have presumed in their more powerful friends: they in whom they presumed have fallen, and have involved in their ruin those who trusted in them.

[132:184] Look back upon the instances to be seen in the human race.

[132:185] Is it anything singular that I am telling you? We speak these things not only from these Scriptures; read them in the whole world.

[132:186] Take heed that ye presume not in money, in a friend, in the honour and the boasting of the world.

[132:187] Take away all these things: but if thou hast them, thank God if thou despisest them.

[132:188] But if thou art puffed up by them; think not when thou wilt be the prey of men; already art thou the Devil's prey.

[132:189] But if thou hast not trusted in these things, thou wilt be among the members of that widow, who is the Church, of whom it is said, "I will bless her widow with blessings;" thou wilt also be poor, and one of those of whom it is said, "And will satisfy her poor with bread".

[132:190] Sometimes, however, and we must not pass over this without mention, thou findest a poor man proud, and a rich man humble: we daily endure such persons.

[132:191] Thou hearest a poor man groaning beneath a rich man, and when the more powerful rich man presseth upon him, then thou seest him humble: sometimes not even then, but even then proud; whence thou seest what he would have been, had he any property.

[132:192] God's poor one is therefore poor in spirit, not in his purse.

[132:193] Sometimes a man goeth forth having a full house, rich lands, many estates, much gold and silver; he knoweth that he must not trust in these, he humbleth himself before God, he doth good with them; thus his heart is raised unto God, so that he is aware that not only do riches themselves profit him nothing, but that they even impede his feet, save He rule them, and aid them: and he is counted among the poor who are satisfied with bread.

[132:194] Thou findest another a proud beggar, or not proud only because he hath nothing, nevertheless seeking whereby he may be puffed up.

[132:195] God doth not heed the means a man hath, but the wish he hath, and judgeth him according to his wish for temporal blessings, not according to the means which it is not his lot to have.

[132:196] Whence the Apostle saith of the rich, "Charge them that are rich in this world, that they be not highminded, nor trust in uncertain riches, but in the living God, who giveth us richly all things to enjoy".

[132:197] What therefore should they do with their riches? He goeth on to say: "That they be rich in good works, ready to distribute, willing to communicate".

[132:198] And see that they are poor in this world: "Laying up in store for themselves," he addeth, "a good foundation against the time to come, that they may lay hold on eternal life".

[132:199] When they have laid hold of eternal life, then will they be rich; but since they have it not as yet, they should know that they are poor.

[132:200] Thus it is that God counteth among His poor all the humble in heart, who are established in that twofold charity, whatever they may have in this world—among His poor, whom He satisfieth with bread.

[132:201] "I will clothe her priests with salvation, and her saints shall rejoice and sing".

[132:202] We are now at the end of the Psalm; attend for a short space, Beloved.

[132:203] "I will clothe her priests with salvation, and her saints shall rejoice and sing".

[132:204] Who is our salvation, save our Christ? What meaneth, therefore, "I will clothe her priests with salvation"? "As many of you as have been baptized into Christ, have put on Christ".

[132:205] "And her saints shall rejoice and sing".

[132:206] Whence shall they rejoice and sing? Because they have been clothed with salvation: not in themselves.

[132:207] For they have become light, but in the Lord; for they were darkness before Therefore he hath added, "There will I raise up the horn of David" : this will be David's height, that trust be put in Christ.

[132:208] For horn signifieth height: and what sort of height? Not carnal.

[132:209] Therefore, while all the bones are wrapped up in flesh, the horn goeth beyond the flesh.

[132:210] Spiritual altitude is a horn.

[132:211] But what is spiritual loftiness, save to trust in Christ? not to say, It is my work, I baptize; but, "He it is who baptizeth".

[132:212] There is the horn of David: and that ye may know that there is the horn of David, heed what followeth: "I have ordained a lantern for mine Anointed".

[132:213] What is a lantern? Ye already know the Lord's words concerning John: "He was a burning and a shining light".

[132:214] And what saith John? "He it is who baptizeth".

[132:215] Herein therefore shall the saints rejoice, herein the priests shall rejoice: because all that is good in themselves, is not of themselves, but of Him who hath the power of baptizing.

[132:216] Fearlessly therefore doth every one who hath received baptism come unto His temple; because it is not man's, but His who made the horn of David to flourish.

[132:217] "Upon Him shall My sanctification flourish".

[132:218] Upon whom? Upon Mine Anointed.

[132:219] For when He saith, "Mine anointed," it is the voice of the Father, who saith, "I will bless her widow with blessings, and will satisfy her poor with bread.

[132:220] I will clothe her priests with salvation, and her saints shall rejoice and sing".

[132:221] He who saith, "There will I raise up the horn of David," is God.

[132:222] He Himself saith, "I have ordained a lantern for Mine Anointed," because Christ is both ours and the Father's: He is our Christ, when He saveth us and ruleth us, as He is also our Lord: He is the Son of the Father, but both our Christ and the Father's.

[132:223] For if He were not the Father's Christ, it would not be said above, "For Thy servant David's sake, turn not Thou away the presence of Thine Anointed".

[132:224] "Upon Him shall My sanctification flourish".

[132:225] It flourisheth upon Christ.

[132:226] Let none of men assume this to himself, that he himself sanctifieth: otherwise it will not be true, "Upon Him shall My sanctification flourish".

[132:227] The glory of sanctification shall flourish.

[132:228] The sanctification of Christ therefore in Christ Himself, is the power of the sanctification of God in Christ.

[132:229] In that he saith, "shall flourish," he refers to His glory: for when trees flourish, then are they beautiful.

[132:230] Sanctification therefore is in Baptism: thence it flourisheth, and is brightened.

[132:231] Why hath the world yielded to this beauty? Because it flourisheth in Christ; for, put it in man's power, and how doth it then flourish? since "all flesh in grass, and all the goodliness thereof as the flower of the grass".

[133:1] Psalm CXXXIII.

[133:2] This is a short Psalm, but one well known and quoted.

[133:3] "Behold, how good and how pleasant is it, that brethren should dwell together in unity".

[133:4] So sweet is that sound, that even they who know not the Psalter, sing that verse.

[133:5] For these same words of the Psalter, this sweet sound, that honeyed melody, as well of the mind as of the hymn, did even beget the Monasteries.

[133:6] By this sound were stirred up the brethren who longed to dwell together.

[133:7] This verse was their trumpet.

[133:8] It sounded through the whole earth, and they who had been divided, were gathered together.

[133:9] The summons of God, the summons of the Holy Spirit, the summons of the Prophets, were not heard in Judah, yet were heard through the whole world.

[133:10] They were deaf to that sound, amid whom it was sung; they were found with their ears open, of whom it was said, "They shall see him, who were not told of him; they shall understand who heard not".

[133:11] Yet, most beloved, if we reflect, the very blessing hath sprung from that wall of circumcision.

[133:12] For have all the Jews perished? and whence were the Apostles, the sons of the Prophets, the sons of the exiles? He speaks as to them who know.

[133:13] Whence those five hundred, who saw the Lord after His resurrection, whom the Apostle Paul commemorates? Whence those hundred and twenty, who were together in one place after the resurrection of the Lord, and His ascension into heaven, on whom when gathered into one place the Holy Spirit descended on the day of Pentecost, sent down from heaven, sent, even as He was promised? All were from thence, and they first dwelt together in unity; who sold all they had, and laid the price of their goods at the Apostles' feet, as is read in the Acts of the Apostles And distribution was made to each one as he had need, and none called anything his own, but they had all things common.

[133:14] And what is "together in unity"? They had, he says, one mind and one heart God-wards So they were the first who heard, Behold how good and how pleasant is it, that brethren dwell together.

[133:15] They were the first to hear, but heard it not alone.

[133:16] From the words of this Psalm was taken the name of Monks, that no one may reproach you who are Catholics by reason of the name.

[133:17] When you with justice reproach heretics by reason of the Circelliones, that they may be saved by shame, they reproach you on the score of the Monks.

[133:18] Moreover, beloved, there are they who are false Monks, and we know men of this kind; but the pious brotherhood is not annulled, because of them who profess to be what they are not.

[133:19] There are false Monks, as there are false men among the Clergy, and among the faithful.

[133:20] Since the Psalm says, "Behold, how good and how pleasant is it, that brethren should dwell together in one," why then should we not call Monks so? for Monos is one.

[133:21] Not one in any manner, for a man in a crowd is one, but though he can be called one along with others, he cannot be Monos, that is, alone, for Monos means "one alone".

[133:22] They then who thus live together as to make one man, so that they really possess what is written, "one mind and one heart," many bodies, but not many minds; many bodies, but not many hearts; can rightly be called Monos, that is, one alone.

[133:23] Let the Psalm tell us what they are like.

[133:24] "As the ointment on the head, which descended to the beard, to Aaron's beard, which descended to the fringe of his garment".

[133:25] What was Aaron? A priest.

[133:26] Who is a priest, except that one Priest, who entered into the Holy of Holies? Who is that priest, save Him, who was at once Victim and Priest? save Him who when he found nothing clean in the world to offer, offered Himself? The ointment is on his head, because Christ is one whole with the Church, but the ointment comes from the head.

[133:27] Our Head is Christ crucified and buried; He rose again, and ascended into heaven; and the Holy Spirit came from the head.

[133:28] Whither? To the beard.

[133:29] The beard signifies the courageous; the beard distinguishes the grown men, the earnest, the active, the vigorous.

[133:30] So that when we describe such, we say, he is a bearded man.

[133:31] Thus that ointment descended first upon the Apostles, descended upon those who bore the first assaults of the world, and therefore the Holy Spirit descended on them.

[133:32] For they who first began to dwell together in unity, suffered persecution, but because the ointment descended to the beard, they suffered, but were not conquered.

[133:33] "As the dew of Hermon, which fell upon the hills of Sion".

[133:34] He would have it understood, my brethren, that it is of God's grace that brethren dwell together in unity.

[133:35] But ye should know what Hermon is.

[133:36] It is a mountain far distant from Jerusalem, that is, from Sion.

[133:37] And so it is strange that he says thus: As the dew of Hermon, which fell upon the mountains of Sion, since mount Hermon is far distant from Jerusalem, for it is said to be over Jordan.

[133:38] Let us then seek out some interpretation of Hermon.

[133:39] The word is Hebrew, and we learn its meaning from them who know that language.

[133:40] Hermon is said to mean, a light set on a high place.

[133:41] For from Christ comes the dew.

[133:42] No light is set on a high place, save Christ.

[133:43] How is He set on high? First on the cross, afterwards in heaven.

[133:44] Set on high on the cross when He was humbled; humbled, but His humiliation could not but be high.

[133:45] The ministry of man grew less and less, as was signified in John; the ministry of God in our Lord Jesus Christ increased, as was shown at their birth.

[133:46] The former was born, as the tradition of the Church shows, on the th of June, when the days begin to shorten.

[133:47] The Lord was born on the th of December, when the days begin to lengthen.

[133:48] Here John himself confessing, "He must increase, but I must decrease".

[133:49] And the passion of each shows this.

[133:50] The Lord was exalted on the cross; John was diminished by beheading.

[133:51] Thus the light set on high is Christ, whence is the dew of Hermon.

[133:52] But if he have the dew of Hermon, which fell on the hill of Sion, he is quiet, peaceable, humble, submissive, pouring forth prayer in place of murmuring.

[133:53] For murmurers are admirably described in a certain passage of the Scriptures, "The heart of a fool is as the wheel of a cart".

[133:54] What is the meaning of "the heart of a fool is as the wheel of a cart"? It carries hay, and creaks.

[133:55] The wheel of a cart cannot cease from creaking.

[133:56] Thus there are many brethren, who do not dwell together, save in the body.

[133:57] But who are they who dwell together? They of whom it is said, "And they had one mind and one heart towards God".

[133:58] "Because there the Lord commanded blessing".

[133:59] Where did He command it? Among the brethren who dwell together.

[133:60] There He enjoined blessing, there they who dwell with one heart bless God.

[133:61] For thou blessest not God in division of heart.

[133:62] Art thou straitened on earth? Depart, have thy habitation in heaven.

[133:63] How shall I, a man clothed in flesh, enslaved to the flesh, thou wilt say, have my habitation in heaven.

[133:64] First go in heart, whither thou wouldest follow in the body.

[133:65] Do not hear, "Lift up your hearts," with a deaf ear.

[133:66] Keep thy heart lifted up, and no one will straiten thee in heaven.

[134:1] Psalm CXXXIV.

[134:2] "Behold, now, bless ye the Lord, all ye servants of the Lord" , "who stand in the house of the Lord, in the courts of the house of our God".

[134:3] Why has he added, "in the courts"? Courts mean the wider spaces of a house.

[134:4] He who stands in the courts is not straitened, is not confined, in some fashion is enlarged.

[134:5] Remain in this enlargement, and thou canst love thy enemy, because thou lovest not things in which an enemy could straiten thee.

[134:6] How canst thou be understood to stand in the courts? Stand in charity, and thou standest in the courts.

[134:7] Breadth lies in charity, straitness in hatred.

[134:8] "Lift up your hands by night in the sanctuary, and bless the Lord".

[134:9] It is easy to bless by day.

[134:10] What is "by day"? In prosperity.

[134:11] For night is a sad thing, day a cheerful.

[134:12] When it is well with thee, thou dost bless the Lord.

[134:13] Thy son was sick, and he is made whole, thou dost bless the Lord.
