[143:71] "I have stretched forth my hands to Thee; my soul is as a land without water," not to me, but "to Thee".

[143:72] I can thirst for Thee, I cannot water myself.

[143:73] "Speedily hear me, Lord".

[143:74] For what need of delay to inflame my thirst, when already I thirst so eagerly? Thou didst delay the rain, that I might drink and imbibe, not reject, Thy inflowing.

[143:75] If then Thou didst for this cause delay, now give; for "my spirit hath failed".

[143:76] Let Thy Spirit fill me.

[143:77] This is the reason why Thou shouldest speedily hear me.

[143:78] I am now become "poor in spirit," make Thou me "blessed in the kingdom of heaven".

[143:79] For he in whom his own spirit liveth, is proud, is puffed up with his own spirit against God.

[143:80] "Turn not Thou away Thy Face from me".

[143:81] Thou didst turn it away from me when proud.

[143:82] For once I was full, and in my fulness I was puffed up.

[143:83] Once "in my fulness I said, I shall never be moved".

[143:84] "I said in my fulness, I shall not be moved," knowing not Thy Righteousness, and establishing mine own; but "Thou, Lord, in Thy Will hast afforded strength to my beauty".

[143:85] "I said in my fulness, I shall not be moved," but from Thee came whatever fulness I had.

[143:86] And to prove to me that it was from Thee, "Thou didst turn away Thy Face from me, and I was troubled".

[143:87] After this trouble, where into I was cast, because Thou didst turn away Thy Face, after the weariness of my spirit, after my heart was troubled within me, because Thou didst turn away Thy Face, then became I "like a land without water to Thee: turn not Thou away Thy Face".

[143:88] Thou turnedst it away from me when proud; give it back to me now I am humble.

[143:89] Because, if Thou turn it away, "I shall be like to them that go down into the pit".

[143:90] What is, "that go down into the pit"? When the sinner has come into the depth of sins, he will show contempt.

[143:91] They "go down into the pit," who lose even confession; against which is said, "Let not the pit close her mouth over me".

[143:92] This depth Scripture calleth mostly "a pit," into which depth when a sinner hath come, "he showeth contempt".

[143:93] What is, "he showeth contempt"? He no longer believeth in Providence, or if he do believe, he thinketh that he has no longer aught to do with it.

[143:94] "Make me to hear in the morning Thy mercy, for in Thee have I hoped".

[143:95] Behold, I am in the night, yet "in Thee have I hoped," until the iniquity of the night pass away.

[143:96] "For we have," as Peter saith, "a more sure word of prophecy, whereunto ye do well that ye take heed, as unto a light that shineth in a dark place, until the day dawn, and the daystar arise in your hearts".

[143:97] "Morning" then he calleth the time after the end of the world, when we shall see what in this world we believe.

[143:98] But what here, until the morning come? For it is not enough to hope for the morning; we must do somewhat.

[143:99] Why do somewhat? God is to be sought with the hands in the night.

[143:100] What is, "with the hands"? By good works.

[143:101] Since then we must thus hope for the morning, and bear this night, and persevere in this patience until the day dawn, what meanwhile must we do here? lest perchance thou think that thou wilt do aught of thyself, whereby thou mayest earn to be brought to the morning.

[143:102] "Make known to me, O Lord, the way wherein I must walk".

[143:103] Therefore did He kindle the lamp of prophecy, therefore did He send the Lord in the vessel, as it were, of the flesh, who should even say, "My strength is dried up like a potsherd".

[143:104] Walk by prophecy, walk by the lamp of future things predicted, walk by the word of God.

[143:105] "Deliver me from mine enemies, O Lord, for unto Thee have I fled for refuge".

[143:106] I who once fled from Thee, now flee to Thee.

[143:107] For Adam fled from the Face of God, and hid himself among the trees of Paradise, so that of him was said in the Book of Job, "As a servant that fleeth from his Lord, and findeth a shadow".

[143:108] He fled from the Face of his Lord, and found a shadow.

[143:109] Woe to him, if he continue in the shade, lest it be said afterward, "All things are passed away like a shadow".

[143:110] The rulers of this world, of this darkness, the rulers of the wicked; against these ye wrestle.

[143:111] Great is your conflict, not to see your enemies, and yet to conquer.

[143:112] Against the rulers of this world, of this darkness, the devil, that is, and his angels; not the rulers of that world, whereof is said, "the world was made by Him," but that world whereof is said, "the world knew Him not".

[143:113] "For unto Thee have I fled for refuge".

[143:114] Whither should I flee? "Whither shall I go from Thy Spirit?".

[143:115] "Teach me to do Thy will, for Thou art my God".

[143:116] Glorious confession! glorious rule! "For Thou," saith he, "art my God".

[143:117] To another will I hasten to be re-made, if by another I was made.

[143:118] Thou art my all, "for Thou art my God".

[143:119] Shall I seek a father to get an inheritance? "Thou art my God," not only the Giver of mine inheritance, but mine Inheritance itself.

[143:120] "The Lord is the portion of mine inheritance".

[143:121] Shall I seek a patron, to obtain redemption? "Thou art my God".

[143:122] Lastly, having been created, do I desire to be re-created? "Thou art my God," my Creator, who hast created me by Thy Word, and re-created me by Thy Word.

[143:123] "Teach Thou me:" for it cannot be that Thou art my God, and yet I am to be mine own master.

[143:124] See how grace is commended to us.

[143:125] This hold fast, this drink in, this let none drive out of your hearts, lest ye have "a zeal, of God, but not according to knowledge".

[143:126] Say then this: "Thy good Spirit," not my bad one, "Thy good Spirit shall lead me into the right land".

[143:127] For my bad spirit hath led me into a crooked land.

[143:128] And what have I deserved? What can be reckoned as my good works without Thy aid, through which I might obtain and be worthy to be led by Thy Spirit into the right land?.

[143:129] Listen, then, with all your power, to the commendation of Grace, whereby ye are saved without price.

[143:130] "For Thy Name's sake, O Lord, Thou shalt quicken me in Thy righteousness" ; not in mine own: not because I have deserved, but because Thou hast mercy.

[143:131] For were I to show mine own desert, nought should I deserve of Thee, save punishment.

[143:132] Thou hast pruned off from me mine own merits; Thou hast grafted in Thine own gifts.

[143:133] "Thou shalt bring forth my soul out of tribulation".

[143:134] "And in thy mercy shalt bring mine enemies to destruction: and thou shalt destroy all them that afflict my soul; for I am Thy servant".

[144:1] Psalm CXLIV.

[144:2] The title of this Psalm is brief in number of words, but heavy in the weight of its mysteries.

[144:3] "To David himself against Goliath".

[144:4] This battle was fought in the time of our fathers, and ye, beloved, remember it with me from Holy Scripture.

[144:5] David put five stones in his scrip, he hurled but one.

[144:6] The five Books were chosen, but unity conquered.

[144:7] Then, having smitten and overthrown him, he took the enemy's sword, and with it cut off his head.

[144:8] This our David also did, He overthrew the devil with his own weapons: and when his great ones, whom he had in his power, by means of whom he slew other souls, believe, they turn their tongues against the devil, and so Goliath's head is cut off with his own sword.

[144:9] "Blessed be the Lord my God, who teacheth my hands for battle, my fingers for war".

[144:10] These are our words, if we be the Body of Christ.

[144:11] It seems a repetition of sentiment; "our hands for battle," and "our fingers for war," are the same.

[144:12] Or is there some difference between "hands" and "fingers"? Certainly both hands and fingers work.

[144:13] Not then without reason do we take "fingers" as put for "hands".

[144:14] But still in the "fingers" we recognise the division of operation, yet still a sort of unity.

[144:15] Behold that grace! the Apostle saith, To one, this; to another, that; "there are diversities of operations; all these worketh one and the self-same Spirit;" there is the root of unity.

[144:16] With these "fingers" then the Body of Christ fighteth, going forth to "war," going forth to "battle".

[144:17] By works of Mercy our enemy is conquered, and we could not have works of mercy unless we had charity, and charity we could have none unless we received it by the Holy Ghost; He then "teacheth our hands for battle, and our fingers for war:" to Him rightfully do we say, "My Mercy," from whom we have also that we are merciful: "for he shall have judgment without mercy, that hath showed no mercy".

[144:18] My Mercy and my Refuge, my Upholder and my Deliverer".

[144:19] Much toileth this combatant, having his flesh lusting against his spirit.

[144:20] Keep what thou hast.

[144:21] Then shalt thou have in full what thou wishest, when "death shall have been swallowed up in victory;" when this mortal body has been raised, and is changed into the condition of the angels, and rises aloft to a heavenly quality.

[144:22] There is life, there are good days, where nought lusteth against the spirit, where it is not said, "Fight," but "Rejoice".

[144:23] But who is he that lusteth for these days? Every man certainly saith, "I do".

[144:24] Hear what followeth.

[144:25] I see that thou art toiling, I see that thou art engaged in battle, and in danger; hear what followeth:"Depart from evil, and do good:" let not the poor first weep under thee, that the poor may rejoice through thee.

[144:26] For what reward, since now thou art fighting? "Seek peace, and ensue it".

[144:27] Learn and say, "My Mercy and my Refuge, mine Upholder and my Deliverer, my Protector:" "mine Upholder," lest I fall; "my Deliverer," lest I stick; "my Protector," lest I be stricken.

[144:28] In all these things, in all my toil, in all my battles, in all my difficulties, in Him have I hoped, "who subdueth my people under me".

[144:29] Behold, our Head speaketh together with us.

[144:30] "Lord, what is man, that Thou hast become known unto him?".

[144:31] All is included in "that Thou hast become known unto him".

[144:32] "Or the son of man, that Thou valuest him?" Thou valuest him, that is, Thou makest him of such importance, Thou countest him of such price, Thou knowest under what Thou placest him, over what Thou placest him.

[144:33] For valuing is considering the price of a thing.

[144:34] How greatly did He value man, who for him shed the blood of His only-begotten Son! For God valueth not man in the same way as one man valueth another: he, when he findeth a slave for sale, giveth a higher price for a horse than for a man.

[144:35] Consider how greatly He valued thee, that thou mayest be able to say, "If God be for us, who can be against us?" And how greatly did He value thee, "who spared not His own Son"? "How shall He not also with Him freely give us all things?" He who giveth this food to the combatant, what keepeth He in store for the conqueror?.

[144:36] "Man is made like unto vanity: his days pass away like a shadow".

[144:37] What vanity? Time, which passeth on, and floweth by.

[144:38] For this "vanity" is said in comparison of the Truth, which ever abideth, and never faileth: for it too is a work of His Hand, in its degree.

[144:39] "For," as it is written, "God filled the earth with His good things".

[144:40] What is "His"? That accord with Him.

[144:41] But all these things, being earthly, fleeting, transitory, if they be compared to that Truth, where it is said, "I Am That I Am," all this which passeth away is called "vanity".

[144:42] For through time it vanisheth, like stroke into the air.

[144:43] And why should I say more than that which the Apostle James said, willing to bring down proud men to humility, "What is," saith he, "your life? It is even a vapour, which appeareth for a little time, and then vanisheth away".

[144:44] Work then, though it be in the night, with thine hands, that is, by good works seek God, before the day come which shall gladden thee, lest the day come which shall sadden thee.

[144:45] For see how safely thou workest, who art not left by Him whom thou seekest; "that thy Father which seeth in secret may reward thee openly".

[144:46] "Lord, bow Thy heavens, and come down: touch the mountains, and they shall smoke".

[144:47] "Flash Thy lightning, and Thou shalt scatter them; send forth Thine arrows, and Thou shalt confound them".

[144:48] "Send forth Thy Hand from above, and deliver me, and draw me out of many waters".

[144:49] The Body of Christ, the humble David, full of grace, relying on God, fighting in this world, calleth for the help of God.

[144:50] What are "heavens bowed down"? Apostles humbled.

[144:51] For those "heavens declare the glory of God;" and of these heavens declaring the glory of God it is presently said, "There is neither speech nor language, but their voices are heard among them," etc When then these heavens sent forth their voices through all lands, and did wonderful things, while the Lord flashed and thundered from them by miracles and commandments, the gods were thought to have come down from heaven to men.

[144:52] For certain of the Gentiles, thinking this, desired even to sacrifice to them.

[144:53] But they commended to these the Lord Jesus Christ, humbling themselves, that God might be praised; because "the heavens" were "bowed," that "God" might "come down".

[144:54] "Touch the mountains, and they shall smoke".

[144:55] So long as they are not touched, they seem to themselves great: they are now about to say, "Great art Thou, O Lord:" the mountains also are about to say, "Thou only art the Most Highest over all the earth".

[144:56] But there are some that conspire, that "gather themselves together against the Lord, and against His Christ".

[144:57] They have come together, they have conspired.

[144:58] "Flash forth Thy lightnings, and Thou shalt scatter them".

[144:59] Abound with Thy miracles, and their conspiracy shall be broken.

[144:60] "Send forth Thine arrows, and Thou shalt confound them".

[144:61] Let the unsound be wounded, that, being well wounded, they may be made sound; and let them say, being set now in the Church, in the Body of Christ, let them say with the Church, "I am wounded with Love".

[144:62] "Send forth Thine Hand from on high".

[144:63] What afterward? What in the end? How conquereth the Body of Christ? By heavenly aid.

[144:64] "For the Lord Himself shall come with the voice of the Archangel, and with the trump of God shall He descend from heaven," Himself the Saviour of the body, the Hand of God.

[144:65] What is, "Out of many waters"? From many peoples.

[144:66] What peoples? Aliens, unbelievers, whether assailing us from without, or laying snares within.

[144:67] Take me out of many waters, in which Thou didst discipline me, in which Thou didst roll me, to free me from my filth.

[144:68] This is the "water of contradiction".

[144:69] "From the hand of strange children".

[144:70] Hear, brethren, among whom we are, among whom we live, from whom we long to be delivered.

[144:71] "Whose mouth hath spoken vanity".

[144:72] All of you to-day, if ye had not gathered yourselves together to these divine shows of the word of God, and were not at this hour engaged in them, how great vanities would ye be hearing! "whose mouth hath spoken vanity:" when, in short, would they, speaking vanity, hear you speaking vanity? "And their right hand is a right hand of iniquity".

[144:73] What doest thou among them with thy pastoral scrip with five stones in it? Say it to me in another form: that same law which thou hast signified by five stones, signify in some other way also.

[144:74] "I will sing a new song unto Thee, O God".

[144:75] "A new song" is of grace; "a new song" is of the new man; "a new song" is of the New Testament.

[144:76] But lest thou shouldest think that grace departeth from the law, whereas rather by grace the law is fulfilled, "upon a psaltery of ten strings will I sing unto Thee".

[144:77] Upon the law of ten commandments: therein may I sing to Thee; therein may I rejoice to Thee; therein may "I sing to Thee a new song;" for, "Love is the fulfilling of the law".

[144:78] But they who have not love may carry the psaltery, sing they cannot.

[144:79] Contradiction cannot make my psaltery to be silent.

[144:80] "Who giveth salvation to kings, who redeemeth David His servant".

[144:81] Ye know who David is; be yourselves David.

[144:82] Whence "redeemeth He David His servant"? Whence redeemeth He Christ? Whence redeemeth He the Body of Christ? "From the sword of ill intent deliver me".

[144:83] "From the sword" is not sufficient; he addeth, "of ill intent".

[144:84] Without doubt there is a sword of good intent.

[144:85] What is the sword of good intent? That whereof the Lord saith, "I came not to send peace on earth, but a sword".

[144:86] For He was about to separate believers from unbelievers, sons from parents, and to sever all other ties, while the sword cut off what was diseased, but healed the members of Christ.

[144:87] Of good intent then is the sword twice sharpened, powerful with both edges, the Old and New Testaments, with the narration of the past and the promise of the future.

[144:88] That then is the sword of good intent: but the other is of ill intent, wherewith they talk vanity, for that is of good intent, wherewith God speaketh verity.

[144:89] For truly "the sons of men have teeth which are spears and arrows, and their tongue is a sharp sword".

[144:90] "From" this "sword deliver me".

[144:91] "And take me out of the hand of strange children, whose mouth hath spoken vanity:" just as before.

[144:92] And that which followeth, "their right hand is a right hand of iniquity," the same he had set down before also, when he called them "many waters".

[144:93] For lest thou shouldest think that the "many waters" were good waters, he explained them by the "sword of ill intent".

[144:94] "Whose sons are like young vines firmly planted in their youth".

[144:95] He wisheth to recount their happiness.

[144:96] Observe, ye sons of light, sons of peace: observe, ye sons of the Church, members of Christ; observe whom he calleth "strangers," whom he calleth "strange children," whom he calleth "waters of contradiction," whom he calleth a "sword of ill intent".

[144:97] Observe, I beseech you, for among them ye are in peril, among their tongues ye fight against the desires of your flesh, among their tongues, set in the hand of the devil wherewith he fightethWhat vanity hath their mouth spoken, and how is their right hand a right hand of iniquity? "Their daughters are fitted and adorned after the similitude of a temple".

[144:98] "Their garners are full, bursting out from one store to another: their sheep are fruitful, multiplying in their streets" : "their oxen are fat: their hedge is not broken down, nor their road, nor is their crying in their streets".

[144:99] Is not this then happiness? I ask the sons of the kingdom of heaven, I ask the offspring of everlasting resurrection, I ask the body of Christ, the members of Christ, the temple of God.

[144:100] Is not this then happiness, to have sons safe, daughters beautiful, garners full, cattle abundant, no downfall, I say not of a wall, but not even of a hedge, no tumult and clamour in the streets, but quiet, peace, abundance, plenty of all things in their houses and in their cities? Is not this then happiness? or ought the righteous to shun it? or findest thou not the house of the righteous too abounding with all these things, full of this happiness? Did not Abraham's house abound with gold, silver, children, servants, cattle? What say we? is not this happiness? Be it so, still it is on the left hand.

[144:101] What is, on the left hand? Temporal, mortal, bodily.

[144:102] I desire not that thou shun it, but that thou think it not to be on the right hand.

[144:103] For what ought they to have set on the right hand? God, eternity, the years of God which fail not, whereof is said, "and Thy years shall not fail".

[144:104] There should be the right hand, there should be our longing.

[144:105] Let us use the left for the time, let us long for the fight for eternity.

[144:106] "If riches increase, set not your heart upon them".

[144:107] "They have called the people blessed who have these things".

[144:108] O men that speak vanity! They have lost the true right hand, wicked and perverse, they have put on the benefits of God inversely.

[144:109] O wicked ones, O speakers of vanity, O strange children! What was on the left hand, they have set on the right.

[144:110] What dost thou, David? What dost thou, Body of Christ? What do ye, members of Christ? What do ye, not strange children, but children of God?What say ye? Say ye with us, "Blessed is the people whose Lord is their God".

[145:1] Psalm CXLV.

[145:2] The title is, "Praise, to David himself".

[145:3] Praise to Christ Himself.

[145:4] And since He is called David, who came to us of the seed of David, yet He was our King, ruling us, and bringing us into His kingdom, therefore "Praise to David himself" is understood to mean, Praise to Christ Himself.

[145:5] Christ according to the flesh is David, because He is the Son of David: but according to His Divine Nature He is the Creator of David, and Lord of David.

[145:6] "I will exalt Thee, my God, my King; and I will bless Thy Name for the age, and age upon age".

[145:7] Ye see that the praise of God is here begun, and this praise is carried on even to the end of the Psalm.

[145:8] Now then begin to praise, if thou intendest to praise for ever.

[145:9] He who will not praise in this transitory "age," will be silent when "age upon age" has come.

[145:10] But lest any one should in any otherwise also understand what he saith, "I will praise Thy Name for the age," and should seek another age, wherein to praise, he saith, "Every day will I bless Thee".

[145:11] Praise then and bless the Lord thy God every day, that when single days have passed, and there has come one day without end, thou mayest go from praise to praise, as "from strength to strength".

[145:12] No day shall pass by, wherein I bless Thee not.

[145:13] And it is no wonder, if in thy day of joy thou bless the Lord.

[145:14] What if perchance some day of sorrow hath dawned on thee, as is natural in the circumstances of our mortal nature, as there is abundance of offences, as temptations are multiplied; what, if something sad befall thee, a man; wilt thou cease to praise God? wilt thou cease to bless thy Creator? If thou cease, thou hast lied in saying, "every day," etc.

[145:15] But if thou cease not, although it seem to thee to be ill with thee in the day of thy sorrow, yet in thy God it shall be well with thee.

[145:16] "Great is the Lord, and very much to be praised".

[145:17] How much was he about to say? what terms was he about to seek? How vast a conception hath he included in the one word, "very much"? Imagine what thou wilt, for how can that be imagined, which cannot be contained? "He is very much to be praised.

[145:18] And of His Greatness there is no end;" therefore said he "very much:" lest perchance thou begin to wish to praise, and think that thou canst reach the end of His praises, whose Greatness can have no end.

[145:19] Think not then that He, whose Greatness has no end, can ever be enough praised by thee.

[145:20] Is it not then better that as He has no end, so neither should thy praise have end? His Greatness is without end; let thy praise also be without end.

[145:21] For how great things besides has His boundless Goodness and illimitable Greatness made, which we do not know! When we lift the gaze of our eyes even to the heaven, and then recall it from sun, moon, and stars to the earth, and there is all this space where our sight can wander; beyond the heavens who can extend the eyesight of his mind, not to say of his flesh? So far then as His works are known to us, let us praise Him through His works.

[145:22] "Generation and generation shall praise Thy works".

[145:23] Every generation shall praise Thy works.

[145:24] For perhaps every generation is meant by "generation and generation".

[145:25] Did he perchance mean to imply two generations by that repetition? For we are in this generation sons of God, we shall be in another generation sons of the Resurrection.

[145:26] Scripture hath called us "sons of the Resurrection;" the Resurrection itself it hath called Regeneration.

[145:27] "In the regeneration," it saith, "when the Son of Man shall be seated in His Majesty".

[145:28] So also in another place; "For they shall not marry, nor be given in marriage, for they are the sons of the Resurrection".

[145:29] Therefore "generation and generation shall praise Thy works.

[145:30] And they shall tell out Thine excellence".

[145:31] For neither shall they praise Thy works, save in order to "tell out Thine excellence".

[145:32] Boys at school are set to praise, and all such things are set before them to be praised, as God hath wrought: a mortal is set to praise the sun, the sky, the earth; to come to even lesser things, to praise a rose, or a laurel; all these are works of God: they are set, they are undertaken, they are praised: the works are lauded, of the Worker they are silent.

[145:33] I desire in the works to praise the Creator: I love not a thankless praiser.

[145:34] Dost thou praise what He hath made, and art silent of Him who made? In that which thou seest, what is it that thou praisest? The form, the usefulness, some virtue, some power in the things.

[145:35] If beauty delight thee, what is more beautiful than the Maker? If usefulness be praised, what more useful than He who made all things? If excellence be praised, what more excellent than He by whom all things were made?.

[145:36] "They shall speak of the magnificence of the glory of Thy Holiness, and shall record Thy wondrous deeds".

[145:37] "And the excellence of Thy fearful works shall they speak of: and Thy greatness, they shall relate it".

[145:38] "The remembrance of the abundance of Thy sweetness they shall pour forth" : none but Thine.

[145:39] See whether this man, meditating on Thy works, hath turned aside from the Worker to the work: see whether he hath sunk from Him who made, to the things which He made.

[145:40] Of the things which He hath made, he hath made a step up to Him, not a descent from Him to them.

[145:41] For if thou love these more than Him, thou wilt not have Him.

[145:42] And what profit is it to thee to overflow with the works, if the Worker leave thee? Truly thou shouldest love them; but love Him more, and love them for His sake.

[145:43] For He doth not hold out promises, without holding out threats also: if He held out no promises, there would be no encouragement; if He held out no threats, there would be no correction.

[145:44] They that praise Thee therefore shall "speak" also "of the excellence of Thy terrible deeds;" the excellence of that work of Thy hands which punisheth and administereth discipline, they shall speak of, they shall not be silent: for they shall not proclaim Thine everlasting kingdom, and be silent about Thine everlasting fire.

[145:45] For the praise of God, setting thee in the way, ought to show thee both what thou shouldest love, and what thou shouldest fear; what thou shouldest seek, and what thou shouldest shun; what thou shouldest choose, and what thou shouldest avoid.

[145:46] The time of choice is now, the time of receiving will be hereafter.

[145:47] Let then the excellence of Thy terrible things be told.

[145:48] Unlimited as it is, though "of Thy greatness there is no end," they shall not be silent about it.

[145:49] How shall they recount it, if there is no end of it? They shall recount it when they praise it; and because there is no end of it, so of His praise also there shall be no end.

[145:50] "The remembrance of the abundance of Thy sweetness they shall pour forth".

[145:51] O happy feasts! What shall they eat, who thus shall "pour forth"!So eat, that thou mayest pour forth again; so receive, that thou mayest give.

[145:52] Thou eatest, when thou learnest; thou pourest forth again, when thou teachest: thou eatest, when thou hearest; thou pourest forth again, when thou preachest; but that thou pourest forth, which thou hast first eaten.

[145:53] Finally, that most eager feaster John, to whom the very table of the Lord sufficed not, unless he leaned on the Lord's breast, and of his inmost heart drank in divine secrets; what did he pour forth? "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God".

[145:54] How is it that it sufficeth not to say, "Thy remembrance;" or, "the remembrance of Thine abundance"? Because, what availeth it if it be abundant, yet not sweet? So also it is annoying if it be sweet but too little.

[145:55] By "pouring forth" this, His preachers "shall exult in His righteousness" not in their own.

[145:56] What then hast Thou done unto us, O Lord, whom we praise, that we should be, that we should praise, that we should "exult in Thy righteousness," that we should "utter forth the remembrance of the abundance of Thy sweetness"? Let us tell it, and, as we tell, let us praise.

[145:57] "Merciful and pitiful is the Lord; long-suffering, and very merciful".

[145:58] "Sweet is the Lord to all, and His compassions reach into all His works".

[145:59] Were He not such as this, there would be no seeking to recover us.

[145:60] Consider thyself: what didst thou deserve, O sinner? Despiser of God, what didst thou deserve? See if aught occur to thee but penalty, if aught occur to thee but punishment.

[145:61] Thou seest then what was due to thee, and what He hath given, who gave gratis.

[145:62] There was given pardon to the sinner; there was given the spirit of justification; there was given charity and love, wherein thou mayest do all good works; and beyond this, He will give thee also life everlasting, and fellowship with the angels: all of His mercy.

[145:63] Hear the Scripture: "I will not the death of a sinner, but rather that he should turn, and live".

[145:64] By these words of God, he is brought back to hope; but there is another snare to be feared, lest through this very hope he sin the more.

[145:65] What then didst thou also say, thou who through hope sinnest yet more? "Whensoever I turn, God will forgive me all; I will do whatsoever I will".

[145:66] Say not then, "To-morrow I will turn, to-morrow I will please God; and all to-day's and yesterday's deeds shall be forgiven me".

[145:67] Thou sayest true: God hath promised pardon to thy conversion; He hath not promised a to-morrow to thy delay.

[145:68] "Sweet is the Lord to all, and His compassions are over all His works".

[145:69] Why then doth He condemn? why doth He scourge? Are not they whom He condemneth, whom He scourgeth, His works? Plainly they are.

[145:70] And wilt thou know how "His compassions are over all His works"? Thence is that long-suffering, whereby "He maketh His sun to rise on the evil and on the good".

[145:71] Are not "His compassions over all His works, who sendeth rain upon the just and upon the unjust"? In His long-suffering He waiteth for the sinner, saying, "Turn ye to Me, and I will turn to you".

[145:72] Are not "His compassions over all His works"? And when He saith, "Go ye into everlasting fire, prepared for the devil and his angels," this is not His compassion, but His severity.

[145:73] His compassion is given to His works: His severity is not over His works, but over thy works.

[145:74] Lastly, if thou remove thine own evil works, and there remain in thee nought but His work, His compassion will not leave thee: but if thou leavest not thy works, there will be severity over thy works, not over His works.

[145:75] "Let all Thy works, O Lord, confess to Thee, and let Thy saints bless Thee".

[145:76] How so? Is not the earth His work? Are not the trees His work? Cattle, beasts, fish, fowl, are not they His works? Plainly they too are.

[145:77] And how shall these too confess to Him? I see indeed in the angels that His works confess to Him, for the angels are His works: and men are His works; and when men confess to Him, His works confess to Him; but have trees and stones the voice of confession? Yes, verily; "let all" His "works confess to" Him.

[145:78] What sayest thou? even the earth and the trees?But there ariseth the same question in regard of praise, as in regard of confession.

[145:79] For if earth and all things devoid of sensation therefore cannot confess, because they have no voice to confess with; neither will they be able to praise, because they have no voice to proclaim with.

[145:80] But do not those Three Children enumerate all things, as they walked amid the harmless flames, who had leisure not only not to fear, but even to praise God? They say to all things, heavenly and earthly, "Bless ye the Lord, praise Him and magnify Him for ever".

[145:81] Behold how they praise.

[145:82] Let none think that the dumb stone or dumb animal hath reason wherewith to comprehend God.

[145:83] They who have thought this, have erred far from the truth.

[145:84] God hath ordered everything, and made everything: to some He hath given sense and understanding and immortality, as to the angels; to some He hath given sense and understanding with mortality, as to man; to some He hath given bodily sense, yet gave them not understanding, or immortality, as to cattle: to some He hath given neither sense, nor understanding, nor immortality, as to herbs, trees, stones: yet even these cannot be wanting in their kind, and by certain degrees He hath ordered His creation, from earth up to heaven, from visible to invisible, from mortal to immortal.

[145:85] This framework of creation, this most perfectly ordered beauty, ascending from lowest to highest, descending from highest to lowest, never broken, but tempered together of things unlike, all praiseth God.

[145:86] Wherefore then doth all praise God? Because when thou considerest it, and seest its beauty, thou in it praisest God.

[145:87] The beauty of the earth is a kind of voice of the dumb earth.

[145:88] And this which thou hast found in it, is the very voice of its confession, that thou praise the Creator.

[145:89] When thou hast thought on the universal beauty of this world, doth not its very beauty as it were with one voice answer thee, "I made not myself, God made me"?.

[145:90] For when Thy saints bless Thee, what say they? "They shall tell the glory of Thy kingdom, and talk of Thy Power".

[145:91] How powerful is God, who hath made the earth! how powerful is God, who hath filled the earth with good things! how powerful is God, who hath given to the animals each its own life! how powerful is God, who hath given different seeds to the womb of the earth, that they might make to spring up such various shoots, such beautiful trees! how powerful, how great is God! Do thou ask, creation answereth, and by its answer, as by the confession of the creature, thou, O saint of God, blessest God, and "talkest of His power".

[145:92] "That they may make known to the sons of men Thy power, and the glory of the greatness of the beauty of Thy kingdom".

[145:93] Thy saints then commend "the glory of the greatness of the beauty of Thy kingdom," the glory of the greatness of its beauty.

[145:94] There is a certain "greatness of the beauty of Thy kingdom:" that is, Thy kingdom hath beauty, and great beauty.

[145:95] Since whatever hath beauty, hath beauty from Thee, how great beauty hath Thy whole kingdom! Let not the kingdom frighten us: it hath beauty also, wherewith to delight us.

[145:96] For what is that beauty, which the saints shall hereafter enjoy, to whom it shall be said, "Come, ye blessed of My Father, enjoy the kingdom"? Whence shall they come? whither shall they come? Behold, brethren, and, if ye can, as far as ye can, think of the beauty of that kingdom which is to come; whence our prayer saith, "Thy kingdom come".

[145:97] For that kingdom we desire may come, that kingdom the saints proclaim to be coming.

[145:98] Observe this world: it is beautiful.

[145:99] How beautiful are earth, sea, air, heavens, stars.

[145:100] Do not all these frighten him who considereth them? Is not the beauty of them so conspicuous, that it seemeth as though nothing more beautiful could be found? And here, in this beauty, in this fairness almost unspeakable, here worm and mice and all creeping things of the earth live with thee, they live with thee in all this beauty.

[145:101] How great is the beauty of that kingdom where none but angels live with Thee! There is a greatness of a certain beauty; let it be loved before it is seen, that when it is seen, it may be retained.

[145:102] "Thy kingdom".

[145:103] What kingdom mean I? "a kingdom of all ages".

[145:104] For the kingdom of this age too hath its own beauty, but there is not in it that greatness of beauty, such as in the "kingdom of all ages".

[145:105] "And Thy dominion is in every generation and generation".

[145:106] This is the repetition we noticed, signifying either every generation, or the generation which will be after this generation.

[145:107] "Faithful is the Lord in His words, and holy in all His works".

[145:108] "Faithful is the Lord in His words:" for what hath He promised that He hath not given? "Faithful is the Lord in His words".

[145:109] Hereto there are certain things which He hath promised, and hath not given; but let Him be believed from the things which He hath given.

[145:110] We might well believe Him, if He only spake: He willed not that we should believe Him speaking, but that we should have His Scriptures in our hands:as though a kind of bond of God's, which all who pass by might read, and might keep to the path of its promise.

[145:111] And how great things hath He already paid in accordance with that bond! Do men hesitate to believe Him concerning the Resurrection of the dead and the Life to come, which alone now remaineth to be paid, when, if He come to reckon with the unbelievers, the unbelievers must blush? If God say to thee, "Thou hast My bond: I have promised judgment, the separation of good and bad, everlasting life for the faithful, and wilt thou not believe? There in My bond read all that I have promised, reckon with me: verily even by counting up what I have paid, thou canst believe that I shall pay what still I owe.

[145:112] In that bond thou hast My only-begotten Son promised, "Whom I spared not, but gave Him up for you all:" reckon this then among what is paid.

[145:113] Read the bond: I promised therein that I would give by My Son the earnest of the Holy Spirit: reckon that as paid.

[145:114] I promised therein the blood and the crowns of the glorious Martyrs; let the White Mass remind you that My debt has been paid.

[145:115] He setteth before the eyes of all His payment of His debts: some He hath paid in the time of our ancestors, which we saw not: some He hath paid in our times, which they saw not; throughout all generations He hath paid what was written.

[145:116] And what remaineth? Do men not believe Him, when He hath paid all this? What remaineth? Behold thou hast reckoned: all this He hath paid: is He become unfaithful for the few things which remain? God forbid! Wherefore? Because "the Lord is faithful in His words, and holy in all His works".

[145:117] "The Lord strengtheneth all that are falling".

[145:118] But who are "all that are falling"? All indeed fall in a general sense, but he meaneth those who fall in a particular way.

[145:119] For many fall from Him, many also fall from their own imaginations.

[145:120] If they had evil imaginations, they fall from them, and "God strengthened all that are falling".

[145:121] They who lose anything in this world, yet are holy, are as it were dishonoured in this world, from rich become poor, from honoured of low estate, yet are they God's saints; they are, as it were, falling.

[145:122] But "God strengtheneth".

[145:123] For "the just falleth seven times, and riseth again; but the wicked shall be weakened in evils".

[145:124] When evils befall the wicked, they are weakened thereby; when evils befall the righteous, "the Lord strengtheneth all that are falling".

[145:125] "And lifteth up all those that have been cast down:" all, that is, who belong to him; for "God resisteth the proud".

[145:126] "The eyes of all hope upon Thee, and Thou givest them food in due season".

[145:127] Just as when thou refreshest a sick man in due season, when he ought to receive, then Thou givest, and what he ought to receive, that Thou givest.

[145:128] Sometimes then men long, and he giveth not: he who tendeth, knoweth the time to give.

[145:129] Wherefore say I this, brethren? Lest any one be faint, if perchance he hath not been heard, when making some righteous request of God.

[145:130] For when he maketh any unrighteous request, he is heard to his punishment: but when making some righteous request of God, if perchance he have not been heard, let him not be down-hearted, let him not faint, let his eyes wait for the food, which He giveth in due season.

[145:131] When He giveth not, He therefore giveth not, lest that which He giveth do harm"Thou givest them meat in due season".

[145:132] "Thou openest Thine Hand, and fillest every living thing with blessing".

[145:133] Though sometimes Thou givest not, yet "in due season" Thou givest: Thou delayest, not deniest, and that in due season".

[145:134] "Righteous is the Lord in all His ways, and holy in all His works".

[145:135] Both when He smiteth and when He healeth, He is righteous, and in Him unrighteousness is not.

[145:136] Finally, all His saints, when set in the midst of tribulation, have first praised His righteousness, and so sought His blessings.

[145:137] They first have said, "What Thou doest is righteous".

[145:138] So did Daniel ask, and other holy men: "Righteous are Thy judgments: rightly have we suffered: deservedly have we suffered".

[145:139] They laid not unrighteousness to God, they laid not to Him injustice and folly.

[145:140] First they praised Him scourging, and so they felt Him feeding.

[145:141] "The Lord is nigh unto all that call upon Him".

[145:142] Where then is that, "Then shall they call upon Me, and I will not hear them"? See then what follows: "all who call upon Him in truth".

[145:143] For many call upon Him, but not in truth.

[145:144] They seek something else from Him, but seek not Himself.

[145:145] Why lovest thou God? "Because He hath made me whole".

[145:146] That is clear: it was He that made thee so.

[145:147] For from none else cometh health, save Him.

[145:148] "Because He gave me," saith another, "a rich wife, whereas I before had nothing, and one that obeyeth me".

[145:149] This too He gave: thou sayest true.

[145:150] "He gave me," saith another, "sons many and good, He gave me a household, He gave me all good things".

[145:151] Dost thou love Him for this?Therefore if God is good, who hath given thee what thou hast, how much more blessed wilt thou be when He hath given thee Himself! Thou hast desired all these things of Him: I beseech thee desire of Him Himself also.

[145:152] For these things are not truly sweeter than He is, nor in any way are they to be compared to Him.

[145:153] He then who preferreth God Himself to all the things which he has received, whereat he rejoiceth, to the things he has received, he "calleth upon God in truth".

[145:154] "He will perform the will of them that fear Him".

[145:155] He will perform it, He will perform it: though He perform it not at once, yet He will perform it.

[145:156] Certainly if therefore thou fearest God, that thou mayest do His will, behold even He in a manner ministereth to thee; He doeth thy will.

[145:157] "And He shall hear their prayer, and save them".

[145:158] Thou seest that for this purpose the Physician hears, that He may save.

[145:159] When? Hear the Apostle telling thee.

[145:160] "For we are saved in hope: but hope which is seen is not hope: but if what we see not we hope for, then do we with patience wait for it: "the salvation," that is, which Peter calleth "ready to be revealed in the last time".

[145:161] "The Lord guardeth all that love Him, and all sinners He will destroy".

[145:162] Thou seest that there is severity with Him, with whom is so great sweetness.

[145:163] He will save all that hope in Him, all the faithful, all that fear Him, all that call upon Him in truth: "and all sinners He will destroy".

[145:164] What "all sinners," save those who persevere in sin; who dare to blame God, not themselves; who daily argue against God; who despair of pardon for their sins, and from this very despair heap up their sins; or who perversely promise themselves pardon, and through this very promise depart not from their sins and impiety? The time will come for all these to be separated, and for the two divisions to be made of them, one on the right hand, the other on the left; and for the righteous to receive the everlasting Kingdom, the wicked to go into everlasting fire.

[145:165] Since this is so, and we have heard the blessing of the Lord, the works of the Lord, the wondrous things of the Lord, the mercies of the Lord, the severity of the Lord, His Providence over all His works, the confession of all His works; observe how He concludeth in His praise, "My mouth shall speak the praise of the Lord, and let all flesh bless His holy Name for ever and ever".

[146:1] Psalm CXLVI.

[146:2] Behold the Psalm soundeth; it is the voice of some one (and that some one are ye, if ye will), of some one encouraging his soul to praise God, and saying to himself, "Praise the Lord, O my soul".

[146:3] For sometimes in the tribulations and temptations of this present life, wh ether we will or no, our soul is troubled; of which troubling he speaketh in another Psalm But to remove this troubling, he suggesteth joy; not as yet in reality, but in hope; and saith to it when troubled and anxious, sad and sorrowing, "Hope in God, for I will yet confess to Him".

[146:4] But who saith it, and to whom saith he it? What shall we say, brethren? Is it the flesh that saith, "Praise thou the Lord, O my soul"? And can the flesh suggest good counsel to the soul? However much the flesh be conquered, and subjected as a servant to us through strength which the Lord imparteth, that it serve us entirely as a bond slave, enough for us that it hinder us not.

[146:5] For the body, inasmuch as it is the body, is even beneath the soul; and every soul, however vile, is found more excellent than the most excellent body.

[146:6] And let not this seem to you to be wonderful, that even any vile and sinful soul is better than any great and most surpassing body.

[146:7] It is better, not in deserts, but in nature.

[146:8] The soul indeed is sinful, is stained with certain defilements of lusts; yet gold, though rusted, is better than the most polished lead.

[146:9] Let your mind then run over every part of creation, and ye will see that what we are saying is not incredible, that a soul, however blameable, is yet more praiseworthy than a praiseworthy body.

[146:10] There are two things, a soul and a body.

[146:11] The soul I chide, the body I praise: the soul I chide, because it is sinful; the body I praise, because it is sound.

[146:12] Yet it is in its own kind that I praise the soul, and in its own kind that I blame the soul: and so in its own kind I praise the body, or blame it.

[146:13] If you ask me which is better, what I have blamed or what I have praised, wondrous is the answer thou wilt receive.

[146:14] So you speak of the best horse and the worst man: yet thou preferrest the man thou findest fault with to the horse thou praisest.

[146:15] The nature of the soul is more excellent than the nature of the body: it surpasseth it by far, it is a thing spiritual, incorporeal, akin to the substance of God.

[146:16] It is somewhat invisible, it ruleth the body, moveth the limbs, guideth the senses, prepareth thoughts, putteth forth actions, taketh in images of countless things; who is there, in short, beloved brethren, who may suffice for the praises of the soul? And yet such is the grace given to it, that this man saith, "Praise the Lord, O my soul".

[146:17] It is not the flesh that saith it.

[146:18] Let the body be angel-like, still it is inferior to the soul, it cannot give advice to its superior.

[146:19] The flesh when duly obedient is the handmaid of the soul: the soul rules, the body obeys; the soul commands, the body performs; how then can the flesh give this advice to the soul? Is it then perchance the soul herself, who saith to herself, and in a manner commandeth herself, and exhorteth and asketh herself? For through certain passions in one part of her nature she wavered; but in another part, which they call the reasonable mind, the wisdom whereby she thinks, clinging to God, and now sighing towards Him, she perceives that certain inferior parts of her are troubled by worldly emotions, and by a certain excitement of earthly desires, betake them to outward things, leaving God who is within; so she recalleth herself from things outward to inward, from lower to higher, and says, "Praise the Lord, O my soul".

[146:20] The soul itself giveth itself counsel from the light of God by the reasonable mind, whereby it conceiveth the wisdom fixed in the everlasting nature of its Author.

[146:21] It readeth there of somewhat to be feared, to be praised, to be loved, to be longed for, and sought after: as yet it graspeth it not, it comprehendeth it not; it is, as it were, dazzled with brightness; it has not strength to abide there.

[146:22] Therefore it gathers itself, as it were, into a sound state, and saith, "Praise the Lord, O my soul".

[146:23] And then the soul, weighed down, as it were, and unable to stand up as is fitting, answereth the mind, "I will praise the Lord in my life".

[146:24] What is, "in my life"? Because now I am in my death.

[146:25] Therefore first encourage thyself, and say, "Praise the Lord, O my soul".

[146:26] Thy soul answereth thee, I do praise so far as I can, slightly, poorly, weakly.

[146:27] Wherefore? Because, "while we are in the body, we are absent from the Lord".

[146:28] "In my life".

[146:29] Now what has it? It might answer thee, "My death".

[146:30] Whence, "My death"? because I am absent from the Lord.

[146:31] For if to cling to Him is life, to depart from Him is death.

[146:32] But what comforteth thee? Hope.

[146:33] Now thou livest in hope: in hope praise, in hope sing.

[146:34] Thy death is from the sadness of this life, thou livest in hope of a future life.

[146:35] And how wilt thou praise thy Lord? "I will sing unto my God, as long as I have my being".

[146:36] What sort of praise is this, "I will sing unto my God as long as I have being"? Behold, my brethren, what sort of being this will be; where there will be everlasting praise, there will be also everlasting being.

[146:37] Behold, now thou hast being: dost thou sing unto God as long as thou hast being? Behold, thou wast singing, and hast turned thyself away to some business, thou singest no longer, yet thou hast being: thou hast being, yet thou singest not.

[146:38] It may be also thy desire turneth thee to somewhat; not only dost thou not sing, but thou even offendest His ears, yet thou hast being.

[146:39] What praise will that be, when thou praisest as long as thou hast being? But what meaneth, "as long as I have being"? Will there be any time when he will not be? Nay, rather, that "long" will be everlasting, and therefore it will be truly "long".

[146:40] For whatever hath end in time, however prolonged it is, is yet not "long".

[146:41] "Put not your trust in princes".

[146:42] Brethren, here we receive a mighty task; it is a voice from heaven, from above it soundeth to us.

[146:43] For now through some kind of weakness the soul of man, whensoever it is in tribulation here, despaireth of God, and chooseth to rely on man.

[146:44] Let it be said to one when set in some affliction, "There is a great man, by whom thou mayest be set free;" he smileth, he rejoiceth, he is lifted up.

[146:45] But if it is said to him, "God freeth thee," he is chilled, so to speak, by despair.

[146:46] The aid of a mortal is promised, and thou rejoicest; the aid of the Immortal is promised, and art thou sad? It is promised thee that thou shalt be freed by one who needeth to be freed with thee, and thou exultest, as at some great aid: thou art promised that Liberator, who needeth none to free Him, and thou despairest, as though it were but a fable.

[146:47] Woe to such thoughts: they wander far; truly there is sad and great death in them.

[146:48] Approach, begin to long, begin to seek and to know Him by whom thou wast made.

[146:49] For He will not leave His work, if He be not left by His work.

[146:50] "His breath shall go forth, and he shall return to his earth: in that day shall all his thoughts perish".

[146:51] Where is swelling? where is pride? where is boasting? But perhaps he will have passed to a good place, if indeed he have passed.

[146:52] For I know not whither he who spake thus hath passed.

[146:53] For he spake in pride; and I know not whither such men pass, save that I look into another Psalm, and see that their passage is an evil one.

[146:54] "I beheld the wicked lifted up above the cedars of Libanus, and I passed by, and, lo, he was not; and I sought him, and his place was not found".

[146:55] The good man, who passed by, and found not the wicked, reached a place where the wicked is not.

[146:56] Wherefore, brethren, let us all listen: brethren, beloved of God, let us all listen; in whatsoever tribulation, in whatsoever longing for the heavenly gift, "let us not trust in princes, nor in sons of men, in whom is no salvation".

[146:57] All this is mortal, fleeting, perishable.

[146:58] What then must we do, if we are not to hope in sons of men, nor in princes? What must we do? "Blessed is he whose Helper is the God of Jacob" : not this man or that man; not this angel or that angel; but, "blessed is he whose Helper is the God of Jacob:" for to Jacob also so great an Helper was He, that of Jacob He made him Israel.

[146:59] O mighty help! now he is Israel, "seeing God".

[146:60] While then thou art placed here, and a wanderer not yet seeing God, if thou hast the God of Jacob for thy Helper, from Jacob thou wilt become Israel, and wilt be "seeing God," and all toil and all groans shall come to an end, gnawing cares shall cease, happy praises shall succeed.

[146:61] "Blessed is he whose Helper is the God of Jacob;" of this Jacob.

[146:62] Wherefore is he happy? Meanwhile, while yet groaning in this life, "his hope is in the Lord his God".

[146:63] Who is this, "Lord his God"?"To us there is one God, the Father, of whom are all things, and one Lord Jesus Christ, through whom are all things".

[146:64] Therefore let Him be thy hope, even the Lord thy God; in Him let thy hope be.

[146:65] His hope too is in the lord his god, who worshippeth Saturn; his hope is in the lord his god, who worshippeth Neptune or Mercury; yea more, I add, who worshippeth his belly, of whom is said, "whose god is their belly".

[146:66] The one is the god of the one, the other of the other.

[146:67] Who is this "blessed" one? for "his hope is in the Lord his God".

[146:68] But who is He? "Who made heaven and earth, the sea, and all that is in them".

[146:69] My brethren, we have a great God; let us bless His holy Name, that He hath deigned to make us His possession.

[146:70] As yet thou seest not God; thou canst not fully love what as yet thou seest not.

[146:71] All that thou seest, He hath made.

[146:72] Thou admirest the world; why not the Maker of the world? Thou lookest up to the heavens, and art amazed: thou considerest the whole earth, and tremblest; when canst thou contain in thy thought the vastness of the sea? Look at the countless number of the stars, look at all the many kind of seeds, all the different sorts of animals, all that swimmeth in the water, creepeth on the earth, flieth in the sky, hovereth in the air; how great are all these, how beautiful, how fair, how amazing! Behold, He who made all these, is thy God.

[146:73] Put thy hope in Him, that thou mayest be happy.

[146:74] "His hope is in the Lord his God".

[146:75] Observe, my brethren, the mighty God, the good God, who maketh all these things.

[146:76] If he mentioned these things only, perhaps thou wouldest answer me, "God, who made heaven and earth and sea, is a great God: but doth He think of me?" It would be said to thee, "He made thee".

[146:77] How so? am I heaven, or am I earth, or am I sea? Surely it is plain; I am neither heaven, nor earth, nor sea: yet I am on earth.

[146:78] At least thou grantest me this, that thou art on earth.

[146:79] Hear then, that God made not only heaven and earth and sea: for He "made heaven and earth and sea, and all that is in them".

[146:80] If then He made all that is in them, He made thee also.

[146:81] It is too little to say, thee; the sparrow, the locust, the worm, none of these did He not make, and He careth for all.

[146:82] His care refers not to His commandment, for this commandment He gave to man alone.

[146:83] As regards then the tenor of the commandment, "God doth not take care for oxen:" as regards His providential care of the universe, whereby He created all things, and ruleth the world, "Thou, Lord, shalt save both man and beast".

[146:84] Here perhaps some one may say to me, "God careth not for oxen," comes from the New Testament: "Thou, Lord, shalt save both man and beast," is from the Old Testament.

[146:85] There are some who find fault and say, that these two Testaments agree not with one another.

[146:86] Let us hear the Lord Himself, the Chief and Master of the Apostles: "Consider," saith He, "the fowls of the air; they sow not, neither do they reap, nor gather into barns, and your heavenly Father feedeth them".

[146:87] Therefore even beside men, these animals are objects of care to God, to be fed, not to receive a law.

[146:88] As far then as regards giving a law, "God careth not for oxen:" as regards creating, feeding, governing, ruling, all things have to do with God.

[146:89] "Are not two sparrows sold for one farthing?" saith our Lord Jesus Christ, "and one of them shall not fall to the ground without the will of your Father: how much better are ye than they".

[146:90] Perhaps thou sayest, God counteth me not in this great multitude.

[146:91] There follows here a wondrous passage in the Gospel: "the hairs of your head are all numbered".

[146:92] "Who keepeth truth for ever".

[146:93] What "truth for ever"? what "truth" doth He "keep," and wherein doth "He keep it for ever"? "Who executeth judgment for them that suffer wrong".

[146:94] He avengeth them that suffer wrong.

[146:95] There cometh at once to thee the voice of the Apostle: "now therefore there is altogether a fault among you, that ye go to law one with another: why do ye not rather suffer wrong?"  He urged thee not to suffer annoyance, but to suffer wrong: for not every annoyance is wrong.

[146:96] For whatever thou sufferest lawfully is not a wrong; lest perchance thou shouldest say, I also am among those who have suffered wrong, for I have suffered such a thing in such a place, and such a thing for such a reason.

[146:97] Consider whether thou hast suffered a wrong.

[146:98] Robbers suffer many things, but they suffer no wrong.

[146:99] Wicked men, evil doers, house-breakers, adulterers, seducers, all these suffer many evils, yet is there no wrong.

[146:100] It is one thing to suffer wrong; it is another to suffer tribulation, or penalty, or annoyance, or punishment.

[146:101] Consider where thou art; see what thou hast done; see why thou art suffering; and then thou seest what thou art suffering.

[146:102] Right and wrong are contraries.

[146:103] Right is what is just.

[146:104] For not all that is called right, is right.

[146:105] What if a man lay down for you unjust right? nor indeed is it to be called right, if it is unjust.

[146:106] That is true right, which is also just.

[146:107] Consider what thou hast done, not what thou art suffering.

[146:108] If thou hast done right, thou art suffering wrong; if thou hast done wrong, thou art suffering right.

[146:109] "Who giveth food to the hungry".

[146:110] Behold, from thee I look for nothing: "God giveth food to the hungry".

[146:111] Who are "the hungry"? All.

[146:112] What is, all? To all things that have life, to all men He giveth food: doth He not reserve some food for His beloved? If they have another kind of hunger, they have also another kind of food.

[146:113] Let us first enquire what their hunger is, and then we shall find their food.

[146:114] "Blessed are they that hunger and thirst after righteousness, for they shall be filled".

[146:115] We ought to be God's hungry ones.

[146:116] "The Lord looseth them that are fettered; the Lord lifteth up them that are dashed down; the Lord maketh wise them that are blind".

[146:117] Perfectly hath he by this last sentence explained to us all the preceding ones: lest perchance, when he had said, "the Lord looseth them that are fettered," we should refer it to those fettered ones, who for some crime are bound in irons by their masters: and in that he said, "He lifteth up them that are dashed down," there should occur to our minds some one stumbling or falling, or thrown from a horse.

[146:118] There is another kind of fall, there are other kinds of fetters, just as there is other darkness and other light.

[146:119] Whereas he said, "He maketh the blind wise;" he would not say, He enlightened the blind, lest thou shouldest understand this also in reference to the flesh, as the man was enlightened by the Lord, when He anointed his eyes with clay made with spittle, and so healed him: that thou mightest not look for anything of this sort, when He is speaking of spiritual things, he pointeth to a sort of light of wisdom, wherewith the blind are enlightened.

[146:120] Therefore in the same way as the blind are enlightened with the light of wisdom, so are the fettered set free, and those who are dashed down are lifted up.

[146:121] Whereby then have we been fettered? whereby dashed down? Our body was once an ornament to us: now, we have sinned, and thereby have had fetters put on us.

[146:122] What are our fetters? Our mortality.

[146:123] "The Lord loveth the righteous".

[146:124] And who are the "righteous"? How far are they righteous now? Just as thou hast; "the Lord, guardeth proselytes".

[146:125] "Proselytes" are strangers.

[146:126] Every Church of the Gentiles is a stranger.

[146:127] For it cometh in to the Fathers, not sprung of their flesh, but their daughter by imitating them.

[146:128] Yet the Lord, not any man, guardeth them.

[146:129] "The orphan and widow He will take up".

[146:130] Let none think that He taketh up the orphan for his inheritance, or the widow for any business of hers.

[146:131] True, God doth help them; and in all the duties of the human race, he doeth a good work, who taketh care of an orphan, who abandoneth not a widow: but in a certain way we are all orphans, not because our Father is dead, but because He is absent.

[146:132] "And the way of sinners He shall root out".

[146:133] What is, "the way of sinners"? To mock at these things which we say.

[146:134] "Who is an orphan, who a widow? What kingdom of heaven, what punishment of hell is there? These are fables of the Christians.

[146:135] To what I see, to that will I live: "let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die".

[146:136] Beware lest such men persuade you of aught: let them not enter through your ears into your heart; let them find thorns in your ears: let him, who seeketh to enter thus, go away pierced: for "evil communications corrupt good manners".

[146:137] But here perhaps thou wilt say, "Wherefore then are they prosperous? Behold, they worship not God, and commit every kind of evil daily: yet they abound in those things, through want of which I toil".

[146:138] Be not envious against sinners.

[146:139] What they receive, thou seest; what is in store for them, seest thou not?Wilt thou not believe even the Lord thy God, who saith, "Broad and spacious is the way that leadeth to destruction, and many there be that walk by it"?  This "way the Lord will root out".

[146:140] And, when "the way of sinners" has been "rooted out," what remaineth for us? "Come, ye blessed of My father, enjoy the Kingdom;" "The Lord shall reign for ever".

[146:141] "O Sion, thy God" shall reign for ever; surely thy God will not reign without thee.

[146:142] "For generation and generation".

[146:143] He hath said it twice, because he could not say it for ever.

[146:144] And think not that eternity is bounded by finite words.

[146:145] The word eternity consists of four syllables; in itself it is without end.

[146:146] It could not be commended to thee, save thus, "for generation and generation".

[146:147] Too little hath he said: if he spoke it all day long, it were too narrow: if he spoke it all his life, must he not at length hold his peace? Love eternity: without end shalt thou reign, if Christ be thine End, with whom thou shalt reign for ever and ever, Amen.

[147:1] Psalm CXLVII.

[147:2] It is said to us, "Praise the Lord".

[147:3] This is said to all nations, not to us alone.

[147:4] And these words, sounded forth through separate places by the Readers, each Church heareth separately; but the one same Voice of God proclaimeth unto all, that we praise Him.

[147:5] And as though we asked wherefore we ought to praise the  Lord, behold what reason he hath brought forward: "Praise the Lord," he saith, "for a Psalm is good".

[147:6] Is this all the reward of them that praise?The "Psalm" is praise of God.

[147:7] This then he saith, "Praise the Lord, for it is good to praise the Lord".

[147:8] Let us not thus pass over the praise of the Lord.

[147:9] It is spoken, and hath passed: it is done, and we are silent: we have praised, and then rested; we have sung, and then rested.

[147:10] We go forth to some business which awaits us, and when other employments have found us, shall the praise of God cease in us ? Not so: thy tongue praiseth but for a while, let thy life ever praise.

[147:11] Thus then "a Psalm is good".

[147:12] For a "Psalm" is a song, not any kind of song, but a song to a psaltery.

[147:13] A psaltery is a kind of instrument of music, like the lyre and the harp, and such kinds of instruments, which were invented for music.

[147:14] He therefore who singeth Psalms, not only singeth with his voice, but with a certain instrument besides, which is called a psaltery, he accompanieth his voice with his hands.

[147:15] Wilt thou then sing a Psalm? Let not thy voice alone sound the praises of God; but let thy works also be in harmony with thy voice.

[147:16] To please then the ear, sing with thy voice; but with thy heart be not  silent, with thy life be not still.

[147:17] Thou devisest no fraud in thy heart: thou singest a Psalm to God.

[147:18] When thou eatest and drinkest, sing a Psalm: not by intermingling sweet sounds suited to the ear, but by eating and drinking moderately, frugally, temperately: for thus saith the Apostle, "whether ye eat or drink, or whatever ye do, do all to the glory of God".

[147:19] If by immoderate voracity thou exceedest the due bounds of nature, and gluttest thyself in excess of wine, however great praises of God thy tongue sound, yet thy life blasphemeth Him.

[147:20] After food and drink thou liest down to sleep: in thy bed neither commit any pollution, nor go beyond the license given by the law of God: let thy marriage bed be kept chaste with thy wife: and if thou desire to beget children, yet let there not be unbridled sensuality of lust: in thy bed give honour to thy wife, for ye are both members of Christ, both made by Him, both renewed by His Blood: so doing thou praisest God, nor will thy praise be altogether silent.

[147:21] What, when sleep has come over thee? Let not an evil conscience rouse thee from rest: so doth the innocence of thy sleep praise God.

[147:22] "Let praises be pleasant to our God".

[147:23] How? If He be praised by our good lives.

[147:24] Hear that then praise will be pleasant to Him.

[147:25] In another place it is said, "Praise is not seemly in the mouth of a sinner".

[147:26] If then in the mouth of a sinner praise is not seemly, neither is it pleasant, for that only is pleasant which is seemly.

[147:27] For praise may be pleasant to a man, when he heareth one praising with neat and clever sentiments, and with a sweet voice; but "let praise be pleasant to our God," whose ears are open not to the mouth, but to the heart; not to the tongue, but to the life of him that praiseth.

[147:28] Who is "our God," that praise should be pleasant to Him? He maketh Himself sweet to us, He commendeth Himself to us; thanks to His condescension.

[147:29] "But God commendeth His love to us""in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us".

[147:30] Let us see whether it be the commendation which the Apostle speaketh of, that Christ died for the sinners and ungodly: "the Lord who buildeth up Jerusalem, and gathereth the dispersions of Israel".

[147:31] For the people of Jerusalem are the people of Israel.

[147:32] It is Jerusalem "eternal in the heavens," whereof the Angels are citizens also.

[147:33] All the citizens then of that city, through "seeing God," rejoice in that great and wide and heavenly city; they gaze upon God Himself.

[147:34] But we are wanderers from that city, driven out by sin, that we should not remain there; weighed down by mortality, that we should not return thither.

[147:35] God looked back on our wandering, and He who "buildeth up Jerusalem," restored the part that had fallen.

[147:36] How restored He the part that had fallen?He sent then to our captive estate His Son as a Redeemer.

[147:37] Take with Thee, said He, a bag, bear therein the price of the captives.

[147:38] For He put on Him our mortal flesh, and therein was the Blood, by the shedding of which we were to be redeemed.

[147:39] With that Blood He "gathered the dispersions of Israel".

[147:40] And if He gathered them that before were dispersed, how must we strive that they be gathered who now are dispersed? If the dispersed have been gathered, that in the Hand of the Builder they might be fashioned into the building, how should they be gathered who through disquiet have fallen from the Hand of the Builder? Behold whom we praise; behold to whom we owe praise all our life long.

[147:41] How doth He gather? What doeth He in order to gather? "Who healeth the bruised in heart".

[147:42] Behold the way in which the dispersions of Israel are gathered, by the healing of the bruised in heart.

[147:43] They who are not of a bruised heart, are not healed.

[147:44] What is to bruise the heart? Let it be known, brethren, let it be done, that ye may be able to be healed.

[147:45] For it is told in many other places of Scripture;"the sacrifice of God is a troubled spirit, a bruised and contrite heart God will not despise".

[147:46] He healeth then the bruised in heart, for He draweth nigh unto them to heal them; as is said in another place, "the Lord is nigh unto them who have bruised their heart".

[147:47] Who are they that have "bruised their heart"? The humble.

[147:48] Who are they that have not "bruised their heart"? The proud.

[147:49] The bruised heart shall be healed, the puffed up heart shall be dashed down.

[147:50] For for this purpose perhaps is it dashed down, that being bruised it may be healed.

[147:51] Let not our heart then, brethren, desire to be set upright, before it be upright.

[147:52] It is ill for that to be uplifted which is not first corrected.

[147:53] What are the means whereby He "bindeth up their bruises"? Just as physicians bind up fractures.

[147:54] For sometimes (observe this, beloved; it is well known to those who have observed it, or have heard it from physicians), sometimes when limbs are sound, but are crooked and distorted, physicians break them in order to set them straight, and make a new wound, because the soundness which was distorted was amiss.

[147:55] What are these means whereby He bindeth? The sacraments of this present life, whereby in the mean time we obtain our comfort: and all the words we speak to you, words which sound and pass away, all that is done in the Church in this present time, are the means whereby "He bindeth up our bruises".

[147:56] For just as, when the limb has become perfectly sound, the physician taketh off the bandage; so in our own city Jerusalem, when we shall have been made equal to the Angels, think ye that we shall receive there, what we have received here? Will it be needful then that the Gospel be read to us, that our faith may abide? or that hands be laid upon us by any Bishop? All these are means of binding up fractures; when we have attained perfect soundness, they will be taken off; but we should never attain it, if they were not bound up.

[147:57] "Who telleth the number of the stars, and calleth them all by their names".

[147:58] What great matter is it for God to "tell the number of the stars"! Men even have endeavoured to do this; whether they have been able to achieve it, is their concern; they would not however attempt it, did they not think that they should achieve it.

[147:59] Let us leave alone what they can do, and how far they have attained; for God I think it no great matter to count all the stars.

[147:60] Or doth He perhaps go over the number, lest He should forget it? Is it any great thing for God to number the stars, by whom "the very hairs of your head are numbered"? The stars are certain lights in the Church comforting our night; all of whom the Apostle saith, "In the midst of a crooked and perverse generation, among whom ye shine as lights in the world, holding the Word of life".

[147:61] These stars God counteth; all who shall reign with Him, all who are to be gathered into the Body of His only-begotten Son, He hath counted, and still counteth them.

[147:62] Whoso is unworthy, is not even counted.

[147:63] Many too have believed, or rather may, with a kind of shadowy appearance of faith, have attached themselves to His people: yet He knoweth what He counteth, what He winnoweth away.

[147:64] For so great is the height of the Gospel, that it hath come to pass as was said, "I have declared, and have spoken: they are multiplied above number:" there are then among the people certain supernumeraries, so to speak.

[147:65] What do I mean by supernumeraries? More than will be there.

[147:66] Within these walls are more than will be in the kingdom of God, in the heavenly Jerusalem; these are above the number.

[147:67] Let each one of you consider whether he shineth in darkness, whether he refuseth to be led astray by the dark iniquity of the world; if he be not led astray, nor conquered, he will be, as it were, a star, which God already numbereth.

[147:68] "And calling them all by their names," he saith.

[147:69] Herein is our whole reward.

[147:70] We may have certain names with God, that God may know our names, this we ought to wish, for this to act, for this to busy ourselves, as far as we are able; not to rejoice in other things, not even in certain spiritual gifts.

[147:71] When the disciples returned from their mission exulting, and saying, "Lord, even the devils are subject unto us in Thy Name" —then He (knowing that many would say, "have we not in Thy Name cast out devils?" to whom He should say, "I know you not") said, "In this rejoice not, that the devils are subject unto you; but rather rejoice, because your names are written in heaven".

[147:72] "Great is our Lord".

[147:73] The Psalmist is filled with joy, he hath poured out his words wonderfully: yet somewhat he was unable to speak, and how availed he to think on it? "And great is His power, and of His understanding is no numbering".

[147:74] He who "numbereth the stars," Himself cannot be numbered.

[147:75] Who can expound this? who can worthily even imagine what is meant by, "and of His understanding is no number"?Whatsoever then that is infinite this world containeth, though it be infinite to man, yet is not to God: too little is it to say, to God: even by the angels it is numbered.

[147:76] His understanding surpasses all calculators; it cannot be counted by us.

[147:77] Numbers themselves who numbereth? What than is there with God? wherewith made He all things, and where made He all things, to whom it is said, "Thou hast arrayed all things in measure, number, and weight"?  Or who can number, or measure, or weigh, measure and number and weight themselves, wherein God hath ordered all things? Therefore, "of His understanding is no number".

[147:78] Let human voices be hushed, human thoughts still: let them not stretch themselves out to incomprehensible things, as though they could comprehend them, but as though they were to partake of them, for partakers we shall be.

[147:79] Partakers then we shall be: let none doubt it: Scripture saith it.

[147:80] And of what shall we be partakers, as though these were parts in God, as though God were divided into parts? Who then can explain how many become partakers of one single substance? Require not then that which I think ye see cannot fitly be said: but return to the healing of the Saviour, bruise your heart.

[147:81] He will guide it, He will bind it up where it is broken, He will make it perfectly sound; and then those things will not be impossible with us, which now are impossible.

[147:82] For it is good that he confess weakness, who desireth to attain to the divine nature.

[147:83] "The Lord taketh up the gentle".

[147:84] For example; thou understandest not, thou failest to understand, canst not attain: honour God's Scripture, honour God's Word, though it be not plain: in reverence wait for understanding.

[147:85] Be not wanton to accuse either the obscurity or seeming contradiction of Scripture.

[147:86] There is nothing in it contradictory: somewhat there is which is obscure, not in order that it may be denied thee, but that it may exercise him that shall afterward receive it.

[147:87] When then it is obscure, that is the Physician's doing, that thou mayest knock.

[147:88] He willed that thou shouldest be exercised in knocking; He willed it, that He might open to thee when thou knockest.

[147:89] By knocking thou shalt be exercised; exercised, thou shalt be enlarged; enlarged, thou shalt contain what is given.

[147:90] Be not then indignant for that it is shut; be mild, be gentle.

[147:91] Kick not against what is dark, nor say, It were better said, if it were said thus.

[147:92] For how canst thou thus say, or judge how it is expedient it be said? It is said as it is expedient it be said.
